You had better not exert yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the widow, \xe2\x80\x9clet me see it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Tom Smart; and, with these words, he placed the\r\nletter in the widow\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gentlemen, I have heard my uncle say, that Tom Smart said the widow\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlamentations when she heard the disclosure would have pierced a heart of\r\nstone. Tom was certainly very tender-hearted, but they pierced his, to\r\nthe very core. The widow rocked herself to and fro, and wrung her hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cOh, the deception and villainy of the man!\xe2\x80\x9d said the widow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cFrightful, my dear ma\xe2\x80\x99am; but compose yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom Smart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I can\xe2\x80\x99t compose myself,\xe2\x80\x9d shrieked the widow. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall never find\r\nanyone else I can love so much!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes you will, my dear soul,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom Smart, letting fall a shower\r\nof the largest-sized tears, in pity for the widow\xe2\x80\x99s misfortunes. Tom\r\nSmart, in the energy of his compassion, had put his arm round the\r\nwidow\xe2\x80\x99s waist; and the widow, in a passion of grief, had clasped Tom\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhand. She looked up in Tom\xe2\x80\x99s face, and smiled through her tears. Tom\r\nlooked down in hers, and smiled through his.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never could find out, gentlemen, whether Tom did or did not kiss the\r\nwidow at that particular moment. He used to tell my uncle he didn\xe2\x80\x99t, but\r\nI have my doubts about it. Between ourselves, gentlemen, I rather think\r\nhe did.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At all events, Tom kicked the very tall man out at the front door half\r\nan hour later, and married the widow a month after. And he used to drive\r\nabout the country, with the clay-coloured gig with the red wheels, and\r\nthe vixenish mare with the fast pace, till he gave up business many\r\nyears afterwards, and went to France with his wife; and then the old\r\nhouse was pulled down.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you allow me to ask you,\xe2\x80\x99 said the inquisitive old gentleman,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98what became of the chair?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the one-eyed bagman, \xe2\x80\x98it was observed to creak very much\r\non the day of the wedding; but Tom Smart couldn\xe2\x80\x99t say for certain\r\nwhether it was with pleasure or bodily infirmity. He rather thought it\r\nwas the latter, though, for it never spoke afterwards.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Everybody believed the story, didn\xe2\x80\x99t they?\xe2\x80\x99 said the dirty-faced man,\r\nrefilling his pipe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Except Tom\xe2\x80\x99s enemies,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the bagman. \xe2\x80\x98Some of \xe2\x80\x98em said Tom\r\ninvented it altogether; and others said he was drunk and fancied it, and\r\ngot hold of the wrong trousers by mistake before he went to bed. But\r\nnobody ever minded what _they _said.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tom Smart said it was all true?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Every word.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And your uncle?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Every letter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They must have been very nice men, both of \xe2\x80\x98em,\xe2\x80\x99 said the dirty-faced\r\nman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, they were,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the bagman; \xe2\x80\x98very nice men indeed!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XV. IN WHICH IS GIVEN A FAITHFUL PORTRAITURE OF TWO\r\nDISTINGUISHED PERSONS; AND AN ACCURATE DESCRIPTION OF A PUBLIC BREAKFAST\r\nIN THEIR HOUSE AND GROUNDS: WHICH PUBLIC BREAKFAST LEADS TO THE\r\nRECOGNITION OF AN OLD ACQUAINTANCE, AND THE COMMENCEMENT OF ANOTHER\r\nCHAPTER\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s conscience had been somewhat reproaching him for his\r\nrecent neglect of his friends at the Peacock; and he was just on the\r\npoint of walking forth in quest of them, on the third morning after the\r\nelection had terminated, when his faithful valet put into his hand a\r\ncard, on which was engraved the following inscription:--\r\n\r\n\r\nMrs. Leo Hunter THE DEN. EATANSWILL.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Person\xe2\x80\x99s a-waitin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, epigrammatically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Does the person want me, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He wants you partickler; and no one else \xe2\x80\x98ll do, as the devil\xe2\x80\x99s private\r\nsecretary said ven he fetched avay Doctor Faustus,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98_He_. Is it a gentleman?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A wery good imitation o\xe2\x80\x99 one, if it ain\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But this is a lady\xe2\x80\x99s card,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Given me by a gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n, howsoever,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam, \xe2\x80\x98and he\xe2\x80\x99s a-waitin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nin the drawing-room--said he\xe2\x80\x99d rather wait all day, than not see you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick, on hearing this determination, descended to the drawing-\r\nroom, where sat a grave man, who started up on his entrance, and said,\r\nwith an air of profound respect:--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pickwick, I presume?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The same.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Allow me, Sir, the honour of grasping your hand. Permit me, Sir, to\r\nshake it,\xe2\x80\x99 said the grave man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. The stranger shook the extended hand,\r\nand then continued--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We have heard of your fame, sir. The noise of your antiquarian\r\ndiscussion has reached the ears of Mrs. Leo Hunter--my wife, sir; I am\r\nMr. Leo Hunter\xe2\x80\x99--the stranger paused, as if he expected that Mr.\r\nPickwick would be overcome by the disclosure; but seeing that he\r\nremained perfectly calm, proceeded--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My wife, sir--Mrs. Leo Hunter--is proud to number among her\r\nacquaintance all those who have rendered themselves celebrated by their\r\nworks and talents. Permit me, sir, to place in a conspicuous part of the\r\nlist the name of Mr. Pickwick, and his brother-members of the club that\r\nderives its name from him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall be extremely happy to make the acquaintance of such a lady,\r\nsir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You _shall _make it, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the grave man. \xe2\x80\x98To-morrow morning, sir,\r\nwe give a public breakfast--a _fete champetre_--to a great number of\r\nthose who have rendered themselves celebrated by their works and\r\ntalents. Permit Mrs. Leo Hunter, Sir, to have the gratification of\r\nseeing you at the Den.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With great pleasure,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Leo Hunter has many of these breakfasts, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed the new\r\nacquaintance--\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cfeasts of reason,\xe2\x80\x9d sir, \xe2\x80\x9cand flows of soul,\xe2\x80\x9d as somebody\r\nwho wrote a sonnet to Mrs. Leo Hunter on her breakfasts, feelingly and\r\noriginally observed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Was _he_ celebrated for his works and talents?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He was Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the grave man, \xe2\x80\x98all Mrs. Leo Hunter\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nacquaintances are; it is her ambition, sir, to have no other\r\nacquaintance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is a very noble ambition,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When I inform Mrs. Leo Hunter, that that remark fell from your lips,\r\nsir, she will indeed be proud,\xe2\x80\x99 said the grave man. \xe2\x80\x98You have a\r\ngentleman in your train, who has produced some beautiful little poems, I\r\nthink, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My friend Mr. Snodgrass has a great taste for poetry,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr.\r\nPickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So has Mrs. Leo Hunter, Sir. She dotes on poetry, sir. She adores it; I\r\nmay say that her whole soul and mind are wound up, and entwined with it.\r\nShe has produced some delightful pieces, herself, sir. You may have met\r\nwith her \xe2\x80\x9cOde to an Expiring Frog,\xe2\x80\x9d sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I have,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You astonish me, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Leo Hunter. \xe2\x80\x98It created an immense\r\nsensation. It was signed with an \xe2\x80\x9cL\xe2\x80\x9d and eight stars, and appeared\r\noriginally in a lady\xe2\x80\x99s magazine. It commenced--\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cCan I view thee panting, lying On thy stomach, without sighing; Can I\r\nunmoved see thee dying On a log Expiring frog!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Beautiful!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fine,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Leo Hunter; \xe2\x80\x98so simple.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The next verse is still more touching. Shall I repeat it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you please,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It runs thus,\xe2\x80\x99 said the grave man, still more gravely.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cSay, have fiends in shape of boys, With wild halloo, and brutal noise,\r\nHunted thee from marshy joys, With a dog, Expiring frog!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Finely expressed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All point, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Leo Hunter; \xe2\x80\x98but you shall hear Mrs. Leo\r\nHunter repeat it. She can do justice to it, Sir. She will repeat it, in\r\ncharacter, Sir, to-morrow morning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In character!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As Minerva. But I forgot--it\xe2\x80\x99s a fancy-dress _dejeune_.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, glancing at his own figure--\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\npossibly--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can\xe2\x80\x99t, sir; can\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Leo Hunter. \xe2\x80\x98Solomon Lucas, the Jew\r\nin the High Street, has thousands of fancy-dresses. Consider, Sir, how\r\nmany appropriate characters are open for your selection. Plato, Zeno,\r\nEpicurus, Pythagoras--all founders of clubs.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98but as I cannot put myself in\r\ncompetition with those great men, I cannot presume to wear their\r\ndresses.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe grave man considered deeply, for a few seconds, and then said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98On reflection, Sir, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether it would not afford Mrs. Leo\r\nHunter greater pleasure, if her guests saw a gentleman of your celebrity\r\nin his own costume, rather than in an assumed one. I may venture to\r\npromise an exception in your case, sir--yes, I am quite certain that, on\r\nbehalf of Mrs. Leo Hunter, I may venture to do so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In that case,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98I shall have great pleasure in\r\ncoming.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I waste your time, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the grave man, as if suddenly\r\nrecollecting himself. \xe2\x80\x98I know its value, sir. I will not detain you. I\r\nmay tell Mrs. Leo Hunter, then, that she may confidently expect you and\r\nyour distinguished friends? Good-morning, Sir, I am proud to have beheld\r\nso eminent a personage--not a step sir; not a word.\xe2\x80\x99 And without giving\r\nMr. Pickwick time to offer remonstrance or denial, Mr. Leo Hunter\r\nstalked gravely away.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick took up his hat, and repaired to the Peacock, but Mr.\r\nWinkle had conveyed the intelligence of the fancy-ball there, before\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Pott\xe2\x80\x99s going,\xe2\x80\x99 were the first words with which he saluted his\r\nleader.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is she?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As Apollo,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Winkle. \xe2\x80\x98Only Pott objects to the tunic.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is right. He is quite right,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick emphatically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; so she\xe2\x80\x99s going to wear a white satin gown with gold spangles.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They\xe2\x80\x99ll hardly know what she\xe2\x80\x99s meant for; will they?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr.\r\nSnodgrass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course they will,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Winkle indignantly. \xe2\x80\x98They\xe2\x80\x99ll see her\r\nlyre, won\xe2\x80\x99t they?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98True; I forgot that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Snodgrass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall go as a bandit,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Tupman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with a sudden start.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As a bandit,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr. Tupman, mildly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to say,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, gazing with solemn sternness\r\nat his friend--\xe2\x80\x98you don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to say, Mr. Tupman, that it is your\r\nintention to put yourself into a green velvet jacket, with a two-inch\r\ntail?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Such _is_ my intention, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Tupman warmly. \xe2\x80\x98And why not,\r\nsir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, considerably excited--\xe2\x80\x98because you\r\nare too old, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Too old!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Tupman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And if any further ground of objection be wanting,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Mr.\r\nPickwick, \xe2\x80\x98you are too fat, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman, his face suffused with a crimson glow, \xe2\x80\x98this is\r\nan insult.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, in the same tone, \xe2\x80\x98it is not half the\r\ninsult to you, that your appearance in my presence in a green velvet\r\njacket, with a two-inch tail, would be to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99re a fellow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99re another!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Tupman advanced a step or two, and glared at Mr. Pickwick. Mr.\r\nPickwick returned the glare, concentrated into a focus by means of his\r\nspectacles, and breathed a bold defiance. Mr. Snodgrass and Mr. Winkle\r\nlooked on, petrified at beholding such a scene between two such men.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman, after a short pause, speaking in a low, deep\r\nvoice, \xe2\x80\x98you have called me old.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And fat.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I reiterate the charge.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And a fellow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So you are!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was a fearful pause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My attachment to your person, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman, speaking in a\r\nvoice tremulous with emotion, and tucking up his wristbands meanwhile,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98is great--very great--but upon that person, I must take summary\r\nvengeance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come on, Sir!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick. Stimulated by the exciting nature\r\nof the dialogue, the heroic man actually threw himself into a paralytic\r\nattitude, confidently supposed by the two bystanders to have been\r\nintended as a posture of defence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Snodgrass, suddenly recovering the power of\r\nspeech, of which intense astonishment had previously bereft him, and\r\nrushing between the two, at the imminent hazard of receiving an\r\napplication on the temple from each--\xe2\x80\x98what! Mr. Pickwick, with the eyes\r\nof the world upon you! Mr. Tupman! who, in common with us all, derives a\r\nlustre from his undying name! For shame, gentlemen; for shame.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe unwonted lines which momentary passion had ruled in Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nclear and open brow, gradually melted away, as his young friend spoke,\r\nlike the marks of a black-lead pencil beneath the softening influence of\r\nindia-rubber. His countenance had resumed its usual benign expression,\r\nere he concluded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have been hasty,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98very hasty. Tupman; your hand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe dark shadow passed from Mr. Tupman\xe2\x80\x99s face, as he warmly grasped the\r\nhand of his friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have been hasty, too,\xe2\x80\x99 said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no,\xe2\x80\x99 interrupted Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98the fault was mine. You will wear\r\nthe green velvet jacket?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Tupman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To oblige me, you will,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, well, I will,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was accordingly settled that Mr. Tupman, Mr. Winkle, and Mr.\r\nSnodgrass, should all wear fancy-dresses. Thus Mr. Pickwick was led by\r\nthe very warmth of his own good feelings to give his consent to a\r\nproceeding from which his better judgment would have recoiled--a more\r\nstriking illustration of his amiable character could hardly have been\r\nconceived, even if the events recorded in these pages had been wholly\r\nimaginary.\r\n\r\nMr. Leo Hunter had not exaggerated the resources of Mr. Solomon Lucas.\r\nHis wardrobe was extensive--very extensive--not strictly classical\r\nperhaps, not quite new, nor did it contain any one garment made\r\nprecisely after the fashion of any age or time, but everything was more\r\nor less spangled; and what can be prettier than spangles! It may be\r\nobjected that they are not adapted to the daylight, but everybody knows\r\nthat they would glitter if there were lamps; and nothing can be clearer\r\nthan that if people give fancy-balls in the day-time, and the dresses do\r\nnot show quite as well as they would by night, the fault lies solely\r\nwith the people who give the fancy-balls, and is in no wise chargeable\r\non the spangles. Such was the convincing reasoning of Mr. Solomon Lucas;\r\nand influenced by such arguments did Mr. Tupman, Mr. Winkle, and Mr.\r\nSnodgrass engage to array themselves in costumes which his taste and\r\nexperience induced him to recommend as admirably suited to the occasion.\r\n\r\nA carriage was hired from the Town Arms, for the accommodation of the\r\nPickwickians, and a chariot was ordered from the same repository, for\r\nthe purpose of conveying Mr. and Mrs. Pott to Mrs. Leo Hunter\xe2\x80\x99s grounds,\r\nwhich Mr. Pott, as a delicate acknowledgment of having received an\r\ninvitation, had already confidently predicted in the Eatanswill\r\n_Gazette_ \xe2\x80\x98would present a scene of varied and delicious enchantment--a\r\nbewildering coruscation of beauty and talent--a lavish and prodigal\r\ndisplay of hospitality--above all, a degree of splendour softened by the\r\nmost exquisite taste; and adornment refined with perfect harmony and the\r\nchastest good keeping--compared with which, the fabled gorgeousness of\r\nEastern fairyland itself would appear to be clothed in as many dark and\r\nmurky colours, as must be the mind of the splenetic and unmanly being\r\nwho could presume to taint with the venom of his envy, the preparations\r\nmade by the virtuous and highly distinguished lady at whose shrine this\r\nhumble tribute of admiration was offered.\xe2\x80\x99 This last was a piece of\r\nbiting sarcasm against the _Independent_, who, in consequence of not\r\nhaving been invited at all, had been, through four numbers, affecting to\r\nsneer at the whole affair, in his very largest type, with all the\r\nadjectives in capital letters.\r\n\r\nThe morning came: it was a pleasant sight to behold Mr. Tupman in full\r\nbrigand\xe2\x80\x99s costume, with a very tight jacket, sitting like a pincushion\r\nover his back and shoulders, the upper portion of his legs incased in\r\nthe velvet shorts, and the lower part thereof swathed in the complicated\r\nbandages to which all brigands are peculiarly attached. It was pleasing\r\nto see his open and ingenuous countenance, well mustachioed and corked,\r\nlooking out from an open shirt collar; and to contemplate the sugar-loaf\r\nhat, decorated with ribbons of all colours, which he was compelled to\r\ncarry on his knee, inasmuch as no known conveyance with a top to it,\r\nwould admit of any man\xe2\x80\x99s carrying it between his head and the roof.\r\nEqually humorous and agreeable was the appearance of Mr. Snodgrass in\r\nblue satin trunks and cloak, white silk tights and shoes, and Grecian\r\nhelmet, which everybody knows (and if they do not, Mr. Solomon Lucas\r\ndid) to have been the regular, authentic, everyday costume of a\r\ntroubadour, from the earliest ages down to the time of their final\r\ndisappearance from the face of the earth. All this was pleasant, but\r\nthis was as nothing compared with the shouting of the populace when the\r\ncarriage drew up, behind Mr. Pott\xe2\x80\x99s chariot, which chariot itself drew\r\nup at Mr. Pott\xe2\x80\x99s door, which door itself opened, and displayed the great\r\nPott accoutred as a Russian officer of justice, with a tremendous knout\r\nin his hand--tastefully typical of the stern and mighty power of the\r\nEatanswill _Gazette_, and the fearful lashings it bestowed on public\r\noffenders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bravo!\xe2\x80\x99 shouted Mr. Tupman and Mr. Snodgrass from the passage, when\r\nthey beheld the walking allegory.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bravo!\xe2\x80\x99 Mr. Pickwick was heard to exclaim, from the passage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hoo-roar Pott!\xe2\x80\x99 shouted the populace. Amid these salutations, Mr. Pott,\r\nsmiling with that kind of bland dignity which sufficiently testified\r\nthat he felt his power, and knew how to exert it, got into the chariot.\r\n\r\nThen there emerged from the house, Mrs. Pott, who would have looked very\r\nlike Apollo if she hadn\xe2\x80\x99t had a gown on, conducted by Mr. Winkle, who,\r\nin his light-red coat could not possibly have been mistaken for anything\r\nbut a sportsman, if he had not borne an equal resemblance to a general\r\npostman. Last of all came Mr. Pickwick, whom the boys applauded as loud\r\nas anybody, probably under the impression that his tights and gaiters\r\nwere some remnants of the dark ages; and then the two vehicles proceeded\r\ntowards Mrs. Leo Hunter\xe2\x80\x99s; Mr. Weller (who was to assist in waiting)\r\nbeing stationed on the box of that in which his master was seated.\r\n\r\nEvery one of the men, women, boys, girls, and babies, who were assembled\r\nto see the visitors in their fancy-dresses, screamed with delight and\r\necstasy, when Mr. Pickwick, with the brigand on one arm, and the\r\ntroubadour on the other, walked solemnly up the entrance. Never were\r\nsuch shouts heard as those which greeted Mr. Tupman\xe2\x80\x99s efforts to fix the\r\nsugar-loaf hat on his head, by way of entering the garden in style.\r\n\r\nThe preparations were on the most delightful scale; fully realising the\r\nprophetic Pott\xe2\x80\x99s anticipations about the gorgeousness of Eastern\r\nfairyland, and at once affording a sufficient contradiction to the\r\nmalignant statements of the reptile _Independent_. The grounds were more\r\nthan an acre and a quarter in extent, and they were filled with people!\r\nNever was such a blaze of beauty, and fashion, and literature. There was\r\nthe young lady who \xe2\x80\x98did\xe2\x80\x99 the poetry in the Eatanswill _Gazette_, in the\r\ngarb of a sultana, leaning upon the arm of the young gentleman who \xe2\x80\x98did\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthe review department, and who was appropriately habited in a field-\r\nmarshal\xe2\x80\x99s uniform--the boots excepted. There were hosts of these\r\ngeniuses, and any reasonable person would have thought it honour enough\r\nto meet them. But more than these, there were half a dozen lions from\r\nLondon--authors, real authors, who had written whole books, and printed\r\nthem afterwards--and here you might see \xe2\x80\x98em, walking about, like\r\nordinary men, smiling, and talking--aye, and talking pretty considerable\r\nnonsense too, no doubt with the benign intention of rendering themselves\r\nintelligible to the common people about them. Moreover, there was a band\r\nof music in pasteboard caps; four something-ean singers in the costume\r\nof their country, and a dozen hired waiters in the costume of _their\r\n_country--and very dirty costume too. And above all, there was Mrs. Leo\r\nHunter in the character of Minerva, receiving the company, and\r\noverflowing with pride and gratification at the notion of having called\r\nsuch distinguished individuals together.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pickwick, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said a servant, as that gentleman approached the\r\npresiding goddess, with his hat in his hand, and the brigand and\r\ntroubadour on either arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What! Where!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mrs. Leo Hunter, starting up, in an affected\r\nrapture of surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it possible that I have really the gratification of beholding Mr.\r\nPickwick himself!\xe2\x80\x99 ejaculated Mrs. Leo Hunter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No other, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, bowing very low. \xe2\x80\x98Permit me to\r\nintroduce my friends--Mr. Tupman--Mr. Winkle--Mr. Snodgrass--to the\r\nauthoress of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Expiring Frog.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nVery few people but those who have tried it, know what a difficult\r\nprocess it is to bow in green velvet smalls, and a tight jacket, and\r\nhigh-crowned hat; or in blue satin trunks and white silks, or knee-cords\r\nand top-boots that were never made for the wearer, and have been fixed\r\nupon him without the remotest reference to the comparative dimensions of\r\nhimself and the suit. Never were such distortions as Mr. Tupman\xe2\x80\x99s frame\r\nunderwent in his efforts to appear easy and graceful--never was such\r\ningenious posturing, as his fancy-dressed friends exhibited.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pickwick,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Leo Hunter, \xe2\x80\x98I must make you promise not to\r\nstir from my side the whole day. There are hundreds of people here, that\r\nI must positively introduce you to.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are very kind, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the first place, here are my little girls; I had almost forgotten\r\nthem,\xe2\x80\x99 said Minerva, carelessly pointing towards a couple of full-grown\r\nyoung ladies, of whom one might be about twenty, and the other a year or\r\ntwo older, and who were dressed in very juvenile costumes--whether to\r\nmake them look young, or their mamma younger, Mr. Pickwick does not\r\ndistinctly inform us.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They are very beautiful,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, as the juveniles turned\r\naway, after being presented.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They are very like their mamma, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pott, majestically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, you naughty man,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mrs. Leo Hunter, playfully tapping the\r\neditor\xe2\x80\x99s arm with her fan (Minerva with a fan!).\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why now, my dear Mrs. Hunter,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pott, who was trumpeter in\r\nordinary at the Den, \xe2\x80\x98you know that when your picture was in the\r\nexhibition of the Royal Academy, last year, everybody inquired whether\r\nit was intended for you, or your youngest daughter; for you were so much\r\nalike that there was no telling the difference between you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, and if they did, why need you repeat it, before strangers?\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMrs. Leo Hunter, bestowing another tap on the slumbering lion of the\r\nEatanswill _Gazette_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Count, count,\xe2\x80\x99 screamed Mrs. Leo Hunter to a well-whiskered individual\r\nin a foreign uniform, who was passing by.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! you want me?\xe2\x80\x99 said the count, turning back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I want to introduce two very clever people to each other,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs.\r\nLeo Hunter. \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pickwick, I have great pleasure in introducing you to\r\nCount Smorltork.\xe2\x80\x99 She added in a hurried whisper to Mr. Pickwick--\xe2\x80\x98The\r\nfamous foreigner--gathering materials for his great work on England--\r\nhem!--Count Smorltork, Mr. Pickwick.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick saluted the count with all the reverence due to so great a\r\nman, and the count drew forth a set of tablets.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What you say, Mrs. Hunt?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the count, smiling graciously on the\r\ngratified Mrs. Leo Hunter, \xe2\x80\x98Pig Vig or Big Vig--what you call--lawyer--\r\neh? I see--that is it. Big Vig\xe2\x80\x99--and the count was proceeding to enter\r\nMr. Pickwick in his tablets, as a gentleman of the long robe, who\r\nderived his name from the profession to which he belonged, when Mrs. Leo\r\nHunter interposed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no, count,\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady, \xe2\x80\x98Pick-wick.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, ah, I see,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the count. \xe2\x80\x98Peek--christian name; Weeks--\r\nsurname; good, ver good. Peek Weeks. How you do, Weeks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite well, I thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, with all his usual\r\naffability. \xe2\x80\x98Have you been long in England?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Long--ver long time--fortnight--more.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you stay here long?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98One week.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will have enough to do,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick smiling, \xe2\x80\x98to gather all\r\nthe materials you want in that time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh, they are gathered,\xe2\x80\x99 said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They are here,\xe2\x80\x99 added the count, tapping his forehead significantly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Large book at home--full of notes--music, picture, science, potry,\r\npoltic; all tings.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The word politics, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98comprises in itself, a\r\ndifficult study of no inconsiderable magnitude.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said the count, drawing out the tablets again, \xe2\x80\x98ver good--fine\r\nwords to begin a chapter. Chapter forty-seven. Poltics. The word poltic\r\nsurprises by himself--\xe2\x80\x99 And down went Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s remark, in Count\r\nSmorltork\xe2\x80\x99s tablets, with such variations and additions as the count\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nexuberant fancy suggested, or his imperfect knowledge of the language\r\noccasioned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Count,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Leo Hunter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Hunt,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is Mr. Snodgrass, a friend of Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s, and a poet.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed the count, bringing out the tablets once more. \xe2\x80\x98Head,\r\npotry--chapter, literary friends--name, Snowgrass; ver good. Introduced\r\nto Snowgrass--great poet, friend of Peek Weeks--by Mrs. Hunt, which\r\nwrote other sweet poem--what is that name?--Fog--Perspiring Fog--ver\r\ngood--ver good indeed.\xe2\x80\x99 And the count put up his tablets, and with\r\nsundry bows and acknowledgments walked away, thoroughly satisfied that\r\nhe had made the most important and valuable additions to his stock of\r\ninformation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wonderful man, Count Smorltork,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Leo Hunter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sound philosopher,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pott.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Clear-headed, strong-minded person,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr. Snodgrass.\r\n\r\nA chorus of bystanders took up the shout of Count Smorltork\xe2\x80\x99s praise,\r\nshook their heads sagely, and unanimously cried, \xe2\x80\x98Very!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs the enthusiasm in Count Smorltork\xe2\x80\x99s favour ran very high, his praises\r\nmight have been sung until the end of the festivities, if the four\r\nsomething-ean singers had not ranged themselves in front of a small\r\napple-tree, to look picturesque, and commenced singing their national\r\nsongs, which appeared by no means difficult of execution, inasmuch as\r\nthe grand secret seemed to be, that three of the something-ean singers\r\nshould grunt, while the fourth howled. This interesting performance\r\nhaving concluded amidst the loud plaudits of the whole company, a boy\r\nforthwith proceeded to entangle himself with the rails of a chair, and\r\nto jump over it, and crawl under it, and fall down with it, and do\r\neverything but sit upon it, and then to make a cravat of his legs, and\r\ntie them round his neck, and then to illustrate the ease with which a\r\nhuman being can be made to look like a magnified toad--all which feats\r\nyielded high delight and satisfaction to the assembled spectators. After\r\nwhich, the voice of Mrs. Pott was heard to chirp faintly forth,\r\nsomething which courtesy interpreted into a song, which was all very\r\nclassical, and strictly in character, because Apollo was himself a\r\ncomposer, and composers can very seldom sing their own music or anybody\r\nelse\xe2\x80\x99s, either. This was succeeded by Mrs. Leo Hunter\xe2\x80\x99s recitation of\r\nher far-famed \xe2\x80\x98Ode to an Expiring Frog,\xe2\x80\x99 which was encored once, and\r\nwould have been encored twice, if the major part of the guests, who\r\nthought it was high time to get something to eat, had not said that it\r\nwas perfectly shameful to take advantage of Mrs. Hunter\xe2\x80\x99s good nature.\r\nSo although Mrs. Leo Hunter professed her perfect willingness to recite\r\nthe ode again, her kind and considerate friends wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t hear of it on\r\nany account; and the refreshment room being thrown open, all the people\r\nwho had ever been there before, scrambled in with all possible despatch-\r\n-Mrs. Leo Hunter\xe2\x80\x99s usual course of proceedings being, to issue cards for\r\na hundred, and breakfast for fifty, or in other words to feed only the\r\nvery particular lions, and let the smaller animals take care of\r\nthemselves.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where is Mr. Pott?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Leo Hunter, as she placed the aforesaid\r\nlions around her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here I am,\xe2\x80\x99 said the editor, from the remotest end of the room; far\r\nbeyond all hope of food, unless something was done for him by the\r\nhostess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Won\xe2\x80\x99t you come up here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, pray don\xe2\x80\x99t mind him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Pott, in the most obliging voice--\r\n\xe2\x80\x98you give yourself a great deal of unnecessary trouble, Mrs. Hunter.\r\nYou\xe2\x80\x99ll do very well there, won\xe2\x80\x99t you--dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly--love,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the unhappy Pott, with a grim smile. Alas for\r\nthe knout! The nervous arm that wielded it, with such a gigantic force\r\non public characters, was paralysed beneath the glance of the imperious\r\nMrs. Pott.\r\n\r\nMrs. Leo Hunter looked round her in triumph. Count Smorltork was busily\r\nengaged in taking notes of the contents of the dishes; Mr. Tupman was\r\ndoing the honours of the lobster salad to several lionesses, with a\r\ndegree of grace which no brigand ever exhibited before; Mr. Snodgrass\r\nhaving cut out the young gentleman who cut up the books for the\r\nEatanswill _Gazette_, was engaged in an impassioned argument with the\r\nyoung lady who did the poetry; and Mr. Pickwick was making himself\r\nuniversally agreeable. Nothing seemed wanting to render the select\r\ncircle complete, when Mr. Leo Hunter--whose department on these\r\noccasions, was to stand about in doorways, and talk to the less\r\nimportant people--suddenly called out--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear; here\xe2\x80\x99s Mr. Charles Fitz-Marshall.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Leo Hunter, \xe2\x80\x98how anxiously I have been expecting\r\nhim. Pray make room, to let Mr. Fitz-Marshall pass. Tell Mr. Fitz-\r\nMarshall, my dear, to come up to me directly, to be scolded for coming\r\nso late.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Coming, my dear ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 cried a voice, \xe2\x80\x98as quick as I can--crowds of\r\npeople--full room--hard work--very.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s knife and fork fell from his hand. He stared across the\r\ntable at Mr. Tupman, who had dropped his knife and fork, and was looking\r\nas if he were about to sink into the ground without further notice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 cried the voice, as its owner pushed his way among the last five-\r\nand-twenty Turks, officers, cavaliers, and Charles the Seconds, that\r\nremained between him and the table, \xe2\x80\x98regular mangle--Baker\xe2\x80\x99s patent--not\r\na crease in my coat, after all this squeezing--might have \xe2\x80\x9cgot up my\r\nlinen\xe2\x80\x9d as I came along--ha! ha! not a bad idea, that--queer thing to\r\nhave it mangled when it\xe2\x80\x99s upon one, though--trying process--very.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith these broken words, a young man dressed as a naval officer made his\r\nway up to the table, and presented to the astonished Pickwickians the\r\nidentical form and features of Mr. Alfred Jingle.\r\n\r\nThe offender had barely time to take Mrs. Leo Hunter\xe2\x80\x99s proffered hand,\r\nwhen his eyes encountered the indignant orbs of Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hollo!\xe2\x80\x99 said Jingle. \xe2\x80\x98Quite forgot--no directions to postillion--give\r\n\xe2\x80\x98em at once--back in a minute.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The servant, or Mr. Hunter will do it in a moment, Mr. Fitz-Marshall,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Mrs. Leo Hunter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no--I\xe2\x80\x99ll do it--shan\xe2\x80\x99t be long--back in no time,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jingle.\r\nWith these words he disappeared among the crowd.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you allow me to ask you, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said the excited Mr. Pickwick,\r\nrising from his seat, \xe2\x80\x98who that young man is, and where he resides?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is a gentleman of fortune, Mr. Pickwick,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Leo Hunter, \xe2\x80\x98to\r\nwhom I very much want to introduce you. The count will be delighted with\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick hastily. \xe2\x80\x98His residence--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is at present at the Angel at Bury.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At Bury?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At Bury St. Edmunds, not many miles from here. But dear me, Mr.\r\nPickwick, you are not going to leave us; surely Mr. Pickwick you cannot\r\nthink of going so soon?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut long before Mrs. Leo Hunter had finished speaking, Mr. Pickwick had\r\nplunged through the throng, and reached the garden, whither he was\r\nshortly afterwards joined by Mr. Tupman, who had followed his friend\r\nclosely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s of no use,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman. \xe2\x80\x98He has gone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98and I will follow him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Follow him! Where?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Tupman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To the Angel at Bury,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, speaking very quickly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How do we know whom he is deceiving there? He deceived a worthy man\r\nonce, and we were the innocent cause. He shall not do it again, if I can\r\nhelp it; I\xe2\x80\x99ll expose him! Sam! Where\xe2\x80\x99s my servant?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here you are, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, emerging from a sequestered spot,\r\nwhere he had been engaged in discussing a bottle of Madeira, which he\r\nhad abstracted from the breakfast-table an hour or two before. \xe2\x80\x98Here\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nyour servant, Sir. Proud o\xe2\x80\x99 the title, as the living skellinton said,\r\nven they show\xe2\x80\x99d him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Follow me instantly,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Tupman, if I stay at Bury,\r\nyou can join me there, when I write. Till then, good-bye!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nRemonstrances were useless. Mr. Pickwick was roused, and his mind was\r\nmade up. Mr. Tupman returned to his companions; and in another hour had\r\ndrowned all present recollection of Mr. Alfred Jingle, or Mr. Charles\r\nFitz-Marshall, in an exhilarating quadrille and a bottle of champagne.\r\nBy that time, Mr. Pickwick and Sam Weller, perched on the outside of a\r\nstage-coach, were every succeeding minute placing a less and less\r\ndistance between themselves and the good old town of Bury St. Edmunds.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVI. TOO FULL OF ADVENTURE TO BE BRIEFLY DESCRIBED\r\n\r\nThere is no month in the whole year in which nature wears a more\r\nbeautiful appearance than in the month of August. Spring has many\r\nbeauties, and May is a fresh and blooming month, but the charms of this\r\ntime of year are enhanced by their contrast with the winter season.\r\nAugust has no such advantage. It comes when we remember nothing but\r\nclear skies, green fields, and sweet-smelling flowers--when the\r\nrecollection of snow, and ice, and bleak winds, has faded from our minds\r\nas completely as they have disappeared from the earth--and yet what a\r\npleasant time it is! Orchards and cornfields ring with the hum of\r\nlabour; trees bend beneath the thick clusters of rich fruit which bow\r\ntheir branches to the ground; and the corn, piled in graceful sheaves,\r\nor waving in every light breath that sweeps above it, as if it wooed the\r\nsickle, tinges the landscape with a golden hue. A mellow softness\r\nappears to hang over the whole earth; the influence of the season seems\r\nto extend itself to the very wagon, whose slow motion across the well-\r\nreaped field is perceptible only to the eye, but strikes with no harsh\r\nsound upon the ear.\r\n\r\nAs the coach rolls swiftly past the fields and orchards which skirt the\r\nroad, groups of women and children, piling the fruit in sieves, or\r\ngathering the scattered ears of corn, pause for an instant from their\r\nlabour, and shading the sun-burned face with a still browner hand, gaze\r\nupon the passengers with curious eyes, while some stout urchin, too\r\nsmall to work, but too mischievous to be left at home, scrambles over\r\nthe side of the basket in which he has been deposited for security, and\r\nkicks and screams with delight. The reaper stops in his work, and stands\r\nwith folded arms, looking at the vehicle as it whirls past; and the\r\nrough cart-horses bestow a sleepy glance upon the smart coach team,\r\nwhich says as plainly as a horse\xe2\x80\x99s glance can, \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s all very fine to\r\nlook at, but slow going, over a heavy field, is better than warm work\r\nlike that, upon a dusty road, after all.\xe2\x80\x99 You cast a look behind you, as\r\nyou turn a corner of the road. The women and children have resumed their\r\nlabour; the reaper once more stoops to his work; the cart-horses have\r\nmoved on; and all are again in motion.\r\n\r\nThe influence of a scene like this, was not lost upon the well-regulated\r\nmind of Mr. Pickwick. Intent upon the resolution he had formed, of\r\nexposing the real character of the nefarious Jingle, in any quarter in\r\nwhich he might be pursuing his fraudulent designs, he sat at first\r\ntaciturn and contemplative, brooding over the means by which his purpose\r\ncould be best attained. By degrees his attention grew more and more\r\nattracted by the objects around him; and at last he derived as much\r\nenjoyment from the ride, as if it had been undertaken for the\r\npleasantest reason in the world.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Delightful prospect, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Beats the chimbley-pots, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, touching his hat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose you have hardly seen anything but chimney-pots and bricks and\r\nmortar all your life, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I worn\xe2\x80\x99t always a boots, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, with a shake of the\r\nhead. \xe2\x80\x98I wos a vaginer\xe2\x80\x99s boy, once.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When was that?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When I wos first pitched neck and crop into the world, to play at leap-\r\nfrog with its troubles,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98I wos a carrier\xe2\x80\x99s boy at\r\nstartin\xe2\x80\x99; then a vaginer\xe2\x80\x99s, then a helper, then a boots. Now I\xe2\x80\x99m a\r\ngen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99s servant. I shall be a gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n myself one of these days,\r\nperhaps, with a pipe in my mouth, and a summer-house in the back-garden.\r\nWho knows? I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be surprised for one.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are quite a philosopher, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It runs in the family, I b\xe2\x80\x99lieve, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98My\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s wery much in that line now. If my mother-in-law blows him up,\r\nhe whistles. She flies in a passion, and breaks his pipe; he steps out,\r\nand gets another. Then she screams wery loud, and falls into \xe2\x80\x98sterics;\r\nand he smokes wery comfortably till she comes to agin. That\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nphilosophy, Sir, ain\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A very good substitute for it, at all events,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick,\r\nlaughing. \xe2\x80\x98It must have been of great service to you, in the course of\r\nyour rambling life, Sam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Service, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Sam. \xe2\x80\x98You may say that. Arter I run away from\r\nthe carrier, and afore I took up with the vaginer, I had unfurnished\r\nlodgin\xe2\x80\x99s for a fortnight.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Unfurnished lodgings?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes--the dry arches of Waterloo Bridge. Fine sleeping-place--vithin ten\r\nminutes\xe2\x80\x99 walk of all the public offices--only if there is any objection\r\nto it, it is that the sitivation\xe2\x80\x99s rayther too airy. I see some queer\r\nsights there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAh, I suppose you did,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with an air of considerable\r\ninterest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sights, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98as \xe2\x80\x98ud penetrate your benevolent\r\nheart, and come out on the other side. You don\xe2\x80\x99t see the reg\xe2\x80\x99lar\r\nwagrants there; trust \xe2\x80\x98em, they knows better than that. Young beggars,\r\nmale and female, as hasn\xe2\x80\x99t made a rise in their profession, takes up\r\ntheir quarters there sometimes; but it\xe2\x80\x99s generally the worn-out,\r\nstarving, houseless creeturs as roll themselves in the dark corners o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthem lonesome places--poor creeturs as ain\xe2\x80\x99t up to the twopenny rope.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And pray, Sam, what is the twopenny rope?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The twopenny rope, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98is just a cheap lodgin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhouse, where the beds is twopence a night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do they call a bed a rope for?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless your innocence, sir, that ain\xe2\x80\x99t it,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Ven the lady\r\nand gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n as keeps the hot-el first begun business, they used to\r\nmake the beds on the floor; but this wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do at no price, \xe2\x80\x98cos\r\ninstead o\xe2\x80\x99 taking a moderate twopenn\xe2\x80\x99orth o\xe2\x80\x99 sleep, the lodgers used to\r\nlie there half the day. So now they has two ropes, \xe2\x80\x98bout six foot apart,\r\nand three from the floor, which goes right down the room; and the beds\r\nare made of slips of coarse sacking, stretched across \xe2\x80\x98em.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98the adwantage o\xe2\x80\x99 the plan\xe2\x80\x99s hobvious. At six\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock every mornin\xe2\x80\x99 they let\xe2\x80\x99s go the ropes at one end, and down falls\r\nthe lodgers. Consequence is, that being thoroughly waked, they get up\r\nwery quietly, and walk away!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Beg your pardon, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, suddenly breaking off in his\r\nloquacious discourse. \xe2\x80\x98Is this Bury St. Edmunds?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\nThe coach rattled through the well-paved streets of a handsome little\r\ntown, of thriving and cleanly appearance, and stopped before a large inn\r\nsituated in a wide open street, nearly facing the old abbey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And this,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, looking up. \xe2\x80\x98Is the Angel! We alight\r\nhere, Sam. But some caution is necessary. Order a private room, and do\r\nnot mention my name. You understand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Right as a trivet, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, with a wink of\r\nintelligence; and having dragged Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s portmanteau from the\r\nhind boot, into which it had been hastily thrown when they joined the\r\ncoach at Eatanswill, Mr. Weller disappeared on his errand. A private\r\nroom was speedily engaged; and into it Mr. Pickwick was ushered without\r\ndelay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98the first thing to be done is to--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOrder dinner, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s wery late, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, so it is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, looking at his watch. \xe2\x80\x98You are right,\r\nSam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And if I might adwise, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99d just have a good\r\nnight\xe2\x80\x99s rest arterwards, and not begin inquiring arter this here deep\r\n\xe2\x80\x98un till the mornin\xe2\x80\x99. There\xe2\x80\x99s nothin\xe2\x80\x99 so refreshen\xe2\x80\x99 as sleep, sir, as\r\nthe servant girl said afore she drank the egg-cupful of laudanum.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think you are right, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98But I must first\r\nascertain that he is in the house, and not likely to go away.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Leave that to me, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Let me order you a snug little\r\ndinner, and make my inquiries below while it\xe2\x80\x99s a-getting ready; I could\r\nworm ev\xe2\x80\x99ry secret out O\xe2\x80\x99 the boots\xe2\x80\x99s heart, in five minutes, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDo so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; and Mr. Weller at once retired.\r\n\r\nIn half an hour, Mr. Pickwick was seated at a very satisfactory dinner;\r\nand in three-quarters Mr. Weller returned with the intelligence that Mr.\r\nCharles Fitz-Marshall had ordered his private room to be retained for\r\nhim, until further notice. He was going to spend the evening at some\r\nprivate house in the neighbourhood, had ordered the boots to sit up\r\nuntil his return, and had taken his servant with him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 argued Mr. Weller, when he had concluded his report, \xe2\x80\x98if I\r\ncan get a talk with this here servant in the mornin\xe2\x80\x99, he\xe2\x80\x99ll tell me all\r\nhis master\xe2\x80\x99s concerns.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How do you know that?\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless your heart, sir, servants always do,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, ah, I forgot that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Well.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you can arrange what\xe2\x80\x99s best to be done, sir, and we can act\r\naccordingly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs it appeared that this was the best arrangement that could be made, it\r\nwas finally agreed upon. Mr. Weller, by his master\xe2\x80\x99s permission, retired\r\nto spend the evening in his own way; and was shortly afterwards elected,\r\nby the unanimous voice of the assembled company, into the taproom chair,\r\nin which honourable post he acquitted himself so much to the\r\nsatisfaction of the gentlemen-frequenters, that their roars of laughter\r\nand approbation penetrated to Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom, and shortened the\r\nterm of his natural rest by at least three hours.\r\n\r\nEarly on the ensuing morning, Mr. Weller was dispelling all the feverish\r\nremains of the previous evening\xe2\x80\x99s conviviality, through the\r\ninstrumentality of a halfpenny shower-bath (having induced a young\r\ngentleman attached to the stable department, by the offer of that coin,\r\nto pump over his head and face, until he was perfectly restored), when\r\nhe was attracted by the appearance of a young fellow in mulberry-\r\ncoloured livery, who was sitting on a bench in the yard, reading what\r\nappeared to be a hymn-book, with an air of deep abstraction, but who\r\noccasionally stole a glance at the individual under the pump, as if he\r\ntook some interest in his proceedings, nevertheless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re a rum \xe2\x80\x98un to look at, you are!\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr. Weller, the first\r\ntime his eyes encountered the glance of the stranger in the mulberry\r\nsuit, who had a large, sallow, ugly face, very sunken eyes, and a\r\ngigantic head, from which depended a quantity of lank black hair.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re a rum \xe2\x80\x98un!\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr. Weller; and thinking this, he went on\r\nwashing himself, and thought no more about him.\r\n\r\nStill the man kept glancing from his hymn-book to Sam, and from Sam to\r\nhis hymn-book, as if he wanted to open a conversation. So at last, Sam,\r\nby way of giving him an opportunity, said with a familiar nod--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How are you, governor?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am happy to say, I am pretty well, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man, speaking with\r\ngreat deliberation, and closing the book. \xe2\x80\x98I hope you are the same,\r\nSir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, if I felt less like a walking brandy-bottle I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be quite\r\nso staggery this mornin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Are you stoppin\xe2\x80\x99 in this house,\r\nold \xe2\x80\x98un?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe mulberry man replied in the affirmative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How was it you worn\xe2\x80\x99t one of us, last night?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam, scrubbing\r\nhis face with the towel. \xe2\x80\x98You seem one of the jolly sort--looks as\r\nconwivial as a live trout in a lime basket,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr. Weller, in an\r\nundertone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was out last night with my master,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the stranger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s his name?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Weller, colouring up very red with\r\nsudden excitement, and the friction of the towel combined.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fitz-Marshall,\xe2\x80\x99 said the mulberry man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Give us your hand,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, advancing; \xe2\x80\x98I should like to know\r\nyou. I like your appearance, old fellow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, that is very strange,\xe2\x80\x99 said the mulberry man, with great\r\nsimplicity of manner. \xe2\x80\x98I like yours so much, that I wanted to speak to\r\nyou, from the very first moment I saw you under the pump.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDid you though?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Upon my word. Now, isn\xe2\x80\x99t that curious?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery sing\xe2\x80\x99ler,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, inwardly congratulating himself upon the\r\nsoftness of the stranger. \xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s your name, my patriarch?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Job.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And a wery good name it is; only one I know that ain\xe2\x80\x99t got a nickname\r\nto it. What\xe2\x80\x99s the other name?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Trotter,\xe2\x80\x99 said the stranger. \xe2\x80\x98What is yours?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSam bore in mind his master\xe2\x80\x99s caution, and replied--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My name\xe2\x80\x99s Walker; my master\xe2\x80\x99s name\xe2\x80\x99s Wilkins. Will you take a drop o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsomethin\xe2\x80\x99 this mornin\xe2\x80\x99, Mr. Trotter?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Trotter acquiesced in this agreeable proposal; and having deposited\r\nhis book in his coat pocket, accompanied Mr. Weller to the tap, where\r\nthey were soon occupied in discussing an exhilarating compound, formed\r\nby mixing together, in a pewter vessel, certain quantities of British\r\nHollands and the fragrant essence of the clove.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what sort of a place have you got?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam, as he filled his\r\ncompanion\xe2\x80\x99s glass, for the second time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bad,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job, smacking his lips, \xe2\x80\x98very bad.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t mean that?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I do, indeed. Worse than that, my master\xe2\x80\x99s going to be married.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; and worse than that, too, he\xe2\x80\x99s going to run away with an immense\r\nrich heiress, from boarding-school.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What a dragon!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, refilling his companion\xe2\x80\x99s glass. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s some\r\nboarding-school in this town, I suppose, ain\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99 Now, although this\r\nquestion was put in the most careless tone imaginable, Mr. Job Trotter\r\nplainly showed by gestures that he perceived his new friend\xe2\x80\x99s anxiety to\r\ndraw forth an answer to it. He emptied his glass, looked mysteriously at\r\nhis companion, winked both of his small eyes, one after the other, and\r\nfinally made a motion with his arm, as if he were working an imaginary\r\npump-handle; thereby intimating that he (Mr. Trotter) considered himself\r\nas undergoing the process of being pumped by Mr. Samuel Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Trotter, in conclusion, \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s not to be told to\r\neverybody. That is a secret--a great secret, Mr. Walker.\xe2\x80\x99 As the\r\nmulberry man said this, he turned his glass upside down, by way of\r\nreminding his companion that he had nothing left wherewith to slake his\r\nthirst. Sam observed the hint; and feeling the delicate manner in which\r\nit was conveyed, ordered the pewter vessel to be refilled, whereat the\r\nsmall eyes of the mulberry man glistened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And so it\xe2\x80\x99s a secret?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should rather suspect it was,\xe2\x80\x99 said the mulberry man, sipping his\r\nliquor, with a complacent face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose your mas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99s wery rich?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\nMr. Trotter smiled, and holding his glass in his left hand, gave four\r\ndistinct slaps on the pockets of his mulberry indescribables with his\r\nright, as if to intimate that his master might have done the same\r\nwithout alarming anybody much by the chinking of coin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s the game, is it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe mulberry man nodded significantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, and don\xe2\x80\x99t you think, old feller,\xe2\x80\x99 remonstrated Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98that\r\nif you let your master take in this here young lady, you\xe2\x80\x99re a precious\r\nrascal?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job Trotter, turning upon his companion a\r\ncountenance of deep contrition, and groaning slightly, \xe2\x80\x98I know that, and\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s what it is that preys upon my mind. But what am I to do?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam; \xe2\x80\x98di-wulge to the missis, and give up your master.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who\xe2\x80\x99d believe me?\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job Trotter. \xe2\x80\x98The young lady\xe2\x80\x99s considered\r\nthe very picture of innocence and discretion. She\xe2\x80\x99d deny it, and so\r\nwould my master. Who\xe2\x80\x99d believe me? I should lose my place, and get\r\nindicted for a conspiracy, or some such thing; that\xe2\x80\x99s all I should take\r\nby my motion.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s somethin\xe2\x80\x99 in that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, ruminating; \xe2\x80\x98there\xe2\x80\x99s somethin\xe2\x80\x99 in\r\nthat.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I knew any respectable gentleman who would take the matter up,\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncontinued Mr. Trotter. \xe2\x80\x98I might have some hope of preventing the\r\nelopement; but there\xe2\x80\x99s the same difficulty, Mr. Walker, just the same. I\r\nknow no gentleman in this strange place; and ten to one if I did,\r\nwhether he would believe my story.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come this way,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, suddenly jumping up, and grasping the\r\nmulberry man by the arm. \xe2\x80\x98My mas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99s the man you want, I see.\xe2\x80\x99 And after\r\na slight resistance on the part of Job Trotter, Sam led his newly-found\r\nfriend to the apartment of Mr. Pickwick, to whom he presented him,\r\ntogether with a brief summary of the dialogue we have just repeated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am very sorry to betray my master, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job Trotter, applying\r\nto his eyes a pink checked pocket-handkerchief about six inches square.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The feeling does you a great deal of honour,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98but it is your duty, nevertheless.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know it is my duty, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job, with great emotion. \xe2\x80\x98We should\r\nall try to discharge our duty, Sir, and I humbly endeavour to discharge\r\nmine, Sir; but it is a hard trial to betray a master, Sir, whose clothes\r\nyou wear, and whose bread you eat, even though he is a scoundrel, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are a very good fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, much affected; \xe2\x80\x98an\r\nhonest fellow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, come,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Sam, who had witnessed Mr. Trotter\xe2\x80\x99s tears with\r\nconsiderable impatience, \xe2\x80\x98blow this \xe2\x80\x98ere water-cart bis\xe2\x80\x99ness. It won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndo no good, this won\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick reproachfully. \xe2\x80\x98I am sorry to find that you\r\nhave so little respect for this young man\xe2\x80\x99s feelings.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98His feelin\xe2\x80\x99s is all wery well, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98and as\r\nthey\xe2\x80\x99re so wery fine, and it\xe2\x80\x99s a pity he should lose \xe2\x80\x98em, I think he\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nbetter keep \xe2\x80\x98em in his own buzzum, than let \xe2\x80\x98em ewaporate in hot water,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98specially as they do no good. Tears never yet wound up a clock, or\r\nworked a steam ingin\xe2\x80\x99. The next time you go out to a smoking party,\r\nyoung fellow, fill your pipe with that \xe2\x80\x98ere reflection; and for the\r\npresent just put that bit of pink gingham into your pocket. \xe2\x80\x98Tain\xe2\x80\x99t so\r\nhandsome that you need keep waving it about, as if you was a tight-rope\r\ndancer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My man is in the right,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. the\r\nold lady, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All them old cats _will _run their heads agin milestones,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Mr.\r\nWeller, in a parenthesis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But When\r\nthe family have retired to rest, we shall come out of the kitchen, and\r\nthe young lady out of her bedroom. A post-chaise will be waiting, and\r\naway we go.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, sir, I have been thinking that if you were in waiting in the\r\ngarden behind, alone--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Alone,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Why alone?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought it very natural,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job, \xe2\x80\x98that the old lady wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlike such an unpleasant discovery to be made before more persons than\r\ncan possibly be helped. I shall be sure to be there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThus, for the second time, did Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s innate good-feeling\r\ninvolve him in an enterprise from which he would most willingly have\r\nstood aloof.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is the name of the house?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Westgate House, Sir. You turn a little to the right when you get to the\r\nend of the town; it stands by itself, some little distance off the high\r\nroad, with the name on a brass plate on the gate.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98I observed it once before, when I was\r\nin this town. You may depend upon me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Trotter made another bow, and turned to depart, when Mr. Pickwick\r\nthrust a guinea into his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re a fine fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98and I admire your goodness\r\nof heart. No thanks. Remember--eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is no fear of my forgetting it, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job Trotter. With\r\nthese words he left the room, followed by Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say,\xe2\x80\x99 said the latter, \xe2\x80\x98not a bad notion that \xe2\x80\x98ere crying. I\xe2\x80\x99d cry\r\nlike a rain-water spout in a shower on such good terms. How do you do\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It comes from the heart, Mr. Walker,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job solemnly. \xe2\x80\x98Good-\r\nmorning, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re a soft customer, you are; we\xe2\x80\x99ve got it all out o\xe2\x80\x99 you, anyhow,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthought Mr. Weller, as Job walked away.\r\n\r\nWe cannot state the precise nature of the thoughts which passed through\r\nMr. Trotter\xe2\x80\x99s mind, because we don\xe2\x80\x99t know what they were.\r\n\r\nThe day wore on, evening came, and at a little before ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock Sam\r\nWeller reported that Mr. Jingle and Job had gone out together, that\r\ntheir luggage was packed up, and that they had ordered a chaise. The\r\nplot was evidently in execution, as Mr. Trotter had foretold.\r\n\r\nHalf-past ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock arrived, and it was time for Mr. Pickwick to issue\r\nforth on his delicate errand. Resisting Sam\xe2\x80\x99s tender of his greatcoat,\r\nin order that he might have no encumbrance in scaling the wall, he set\r\nforth, followed by his attendant.\r\n\r\nThere was a bright moon, but it was behind the clouds. It was a fine dry\r\nnight, but it was most uncommonly dark. Paths, hedges, fields, houses,\r\nand trees, were enveloped in one deep shade. The atmosphere was hot and\r\nsultry, the summer lightning quivered faintly on the verge of the\r\nhorizon, and was the only sight that varied the dull gloom in which\r\neverything was wrapped--sound there was none, except the distant barking\r\nof some restless house-dog.\r\n\r\nThey found the house, read the brass plate, walked round the wall, and\r\nstopped at that portion of it which divided them from the bottom of the\r\ngarden.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will return to the inn, Sam, when you have assisted me over,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery well, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you will sit up, till I return.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Cert\xe2\x80\x99nly, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take hold of my leg; and, when I say \xe2\x80\x9cOver,\xe2\x80\x9d raise me gently.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All right, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHaving settled these preliminaries, Mr. Pickwick grasped the top of the\r\nwall, and gave the word \xe2\x80\x98Over,\xe2\x80\x99 which was literally obeyed. Whether his\r\nbody partook in some degree of the elasticity of his mind, or whether\r\nMr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s notions of a gentle push were of a somewhat rougher\r\ndescription than Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s, the immediate effect of his assistance\r\nwas to jerk that immortal gentleman completely over the wall on to the\r\nbed beneath, where, after crushing three gooseberry-bushes and a rose-\r\ntree, he finally alighted at full length.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You ha\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t hurt yourself, I hope, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, in a loud whisper, as\r\nsoon as he had recovered from the surprise consequent upon the\r\nmysterious disappearance of his master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have not hurt _myself_, Sam, certainly,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, from\r\nthe other side of the wall, \xe2\x80\x98but I rather think that _you _have hurt\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope not, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never mind,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, rising, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s nothing but a few\r\nscratches. Go away, or we shall be overheard.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-bye, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-bye.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith stealthy steps Sam Weller departed, leaving Mr. Pickwick alone in\r\nthe garden.\r\n\r\nLights occasionally appeared in the different windows of the house, or\r\nglanced from the staircases, as if the inmates were retiring to rest.\r\nNot caring to go too near the door, until the appointed time, Mr.\r\nPickwick crouched into an angle of the wall, and awaited its arrival.\r\n\r\nIt was a situation which might well have depressed the spirits of many a\r\nman. Mr. Pickwick, however, felt neither depression nor misgiving. He\r\nknew that his purpose was in the main a good one, and he placed implicit\r\nreliance on the high-minded Job. It was dull, certainly; not to say\r\ndreary; but a contemplative man can always employ himself in meditation.\r\nMr. Pickwick had meditated himself into a doze, when he was roused by\r\nthe chimes of the neighbouring church ringing out the hour--half-past\r\neleven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s the time,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr. Pickwick, getting cautiously on his feet.\r\nHe looked up at the house. The lights had disappeared, and the shutters\r\nwere closed--all in bed, no doubt. He walked on tiptoe to the door, and\r\ngave a gentle tap. Two or three minutes passing without any reply, he\r\ngave another tap rather louder, and then another rather louder than\r\nthat.\r\n\r\nAt length the sound of feet was audible upon the stairs, and then the\r\nlight of a candle shone through the keyhole of the door. There was a\r\ngood deal of unchaining and unbolting, and the door was slowly opened.\r\n\r\nNow the door opened outwards; and as the door opened wider and wider,\r\nMr. Pickwick receded behind it, more and more. What was his astonishment\r\nwhen he just peeped out, by way of caution, to see that the person who\r\nhad opened it was--not Job Trotter, but a servant-girl with a candle in\r\nher hand! Mr. Pickwick drew in his head again, with the swiftness\r\ndisplayed by that admirable melodramatic performer, Punch, when he lies\r\nin wait for the flat-headed comedian with the tin box of music.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It must have been the cat, Sarah,\xe2\x80\x99 said the girl, addressing herself to\r\nsome one in the house. \xe2\x80\x98Puss, puss, puss,--tit, tit, tit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut no animal being decoyed by these blandishments, the girl slowly\r\nclosed the door, and re-fastened it; leaving Mr. Pickwick drawn up\r\nstraight against the wall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is very curious,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98They are sitting up\r\nbeyond their usual hour, I suppose. Extremely unfortunate, that they\r\nshould have chosen this night, of all others, for such a purpose--\r\nexceedingly.\xe2\x80\x99 And with these thoughts, Mr. Pickwick cautiously retired\r\nto the angle of the wall in which he had been before ensconced; waiting\r\nuntil such time as he might deem it safe to repeat the signal.\r\n\r\nHe had not been here five minutes, when a vivid flash of lightning was\r\nfollowed by a loud peal of thunder that crashed and rolled away in the\r\ndistance with a terrific noise--then came another flash of lightning,\r\nbrighter than the other, and a second peal of thunder louder than the\r\nfirst; and then down came the rain, with a force and fury that swept\r\neverything before it.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick was perfectly aware that a tree is a very dangerous\r\nneighbour in a thunderstorm. He had a tree on his right, a tree on his\r\nleft, a third before him, and a fourth behind. If he remained where he\r\nwas, he might fall the victim of an accident; if he showed himself in\r\nthe centre of the garden, he might be consigned to a constable. Once or\r\ntwice he tried to scale the wall, but having no other legs this time,\r\nthan those with which Nature had furnished him, the only effect of his\r\nstruggles was to inflict a variety of very unpleasant gratings on his\r\nknees and shins, and to throw him into a state of the most profuse\r\nperspiration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What a dreadful situation,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, pausing to wipe his brow\r\nafter this exercise. He looked up at the house--all was dark. They must\r\nbe gone to bed now. He would try the signal again.\r\n\r\nHe walked on tiptoe across the moist gravel, and tapped at the door. He\r\nheld his breath, and listened at the key-hole. No reply: very odd.\r\nAnother knock. He listened again. There was a low whispering inside, and\r\nthen a voice cried--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who\xe2\x80\x99s there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s not Job,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr. Pickwick, hastily drawing himself straight\r\nup against the wall again. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a woman.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe had scarcely had time to form this conclusion, when a window above\r\nstairs was thrown up, and three or four female voices repeated the\r\nquery--\xe2\x80\x98Who\xe2\x80\x99s there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick dared not move hand or foot. It was clear that the whole\r\nestablishment was roused. He made up his mind to remain where he was,\r\nuntil the alarm had subsided; and then by a supernatural effort, to get\r\nover the wall, or perish in the attempt.\r\n\r\nLike all Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s determinations, this was the best that could be\r\nmade under the circumstances; but, unfortunately, it was founded upon\r\nthe assumption that they would not venture to open the door again. What\r\nwas his discomfiture, when he heard the chain and bolts withdrawn, and\r\nsaw the door slowly opening, wider and wider! He retreated into the\r\ncorner, step by step; but do what he would, the interposition of his own\r\nperson, prevented its being opened to its utmost width.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who\xe2\x80\x99s there?\xe2\x80\x99 screamed a numerous chorus of treble voices from the\r\nstaircase inside, consisting of the spinster lady of the establishment,\r\nthree teachers, five female servants, and thirty boarders, all half-\r\ndressed and in a forest of curl-papers.\r\n\r\n\r\nOf course Mr. Pickwick didn\xe2\x80\x99t say who was there: and then the burden of\r\nthe chorus changed into--\xe2\x80\x98Lor! I am so frightened.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Cook,\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady abbess, who took care to be on the top stair, the\r\nvery last of the group--\xe2\x80\x98cook, why don\xe2\x80\x99t you go a little way into the\r\ngarden?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPlease, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, I don\xe2\x80\x99t like,\xe2\x80\x99 responded the cook.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lor, what a stupid thing that cook is!\xe2\x80\x99 said the thirty boarders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Cook,\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady abbess, with great dignity; \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t answer me, if\r\nyou please. I insist upon your looking into the garden immediately.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere the cook began to cry, and the housemaid said it was \xe2\x80\x98a shame!\xe2\x80\x99 for\r\nwhich partisanship she received a month\xe2\x80\x99s warning on the spot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you hear, cook?\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady abbess, stamping her foot\r\nimpatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you hear your missis, cook?\xe2\x80\x99 said the three teachers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What an impudent thing that cook is!\xe2\x80\x99 said the thirty boarders.\r\n\r\nThe unfortunate cook, thus strongly urged, advanced a step or two, and\r\nholding her candle just where it prevented her from seeing at all,\r\ndeclared there was nothing there, and it must have been the wind. The\r\ndoor was just going to be closed in consequence, when an inquisitive\r\nboarder, who had been peeping between the hinges, set up a fearful\r\nscreaming, which called back the cook and housemaid, and all the more\r\nadventurous, in no time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is the matter with Miss Smithers?\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady abbess, as the\r\naforesaid Miss Smithers proceeded to go into hysterics of four young\r\nlady power.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lor, Miss Smithers, dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said the other nine-and-twenty boarders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, the man--the man--behind the door!\xe2\x80\x99 screamed Miss Smithers.\r\n\r\nThe lady abbess no sooner heard this appalling cry, than she retreated\r\nto her own bedroom, double-locked the door, and fainted away\r\ncomfortably. The boarders, and the teachers, and the servants, fell back\r\nupon the stairs, and upon each other; and never was such a screaming,\r\nand fainting, and struggling beheld. In the midst of the tumult, Mr.\r\nPickwick emerged from his concealment, and presented himself amongst\r\nthem.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ladies--dear ladies,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh. he says we\xe2\x80\x99re dear,\xe2\x80\x99 cried the oldest and ugliest teacher. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, the\r\nwretch!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ladies,\xe2\x80\x99 roared Mr. Pickwick, rendered desperate by the danger of his\r\nsituation. \xe2\x80\x98Hear me. I am no robber. I want the lady of the house.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, what a ferocious monster!\xe2\x80\x99 screamed another teacher. \xe2\x80\x98He wants Miss\r\nTomkins.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere there was a general scream.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ring the alarm bell, somebody!\xe2\x80\x99 cried a dozen voices.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t--don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 shouted Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Look at me. Do I look like a\r\nrobber! My dear ladies--you may bind me hand and leg, or lock me up in a\r\ncloset, if you like.
