Only hear what I have got to say--only hear me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How did you come in our garden?\xe2\x80\x99 faltered the housemaid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Call the lady of the house, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell her everything,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nPickwick, exerting his lungs to the utmost pitch. \xe2\x80\x98Call her--only be\r\nquiet, and call her, and you shall hear everything.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt might have been Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s appearance, or it might have been his\r\nmanner, or it might have been the temptation--irresistible to a female\r\nmind--of hearing something at present enveloped in mystery, that reduced\r\nthe more reasonable portion of the establishment (some four individuals)\r\nto a state of comparative quiet. By them it was proposed, as a test of\r\nMr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s sincerity, that he should immediately submit to personal\r\nrestraint; and that gentleman having consented to hold a conference with\r\nMiss Tomkins, from the interior of a closet in which the day boarders\r\nhung their bonnets and sandwich-bags, he at once stepped into it, of his\r\nown accord, and was securely locked in. This revived the others; and\r\nMiss Tomkins having been brought to, and brought down, the conference\r\nbegan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What did you do in my garden, man?\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Tomkins, in a faint\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I came to warn you that one of your young ladies was going to elope to-\r\nnight,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, from the interior of the closet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Elope!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Miss Tomkins, the three teachers, the thirty\r\nboarders, and the five servants. \xe2\x80\x98Who with?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nYour friend, Mr. Charles Fitz-Marshall.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98_My_ friend! I don\xe2\x80\x99t know any such person.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Mr. Jingle, then.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never heard the name in my life.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then, I have been deceived, and deluded,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98I have\r\nbeen the victim of a conspiracy--a foul and base conspiracy. Send to the\r\nAngel, my dear ma\xe2\x80\x99am, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t believe me. Send to the Angel for Mr.\r\nPickwick\xe2\x80\x99s manservant, I implore you, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He must be respectable--he keeps a manservant,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Tomkins to\r\nthe writing and ciphering governess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s my opinion, Miss Tomkins,\xe2\x80\x99 said the writing and ciphering\r\ngoverness, \xe2\x80\x98that his manservant keeps him, I think he\xe2\x80\x99s a madman, Miss\r\nTomkins, and the other\xe2\x80\x99s his keeper.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think you are very right, Miss Gwynn,\xe2\x80\x99 responded Miss Tomkins. \xe2\x80\x98Let\r\ntwo of the servants repair to the Angel, and let the others remain here,\r\nto protect us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo two of the servants were despatched to the Angel in search of Mr.\r\nSamuel Weller; and the remaining three stopped behind to protect Miss\r\nTomkins, and the three teachers, and the thirty boarders. And Mr.\r\nPickwick sat down in the closet, beneath a grove of sandwich-bags, and\r\nawaited the return of the messengers, with all the philosophy and\r\nfortitude he could summon to his aid.\r\n\r\nAn hour and a half elapsed before they came back, and when they did\r\ncome, Mr. Pickwick recognised, in addition to the voice of Mr. Samuel\r\nWeller, two other voices, the tones of which struck familiarly on his\r\near; but whose they were, he could not for the life of him call to mind.\r\n\r\nA very brief conversation ensued. The door was unlocked. Mr. Pickwick\r\nstepped out of the closet, and found himself in the presence of the\r\nwhole establishment of Westgate House, Mr Samuel Weller, and--old\r\nWardle, and his destined son-in-law, Mr. Trundle!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear friend,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, running forward and grasping\r\nWardle\xe2\x80\x99s hand, \xe2\x80\x98my dear friend, pray, for Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake, explain to this\r\nlady the unfortunate and dreadful situation in which I am placed. You\r\nmust have heard it from my servant; say, at all events, my dear fellow,\r\nthat I am neither a robber nor a madman.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have said so, my dear friend. I have said so already,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr.\r\nWardle, shaking the right hand of his friend, while Mr. Trundle shook\r\nthe left.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And whoever says, or has said, he is,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Weller, stepping\r\nforward, \xe2\x80\x98says that which is not the truth, but so far from it, on the\r\ncontrary, quite the rewerse. And if there\xe2\x80\x99s any number o\xe2\x80\x99 men on these\r\nhere premises as has said so, I shall be wery happy to give \xe2\x80\x98em all a\r\nwery convincing proof o\xe2\x80\x99 their being mistaken, in this here wery room,\r\nif these wery respectable ladies \xe2\x80\x98ll have the goodness to retire, and\r\norder \xe2\x80\x98em up, one at a time.\xe2\x80\x99 Having delivered this defiance with great\r\nvolubility, Mr. Weller struck his open palm emphatically with his\r\nclenched fist, and winked pleasantly on Miss Tomkins, the intensity of\r\nwhose horror at his supposing it within the bounds of possibility that\r\nthere could be any men on the premises of Westgate House Establishment\r\nfor Young Ladies, it is impossible to describe.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s explanation having already been partially made, was soon\r\nconcluded. But neither in the course of his walk home with his friends,\r\nnor afterwards when seated before a blazing fire at the supper he so\r\nmuch needed, could a single observation be drawn from him. He seemed\r\nbewildered and amazed. Once, and only once, he turned round to Mr.\r\nWardle, and said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How did you come here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Trundle and I came down here, for some good shooting on the first,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nreplied Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98We arrived to-night, and were astonished to hear from\r\nyour servant that you were here too. But I am glad you are,\xe2\x80\x99 said the\r\nold fellow, slapping him on the back--\xe2\x80\x98I am glad you are. We shall have\r\na jovial party on the first, and we\xe2\x80\x99ll give Winkle another chance--eh,\r\nold boy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick made no reply, he did not even ask after his friends at\r\nDingley Dell, and shortly afterwards retired for the night, desiring Sam\r\nto fetch his candle when he rung.\r\n\r\nThe bell did ring in due course, and Mr. Weller presented himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, looking out from under the bed-clothes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick paused, and Mr. Weller snuffed the candle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick again, as if with a desperate effort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, once more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where is that Trotter?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Job, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gone, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With his master, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Friend or master, or whatever he is, he\xe2\x80\x99s gone with him,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr.\r\nWeller. \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s a pair on \xe2\x80\x98em, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Jingle suspected my design, and set that fellow on you, with this\r\nstory, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, half choking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just that, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was all false, of course?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Reg\xe2\x80\x99lar do, sir; artful dodge.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think he\xe2\x80\x99ll escape us quite so easily the next time, Sam!\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think he will, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Whenever I meet that Jingle again, wherever it is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick,\r\nraising himself in bed, and indenting his pillow with a tremendous blow,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll inflict personal chastisement on him, in addition to the exposure\r\nhe so richly merits. I will, or my name is not Pickwick.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And venever I catches hold o\xe2\x80\x99 that there melan-cholly chap with the\r\nblack hair,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98if I don\xe2\x80\x99t bring some real water into his eyes,\r\nfor once in a way, my name ain\xe2\x80\x99t Weller. Good-night, Sir!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVII. SHOWING THAT AN ATTACK OF RHEUMATISM, IN SOME CASES, ACTS\r\nAS A QUICKENER TO INVENTIVE GENIUS\r\n\r\nThe constitution of Mr. Pickwick, though able to sustain a very\r\nconsiderable amount of exertion and fatigue, was not proof against such\r\na combination of attacks as he had undergone on the memorable night,\r\nrecorded in the last chapter. The process of being washed in the night\r\nair, and rough-dried in a closet, is as dangerous as it is peculiar. Mr.\r\nPickwick was laid up with an attack of rheumatism.\r\n\r\nBut although the bodily powers of the great man were thus impaired, his\r\nmental energies retained their pristine vigour. His spirits were\r\nelastic; his good-humour was restored. Even the vexation consequent upon\r\nhis recent adventure had vanished from his mind; and he could join in\r\nthe hearty laughter, which any allusion to it excited in Mr. Wardle,\r\nwithout anger and without embarrassment. Nay, more. During the two days\r\nMr. Pickwick was confined to bed, Sam was his constant attendant. On the\r\nfirst, he endeavoured to amuse his master by anecdote and conversation;\r\non the second, Mr. Pickwick demanded his writing-desk, and pen and ink,\r\nand was deeply engaged during the whole day. On the third, being able to\r\nsit up in his bedchamber, he despatched his valet with a message to Mr.\r\nWardle and Mr. Trundle, intimating that if they would take their wine\r\nthere, that evening, they would greatly oblige him. The invitation was\r\nmost willingly accepted; and when they were seated over their wine, Mr.\r\nPickwick, with sundry blushes, produced the following little tale, as\r\nhaving been \xe2\x80\x98edited\xe2\x80\x99 by himself, during his recent indisposition, from\r\nhis notes of Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s unsophisticated recital.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE PARISH CLERK A TALE OF TRUE LOVE\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Once upon a time, in a very small country town, at a considerable\r\ndistance from London, there lived a little man named Nathaniel Pipkin,\r\nwho was the parish clerk of the little town, and lived in a little house\r\nin the little High Street, within ten minutes\xe2\x80\x99 walk from the little\r\nchurch; and who was to be found every day, from nine till four, teaching\r\na little learning to the little boys. Nathaniel Pipkin was a harmless,\r\ninoffensive, good-natured being, with a turned-up nose, and rather\r\nturned-in legs, a cast in his eye, and a halt in his gait; and he\r\ndivided his time between the church and his school, verily believing\r\nthat there existed not, on the face of the earth, so clever a man as the\r\ncurate, so imposing an apartment as the vestry-room, or so well-ordered\r\na seminary as his own. Once, and only once, in his life, Nathaniel\r\nPipkin had seen a bishop--a real bishop, with his arms in lawn sleeves,\r\nand his head in a wig. He had seen him walk, and heard him talk, at a\r\nconfirmation, on which momentous occasion Nathaniel Pipkin was so\r\novercome with reverence and awe, when the aforesaid bishop laid his hand\r\non his head, that he fainted right clean away, and was borne out of\r\nchurch in the arms of the beadle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This was a great event, a tremendous era, in Nathaniel Pipkin\xe2\x80\x99s life,\r\nand it was the only one that had ever occurred to ruffle the smooth\r\ncurrent of his quiet existence, when happening one fine afternoon, in a\r\nfit of mental abstraction, to raise his eyes from the slate on which he\r\nwas devising some tremendous problem in compound addition for an\r\noffending urchin to solve, they suddenly rested on the blooming\r\ncountenance of Maria Lobbs, the only daughter of old Lobbs, the great\r\nsaddler over the way. Now, the eyes of Mr. Pipkin had rested on the\r\npretty face of Maria Lobbs many a time and oft before, at church and\r\nelsewhere; but the eyes of Maria Lobbs had never looked so bright, the\r\ncheeks of Maria Lobbs had never looked so ruddy, as upon this particular\r\noccasion. No wonder then, that Nathaniel Pipkin was unable to take his\r\neyes from the countenance of Miss Lobbs; no wonder that Miss Lobbs,\r\nfinding herself stared at by a young man, withdrew her head from the\r\nwindow out of which she had been peeping, and shut the casement and\r\npulled down the blind; no wonder that Nathaniel Pipkin, immediately\r\nthereafter, fell upon the young urchin who had previously offended, and\r\ncuffed and knocked him about to his heart\xe2\x80\x99s content. All this was very\r\nnatural, and there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing at all to wonder at about it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It _is_ matter of wonder, though, that anyone of Mr. Nathaniel Pipkin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nretiring disposition, nervous temperament, and most particularly\r\ndiminutive income, should from this day forth, have dared to aspire to\r\nthe hand and heart of the only daughter of the fiery old Lobbs--of old\r\nLobbs, the great saddler, who could have bought up the whole village at\r\none stroke of his pen, and never felt the outlay--old Lobbs, who was\r\nwell known to have heaps of money, invested in the bank at the nearest\r\nmarket town--who was reported to have countless and inexhaustible\r\ntreasures hoarded up in the little iron safe with the big keyhole, over\r\nthe chimney-piece in the back parlour--and who, it was well known, on\r\nfestive occasions garnished his board with a real silver teapot, cream-\r\newer, and sugar-basin, which he was wont, in the pride of his heart, to\r\nboast should be his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s property when she found a man to her\r\nmind. I repeat it, to be matter of profound astonishment and intense\r\nwonder, that Nathaniel Pipkin should have had the temerity to cast his\r\neyes in this direction. But love is blind; and Nathaniel had a cast in\r\nhis eye; and perhaps these two circumstances, taken together, prevented\r\nhis seeing the matter in its proper light.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, if old Lobbs had entertained the most remote or distant idea of\r\nthe state of the affections of Nathaniel Pipkin, he would just have\r\nrazed the school-room to the ground, or exterminated its master from the\r\nsurface of the earth, or committed some other outrage and atrocity of an\r\nequally ferocious and violent description; for he was a terrible old\r\nfellow, was Lobbs, when his pride was injured, or his blood was up.\r\nSwear! Such trains of oaths would come rolling and pealing over the way,\r\nsometimes, when he was denouncing the idleness of the bony apprentice\r\nwith the thin legs, that Nathaniel Pipkin would shake in his shoes with\r\nhorror, and the hair of the pupils\xe2\x80\x99 heads would stand on end with\r\nfright.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well! Day after day, when school was over, and the pupils gone, did\r\nNathaniel Pipkin sit himself down at the front window, and, while he\r\nfeigned to be reading a book, throw sidelong glances over the way in\r\nsearch of the bright eyes of Maria Lobbs; and he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t sat there many\r\ndays, before the bright eyes appeared at an upper window, apparently\r\ndeeply engaged in reading too. This was delightful, and gladdening to\r\nthe heart of Nathaniel Pipkin. It was something to sit there for hours\r\ntogether, and look upon that pretty face when the eyes were cast down;\r\nbut when Maria Lobbs began to raise her eyes from her book, and dart\r\ntheir rays in the direction of Nathaniel Pipkin, his delight and\r\nadmiration were perfectly boundless. At last, one day when he knew old\r\nLobbs was out, Nathaniel Pipkin had the temerity to kiss his hand to\r\nMaria Lobbs; and Maria Lobbs, instead of shutting the window, and\r\npulling down the blind, kissed _hers _to him, and smiled. Upon which\r\nNathaniel Pipkin determined, that, come what might, he would develop the\r\nstate of his feelings, without further delay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A prettier foot, a gayer heart, a more dimpled face, or a smarter form,\r\nnever bounded so lightly over the earth they graced, as did those of\r\nMaria Lobbs, the old saddler\xe2\x80\x99s daughter. There was a roguish twinkle in\r\nher sparkling eyes, that would have made its way to far less susceptible\r\nbosoms than that of Nathaniel Pipkin; and there was such a joyous sound\r\nin her merry laugh, that the sternest misanthrope must have smiled to\r\nhear it. Even old Lobbs himself, in the very height of his ferocity,\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t resist the coaxing of his pretty daughter; and when she, and\r\nher cousin Kate--an arch, impudent-looking, bewitching little person--\r\nmade a dead set upon the old man together, as, to say the truth, they\r\nvery often did, he could have refused them nothing, even had they asked\r\nfor a portion of the countless and inexhaustible treasures, which were\r\nhidden from the light, in the iron safe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nathaniel Pipkin\xe2\x80\x99s heart beat high within him, when he saw this\r\nenticing little couple some hundred yards before him one summer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nevening, in the very field in which he had many a time strolled about\r\ntill night-time, and pondered on the beauty of Maria Lobbs. But though\r\nhe had often thought then, how briskly he would walk up to Maria Lobbs\r\nand tell her of his passion if he could only meet her, he felt, now that\r\nshe was unexpectedly before him, all the blood in his body mounting to\r\nhis face, manifestly to the great detriment of his legs, which, deprived\r\nof their usual portion, trembled beneath him. When they stopped to\r\ngather a hedge flower, or listen to a bird, Nathaniel Pipkin stopped\r\ntoo, and pretended to be absorbed in meditation, as indeed he really\r\nwas; for he was thinking what on earth he should ever do, when they\r\nturned back, as they inevitably must in time, and meet him face to face.\r\nBut though he was afraid to make up to them, he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t bear to lose\r\nsight of them; so when they walked faster he walked faster, when they\r\nlingered he lingered, and when they stopped he stopped; and so they\r\nmight have gone on, until the darkness prevented them, if Kate had not\r\nlooked slyly back, and encouragingly beckoned Nathaniel to advance.\r\nThere was something in Kate\xe2\x80\x99s manner that was not to be resisted, and so\r\nNathaniel Pipkin complied with the invitation; and after a great deal of\r\nblushing on his part, and immoderate laughter on that of the wicked\r\nlittle cousin, Nathaniel Pipkin went down on his knees on the dewy\r\ngrass, and declared his resolution to remain there for ever, unless he\r\nwere permitted to rise the accepted lover of Maria Lobbs. Upon this, the\r\nmerry laughter of Miss Lobbs rang through the calm evening air--without\r\nseeming to disturb it, though; it had such a pleasant sound--and the\r\nwicked little cousin laughed more immoderately than before, and\r\nNathaniel Pipkin blushed deeper than ever. At length, Maria Lobbs being\r\nmore strenuously urged by the love-worn little man, turned away her\r\nhead, and whispered her cousin to say, or at all events Kate did say,\r\nthat she felt much honoured by Mr. Pipkin\xe2\x80\x99s addresses; that her hand and\r\nheart were at her father\xe2\x80\x99s disposal; but that nobody could be insensible\r\nto Mr. Pipkin\xe2\x80\x99s merits. As all this was said with much gravity, and as\r\nNathaniel Pipkin walked home with Maria Lobbs, and struggled for a kiss\r\nat parting, he went to bed a happy man, and dreamed all night long, of\r\nsoftening old Lobbs, opening the strong box, and marrying Maria.\r\n\r\nThe next day, Nathaniel Pipkin saw old Lobbs go out upon his old gray\r\npony, and after a great many signs at the window from the wicked little\r\ncousin, the object and meaning of which he could by no means understand,\r\nthe bony apprentice with the thin legs came over to say that his master\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t coming home all night, and that the ladies expected Mr. Pipkin to\r\ntea, at six o\xe2\x80\x99clock precisely. How the lessons were got through that\r\nday, neither Nathaniel Pipkin nor his pupils knew any more than you do;\r\nbut they were got through somehow, and, after the boys had gone,\r\nNathaniel Pipkin took till full six o\xe2\x80\x99clock to dress himself to his\r\nsatisfaction. Not that it took long to select the garments he should\r\nwear, inasmuch as he had no choice about the matter; but the putting of\r\nthem on to the best advantage, and the touching of them up previously,\r\nwas a task of no inconsiderable difficulty or importance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There was a very snug little party, consisting of Maria Lobbs and her\r\ncousin Kate, and three or four romping, good-humoured, rosy-cheeked\r\ngirls. Nathaniel Pipkin had ocular demonstration of the fact, that the\r\nrumours of old Lobbs\xe2\x80\x99s treasures were not exaggerated. There were the\r\nreal solid silver teapot, cream-ewer, and sugar-basin, on the table, and\r\nreal silver spoons to stir the tea with, and real china cups to drink it\r\nout of, and plates of the same, to hold the cakes and toast in. The only\r\neye-sore in the whole place was another cousin of Maria Lobbs\xe2\x80\x99s, and a\r\nbrother of Kate, whom Maria Lobbs called \xe2\x80\x9cHenry,\xe2\x80\x9d and who seemed to keep\r\nMaria Lobbs all to himself, up in one corner of the table. It\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\ndelightful thing to see affection in families, but it may be carried\r\nrather too far, and Nathaniel Pipkin could not help thinking that Maria\r\nLobbs must be very particularly fond of her relations, if she paid as\r\nmuch attention to all of them as to this individual cousin. After tea,\r\ntoo, when the wicked little cousin proposed a game at blind man\xe2\x80\x99s buff,\r\nit somehow or other happened that Nathaniel Pipkin was nearly always\r\nblind, and whenever he laid his hand upon the male cousin, he was sure\r\nto find that Maria Lobbs was not far off. And though the wicked little\r\ncousin and the other girls pinched him, and pulled his hair, and pushed\r\nchairs in his way, and all sorts of things, Maria Lobbs never seemed to\r\ncome near him at all; and once--once--Nathaniel Pipkin could have sworn\r\nhe heard the sound of a kiss, followed by a faint remonstrance from\r\nMaria Lobbs, and a half-suppressed laugh from her female friends. All\r\nthis was odd--very odd--and there is no saying what Nathaniel Pipkin\r\nmight or might not have done, in consequence, if his thoughts had not\r\nbeen suddenly directed into a new channel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The circumstance which directed his thoughts into a new channel was a\r\nloud knocking at the street door, and the person who made this loud\r\nknocking at the street door was no other than old Lobbs himself, who had\r\nunexpectedly returned, and was hammering away, like a coffin-maker; for\r\nhe wanted his supper. The alarming intelligence was no sooner\r\ncommunicated by the bony apprentice with the thin legs, than the girls\r\ntripped upstairs to Maria Lobbs\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom, and the male cousin and\r\nNathaniel Pipkin were thrust into a couple of closets in the sitting-\r\nroom, for want of any better places of concealment; and when Maria Lobbs\r\nand the wicked little cousin had stowed them away, and put the room to\r\nrights, they opened the street door to old Lobbs, who had never left off\r\nknocking since he first began.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now it did unfortunately happen that old Lobbs being very hungry was\r\nmonstrous cross. Nathaniel Pipkin could hear him growling away like an\r\nold mastiff with a sore throat; and whenever the unfortunate apprentice\r\nwith the thin legs came into the room, so surely did old Lobbs commence\r\nswearing at him in a most Saracenic and ferocious manner, though\r\napparently with no other end or object than that of easing his bosom by\r\nthe discharge of a few superfluous oaths. At length some supper, which\r\nhad been warming up, was placed on the table, and then old Lobbs fell\r\nto, in regular style; and having made clear work of it in no time,\r\nkissed his daughter, and demanded his pipe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nature had placed Nathaniel Pipkin\xe2\x80\x99s knees in very close juxtaposition,\r\nbut when he heard old Lobbs demand his pipe, they knocked together, as\r\nif they were going to reduce each other to powder; for, depending from a\r\ncouple of hooks, in the very closet in which he stood, was a large,\r\nbrown-stemmed, silver-bowled pipe, which pipe he himself had seen in the\r\nmouth of old Lobbs, regularly every afternoon and evening, for the last\r\nfive years. The two girls went downstairs for the pipe, and upstairs for\r\nthe pipe, and everywhere but where they knew the pipe was, and old Lobbs\r\nstormed away meanwhile, in the most wonderful manner. At last he thought\r\nof the closet, and walked up to it. It was of no use a little man like\r\nNathaniel Pipkin pulling the door inwards, when a great strong fellow\r\nlike old Lobbs was pulling it outwards. Old Lobbs gave it one tug, and\r\nopen it flew, disclosing Nathaniel Pipkin standing bolt upright inside,\r\nand shaking with apprehension from head to foot. Bless us! what an\r\nappalling look old Lobbs gave him, as he dragged him out by the collar,\r\nand held him at arm\xe2\x80\x99s length.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what the devil do you want here?\xe2\x80\x9d said old Lobbs, in a fearful\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nathaniel Pipkin could make no reply, so old Lobbs shook him backwards\r\nand forwards, for two or three minutes, by way of arranging his ideas\r\nfor him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want here?\xe2\x80\x9d roared Lobbs; \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you have come after\r\nmy daughter, now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Old Lobbs merely said this as a sneer: for he did not believe that\r\nmortal presumption could have carried Nathaniel Pipkin so far. What was\r\nhis indignation, when that poor man replied--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I did, Mr. Lobbs, I did come after your daughter. I love her, Mr.\r\nLobbs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you snivelling, wry-faced, puny villain,\xe2\x80\x9d gasped old Lobbs,\r\nparalysed by the atrocious confession; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you mean by that? Say\r\nthis to my face! Damme, I\xe2\x80\x99ll throttle you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is by no means improbable that old Lobbs would have carried his\r\nthreat into execution, in the excess of his rage, if his arm had not\r\nbeen stayed by a very unexpected apparition: to wit, the male cousin,\r\nwho, stepping out of his closet, and walking up to old Lobbs, said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot allow this harmless person, Sir, who has been asked here, in\r\nsome girlish frolic, to take upon himself, in a very noble manner, the\r\nfault (if fault it is) which I am guilty of, and am ready to avow. I\r\nlove your daughter, sir; and I came here for the purpose of meeting\r\nher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Old Lobbs opened his eyes very wide at this, but not wider than\r\nNathaniel Pipkin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cYou did?\xe2\x80\x9d said Lobbs, at last finding breath to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cI did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I forbade you this house, long ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cYou did, or I should not have been here, clandestinely, to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sorry to record it of old Lobbs, but I think he would have struck\r\nthe cousin, if his pretty daughter, with her bright eyes swimming in\r\ntears, had not clung to his arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t stop him, Maria,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man; \xe2\x80\x9cif he has the will to\r\nstrike me, let him. I would not hurt a hair of his gray head, for the\r\nriches of the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The old man cast down his eyes at this reproof, and they met those of\r\nhis daughter. I have hinted once or twice before, that they were very\r\nbright eyes, and, though they were tearful now, their influence was by\r\nno means lessened. Old Lobbs turned his head away, as if to avoid being\r\npersuaded by them, when, as fortune would have it, he encountered the\r\nface of the wicked little cousin, who, half afraid for her brother, and\r\nhalf laughing at Nathaniel Pipkin, presented as bewitching an expression\r\nof countenance, with a touch of slyness in it, too, as any man, old or\r\nyoung, need look upon. She drew her arm coaxingly through the old man\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nand whispered something in his ear; and do what he would, old Lobbs\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t help breaking out into a smile, while a tear stole down his\r\ncheek at the same time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Five minutes after this, the girls were brought down from the bedroom\r\nwith a great deal of giggling and modesty; and while the young people\r\nwere making themselves perfectly happy, old Lobbs got down the pipe, and\r\nsmoked it; and it was a remarkable circumstance about that particular\r\npipe of tobacco, that it was the most soothing and delightful one he\r\never smoked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nathaniel Pipkin thought it best to keep his own counsel, and by so\r\ndoing gradually rose into high favour with old Lobbs, who taught him to\r\nsmoke in time; and they used to sit out in the garden on the fine\r\nevenings, for many years afterwards, smoking and drinking in great\r\nstate. He soon recovered the effects of his attachment, for we find his\r\nname in the parish register, as a witness to the marriage of Maria Lobbs\r\nto her cousin; and it also appears, by reference to other documents,\r\nthat on the night of the wedding he was incarcerated in the village\r\ncage, for having, in a state of extreme intoxication, committed sundry\r\nexcesses in the streets, in all of which he was aided and abetted by the\r\nbony apprentice with the thin legs.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVIII. BRIEFLY ILLUSTRATIVE OF TWO POINTS; FIRST, THE POWER OF\r\nHYSTERICS, AND, SECONDLY, THE FORCE OF CIRCUMSTANCES\r\n\r\nFor two days after the _dejeune _at Mrs. Hunter\xe2\x80\x99s, the Pickwickians\r\nremained at Eatanswill, anxiously awaiting the arrival of some\r\nintelligence from their revered leader. Mr. Tupman and Mr. Snodgrass\r\nwere once again left to their own means of amusement; for Mr. Winkle, in\r\ncompliance with a most pressing invitation, continued to reside at Mr.\r\nPott\xe2\x80\x99s house, and to devote his time to the companionship of his amiable\r\nlady. Nor was the occasional society of Mr. Pott himself wanting to\r\ncomplete their felicity. Deeply immersed in the intensity of his\r\nspeculations for the public weal and the destruction of the\r\n_Independent_, it was not the habit of that great man to descend from\r\nhis mental pinnacle to the humble level of ordinary minds. On this\r\noccasion, however, and as if expressly in compliment to any follower of\r\nMr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s, he unbent, relaxed, stepped down from his pedestal, and\r\nwalked upon the ground, benignly adapting his remarks to the\r\ncomprehension of the herd, and seeming in outward form, if not in\r\nspirit, to be one of them.\r\n\r\nSuch having been the demeanour of this celebrated public character\r\ntowards Mr. Winkle, it will be readily imagined that considerable\r\nsurprise was depicted on the countenance of the latter gentleman, when,\r\nas he was sitting alone in the breakfast-room, the door was hastily\r\nthrown open, and as hastily closed, on the entrance of Mr. Pott, who,\r\nstalking majestically towards him, and thrusting aside his proffered\r\nhand, ground his teeth, as if to put a sharper edge on what he was about\r\nto utter, and exclaimed, in a saw-like voice--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Serpent!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Winkle, starting from his chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Serpent, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr. Pott, raising his voice, and then suddenly\r\ndepressing it: \xe2\x80\x98I said, serpent, sir--make the most of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhen you have parted with a man at two o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, on terms\r\nof the utmost good-fellowship, and he meets you again, at half-past\r\nnine, and greets you as a serpent, it is not unreasonable to conclude\r\nthat something of an unpleasant nature has occurred meanwhile. So Mr.\r\nWinkle thought. He returned Mr. Pott\xe2\x80\x99s gaze of stone, and in compliance\r\nwith that gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s request, proceeded to make the most he could of\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x98serpent.\xe2\x80\x99 The most, however, was nothing at all; so, after a\r\nprofound silence of some minutes\xe2\x80\x99 duration, he said,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Serpent, Sir! Serpent, Mr. Pott! What can you mean, Sir?--this is\r\npleasantry.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pleasantry, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Pott, with a motion of the hand, indicative\r\nof a strong desire to hurl the Britannia metal teapot at the head of the\r\nvisitor. \xe2\x80\x98Pleasantry, sir!--But--no, I will be calm; I will be calm,\r\nSir;\xe2\x80\x99 in proof of his calmness, Mr. Pott flung himself into a chair, and\r\nfoamed at the mouth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear sir,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98_DEAR _Sir!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Pott. \xe2\x80\x98How dare you address me, as dear Sir, Sir?\r\nHow dare you look me in the face and do it, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Sir, if you come to that,\xe2\x80\x99 responded Mr. Winkle, \xe2\x80\x98how dare you\r\nlook me in the face, and call me a serpent, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because you are one,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pott.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Prove it, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle warmly. \xe2\x80\x98Prove it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA malignant scowl passed over the profound face of the editor, as he\r\ndrew from his pocket the _Independent_ of that morning; and laying his\r\nfinger on a particular paragraph, threw the journal across the table to\r\nMr. Winkle.\r\n\r\nThat gentleman took it up, and read as follows:--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Our obscure and filthy contemporary, in some disgusting observations on\r\nthe recent election for this borough, has presumed to violate the\r\nhallowed sanctity of private life, and to refer in a manner not to be\r\nmisunderstood, to the personal affairs of our late candidate--aye, and\r\nnotwithstanding his base defeat, we will add, our future member, Mr.\r\nFizkin. What does our dastardly contemporary mean? What would the\r\nruffian say, if we, setting at naught, like him, the decencies of social\r\nintercourse, were to raise the curtain which happily conceals _His_\r\nprivate life from general ridicule, not to say from general execration?\r\nWhat, if we were even to point out, and comment on, facts and\r\ncircumstances, which are publicly notorious, and beheld by every one but\r\nour mole-eyed contemporary--what if we were to print the following\r\neffusion, which we received while we were writing the commencement of\r\nthis article, from a talented fellow-townsman and correspondent?\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cLINES TO A BRASS POT\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cOh Pott! if you\xe2\x80\x99d known How false she\xe2\x80\x99d have grown, When you heard the\r\nmarriage bells tinkle; You\xe2\x80\x99d have done then, I vow, What you cannot help\r\nnow,\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pott solemnly--\xe2\x80\x98what rhymes to \xe2\x80\x9ctinkle,\xe2\x80\x9d villain?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What rhymes to tinkle?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Pott, whose entrance at the moment\r\nforestalled the reply. \xe2\x80\x98What rhymes to tinkle? Why, Winkle, I should\r\nconceive.\xe2\x80\x99 Saying this, Mrs. Pott smiled sweetly on the disturbed\r\nPickwickian, and extended her hand towards him. The agitated young man\r\nwould have accepted it, in his confusion, had not Pott indignantly\r\ninterposed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Back, ma\xe2\x80\x99am--back!\xe2\x80\x99 said the editor. \xe2\x80\x98Take his hand before my very\r\nface!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. P.!\xe2\x80\x99 said his astonished lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wretched woman, look here,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed the husband. \xe2\x80\x98Look here, ma\xe2\x80\x99am--\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLines to a Brass Pot.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBrass Pot\xe2\x80\x9d; that\xe2\x80\x99s me, ma\xe2\x80\x99am. \xe2\x80\x9cFalse _she\xe2\x80\x99d_\r\nhave grown\xe2\x80\x9d; that\xe2\x80\x99s you, ma\xe2\x80\x99am--you.\xe2\x80\x99 With this ebullition of rage,\r\nwhich was not unaccompanied with something like a tremble, at the\r\nexpression of his wife\xe2\x80\x99s face, Mr. Pott dashed the current number of the\r\nEatanswill _Independent_ at her feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Upon my word, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the astonished Mrs. Pott, stooping to pick up\r\nthe paper. \xe2\x80\x98Upon my word, Sir!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pott winced beneath the contemptuous gaze of his wife. He had made a\r\ndesperate struggle to screw up his courage, but it was fast coming\r\nunscrewed again.\r\n\r\nThere appears nothing very tremendous in this little sentence, \xe2\x80\x98Upon my\r\nword, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 when it comes to be read; but the tone of voice in which it\r\nwas delivered, and the look that accompanied it, both seeming to bear\r\nreference to some revenge to be thereafter visited upon the head of\r\nPott, produced their effect upon him. The most unskilful observer could\r\nhave detected in his troubled countenance, a readiness to resign his\r\nWellington boots to any efficient substitute who would have consented to\r\nstand in them at that moment.\r\n\r\nMrs. Pott read the paragraph, uttered a loud shriek, and threw herself\r\nat full length on the hearth-rug, screaming, and tapping it with the\r\nheels of her shoes, in a manner which could leave no doubt of the\r\npropriety of her feelings on the occasion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said the terrified Pott, \xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t say I believed it;--I--\xe2\x80\x99\r\nbut the unfortunate man\xe2\x80\x99s voice was drowned in the screaming of his\r\npartner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Pott, let me entreat you, my dear ma\xe2\x80\x99am, to compose yourself,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Mr. Winkle; but the shrieks and tappings were louder, and more\r\nfrequent than ever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pott, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m very sorry. If you won\xe2\x80\x99t consider your\r\nown health, consider me, my dear. We shall have a crowd round the\r\nhouse.\xe2\x80\x99 But the more strenuously Mr. Pott entreated, the more vehemently\r\nthe screams poured forth.\r\n\r\nVery fortunately, however, attached to Mrs. Pott\xe2\x80\x99s person was a\r\nbodyguard of one, a young lady whose ostensible employment was to\r\npreside over her toilet, but who rendered herself useful in a variety of\r\nways, and in none more so than in the particular department of\r\nconstantly aiding and abetting her mistress in every wish and\r\ninclination opposed to the desires of the unhappy Pott. The screams\r\nreached this young lady\xe2\x80\x99s ears in due course, and brought her into the\r\nroom with a speed which threatened to derange, materially, the very\r\nexquisite arrangement of her cap and ringlets.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, my dear, dear mistress!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed the bodyguard, kneeling\r\nfrantically by the side of the prostrate Mrs. Pott. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, my dear\r\nmistress, what is the matter?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your master--your brutal master,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured the patient.\r\n\r\nPott was evidently giving way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a shame,\xe2\x80\x99 said the bodyguard reproachfully. \xe2\x80\x98I know he\xe2\x80\x99ll be the\r\ndeath on you, ma\xe2\x80\x99am. Poor dear thing!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe gave way more. The opposite party followed up the attack.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, don\xe2\x80\x99t leave me--don\xe2\x80\x99t leave me, Goodwin,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Mrs. Pott,\r\nclutching at the wrist of the said Goodwin with an hysteric jerk.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re the only person that\xe2\x80\x99s kind to me, Goodwin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt this affecting appeal, Goodwin got up a little domestic tragedy of\r\nher own, and shed tears copiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never, ma\xe2\x80\x99am--never,\xe2\x80\x99 said Goodwin. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, sir, you should be careful--\r\nyou should indeed; you don\xe2\x80\x99t know what harm you may do missis; you\xe2\x80\x99ll be\r\nsorry for it one day, I know--I\xe2\x80\x99ve always said so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe unlucky Pott looked timidly on, but said nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Goodwin,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Pott, in a soft voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Goodwin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you only knew how I have loved that man--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t distress yourself by recollecting it, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said the bodyguard.\r\n\r\nPott looked very frightened. It was time to finish him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And now,\xe2\x80\x99 sobbed Mrs. Pott, \xe2\x80\x98now, after all, to be treated in this way;\r\nto be reproached and insulted in the presence of a third party, and that\r\nparty almost a stranger. But I will not submit to it! Goodwin,\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncontinued Mrs. Pott, raising herself in the arms of her attendant, \xe2\x80\x98my\r\nbrother, the lieutenant, shall interfere. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be separated, Goodwin!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would certainly serve him right, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Goodwin.\r\n\r\nWhatever thoughts the threat of a separation might have awakened in Mr.\r\nPott\xe2\x80\x99s mind, he forbore to give utterance to them, and contented himself\r\nby saying, with great humility:--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear, will you hear me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA fresh train of sobs was the only reply, as Mrs. Pott grew more\r\nhysterical, requested to be informed why she was ever born, and required\r\nsundry other pieces of information of a similar description.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear,\xe2\x80\x99 remonstrated Mr. Pott, \xe2\x80\x98do not give way to these sensitive\r\nfeelings. I never believed that the paragraph had any foundation, my\r\ndear--impossible. I was only angry, my dear--I may say outrageous--with\r\nthe _Independent_ people for daring to insert it; that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x99 Mr. Pott\r\ncast an imploring look at the innocent cause of the mischief, as if to\r\nentreat him to say nothing about the serpent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what steps, sir, do you mean to take to obtain redress?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired\r\nMr. Winkle, gaining courage as he saw Pott losing it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Goodwin,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Mrs. Pott, \xe2\x80\x98does he mean to horsewhip the editor\r\nof the _Independent_--does he, Goodwin?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hush, hush, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; pray keep yourself quiet,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the bodyguard. \xe2\x80\x98I\r\ndare say he will, if you wish it, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pott, as his wife evinced decided symptoms of going\r\noff again. \xe2\x80\x98Of course I shall.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When, Goodwin--when?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Pott, still undecided about the going\r\noff.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Immediately, of course,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pott; \xe2\x80\x98before the day is out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Goodwin,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Mrs. Pott, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s the only way of meeting the\r\nslander, and setting me right with the world.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Goodwin. \xe2\x80\x98No man as is a man, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, could\r\nrefuse to do it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo, as the hysterics were still hovering about, Mr. Pott said once more\r\nthat he would do it; but Mrs. Pott was so overcome at the bare idea of\r\nhaving ever been suspected, that she was half a dozen times on the very\r\nverge of a relapse, and most unquestionably would have gone off, had it\r\nnot been for the indefatigable efforts of the assiduous Goodwin, and\r\nrepeated entreaties for pardon from the conquered Pott; and finally,\r\nwhen that unhappy individual had been frightened and snubbed down to his\r\nproper level, Mrs. Pott recovered, and they went to breakfast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will not allow this base newspaper slander to shorten your stay\r\nhere, Mr. Winkle?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Pott, smiling through the traces of her\r\ntears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope not,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pott, actuated, as he spoke, by a wish that his\r\nvisitor would choke himself with the morsel of dry toast which he was\r\nraising to his lips at the moment, and so terminate his stay\r\neffectually.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are very good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle; \xe2\x80\x98but a letter has been received\r\nfrom Mr. Pickwick--so I learn by a note from Mr. Tupman, which was\r\nbrought up to my bedroom door, this morning--in which he requests us to\r\njoin him at Bury to-day; and we are to leave by the coach at noon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you will come back?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Pott.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, certainly,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are quite sure?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Pott, stealing a tender look at her\r\nvisitor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite,\xe2\x80\x99 responded Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\nThe breakfast passed off in silence, for each of the party was brooding\r\nover his, or her, own personal grievances. Mrs. Pott was regretting the\r\nloss of a beau; Mr. Pott his rash pledge to horsewhip the _Independent_;\r\nMr. Winkle his having innocently placed himself in so awkward a\r\nsituation. Noon approached, and after many adieux and promises to\r\nreturn, he tore himself away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If he ever comes back, I\xe2\x80\x99ll poison him,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr. Pott, as he turned\r\ninto the little back office where he prepared his thunderbolts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I ever do come back, and mix myself up with these people again,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthought Mr. Winkle, as he wended his way to the Peacock, \xe2\x80\x98I shall\r\ndeserve to be horsewhipped myself--that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis friends were ready, the coach was nearly so, and in half an hour\r\nthey were proceeding on their journey, along the road over which Mr.\r\nPickwick and Sam had so recently travelled, and of which, as we have\r\nalready said something, we do not feel called upon to extract Mr.\r\nSnodgrass\xe2\x80\x99s poetical and beautiful description.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller was standing at the door of the Angel, ready to receive them,\r\nand by that gentleman they were ushered to the apartment of Mr.\r\nPickwick, where, to the no small surprise of Mr. Winkle and Mr.\r\nSnodgrass, and the no small embarrassment of Mr. Tupman, they found old\r\nWardle and Trundle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How are you?\xe2\x80\x99 said the old man, grasping Mr. Tupman\xe2\x80\x99s hand. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t hang\r\nback, or look sentimental about it; it can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped, old fellow. For\r\nher sake, I wish you\xe2\x80\x99d had her; for your own, I\xe2\x80\x99m very glad you have\r\nnot. A young fellow like you will do better one of these days, eh?\xe2\x80\x99 With\r\nthis conclusion, Wardle slapped Mr. Tupman on the back, and laughed\r\nheartily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, and how are you, my fine fellows?\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman,\r\nshaking hands with Mr. Winkle and Mr. Snodgrass at the same time. \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nhave just been telling Pickwick that we must have you all down at\r\nChristmas. We\xe2\x80\x99re going to have a wedding--a real wedding this time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A wedding!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Snodgrass, turning very pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, a wedding. But don\xe2\x80\x99t be frightened,\xe2\x80\x99 said the good-humoured old\r\nman; \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s only Trundle there, and Bella.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, is that all?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Snodgrass, relieved from a painful doubt\r\nwhich had fallen heavily on his breast. \xe2\x80\x98Give you joy, Sir. How is Joe?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98Sleepy as ever.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And your mother, and the clergyman, and all of \xe2\x80\x98em?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite well.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman, with an effort--\xe2\x80\x98where is--_she_, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 and he\r\nturned away his head, and covered his eyes with his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98_She_!\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman, with a knowing shake of the head. \xe2\x80\x98Do\r\nyou mean my single relative--eh?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Tupman, by a nod, intimated that his question applied to the\r\ndisappointed Rachael.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, she\xe2\x80\x99s gone away,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98She\xe2\x80\x99s living at a\r\nrelation\xe2\x80\x99s, far enough off. She couldn\xe2\x80\x99t bear to see the girls, so I let\r\nher go. But come! Here\xe2\x80\x99s the dinner. You must be hungry after your ride.\r\nI am, without any ride at all; so let us fall to.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmple justice was done to the meal; and when they were seated round the\r\ntable, after it had been disposed of, Mr. Pickwick, to the intense\r\nhorror and indignation of his followers, related the adventure he had\r\nundergone, and the success which had attended the base artifices of the\r\ndiabolical Jingle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And the attack of rheumatism which I caught in that garden,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nPickwick, in conclusion, \xe2\x80\x98renders me lame at this moment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I, too, have had something of an adventure,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle, with a\r\nsmile; and, at the request of Mr. Pickwick, he detailed the malicious\r\nlibel of the Eatanswill _Independent_, and the consequent excitement of\r\ntheir friend, the editor.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s brow darkened during the recital. His friends observed\r\nit, and, when Mr. Winkle had concluded, maintained a profound silence.\r\nMr. Pickwick struck the table emphatically with his clenched fist, and\r\nspoke as follows:--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it not a wonderful circumstance,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98that we seem\r\ndestined to enter no man\xe2\x80\x99s house without involving him in some degree of\r\ntrouble? Does it not, I ask, bespeak the indiscretion, or, worse than\r\nthat, the blackness of heart--that I should say so!--of my followers,\r\nthat, beneath whatever roof they locate, they disturb the peace of mind\r\nand happiness of some confiding female? Is it not, I say--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick would in all probability have gone on for some time, had\r\nnot the entrance of Sam, with a letter, caused him to break off in his\r\neloquent discourse. He passed his handkerchief across his forehead, took\r\noff his spectacles, wiped them, and put them on again; and his voice had\r\nrecovered its wonted softness of tone when he said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What have you there, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Called at the post-office just now, and found this here letter, as has\r\nlaid there for two days,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s sealed vith a vafer,\r\nand directed in round hand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know this hand,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, opening the letter. \xe2\x80\x98Mercy\r\non us! what\xe2\x80\x99s this? It must be a jest; it--it--can\xe2\x80\x99t be true.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x99 was the general inquiry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nobody dead, is there?\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle, alarmed at the horror in Mr.\r\nPickwick\xe2\x80\x99s countenance.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick made no reply, but, pushing the letter across the table,\r\nand desiring Mr. Tupman to read it aloud, fell back in his chair with a\r\nlook of vacant astonishment quite alarming to behold.\r\n\r\nMr. Tupman, with a trembling voice, read the letter, of which the\r\nfollowing is a copy:--\r\n\r\nFreeman\xe2\x80\x99s Court, Cornhill, August 28th, 1827.\r\n\r\nBardell against Pickwick.\r\n\r\nSir,\r\n\r\nHaving been instructed by Mrs. Martha Bardell to commence an action\r\nagainst you for a breach of promise of marriage, for which the plaintiff\r\nlays her damages at fifteen hundred pounds, we beg to inform you that a\r\nwrit has been issued against you in this suit in the Court of Common\r\nPleas; and request to know, by return of post, the name of your attorney\r\nin London, who will accept service thereof.\r\n\r\nWe are, Sir, Your obedient servants, Dodson & Fogg.\r\n\r\nMr. Samuel Pickwick.\r\n\r\nThere was something so impressive in the mute astonishment with which\r\neach man regarded his neighbour, and every man regarded Mr. Pickwick,\r\nthat all seemed afraid to speak. The silence was at length broken by Mr.\r\nTupman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dodson and Fogg,\xe2\x80\x99 he repeated mechanically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bardell and Pickwick,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Snodgrass, musing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Peace of mind and happiness of confiding females,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Mr. Winkle,\r\nwith an air of abstraction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a conspiracy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, at length recovering the power\r\nof speech; \xe2\x80\x98a base conspiracy between these two grasping attorneys,\r\nDodson and Fogg. Mrs. Bardell would never do it;--she hasn\xe2\x80\x99t the heart\r\nto do it;--she hasn\xe2\x80\x99t the case to do it. Ridiculous--ridiculous.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOf her heart,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle, with a smile, \xe2\x80\x98you should certainly be the\r\nbest judge. I don\xe2\x80\x99t wish to discourage you, but I should certainly say\r\nthat, of her case, Dodson and Fogg are far better judges than any of us\r\ncan be.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a vile attempt to extort money,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope it is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle, with a short, dry cough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who ever heard me address her in any way but that in which a lodger\r\nwould address his landlady?\xe2\x80\x99 continued Mr. Pickwick, with great\r\nvehemence. \xe2\x80\x98Who ever saw me with her? Not even my friends here--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Except on one occasion,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick changed colour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98Well, that\xe2\x80\x99s important. There was nothing\r\nsuspicious then, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Tupman glanced timidly at his leader. \xe2\x80\x98Why,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98there was\r\nnothing suspicious; but--I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how it happened, mind--she\r\ncertainly was reclining in his arms.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gracious powers!\xe2\x80\x99 ejaculated Mr. Pickwick, as the recollection of the\r\nscene in question struck forcibly upon him; \xe2\x80\x98what a dreadful instance of\r\nthe force of circumstances! So she was--so she was.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And our friend was soothing her anguish,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle, rather\r\nmaliciously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So I was,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t deny it. So I was.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hollo!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle; \xe2\x80\x98for a case in which there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing suspicious,\r\nthis looks rather queer--eh, Pickwick? Ah, sly dog--sly dog!\xe2\x80\x99 and he\r\nlaughed till the glasses on the sideboard rang again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What a dreadful conjunction of appearances!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick,\r\nresting his chin upon his hands. \xe2\x80\x98Winkle--Tupman--I beg your pardon for\r\nthe observations I made just now. We are all the victims of\r\ncircumstances, and I the greatest.\xe2\x80\x99 With this apology Mr. Pickwick\r\nburied his head in his hands, and ruminated; while Wardle measured out a\r\nregular circle of nods and winks, addressed to the other members of the\r\ncompany.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll have it explained, though,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, raising his head\r\nand hammering the table. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll see this Dodson and Fogg! I\xe2\x80\x99ll go to\r\nLondon to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle; \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99re too lame.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, then, next day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Next day is the first of September, and you\xe2\x80\x99re pledged to ride out with\r\nus, as far as Sir Geoffrey Manning\xe2\x80\x99s grounds at all events, and to meet\r\nus at lunch, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t take the field.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, then, the day after,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98Thursday.--Sam!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take two places outside to London, on Thursday morning, for yourself\r\nand me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery well, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller left the room, and departed slowly on his errand, with his\r\nhands in his pocket and his eyes fixed on the ground.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Rum feller, the hemperor,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, as he walked slowly up the\r\nstreet. \xe2\x80\x98Think o\xe2\x80\x99 his makin\xe2\x80\x99 up to that \xe2\x80\x98ere Mrs. Bardell--vith a little\r\nboy, too! Always the vay vith these here old \xe2\x80\x98uns howsoever, as is such\r\nsteady goers to look at. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t think he\xe2\x80\x99d ha\xe2\x80\x99 done it, though--I\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t think he\xe2\x80\x99d ha\xe2\x80\x99 done it!\xe2\x80\x99 Moralising in this strain, Mr. Samuel\r\nWeller bent his steps towards the booking-office.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIX. A PLEASANT DAY WITH AN UNPLEASANT TERMINATION\r\n\r\nThe birds, who, happily for their own peace of mind and personal\r\ncomfort, were in blissful ignorance of the preparations which had been\r\nmaking to astonish them, on the first of September, hailed it, no doubt,\r\nas one of the pleasantest mornings they had seen that season. Many a\r\nyoung partridge who strutted complacently among the stubble, with all\r\nthe finicking coxcombry of youth, and many an older one who watched his\r\nlevity out of his little round eye, with the contemptuous air of a bird\r\nof wisdom and experience, alike unconscious of their approaching doom,\r\nbasked in the fresh morning air with lively and blithesome feelings, and\r\na few hours afterwards were laid low upon the earth. But we grow\r\naffecting: let us proceed.\r\n\r\nIn plain commonplace matter-of-fact, then, it was a fine morning--so\r\nfine that you would scarcely have believed that the few months of an\r\nEnglish summer had yet flown by. Hedges, fields, and trees, hill and\r\nmoorland, presented to the eye their ever-varying shades of deep rich\r\ngreen; scarce a leaf had fallen, scarce a sprinkle of yellow mingled\r\nwith the hues of summer, warned you that autumn had begun. The sky was\r\ncloudless; the sun shone out bright and warm; the songs of birds, the\r\nhum of myriads of summer insects, filled the air; and the cottage\r\ngardens, crowded with flowers of every rich and beautiful tint,\r\nsparkled, in the heavy dew, like beds of glittering jewels. Everything\r\nbore the stamp of summer, and none of its beautiful colour had yet faded\r\nfrom the die.\r\n\r\nSuch was the morning, when an open carriage, in which were three\r\nPickwickians (Mr. Snodgrass having preferred to remain at home), Mr.\r\nWardle, and Mr. Trundle, with Sam Weller on the box beside the driver,\r\npulled up by a gate at the roadside, before which stood a tall, raw-\r\nboned gamekeeper, and a half-booted, leather-legginged boy, each bearing\r\na bag of capacious dimensions, and accompanied by a brace of pointers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Mr. Winkle to Wardle, as the man let down the steps,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98they don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose we\xe2\x80\x99re going to kill game enough to fill those bags,\r\ndo they?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fill them!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed old Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98Bless you, yes! You shall fill one,\r\nand I the other; and when we\xe2\x80\x99ve done with them, the pockets of our\r\nshooting-jackets will hold as much more.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle dismounted without saying anything in reply to this\r\nobservation; but he thought within himself, that if the party remained\r\nin the open air, till he had filled one of the bags, they stood a\r\nconsiderable chance of catching colds in their heads.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hi, Juno, lass-hi, old girl; down, Daph, down,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle, caressing\r\nthe dogs. \xe2\x80\x98Sir Geoffrey still in Scotland, of course, Martin?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe tall gamekeeper replied in the affirmative, and looked with some\r\nsurprise from Mr. Winkle, who was holding his gun as if he wished his\r\ncoat pocket to save him the trouble of pulling the trigger, to Mr.\r\nTupman, who was holding his as if he was afraid of it--as there is no\r\nearthly reason to doubt he really was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My friends are not much in the way of this sort of thing yet, Martin,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Wardle, noticing the look. \xe2\x80\x98Live and learn, you know. They\xe2\x80\x99ll be\r\ngood shots one of these days. I beg my friend Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s pardon, though;\r\nhe has had some practice.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle smiled feebly over his blue neckerchief in acknowledgment of\r\nthe compliment, and got himself so mysteriously entangled with his gun,\r\nin his modest confusion, that if the piece had been loaded, he must\r\ninevitably have shot himself dead upon the spot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You mustn\xe2\x80\x99t handle your piece in that \xe2\x80\x98ere way, when you come to have\r\nthe charge in it, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the tall gamekeeper gruffly; \xe2\x80\x98or I\xe2\x80\x99m damned\r\nif you won\xe2\x80\x99t make cold meat of some on us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle, thus admonished, abruptly altered his position, and in so\r\ndoing, contrived to bring the barrel into pretty smart contact with Mr.\r\nWeller\xe2\x80\x99s head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hollo!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, picking up his hat, which had been knocked off, and\r\nrubbing his temple. \xe2\x80\x98Hollo, sir! if you comes it this vay, you\xe2\x80\x99ll fill\r\none o\xe2\x80\x99 them bags, and something to spare, at one fire.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere the leather-legginged boy laughed very heartily, and then tried to\r\nlook as if it was somebody else, whereat Mr. Winkle frowned\r\nmajestically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where did you tell the boy to meet us with the snack, Martin?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired\r\nWardle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Side of One-tree Hill, at twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s not Sir Geoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s land, is it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Sir; but it\xe2\x80\x99s close by it. It\xe2\x80\x99s Captain Boldwig\xe2\x80\x99s land; but\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99ll be nobody to interrupt us, and there\xe2\x80\x99s a fine bit of turf\r\nthere.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well,\xe2\x80\x99 said old Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98Now the sooner we\xe2\x80\x99re off the better. Will\r\nyou join us at twelve, then, Pickwick?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick was particularly desirous to view the sport, the more\r\nespecially as he was rather anxious in respect of Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s life and\r\nlimbs. On so inviting a morning, too, it was very tantalising to turn\r\nback, and leave his friends to enjoy themselves. It was, therefore, with\r\na very rueful air that he replied--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, I suppose I must.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ain\xe2\x80\x99t the gentleman a shot, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the long gamekeeper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wardle; \xe2\x80\x98and he\xe2\x80\x99s lame besides.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should very much like to go,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick--\xe2\x80\x98very much.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was a short pause of commiseration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s a barrow t\xe2\x80\x99other side the hedge,\xe2\x80\x99 said the boy. \xe2\x80\x98If the\r\ngentleman\xe2\x80\x99s servant would wheel along the paths, he could keep nigh us,\r\nand we could lift it over the stiles, and that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The wery thing,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, who was a party interested, inasmuch\r\nas he ardently longed to see the sport. \xe2\x80\x98The wery thing. Well said,\r\nSmallcheek; I\xe2\x80\x99ll have it out in a minute.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut here a difficulty arose. The long gamekeeper resolutely protested\r\nagainst the introduction into a shooting party, of a gentleman in a\r\nbarrow, as a gross violation of all established rules and precedents.\r\n\r\nIt was a great objection, but not an insurmountable one. The gamekeeper\r\nhaving been coaxed and feed, and having, moreover, eased his mind by\r\n\xe2\x80\x98punching\xe2\x80\x99 the head of the inventive youth who had first suggested the\r\nuse of the machine, Mr. Pickwick was placed in it, and off the party\r\nset; Wardle and the long gamekeeper leading the way, and Mr. Pickwick in\r\nthe barrow, propelled by Sam, bringing up the rear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, when they had got half across the first\r\nfield.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter now?\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I won\xe2\x80\x99t suffer this barrow to be moved another step,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nPickwick, resolutely, \xe2\x80\x98unless Winkle carries that gun of his in a\r\ndifferent manner.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How _am_ I to carry it?\xe2\x80\x99 said the wretched Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Carry it with the muzzle to the ground,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s so unsportsmanlike,\xe2\x80\x99 reasoned Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t care whether it\xe2\x80\x99s unsportsmanlike or not,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr.\r\nPickwick; \xe2\x80\x98I am not going to be shot in a wheel-barrow, for the sake of\r\nappearances, to please anybody.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know the gentleman\xe2\x80\x99ll put that \xe2\x80\x98ere charge into somebody afore he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndone,\xe2\x80\x99 growled the long man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, well--I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind,\xe2\x80\x99 said poor Winkle, turning his gun-stock\r\nuppermost--\xe2\x80\x98there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Anythin\xe2\x80\x99 for a quiet life,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller; and on they went again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, after they had gone a few yards farther.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What now?\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That gun of Tupman\xe2\x80\x99s is not safe: I know it isn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh? What! not safe?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman, in a tone of great alarm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not as you are carrying it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98I am very sorry to\r\nmake any further objection, but I cannot consent to go on, unless you\r\ncarry it as Winkle does his.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think you had better, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the long gamekeeper, \xe2\x80\x98or you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nquite as likely to lodge the charge in yourself as in anything else.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Tupman, with the most obliging haste, placed his piece in the\r\nposition required, and the party moved on again; the two amateurs\r\nmarching with reversed arms, like a couple of privates at a royal\r\nfuneral.\r\n\r\nThe dogs suddenly came to a dead stop, and the party advancing\r\nstealthily a single pace, stopped too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with the dogs\xe2\x80\x99 legs?\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Mr. Winkle. \xe2\x80\x98How\r\nqueer they\xe2\x80\x99re standing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hush, can\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wardle softly. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see, they\xe2\x80\x99re making\r\na point?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Making a point!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle, staring about him, as if he expected\r\nto discover some particular beauty in the landscape, which the sagacious\r\nanimals were calling special attention to. \xe2\x80\x98Making a point! What are\r\nthey pointing at?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Keep your eyes open,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle, not heeding the question in the\r\nexcitement of the moment. \xe2\x80\x98Now then.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was a sharp whirring noise, that made Mr. Winkle start back as if\r\nhe had been shot himself. Bang, bang, went a couple of guns--the smoke\r\nswept quickly away over the field, and curled into the air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where are they!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle, in a state of the highest excitement,\r\nturning round and round in all directions. \xe2\x80\x98Where are they? Tell me when\r\nto fire. Where are they--where are they?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where are they!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle, taking up a brace of birds which the dogs\r\nhad deposited at his feet. \xe2\x80\x98Why, here they are.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no; I mean the others,\xe2\x80\x99 said the bewildered Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Far enough off, by this time,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wardle, coolly reloading his\r\ngun.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We shall very likely be up with another covey in five minutes,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nthe long gamekeeper. \xe2\x80\x98If the gentleman begins to fire now, perhaps he\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\njust get the shot out of the barrel by the time they rise.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha! ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x99 roared Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, compassionating his follower\xe2\x80\x99s confusion and\r\nembarrassment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t laugh.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly not, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99 So, by way of indemnification, Mr. Weller\r\ncontorted his features from behind the wheel-barrow, for the exclusive\r\namusement of the boy with the leggings, who thereupon burst into a\r\nboisterous laugh, and was summarily cuffed by the long gamekeeper, who\r\nwanted a pretext for turning round, to hide his own merriment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bravo, old fellow!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle to Mr. Tupman; \xe2\x80\x98you fired that time, at\r\nall events.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, yes,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Tupman, with conscious pride. \xe2\x80\x98I let it off.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well done. You\xe2\x80\x99ll hit something next time, if you look sharp. Very\r\neasy, ain\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, it\xe2\x80\x99s very easy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman. \xe2\x80\x98How it hurts one\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder,\r\nthough. It nearly knocked me backwards. I had no idea these small\r\nfirearms kicked so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman, smiling, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99ll get used to it in time.\r\nNow then--all ready--all right with the barrow there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All right, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come along, then.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hold hard, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, raising the barrow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Aye, aye,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick; and on they went, as briskly as need\r\nbe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Keep that barrow back now,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Wardle, when it had been hoisted over\r\na stile into another field, and Mr. Pickwick had been deposited in it\r\nonce more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All right, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, pausing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Winkle,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman, \xe2\x80\x98follow me softly, and don\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\ntoo late this time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never fear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle. \xe2\x80\x98Are they pointing?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no; not now. Quietly now, quietly.\xe2\x80\x99 On they crept, and very quietly\r\nthey would have advanced, if Mr. Winkle, in the performance of some very\r\nintricate evolutions with his gun, had not accidentally fired, at the\r\nmost critical moment, over the boy\xe2\x80\x99s head, exactly in the very spot\r\nwhere the tall man\xe2\x80\x99s brain would have been, had he been there instead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, what on earth did you do that for?\xe2\x80\x99 said old Wardle, as the birds\r\nflew unharmed away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never saw such a gun in my life,\xe2\x80\x99 replied poor Mr. Winkle, looking at\r\nthe lock, as if that would do any good. \xe2\x80\x98It goes off of its own accord.\r\nIt _will _do it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will do it!\xe2\x80\x99 echoed Wardle, with something of irritation in his manner.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish it would kill something of its own accord.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99ll do that afore long, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 observed the tall man, in a low,\r\nprophetic voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean by that observation, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Winkle,\r\nangrily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never mind, Sir, never mind,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the long gamekeeper; \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve no\r\nfamily myself, sir; and this here boy\xe2\x80\x99s mother will get something\r\nhandsome from Sir Geoffrey, if he\xe2\x80\x99s killed on his land. Load again, Sir,\r\nload again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take away his gun,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr. Pickwick from the barrow, horror-stricken\r\nat the long man\xe2\x80\x99s dark insinuations. \xe2\x80\x98Take away his gun, do you hear,\r\nsomebody?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNobody, however, volunteered to obey the command; and Mr. Winkle, after\r\ndarting a rebellious glance at Mr. Pickwick, reloaded his gun, and\r\nproceeded onwards with the rest.\r\n\r\nWe are bound, on the authority of Mr. Pickwick, to state, that Mr.\r\nTupman\xe2\x80\x99s mode of proceeding evinced far more of prudence and\r\ndeliberation, than that adopted by Mr. Winkle. Still, this by no means\r\ndetracts from the great authority of the latter gentleman, on all\r\nmatters connected with the field; because, as Mr. Pickwick beautifully\r\nobserves, it has somehow or other happened, from time immemorial, that\r\nmany of the best and ablest philosophers, who have been perfect lights\r\nof science in matters of theory, have been wholly unable to reduce them\r\nto practice.\r\n\r\nMr. Tupman\xe2\x80\x99s process, like many of our most sublime discoveries, was\r\nextremely simple. With the quickness and penetration of a man of genius,\r\nhe had at once observed that the two great points to be attained were--\r\nfirst, to discharge his piece without injury to himself, and, secondly,\r\nto do so, without danger to the bystanders--obviously, the best thing to\r\ndo, after surmounting the difficulty of firing at all, was to shut his\r\neyes firmly, and fire into the air.\r\n\r\nOn one occasion, after performing this feat, Mr. Tupman, on opening his\r\neyes, beheld a plump partridge in the act of falling, wounded, to the\r\nground. He was on the point of congratulating Mr. Wardle on his\r\ninvariable success, when that gentleman advanced towards him, and\r\ngrasped him warmly by the hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tupman,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman, \xe2\x80\x98you singled out that particular\r\nbird?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman--\xe2\x80\x98no.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You did,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98I saw you do it--I observed you pick him out--I\r\nnoticed you, as you raised your piece to take aim; and I will say this,\r\nthat the best shot in existence could not have done it more beautifully.\r\nYou are an older hand at this than I thought you, Tupman; you have been\r\nout before.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was in vain for Mr. Tupman to protest, with a smile of self-denial,\r\nthat he never had. The very smile was taken as evidence to the contrary;\r\nand from that time forth his reputation was established. It is not the\r\nonly reputation that has been acquired as easily, nor are such fortunate\r\ncircumstances confined to partridge-shooting.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, Mr. Winkle flashed, and blazed, and smoked away, without\r\nproducing any material results worthy of being noted down; sometimes\r\nexpending his charge in mid-air, and at others sending it skimming along\r\nso near the surface of the ground as to place the lives of the two dogs\r\non a rather uncertain and precarious tenure. As a display of fancy-\r\nshooting, it was extremely varied and curious; as an exhibition of\r\nfiring with any precise object, it was, upon the whole, perhaps a\r\nfailure. It is an established axiom, that \xe2\x80\x98every bullet has its billet.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nIf it apply in an equal degree to shot, those of Mr. Winkle were\r\nunfortunate foundlings, deprived of their natural rights, cast loose\r\nupon the world, and billeted nowhere.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle, walking up to the side of the barrow, and wiping\r\nthe streams of perspiration from his jolly red face; \xe2\x80\x98smoking day, isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is, indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick. The sun is tremendously hot, even\r\nto me. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how you must feel it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman, \xe2\x80\x98pretty hot. It\xe2\x80\x99s past twelve, though.\r\nYou see that green hill there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s the place where we are to lunch; and, by Jove, there\xe2\x80\x99s the boy\r\nwith the basket, punctual as clockwork!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So he is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, brightening up. \xe2\x80\x98Good boy, that. I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ngive him a shilling, presently. Now, then, Sam, wheel away.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hold on, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, invigorated with the prospect of\r\nrefreshments. \xe2\x80\x98Out of the vay, young leathers. If you walley my precious\r\nlife don\xe2\x80\x99t upset me, as the gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n said to the driver when they was\r\na-carryin\xe2\x80\x99 him to Tyburn.\xe2\x80\x99 And quickening his pace to a sharp run, Mr.\r\nWeller wheeled his master nimbly to the green hill, shot him dexterously\r\nout by the very side of the basket, and proceeded to unpack it with the\r\nutmost despatch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Weal pie,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, soliloquising, as he arranged the eatables\r\non the grass. \xe2\x80\x98Wery good thing is weal pie, when you know the lady as\r\nmade it, and is quite sure it ain\xe2\x80\x99t kittens;
