and arter all though,\r\nwhere\xe2\x80\x99s the odds, when they\xe2\x80\x99re so like weal that the wery piemen\r\nthemselves don\xe2\x80\x99t know the difference?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t they, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not they, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, touching his hat. \xe2\x80\x98I lodged in the\r\nsame house vith a pieman once, sir, and a wery nice man he was--reg\xe2\x80\x99lar\r\nclever chap, too--make pies out o\xe2\x80\x99 anything, he could. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a number o\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncats you keep, Mr. Brooks,\xe2\x80\x9d says I, when I\xe2\x80\x99d got intimate with him.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d says he, \xe2\x80\x9cI do--a good many,\xe2\x80\x9d says he, \xe2\x80\x9cYou must be wery fond o\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncats,\xe2\x80\x9d says I. \xe2\x80\x9cOther people is,\xe2\x80\x9d says he, a-winkin\xe2\x80\x99 at me; \xe2\x80\x9cthey ain\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nin season till the winter though,\xe2\x80\x9d says he. \xe2\x80\x9cNot in season!\xe2\x80\x9d says I.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d says he, \xe2\x80\x9cfruits is in, cats is out.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n says I. \xe2\x80\x9cMean!\xe2\x80\x9d says he. \xe2\x80\x9cThat I\xe2\x80\x99ll never be a party to the combination\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 the butchers, to keep up the price o\xe2\x80\x99 meat,\xe2\x80\x9d says he. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n says he, a-squeezing my hand wery hard, and vispering in my ear--\xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmention this here agin--but it\xe2\x80\x99s the seasonin\xe2\x80\x99 as does it. They\xe2\x80\x99re all\r\nmade o\xe2\x80\x99 them noble animals,\xe2\x80\x9d says he, a-pointin\xe2\x80\x99 to a wery nice little\r\ntabby kitten, \xe2\x80\x9cand I seasons \xe2\x80\x98em for beefsteak, weal or kidney, \xe2\x80\x98cording\r\nto the demand. And more than that,\xe2\x80\x9d says he, \xe2\x80\x9cI can make a weal a beef-\r\nsteak, or a beef-steak a kidney, or any one on \xe2\x80\x98em a mutton, at a\r\nminute\xe2\x80\x99s notice, just as the market changes, and appetites wary!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He must have been a very ingenious young man, that, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nPickwick, with a slight shudder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just was, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, continuing his occupation of\r\nemptying the basket, \xe2\x80\x98and the pies was beautiful. Tongue--, well that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na wery good thing when it ain\xe2\x80\x99t a woman\xe2\x80\x99s. Bread--knuckle o\xe2\x80\x99 ham,\r\nreg\xe2\x80\x99lar picter--cold beef in slices, wery good. What\xe2\x80\x99s in them stone\r\njars, young touch-and-go?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Beer in this one,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the boy, taking from his shoulder a couple\r\nof large stone bottles, fastened together by a leathern strap--\xe2\x80\x98cold\r\npunch in t\xe2\x80\x99other.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And a wery good notion of a lunch it is, take it altogether,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nWeller, surveying his arrangement of the repast with great satisfaction.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n, \xe2\x80\x9cfall on,\xe2\x80\x9d as the English said to the French when they\r\nfixed bagginets.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt needed no second invitation to induce the party to yield full justice\r\nto the meal; and as little pressing did it require to induce Mr. Weller,\r\nthe long gamekeeper, and the two boys, to station themselves on the\r\ngrass, at a little distance, and do good execution upon a decent\r\nproportion of the viands. An old oak afforded a pleasant shelter to the\r\ngroup, and a rich prospect of arable and meadow land, intersected with\r\nluxuriant hedges, and richly ornamented with wood, lay spread out before\r\nthem.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is delightful--thoroughly delightful!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; the skin\r\nof whose expressive countenance was rapidly peeling off, with exposure\r\nto the sun.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So it is--so it is, old fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98Come; a glass of\r\npunch!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With great pleasure,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; the satisfaction of whose\r\ncountenance, after drinking it, bore testimony to the sincerity of the\r\nreply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, smacking his lips. \xe2\x80\x98Very good. I\xe2\x80\x99ll take\r\nanother. Cool; very cool. Come, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Mr. Pickwick,\r\nstill retaining his hold upon the jar, \xe2\x80\x98a toast. Our friends at Dingley\r\nDell.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe toast was drunk with loud acclamations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what I shall do, to get up my shooting again,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nWinkle, who was eating bread and ham with a pocket-knife. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll put a\r\nstuffed partridge on the top of a post, and practise at it, beginning at\r\na short distance, and lengthening it by degrees. I understand it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncapital practice.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know a gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99man, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98as did that, and begun at\r\ntwo yards; but he never tried it on agin; for he blowed the bird right\r\nclean away at the first fire, and nobody ever seed a feather on him\r\narterwards.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have the goodness to reserve your anecdotes till they are called for.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Cert\xe2\x80\x99nly, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere Mr. Weller winked the eye which was not concealed by the beer-can\r\nhe was raising to his lips, with such exquisite facetiousness, that the\r\ntwo boys went into spontaneous convulsions, and even the long man\r\ncondescended to smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, that certainly is most capital cold punch,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick,\r\nlooking earnestly at the stone bottle; \xe2\x80\x98and the day is extremely warm,\r\nand--Tupman, my dear friend, a glass of punch?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With the greatest delight,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Tupman; and having drank that\r\nglass, Mr. Pickwick took another, just to see whether there was any\r\norange peel in the punch, because orange peel always disagreed with him;\r\nand finding that there was not, Mr. Pickwick took another glass to the\r\nhealth of their absent friend, and then felt himself imperatively called\r\nupon to propose another in honour of the punch-compounder, unknown.\r\n\r\nThis constant succession of glasses produced considerable effect upon\r\nMr. Pickwick; his countenance beamed with the most sunny smiles,\r\nlaughter played around his lips, and good-humoured merriment twinkled in\r\nhis eye. Yielding by degrees to the influence of the exciting liquid,\r\nrendered more so by the heat, Mr. Pickwick expressed a strong desire to\r\nrecollect a song which he had heard in his infancy, and the attempt\r\nproving abortive, sought to stimulate his memory with more glasses of\r\npunch, which appeared to have quite a contrary effect; for, from\r\nforgetting the words of the song, he began to forget how to articulate\r\nany words at all; and finally, after rising to his legs to address the\r\ncompany in an eloquent speech, he fell into the barrow, and fast asleep,\r\nsimultaneously.\r\n\r\nThe basket having been repacked, and it being found perfectly impossible\r\nto awaken Mr. Pickwick from his torpor, some discussion took place\r\nwhether it would be better for Mr. Weller to wheel his master back\r\nagain, or to leave him where he was, until they should all be ready to\r\nreturn. The latter course was at length decided on; and as the further\r\nexpedition was not to exceed an hour\xe2\x80\x99s duration, and as Mr. Weller\r\nbegged very hard to be one of the party, it was determined to leave Mr.\r\nPickwick asleep in the barrow, and to call for him on their return. So\r\naway they went, leaving Mr. Pickwick snoring most comfortably in the\r\nshade.\r\n\r\nThat Mr. Pickwick would have continued to snore in the shade until his\r\nfriends came back, or, in default thereof, until the shades of evening\r\nhad fallen on the landscape, there appears no reasonable cause to doubt;\r\nalways supposing that he had been suffered to remain there in peace. But\r\nhe was _not _suffered to remain there in peace. And this was what\r\nprevented him.\r\n\r\nCaptain Boldwig was a little fierce man in a stiff black neckerchief and\r\nblue surtout, who, when he did condescend to walk about his property,\r\ndid it in company with a thick rattan stick with a brass ferrule, and a\r\ngardener and sub-gardener with meek faces, to whom (the gardeners, not\r\nthe stick) Captain Boldwig gave his orders with all due grandeur and\r\nferocity; for Captain Boldwig\xe2\x80\x99s wife\xe2\x80\x99s sister had married a marquis, and\r\nthe captain\xe2\x80\x99s house was a villa, and his land \xe2\x80\x98grounds,\xe2\x80\x99 and it was all\r\nvery high, and mighty, and great.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick had not been asleep half an hour when little Captain\r\nBoldwig, followed by the two gardeners, came striding along as fast as\r\nhis size and importance would let him; and when he came near the oak\r\ntree, Captain Boldwig paused and drew a long breath, and looked at the\r\nprospect as if he thought the prospect ought to be highly gratified at\r\nhaving him to take notice of it; and then he struck the ground\r\nemphatically with his stick, and summoned the head-gardener.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hunt,\xe2\x80\x99 said Captain Boldwig.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the gardener.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Roll this place to-morrow morning--do you hear, Hunt?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And take care that you keep this place in good order--do you hear,\r\nHunt?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And remind me to have a board done about trespassers, and spring guns,\r\nand all that sort of thing, to keep the common people out. Do you hear,\r\nHunt; do you hear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll not forget it, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the other man, advancing, with his hand\r\nto his hat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Wilkins, what\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with you?\xe2\x80\x99 said Captain Boldwig.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon, sir--but I think there have been trespassers here\r\nto-day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha!\xe2\x80\x99 said the captain, scowling around him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, sir--they have been dining here, I think, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, damn their audacity, so they have,\xe2\x80\x99 said Captain Boldwig, as the\r\ncrumbs and fragments that were strewn upon the grass met his eye. \xe2\x80\x98They\r\nhave actually been devouring their food here. I wish I had the vagabonds\r\nhere!\xe2\x80\x99 said the captain, clenching the thick stick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish I had the vagabonds here,\xe2\x80\x99 said the captain wrathfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Beg your pardon, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wilkins, \xe2\x80\x98but--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But what? Eh?\xe2\x80\x99 roared the captain; and following the timid glance of\r\nWilkins, his eyes encountered the wheel-barrow and Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who are you, you rascal?\xe2\x80\x99 said the captain, administering several pokes\r\nto Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s body with the thick stick. \xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s your name?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Cold punch,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Mr. Pickwick, as he sank to sleep again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded Captain Boldwig.\r\n\r\nNo reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What did he say his name was?\xe2\x80\x99 asked the captain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Punch, I think, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wilkins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s his impudence--that\xe2\x80\x99s his confounded impudence,\xe2\x80\x99 said Captain\r\nBoldwig. \xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s only feigning to be asleep now,\xe2\x80\x99 said the captain, in a\r\nhigh passion. \xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s drunk; he\xe2\x80\x99s a drunken plebeian. Wheel him away,\r\nWilkins, wheel him away directly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhere shall I wheel him to, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Wilkins, with great timidity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wheel him to the devil,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Captain Boldwig.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wilkins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stay,\xe2\x80\x99 said the captain.\r\n\r\nWilkins stopped accordingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wheel him,\xe2\x80\x99 said the captain--\xe2\x80\x98wheel him to the pound; and let us see\r\nwhether he calls himself Punch when he comes to himself. He shall not\r\nbully me--he shall not bully me. Wheel him away.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAway Mr. Pickwick was wheeled in compliance with this imperious mandate;\r\nand the great Captain Boldwig, swelling with indignation, proceeded on\r\nhis walk.\r\n\r\nInexpressible was the astonishment of the little party when they\r\nreturned, to find that Mr. Pickwick had disappeared, and taken the\r\nwheel-barrow with him. It was the most mysterious and unaccountable\r\nthing that was ever heard of. For a lame man to have got upon his legs\r\nwithout any previous notice, and walked off, would have been most\r\nextraordinary; but when it came to his wheeling a heavy barrow before\r\nhim, by way of amusement, it grew positively miraculous. They searched\r\nevery nook and corner round, together and separately; they shouted,\r\nwhistled, laughed, called--and all with the same result. Mr. Pickwick\r\nwas not to be found. After some hours of fruitless search, they arrived\r\nat the unwelcome conclusion that they must go home without him.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile Mr. Pickwick had been wheeled to the Pound, and safely\r\ndeposited therein, fast asleep in the wheel-barrow, to the immeasurable\r\ndelight and satisfaction not only of all the boys in the village, but\r\nthree-fourths of the whole population, who had gathered round, in\r\nexpectation of his waking. If their most intense gratification had been\r\nawakened by seeing him wheeled in, how many hundredfold was their joy\r\nincreased when, after a few indistinct cries of \xe2\x80\x98Sam!\xe2\x80\x99 he sat up in the\r\nbarrow, and gazed with indescribable astonishment on the faces before\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nA general shout was of course the signal of his having woke up; and his\r\ninvoluntary inquiry of \xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x99 occasioned another, louder\r\nthan the first, if possible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here\xe2\x80\x99s a game!\xe2\x80\x99 roared the populace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where am I?\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the pound,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the mob.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How came I here? What was I doing? Where was I brought from?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBoldwig! Captain Boldwig!\xe2\x80\x99 was the only reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let me out,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Where\xe2\x80\x99s my servant? Where are my\r\nfriends?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You ain\xe2\x80\x99t got no friends. Hurrah!\xe2\x80\x99 Then there came a turnip, then a\r\npotato, and then an egg; with a few other little tokens of the playful\r\ndisposition of the many-headed.\r\n\r\nHow long this scene might have lasted, or how much Mr. Pickwick might\r\nhave suffered, no one can tell, had not a carriage, which was driving\r\nswiftly by, suddenly pulled up, from whence there descended old Wardle\r\nand Sam Weller, the former of whom, in far less time than it takes to\r\nwrite it, if not to read it, had made his way to Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s side,\r\nand placed him in the vehicle, just as the latter had concluded the\r\nthird and last round of a single combat with the town-beadle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Run to the justice\xe2\x80\x99s!\xe2\x80\x99 cried a dozen voices.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, run avay,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, jumping up on the box. \xe2\x80\x98Give my\r\ncompliments--Mr. Veller\xe2\x80\x99s compliments--to the justice, and tell him I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nspiled his beadle, and that, if he\xe2\x80\x99ll swear in a new \xe2\x80\x98un, I\xe2\x80\x99ll come back\r\nagain to-morrow and spile him. Drive on, old feller.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll give directions for the commencement of an action for false\r\nimprisonment against this Captain Boldwig, directly I get to London,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Mr. Pickwick, as soon as the carriage turned out of the town.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We were trespassing, it seems,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t care,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll bring the action.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, you won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will, by--\xe2\x80\x99 But as there was a humorous expression in Wardle\xe2\x80\x99s face,\r\nMr. Pickwick checked himself, and said, \xe2\x80\x98Why not?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because,\xe2\x80\x99 said old Wardle, half-bursting with laughter, \xe2\x80\x98because they\r\nmight turn on some of us, and say we had taken too much cold punch.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDo what he would, a smile would come into Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s face; the smile\r\nextended into a laugh; the laugh into a roar; the roar became general.\r\nSo, to keep up their good-humour, they stopped at the first roadside\r\ntavern they came to, and ordered a glass of brandy-and-water all round,\r\nwith a magnum of extra strength for Mr. Samuel Weller.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XX. SHOWING HOW DODSON AND FOGG WERE MEN OF BUSINESS, AND THEIR\r\nCLERKS MEN OF PLEASURE; AND HOW AN AFFECTING INTERVIEW TOOK PLACE\r\nBETWEEN MR. WELLER AND HIS LONG-LOST PARENT; SHOWING ALSO WHAT CHOICE\r\nSPIRITS ASSEMBLED AT THE MAGPIE AND STUMP, AND WHAT A CAPITAL CHAPTER\r\nTHE NEXT ONE WILL BE\r\n\r\nIn the ground-floor front of a dingy house, at the very farthest end of\r\nFreeman\xe2\x80\x99s Court, Cornhill, sat the four clerks of Messrs. Dodson & Fogg,\r\ntwo of his Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s attorneys of the courts of King\xe2\x80\x99s Bench and Common\r\nPleas at Westminster, and solicitors of the High Court of Chancery--the\r\naforesaid clerks catching as favourable glimpses of heaven\xe2\x80\x99s light and\r\nheaven\xe2\x80\x99s sun, in the course of their daily labours, as a man might hope\r\nto do, were he placed at the bottom of a reasonably deep well; and\r\nwithout the opportunity of perceiving the stars in the day-time, which\r\nthe latter secluded situation affords.\r\n\r\nThe clerks\xe2\x80\x99 office of Messrs. Dodson & Fogg was a dark, mouldy, earthy-\r\nsmelling room, with a high wainscotted partition to screen the clerks\r\nfrom the vulgar gaze, a couple of old wooden chairs, a very loud-ticking\r\nclock, an almanac, an umbrella-stand, a row of hat-pegs, and a few\r\nshelves, on which were deposited several ticketed bundles of dirty\r\npapers, some old deal boxes with paper labels, and sundry decayed stone\r\nink bottles of various shapes and sizes. There was a glass door leading\r\ninto the passage which formed the entrance to the court, and on the\r\nouter side of this glass door, Mr. Pickwick, closely followed by Sam\r\nWeller, presented himself on the Friday morning succeeding the\r\noccurrence of which a faithful narration is given in the last chapter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come in, can\xe2\x80\x99t you!\xe2\x80\x99 cried a voice from behind the partition, in reply\r\nto Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s gentle tap at the door. And Mr. Pickwick and Sam\r\nentered accordingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Dodson or Mr. Fogg at home, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick, gently,\r\nadvancing, hat in hand, towards the partition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Dodson ain\xe2\x80\x99t at home, and Mr. Fogg\xe2\x80\x99s particularly engaged,\xe2\x80\x99 replied\r\nthe voice; and at the same time the head to which the voice belonged,\r\nwith a pen behind its ear, looked over the partition, and at Mr.\r\nPickwick.\r\n\r\nIt was a ragged head, the sandy hair of which, scrupulously parted on\r\none side, and flattened down with pomatum, was twisted into little semi-\r\ncircular tails round a flat face ornamented with a pair of small eyes,\r\nand garnished with a very dirty shirt collar, and a rusty black stock.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Dodson ain\xe2\x80\x99t at home, and Mr. Fogg\xe2\x80\x99s particularly engaged,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nthe man to whom the head belonged.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When will Mr. Dodson be back, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can\xe2\x80\x99t say.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will it be long before Mr. Fogg is disengaged, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere the man proceeded to mend his pen with great deliberation, while\r\nanother clerk, who was mixing a Seidlitz powder, under cover of the lid\r\nof his desk, laughed approvingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think I\xe2\x80\x99ll wait,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. There was no reply; so Mr.\r\nPickwick sat down unbidden, and listened to the loud ticking of the\r\nclock and the murmured conversation of the clerks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That was a game, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99 said one of the gentlemen, in a brown coat\r\nand brass buttons, inky drabs, and bluchers, at the conclusion of some\r\ninaudible relation of his previous evening\xe2\x80\x99s adventures.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Devilish good--devilish good,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Seidlitz-powder man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tom Cummins was in the chair,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man with the brown coat. \xe2\x80\x98It\r\nwas half-past four when I got to Somers Town, and then I was so uncommon\r\nlushy, that I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t find the place where the latch-key went in, and\r\nwas obliged to knock up the old \xe2\x80\x98ooman. I say, I wonder what old Fogg\r\n\xe2\x80\x98ud say, if he knew it. I should get the sack, I s\xe2\x80\x99pose--eh?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt this humorous notion, all the clerks laughed in concert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There was such a game with Fogg here, this mornin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man in\r\nthe brown coat, \xe2\x80\x98while Jack was upstairs sorting the papers, and you two\r\nwere gone to the stamp-office. Fogg was down here, opening the letters\r\nwhen that chap as we issued the writ against at Camberwell, you know,\r\ncame in--what\xe2\x80\x99s his name again?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ramsey,\xe2\x80\x99 said the clerk who had spoken to Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, Ramsey--a precious seedy-looking customer. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d says old\r\nFogg, looking at him very fierce--you know his way--\xe2\x80\x9cwell, Sir, have you\r\ncome to settle?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cYes, I have, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ramsey, putting his hand in\r\nhis pocket, and bringing out the money, \xe2\x80\x9cthe debt\xe2\x80\x99s two pound ten, and\r\nthe costs three pound five, and here it is, Sir;\xe2\x80\x9d and he sighed like\r\nbricks, as he lugged out the money, done up in a bit of blotting-paper.\r\nOld Fogg looked first at the money, and then at him, and then he coughed\r\nin his rum way, so that I knew something was coming. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s a declaration filed, which increases the costs materially, I\r\nsuppose,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fogg. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t say that, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ramsey, starting\r\nback; \xe2\x80\x9cthe time was only out last night, Sir.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI do say it, though,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n said Fogg, \xe2\x80\x9cmy clerk\xe2\x80\x99s just gone to file it. Hasn\xe2\x80\x99t Mr. Jackson gone to\r\nfile that declaration in Bullman and Ramsey, Mr. Wicks?\xe2\x80\x9d Of course I\r\nsaid yes, and then Fogg coughed again, and looked at Ramsey. \xe2\x80\x9cMy God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n said Ramsey; \xe2\x80\x9cand here have I nearly driven myself mad, scraping this\r\nmoney together, and all to no purpose.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cNone at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fogg coolly;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cso you had better go back and scrape some more together, and bring it\r\nhere in time.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t get it, by God!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ramsey, striking the desk\r\nwith his fist. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t bully me, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fogg, getting into a passion\r\non purpose. \xe2\x80\x9cI am not bullying you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ramsey. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nFogg; \xe2\x80\x9cget out, sir; get out of this office, Sir, and come back, Sir,\r\nwhen you know how to behave yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d Well, Ramsey tried to speak, but\r\nFogg wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t let him, so he put the money in his pocket, and sneaked\r\nout. The door was scarcely shut, when old Fogg turned round to me, with\r\na sweet smile on his face, and drew the declaration out of his coat\r\npocket. \xe2\x80\x9cHere, Wicks,\xe2\x80\x9d says Fogg, \xe2\x80\x9ctake a cab, and go down to the Temple\r\nas quick as you can, and file that. The costs are quite safe, for he\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nsteady man with a large family, at a salary of five-and-twenty shillings\r\na week, and if he gives us a warrant of attorney, as he must in the end,\r\nI know his employers will see it paid; so we may as well get all we can\r\nget out of him, Mr. Wicks; it\xe2\x80\x99s a Christian act to do it, Mr. Wicks, for\r\nwith his large family and small income, he\xe2\x80\x99ll be all the better for a\r\ngood lesson against getting into debt--won\xe2\x80\x99t he, Mr. Wicks, won\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x9d--\r\nand he smiled so good-naturedly as he went away, that it was delightful\r\nto see him. He is a capital man of business,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wicks, in a tone of\r\nthe deepest admiration, \xe2\x80\x98capital, isn\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe other three cordially subscribed to this opinion, and the anecdote\r\nafforded the most unlimited satisfaction.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nice men these here, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Mr. Weller to his master; \xe2\x80\x98wery\r\nnice notion of fun they has, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick nodded assent, and coughed to attract the attention of the\r\nyoung gentlemen behind the partition, who, having now relaxed their\r\nminds by a little conversation among themselves, condescended to take\r\nsome notice of the stranger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wonder whether Fogg\xe2\x80\x99s disengaged now?\xe2\x80\x99 said Jackson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll see,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wicks, dismounting leisurely from his stool. \xe2\x80\x98What name\r\nshall I tell Mr. Fogg?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pickwick,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the illustrious subject of these memoirs.\r\n\r\nMr. Jackson departed upstairs on his errand, and immediately returned\r\nwith a message that Mr. Fogg would see Mr. Pickwick in five minutes; and\r\nhaving delivered it, returned again to his desk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What did he say his name was?\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Wicks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pickwick,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jackson; \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s the defendant in Bardell and\r\nPickwick.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA sudden scraping of feet, mingled with the sound of suppressed\r\nlaughter, was heard from behind the partition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They\xe2\x80\x99re a-twiggin\xe2\x80\x99 of you, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Twigging of me, Sam!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98what do you mean by\r\ntwigging me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller replied by pointing with his thumb over his shoulder, and Mr.\r\nPickwick, on looking up, became sensible of the pleasing fact, that all\r\nthe four clerks, with countenances expressive of the utmost amusement,\r\nand with their heads thrust over the wooden screen, were minutely\r\ninspecting the figure and general appearance of the supposed trifler\r\nwith female hearts, and disturber of female happiness. On his looking\r\nup, the row of heads suddenly disappeared, and the sound of pens\r\ntravelling at a furious rate over paper, immediately succeeded.\r\n\r\nA sudden ring at the bell which hung in the office, summoned Mr. Jackson\r\nto the apartment of Fogg, from whence he came back to say that he (Fogg)\r\nwas ready to see Mr. Pickwick if he would step upstairs.\r\n\r\nUpstairs Mr. Pickwick did step accordingly, leaving Sam Weller below.\r\nThe room door of the one-pair back, bore inscribed in legible characters\r\nthe imposing words, \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Fogg\xe2\x80\x99; and, having tapped thereat, and been\r\ndesired to come in, Jackson ushered Mr. Pickwick into the presence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is Mr. Dodson in?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Fogg.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just come in, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jackson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ask him to step here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, sir.\xe2\x80\x99 Exit Jackson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take a seat, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg; \xe2\x80\x98there is the paper, sir; my partner will\r\nbe here directly, and we can converse about this matter, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick took a seat and the paper, but, instead of reading the\r\nlatter, peeped over the top of it, and took a survey of the man of\r\nbusiness, who was an elderly, pimply-faced, vegetable-diet sort of man,\r\nin a black coat, dark mixture trousers, and small black gaiters; a kind\r\nof being who seemed to be an essential part of the desk at which he was\r\nwriting, and to have as much thought or feeling.\r\n\r\nAfter a few minutes\xe2\x80\x99 silence, Mr. Dodson, a plump, portly, stern-looking\r\nman, with a loud voice, appeared; and the conversation commenced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is Mr. Pickwick,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! You are the defendant, Sir, in Bardell and Pickwick?\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson, \xe2\x80\x98and what do you propose?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg, thrusting his hands into his trousers\xe2\x80\x99 pockets, and\r\nthrowing himself back in his chair, \xe2\x80\x98what do you propose, Mr Pickwick?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hush, Fogg,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson, \xe2\x80\x98let me hear what Mr. Pickwick has to say.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I came, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, gazing placidly on the two\r\npartners, \xe2\x80\x98I came here, gentlemen, to express the surprise with which I\r\nreceived your letter of the other day, and to inquire what grounds of\r\naction you can have against me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Grounds of--\xe2\x80\x99 Fogg had ejaculated this much, when he was stopped by\r\nDodson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Fogg,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson, \xe2\x80\x98I am going to speak.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nI beg your pardon, Mr. Dodson,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For the grounds of action, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Dodson, with moral elevation\r\nin his air, \xe2\x80\x98you will consult your own conscience and your own feelings.\r\nWe, Sir, we, are guided entirely by the statement of our client. That\r\nstatement, Sir, may be true, or it may be false; it may be credible, or\r\nit may be incredible; but, if it be true, and if it be credible, I do\r\nnot hesitate to say, Sir, that our grounds of action, Sir, are strong,\r\nand not to be shaken. You may be an unfortunate man, Sir, or you may be\r\na designing one; but if I were called upon, as a juryman upon my oath,\r\nSir, to express an opinion of your conduct, Sir, I do not hesitate to\r\nassert that I should have but one opinion about it.\xe2\x80\x99 Here Dodson drew\r\nhimself up, with an air of offended virtue, and looked at Fogg, who\r\nthrust his hands farther in his pockets, and nodding his head sagely,\r\nsaid, in a tone of the fullest concurrence, \xe2\x80\x98Most certainly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with considerable pain depicted in his\r\ncountenance, \xe2\x80\x98you will permit me to assure you that I am a most\r\nunfortunate man, so far as this case is concerned.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope you are, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Dodson; \xe2\x80\x98I trust you may be, Sir. If you\r\nare really innocent of what is laid to your charge, you are more\r\nunfortunate than I had believed any man could possibly be. What do you\r\nsay, Mr. Fogg?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say precisely what you say,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Fogg, with a smile of\r\nincredulity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The writ, Sir, which commences the action,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Dodson, \xe2\x80\x98was\r\nissued regularly. Mr. Fogg, where is the _Praecipe _book?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here it is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg, handing over a square book, with a parchment\r\ncover.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here is the entry,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Dodson. \xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cMiddlesex, Capias MARTHA BARDELL,\r\nWIDOW, v. SAMUEL PICKWICK. Damages \xc2\xa31500. Dodson & Fogg for the\r\nplaintiff, Aug. 28, 1827.\xe2\x80\x9d All regular, Sir; perfectly.\xe2\x80\x99 Dodson coughed\r\nand looked at Fogg, who said \xe2\x80\x98Perfectly,\xe2\x80\x99 also. And then they both\r\nlooked at Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am to understand, then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98that it really is your\r\nintention to proceed with this action?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Understand, sir!--that you certainly may,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Dodson, with\r\nsomething as near a smile as his importance would allow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And that the damages are actually laid at fifteen hundred pounds?\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To which understanding you may add my assurance, that if we could have\r\nprevailed upon our client, they would have been laid at treble the\r\namount, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Dodson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I believe Mrs. Bardell specially said, however,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Fogg,\r\nglancing at Dodson, \xe2\x80\x98that she would not compromise for a farthing less.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Unquestionably,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Dodson sternly. For the action was only just\r\nbegun; and it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have done to let Mr. Pickwick compromise it then,\r\neven if he had been so disposed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As you offer no terms, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson, displaying a slip of\r\nparchment in his right hand, and affectionately pressing a paper copy of\r\nit, on Mr. Pickwick with his left, \xe2\x80\x98I had better serve you with a copy\r\nof this writ, sir. Here is the original, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well, gentlemen, very well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, rising in person\r\nand wrath at the same time; \xe2\x80\x98you shall hear from my solicitor,\r\ngentlemen.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We shall be very happy to do so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg, rubbing his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson, opening the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And before I go, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 said the excited Mr. Pickwick, turning\r\nround on the landing, \xe2\x80\x98permit me to say, that of all the disgraceful and\r\nrascally proceedings--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stay, sir, stay,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Dodson, with great politeness. \xe2\x80\x98Mr.\r\nJackson! Mr. Wicks!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the two clerks, appearing at the bottom of the stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I merely want you to hear what this gentleman says,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Dodson.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pray, go on, sir--disgraceful and rascally proceedings, I think you\r\nsaid?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I did,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, thoroughly roused. \xe2\x80\x98I said, Sir, that of all\r\nthe disgraceful and rascally proceedings that ever were attempted, this\r\nis the most so. I repeat it, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You hear that, Mr. Wicks,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You won\xe2\x80\x99t forget these expressions, Mr. Jackson?\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps you would like to call us swindlers, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson. \xe2\x80\x98Pray\r\ndo, Sir, if you feel disposed; now pray do, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I do,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98You _are _swindlers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson. \xe2\x80\x98You can hear down there, I hope, Mr. Wicks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, yes, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wicks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You had better come up a step or two higher, if you can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr.\r\nFogg. \xe2\x80\x98Go on, Sir; do go on. You had better call us thieves, Sir; or\r\nperhaps You would like to assault one of _us_. Pray do it, Sir, if you\r\nwould; we will not make the smallest resistance. Pray do it, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Fogg put himself very temptingly within the reach of Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nclenched fist, there is little doubt that that gentleman would have\r\ncomplied with his earnest entreaty, but for the interposition of Sam,\r\nwho, hearing the dispute, emerged from the office, mounted the stairs,\r\nand seized his master by the arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You just come away,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Battledore and shuttlecock\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nwery good game, vhen you ain\xe2\x80\x99t the shuttlecock and two lawyers the\r\nbattledores, in which case it gets too excitin\xe2\x80\x99 to be pleasant. Come\r\navay, Sir. If you want to ease your mind by blowing up somebody, come\r\nout into the court and blow up me; but it\xe2\x80\x99s rayther too expensive work\r\nto be carried on here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAnd without the slightest ceremony, Mr. Weller hauled his master down\r\nthe stairs, and down the court, and having safely deposited him in\r\nCornhill, fell behind, prepared to follow whithersoever he should lead.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick walked on abstractedly, crossed opposite the Mansion House,\r\nand bent his steps up Cheapside. Sam began to wonder where they were\r\ngoing, when his master turned round, and said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam, I will go immediately to Mr. Perker\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s just exactly the wery place vere you ought to have gone last\r\nnight, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think it is, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I _know _it is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, well, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98we will go there at once; but\r\nfirst, as I have been rather ruffled, I should like a glass of brandy-\r\nand-water warm, Sam. Where can I have it, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s knowledge of London was extensive and peculiar. He replied,\r\nwithout the slightest consideration--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Second court on the right hand side--last house but vun on the same\r\nside the vay--take the box as stands in the first fireplace, \xe2\x80\x98cos there\r\nain\xe2\x80\x99t no leg in the middle o\xe2\x80\x99 the table, which all the others has, and\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s wery inconvenient.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick observed his valet\xe2\x80\x99s directions implicitly, and bidding Sam\r\nfollow him, entered the tavern he had pointed out, where the hot brandy-\r\nand-water was speedily placed before him; while Mr. Weller, seated at a\r\nrespectful distance, though at the same table with his master, was\r\naccommodated with a pint of porter.\r\n\r\nThe room was one of a very homely description, and was apparently under\r\nthe especial patronage of stage-coachmen; for several gentleman, who had\r\nall the appearance of belonging to that learned profession, were\r\ndrinking and smoking in the different boxes. Among the number was one\r\nstout, red-faced, elderly man, in particular, seated in an opposite box,\r\nwho attracted Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s attention. The stout man was smoking with\r\ngreat vehemence, but between every half-dozen puffs, he took his pipe\r\nfrom his mouth, and looked first at Mr. Weller and then at Mr. Pickwick.\r\nThen, he would bury in a quart pot, as much of his countenance as the\r\ndimensions of the quart pot admitted of its receiving, and take another\r\nlook at Sam and Mr. Pickwick. Then he would take another half-dozen\r\npuffs with an air of profound meditation and look at them again. At last\r\nthe stout man, putting up his legs on the seat, and leaning his back\r\nagainst the wall, began to puff at his pipe without leaving off at all,\r\nand to stare through the smoke at the new-comers, as if he had made up\r\nhis mind to see the most he could of them.\r\n\r\nAt first the evolutions of the stout man had escaped Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nobservation, but by degrees, as he saw Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s eyes every now and\r\nthen turning towards him, he began to gaze in the same direction, at the\r\nsame time shading his eyes with his hand, as if he partially recognised\r\nthe object before him, and wished to make quite sure of its identity.\r\nHis doubts were speedily dispelled, however; for the stout man having\r\nblown a thick cloud from his pipe, a hoarse voice, like some strange\r\neffort of ventriloquism, emerged from beneath the capacious shawls which\r\nmuffled his throat and chest, and slowly uttered these sounds--\xe2\x80\x98Wy,\r\nSammy!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who\xe2\x80\x99s that, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t ha\xe2\x80\x99 believed it, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, with\r\nastonished eyes. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s the old \xe2\x80\x98un.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Old one,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98What old one?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My father, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98How are you, my ancient?\xe2\x80\x99 And\r\nwith this beautiful ebullition of filial affection, Mr. Weller made room\r\non the seat beside him, for the stout man, who advanced pipe in mouth\r\nand pot in hand, to greet him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wy, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said the father, \xe2\x80\x98I ha\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t seen you, for two year and\r\nbetter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nor more you have, old codger,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the son. \xe2\x80\x98How\xe2\x80\x99s mother-in-law?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wy, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, senior, with much\r\nsolemnity in his manner; \xe2\x80\x98there never was a nicer woman as a widder,\r\nthan that \xe2\x80\x98ere second wentur o\xe2\x80\x99 mine--a sweet creetur she was, Sammy;\r\nall I can say on her now, is, that as she was such an uncommon pleasant\r\nwidder, it\xe2\x80\x99s a great pity she ever changed her condition. She don\xe2\x80\x99t act\r\nas a vife, Sammy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t she, though?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Weller, junior.\r\n\r\nThe elder Mr. Weller shook his head, as he replied with a sigh, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ndone it once too often, Sammy; I\xe2\x80\x99ve done it once too often. Take example\r\nby your father, my boy, and be wery careful o\xe2\x80\x99 widders all your life,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98specially if they\xe2\x80\x99ve kept a public-house, Sammy.\xe2\x80\x99 Having delivered this\r\nparental advice with great pathos, Mr. Weller, senior, refilled his pipe\r\nfrom a tin box he carried in his pocket; and, lighting his fresh pipe\r\nfrom the ashes of the old One, commenced smoking at a great rate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Beg your pardon, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, renewing the subject, and addressing\r\nMr. Pickwick, after a considerable pause, \xe2\x80\x98nothin\xe2\x80\x99 personal, I hope,\r\nsir; I hope you ha\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t got a widder, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not I,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, laughing; and while Mr. Pickwick laughed,\r\nSam Weller informed his parent in a whisper, of the relation in which he\r\nstood towards that gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Beg your pardon, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, senior, taking off his hat, \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nhope you\xe2\x80\x99ve no fault to find with Sammy, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98None whatever,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery glad to hear it, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the old man; \xe2\x80\x98I took a good deal o\xe2\x80\x99\r\npains with his eddication, sir; let him run in the streets when he was\r\nwery young, and shift for hisself. It\xe2\x80\x99s the only way to make a boy\r\nsharp, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Rather a dangerous process, I should imagine,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with\r\na smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And not a wery sure one, neither,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98I got reg\xe2\x80\x99larly\r\ndone the other day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No!\xe2\x80\x99 said his father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I did,\xe2\x80\x99 said the son; and he proceeded to relate, in as few words as\r\npossible, how he had fallen a ready dupe to the stratagems of Job\r\nTrotter.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller, senior, listened to the tale with the most profound\r\nattention, and, at its termination, said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Worn\xe2\x80\x99t one o\xe2\x80\x99 these chaps slim and tall, with long hair, and the gift\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 the gab wery gallopin\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick did not quite understand the last item of description, but,\r\ncomprehending the first, said \xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 at a venture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98T\xe2\x80\x99 other\xe2\x80\x99s a black-haired chap in mulberry livery, with a wery large\r\nhead?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, yes, he is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick and Sam, with great earnestness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I know where they are, and that\xe2\x80\x99s all about it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98they\xe2\x80\x99re at Ipswich, safe enough, them two.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fact,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98and I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you how I know it. I work an\r\nIpswich coach now and then for a friend o\xe2\x80\x99 mine. I worked down the wery\r\nday arter the night as you caught the rheumatic, and at the Black Boy at\r\nChelmsford--the wery place they\xe2\x80\x99d come to--I took \xe2\x80\x98em up, right through\r\nto Ipswich, where the man-servant--him in the mulberries--told me they\r\nwas a-goin\xe2\x80\x99 to put up for a long time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll follow him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98we may as well see Ipswich as any\r\nother place. I\xe2\x80\x99ll follow him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re quite certain it was them, governor?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Weller,\r\njunior.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite, Sammy, quite,\xe2\x80\x99 replied his father, \xe2\x80\x98for their appearance is wery\r\nsing\xe2\x80\x99ler; besides that \xe2\x80\x98ere, I wondered to see the gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n so\r\nformiliar with his servant; and, more than that, as they sat in the\r\nfront, right behind the box, I heerd \xe2\x80\x98em laughing and saying how they\xe2\x80\x99d\r\ndone old Fireworks.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Old who?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Old Fireworks, Sir; by which, I\xe2\x80\x99ve no doubt, they meant you, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere is nothing positively vile or atrocious in the appellation of \xe2\x80\x98old\r\nFireworks,\xe2\x80\x99 but still it is by no means a respectful or flattering\r\ndesignation. The recollection of all the wrongs he had sustained at\r\nJingle\xe2\x80\x99s hands, had crowded on Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s mind, the moment Mr.\r\nWeller began to speak; it wanted but a feather to turn the scale, and\r\n\xe2\x80\x98old Fireworks\xe2\x80\x99 did it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll follow him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with an emphatic blow on the\r\ntable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall work down to Ipswich the day arter to-morrow, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nWeller the elder, \xe2\x80\x98from the Bull in Whitechapel; and if you really mean\r\nto go, you\xe2\x80\x99d better go with me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So we had,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98very true; I can write to Bury, and\r\ntell them to meet me at Ipswich. We will go with you. But don\xe2\x80\x99t hurry\r\naway, Mr. Weller; won\xe2\x80\x99t you take anything?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re wery good, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. W., stopping short;--\xe2\x80\x98perhaps a\r\nsmall glass of brandy to drink your health, and success to Sammy, Sir,\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be amiss.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly not,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A glass of brandy here!\xe2\x80\x99 The brandy was brought; and Mr. Weller, after\r\npulling his hair to Mr. Pickwick, and nodding to Sam, jerked it down his\r\ncapacious throat as if it had been a small thimbleful.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well done, father,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98take care, old fellow, or you\xe2\x80\x99ll have a\r\ntouch of your old complaint, the gout.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve found a sov\xe2\x80\x99rin\xe2\x80\x99 cure for that, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, setting\r\ndown the glass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A sovereign cure for the gout,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, hastily producing\r\nhis note-book--\xe2\x80\x98what is it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The gout, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98the gout is a complaint as arises\r\nfrom too much ease and comfort. If ever you\xe2\x80\x99re attacked with the gout,\r\nsir, jist you marry a widder as has got a good loud woice, with a decent\r\nnotion of usin\xe2\x80\x99 it, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll never have the gout agin. It\xe2\x80\x99s a capital\r\nprescription, sir. I takes it reg\xe2\x80\x99lar, and I can warrant it to drive\r\naway any illness as is caused by too much jollity.\xe2\x80\x99 Having imparted this\r\nvaluable secret, Mr. Weller drained his glass once more, produced a\r\nlaboured wink, sighed deeply, and slowly retired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, what do you think of what your father says, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr.\r\nPickwick, with a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Think, Sir!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98why, I think he\xe2\x80\x99s the wictim o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nconnubiality, as Blue Beard\xe2\x80\x99s domestic chaplain said, vith a tear of\r\npity, ven he buried him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was no replying to this very apposite conclusion, and, therefore,\r\nMr. Pickwick, after settling the reckoning, resumed his walk to Gray\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nInn. By the time he reached its secluded groves, however, eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock\r\nhad struck, and the unbroken stream of gentlemen in muddy high-lows,\r\nsoiled white hats, and rusty apparel, who were pouring towards the\r\ndifferent avenues of egress, warned him that the majority of the offices\r\nhad closed for that day.\r\n\r\nAfter climbing two pairs of steep and dirty stairs, he found his\r\nanticipations were realised. Do you\r\nknow?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I know where he is, but he won\xe2\x80\x99t thank me for telling you,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nreplied the laundress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have very particular business with him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Won\xe2\x80\x99t it do in the morning?\xe2\x80\x99 said the woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not so well,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old woman, \xe2\x80\x98if it was anything very particular, I was\r\nto say where he was, so I suppose there\xe2\x80\x99s no harm in telling. If you\r\njust go to the Magpie and Stump, and ask at the bar for Mr. Lowten,\r\nthey\xe2\x80\x99ll show you in to him, and he\xe2\x80\x99s Mr. Perker\xe2\x80\x99s clerk.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith this direction, and having been furthermore informed that the\r\nhostelry in question was situated in a court, happy in the double\r\nadvantage of being in the vicinity of Clare Market, and closely\r\napproximating to the back of New Inn, Mr. Pickwick and Sam descended the\r\nrickety staircase in safety, and issued forth in quest of the Magpie and\r\nStump.\r\n\r\nThis favoured tavern, sacred to the evening orgies of Mr. Lowten and his\r\ncompanions, was what ordinary people would designate a public-house.\r\nThat the landlord was a man of money-making turn was sufficiently\r\ntestified by the fact of a small bulkhead beneath the tap-room window,\r\nin size and shape not unlike a sedan-chair, being underlet to a mender\r\nof shoes: and that he was a being of a philanthropic mind was evident\r\nfrom the protection he afforded to a pieman, who vended his delicacies\r\nwithout fear of interruption, on the very door-step. In the lower\r\nwindows, which were decorated with curtains of a saffron hue, dangled\r\ntwo or three printed cards, bearing reference to Devonshire cider and\r\nDantzic spruce, while a large blackboard, announcing in white letters to\r\nan enlightened public, that there were 500,000 barrels of double stout\r\nin the cellars of the establishment, left the mind in a state of not\r\nunpleasing doubt and uncertainty as to the precise direction in the\r\nbowels of the earth, in which this mighty cavern might be supposed to\r\nextend. When we add that the weather-beaten signboard bore the half-\r\nobliterated semblance of a magpie intently eyeing a crooked streak of\r\nbrown paint, which the neighbours had been taught from infancy to\r\nconsider as the \xe2\x80\x98stump,\xe2\x80\x99 we have said all that need be said of the\r\nexterior of the edifice.\r\n\r\nOn Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s presenting himself at the bar, an elderly female\r\nemerged from behind the screen therein, and presented herself before\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is Mr. Lowten here, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, he is, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the landlady. \xe2\x80\x98Here, Charley, show the\r\ngentleman in to Mr. Lowten.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n can\xe2\x80\x99t go in just now,\xe2\x80\x99 said a shambling pot-boy, with a\r\nred head, \xe2\x80\x98cos\xe2\x80\x99 Mr. Lowten\xe2\x80\x99s a-singin\xe2\x80\x99 a comic song, and he\xe2\x80\x99ll put him\r\nout. He\xe2\x80\x99ll be done directly, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe red-headed pot-boy had scarcely finished speaking, when a most\r\nunanimous hammering of tables, and jingling of glasses, announced that\r\nthe song had that instant terminated; and Mr. Pickwick, after desiring\r\nSam to solace himself in the tap, suffered himself to be conducted into\r\nthe presence of Mr. Lowten.\r\n\r\nAt the announcement of \xe2\x80\x98A gentleman to speak to you, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 a puffy-faced\r\nyoung man, who filled the chair at the head of the table, looked with\r\nsome surprise in the direction from whence the voice proceeded; and the\r\nsurprise seemed to be by no means diminished, when his eyes rested on an\r\nindividual whom he had never seen before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98and I am very sorry to\r\ndisturb the other gentlemen, too, but I come on very particular\r\nbusiness; and if you will suffer me to detain you at this end of the\r\nroom for five minutes, I shall be very much obliged to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe puffy-faced young man rose, and drawing a chair close to Mr.\r\nPickwick in an obscure corner of the room, listened attentively to his\r\ntale of woe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, when Mr. Pickwick had concluded, \xe2\x80\x98Dodson and Fogg--sharp\r\npractice theirs--capital men of business, Dodson and Fogg, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick admitted the sharp practice of Dodson and Fogg, and Lowten\r\nresumed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perker ain\xe2\x80\x99t in town, and he won\xe2\x80\x99t be, neither, before the end of next\r\nweek; but if you want the action defended, and will leave the copy with\r\nme, I can do all that\xe2\x80\x99s needful till he comes back.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s exactly what I came here for,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, handing over\r\nthe document. \xe2\x80\x98If anything particular occurs, you can write to me at the\r\npost-office, Ipswich.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s all right,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Perker\xe2\x80\x99s clerk; We are capital company here to-\r\nnight. There\xe2\x80\x99s Samkin and Green\xe2\x80\x99s managing-clerk, and Smithers and\r\nPrice\xe2\x80\x99s chancery, and Pimkin and Thomas\xe2\x80\x99s out o\xe2\x80\x99 doors--sings a capital\r\nsong, he does--and Jack Bamber, and ever so many more.
