There--Peter\r\nMagnus--sounds well, I think, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Curious circumstance about those initials, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Magnus. \xe2\x80\x98You\r\nwill observe--P.M.--post meridian. In hasty notes to intimate\r\nacquaintance, I sometimes sign myself \xe2\x80\x9cAfternoon.\xe2\x80\x9d It amuses my friends\r\nvery much, Mr. Pickwick.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is calculated to afford them the highest gratification, I should\r\nconceive,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, rather envying the ease with which Mr.\r\nMagnus\xe2\x80\x99s friends were entertained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n,\xe2\x80\x99 said the hostler, \xe2\x80\x98coach is ready, if you please.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is all my luggage in?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Magnus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All right, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is the red bag in?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All right, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And the striped bag?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fore boot, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And the brown-paper parcel?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Under the seat, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And the leather hat-box?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They\xe2\x80\x99re all in, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, will you get up?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Excuse me,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Magnus, standing on the wheel. \xe2\x80\x98Excuse me, Mr.\r\nPickwick. I cannot consent to get up, in this state of uncertainty. I am\r\nquite satisfied from that man\xe2\x80\x99s manner, that the leather hat-box is not\r\nin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe solemn protestations of the hostler being wholly unavailing, the\r\nleather hat-box was obliged to be raked up from the lowest depth of the\r\nboot, to satisfy him that it had been safely packed; and after he had\r\nbeen assured on this head, he felt a solemn presentiment, first, that\r\nthe red bag was mislaid, and next that the striped bag had been stolen,\r\nand then that the brown-paper parcel \xe2\x80\x98had come untied.\xe2\x80\x99 At length when\r\nhe had received ocular demonstration of the groundless nature of each\r\nand every of these suspicions, he consented to climb up to the roof of\r\nthe coach, observing that now he had taken everything off his mind, he\r\nfelt quite comfortable and happy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re given to nervousness, ain\xe2\x80\x99t you, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Weller,\r\nsenior, eyeing the stranger askance, as he mounted to his place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; I always am rather about these little matters,\xe2\x80\x99 said the stranger,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98but I am all right now--quite right.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, that\xe2\x80\x99s a blessin\xe2\x80\x99, said Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Sammy, help your master up\r\nto the box; t\xe2\x80\x99other leg, Sir, that\xe2\x80\x99s it; give us your hand, Sir. Up with\r\nyou. You was a lighter weight when you was a boy, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nTrue enough, that, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 said the breathless Mr. Pickwick good-\r\nhumouredly, as he took his seat on the box beside him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Jump up in front, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Now Villam, run \xe2\x80\x98em out.\r\nTake care o\xe2\x80\x99 the archvay, gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n. \xe2\x80\x9cHeads,\xe2\x80\x9d as the pieman says.\r\nThat\xe2\x80\x99ll do, Villam. Let \xe2\x80\x98em alone.\xe2\x80\x99 And away went the coach up\r\nWhitechapel, to the admiration of the whole population of that pretty\r\ndensely populated quarter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a wery nice neighbourhood, this, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, with a touch of\r\nthe hat, which always preceded his entering into conversation with his\r\nmaster.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is not indeed, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, surveying the crowded and\r\nfilthy street through which they were passing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a wery remarkable circumstance, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98that poverty and\r\noysters always seem to go together.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand you, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What I mean, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98is, that the poorer a place is, the\r\ngreater call there seems to be for oysters. Look here, sir; here\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\noyster-stall to every half-dozen houses. The street\xe2\x80\x99s lined vith \xe2\x80\x98em.\r\nBlessed if I don\xe2\x80\x99t think that ven a man\xe2\x80\x99s wery poor, he rushes out of\r\nhis lodgings, and eats oysters in reg\xe2\x80\x99lar desperation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be sure he does,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, senior; \xe2\x80\x98and it\xe2\x80\x99s just the same\r\nvith pickled salmon!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Those are two very remarkable facts, which never occurred to me\r\nbefore,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98The very first place we stop at, I\xe2\x80\x99ll make\r\na note of them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBy this time they had reached the turnpike at Mile End; a profound\r\nsilence prevailed until they had got two or three miles farther on, when\r\nMr. Weller, senior, turning suddenly to Mr. Pickwick, said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery queer life is a pike-keeper\xe2\x80\x99s, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A what?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A pike-keeper.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean by a pike-keeper?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Peter Magnus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The old \xe2\x80\x98un means a turnpike-keeper, gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Mr. Samuel\r\nWeller, in explanation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98I see. Yes; very curious life. Very\r\nuncomfortable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They\xe2\x80\x99re all on \xe2\x80\x98em men as has met vith some disappointment in life,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Mr. Weller, senior.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay, ay,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. Consequence of vich, they retires from the world, and shuts\r\nthemselves up in pikes; partly with the view of being solitary, and\r\npartly to rewenge themselves on mankind by takin\xe2\x80\x99 tolls.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98I never knew that before.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fact, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98if they was gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n, you\xe2\x80\x99d call \xe2\x80\x98em\r\nmisanthropes, but as it is, they only takes to pike-keepin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith such conversation, possessing the inestimable charm of blending\r\namusement with instruction, did Mr. Weller beguile the tediousness of\r\nthe journey, during the greater part of the day. Topics of conversation\r\nwere never wanting, for even when any pause occurred in Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nloquacity, it was abundantly supplied by the desire evinced by Mr.\r\nMagnus to make himself acquainted with the whole of the personal history\r\nof his fellow-travellers, and his loudly-expressed anxiety at every\r\nstage, respecting the safety and well-being of the two bags, the leather\r\nhat-box, and the brown-paper parcel.\r\n\r\nIn the main street of Ipswich, on the left-hand side of the way, a short\r\ndistance after you have passed through the open space fronting the Town\r\nHall, stands an inn known far and wide by the appellation of the Great\r\nWhite Horse, rendered the more conspicuous by a stone statue of some\r\nrampacious animal with flowing mane and tail, distantly resembling an\r\ninsane cart-horse, which is elevated above the principal door. The Great\r\nWhite Horse is famous in the neighbourhood, in the same degree as a\r\nprize ox, or a county-paper-chronicled turnip, or unwieldy pig--for its\r\nenormous size. Never was such labyrinths of uncarpeted passages, such\r\nclusters of mouldy, ill-lighted rooms, such huge numbers of small dens\r\nfor eating or sleeping in, beneath any one roof, as are collected\r\ntogether between the four walls of the Great White Horse at Ipswich.\r\n\r\nIt was at the door of this overgrown tavern that the London coach\r\nstopped, at the same hour every evening; and it was from this same\r\nLondon coach that Mr. Pickwick, Sam Weller, and Mr. Peter Magnus\r\ndismounted, on the particular evening to which this chapter of our\r\nhistory bears reference.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you stop here, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Peter Magnus, when the striped\r\nbag, and the red bag, and the brown-paper parcel, and the leather hat-\r\nbox, had all been deposited in the passage. \xe2\x80\x98Do you stop here, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I do,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Magnus, \xe2\x80\x98I never knew anything like these\r\nextraordinary coincidences. Why, I stop here too. I hope we dine\r\ntogether?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With pleasure,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98I am not quite certain whether I\r\nhave any friends here or not, though. Is there any gentleman of the name\r\nof Tupman here, waiter?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA corpulent man, with a fortnight\xe2\x80\x99s napkin under his arm, and coeval\r\nstockings on his legs, slowly desisted from his occupation of staring\r\ndown the street, on this question being put to him by Mr. Pickwick; and,\r\nafter minutely inspecting that gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s appearance, from the crown of\r\nhis hat to the lowest button of his gaiters, replied emphatically--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nor any gentleman of the name of Snodgrass?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nor Winkle?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My friends have not arrived to-day, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98We will\r\ndine alone, then. Show us a private room, waiter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOn this request being preferred, the corpulent man condescended to order\r\nthe boots to bring in the gentlemen\xe2\x80\x99s luggage; and preceding them down a\r\nlong, dark passage, ushered them into a large, badly-furnished\r\napartment, with a dirty grate, in which a small fire was making a\r\nwretched attempt to be cheerful, but was fast sinking beneath the\r\ndispiriting influence of the place. After the lapse of an hour, a bit of\r\nfish and a steak was served up to the travellers, and when the dinner\r\nwas cleared away, Mr. Pickwick and Mr. Peter Magnus drew their chairs up\r\nto the fire, and having ordered a bottle of the worst possible port\r\nwine, at the highest possible price, for the good of the house, drank\r\nbrandy-and-water for their own.\r\n\r\nMr. Peter Magnus was naturally of a very communicative disposition, and\r\nthe brandy-and-water operated with wonderful effect in warming into life\r\nthe deepest hidden secrets of his bosom. After sundry accounts of\r\nhimself, his family, his connections, his friends, his jokes, his\r\nbusiness, and his brothers (most talkative men have a great deal to say\r\nabout their brothers), Mr. Peter Magnus took a view of Mr. Pickwick\r\nthrough his coloured spectacles for several minutes, and then said, with\r\nan air of modesty--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what do you think--what _do_ you think, Mr. Pickwick--I have come\r\ndown here for?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Upon my word,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98it is wholly impossible for me to\r\nguess; on business, perhaps.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Partly right, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Peter Magnus, \xe2\x80\x98but partly wrong at the\r\nsame time; try again, Mr. Pickwick.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Really,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98I must throw myself on your mercy, to tell\r\nme or not, as you may think best; for I should never guess, if I were to\r\ntry all night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, then, he-he-he!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Peter Magnus, with a bashful titter,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98what should you think, Mr. Pickwick, if I had come down here to make a\r\nproposal, Sir, eh? He, he, he!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Think! That you are very likely to succeed,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, with\r\none of his beaming smiles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Magnus. \xe2\x80\x98But do you really think so, Mr. Pickwick? Do\r\nyou, though?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No; but you\xe2\x80\x99re joking, though.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not, indeed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Magnus, \xe2\x80\x98to let you into a little secret, I think\r\nso too. I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind telling you, Mr. Pickwick, although I\xe2\x80\x99m dreadful\r\njealous by nature--horrid--that the lady is in this house.\xe2\x80\x99 Here Mr.\r\nMagnus took off his spectacles, on purpose to wink, and then put them on\r\nagain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s what you were running out of the room for, before dinner, then,\r\nso often,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick archly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hush! Yes, you\xe2\x80\x99re right, that was it; not such a fool as to see her,\r\nthough.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No; wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do, you know, after having just come off a journey. Wait\r\ntill to-morrow, sir; double the chance then. Mr. Pickwick, Sir, there is\r\na suit of clothes in that bag, and a hat in that box, which, I expect,\r\nin the effect they will produce, will be invaluable to me, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; you must have observed my anxiety about them to-day. I do not\r\nbelieve that such another suit of clothes, and such a hat, could be\r\nbought for money, Mr. Pickwick.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick congratulated the fortunate owner of the irresistible\r\ngarments on their acquisition; and Mr. Peter Magnus remained a few\r\nmoments apparently absorbed in contemplation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She\xe2\x80\x99s a fine creature,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Magnus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is she?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Magnus. \xe2\x80\x98Very. She lives about twenty miles from here,\r\nMr. Pickwick. I heard she would be here to-night and all to-morrow\r\nforenoon, and came down to seize the opportunity. I think an inn is a\r\ngood sort of a place to propose to a single woman in, Mr. Pickwick. She\r\nis more likely to feel the loneliness of her situation in travelling,\r\nperhaps, than she would be at home. What do you think, Mr. Pickwick?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think it is very probable,\xe2\x80\x99 replied that gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon, Mr. Pickwick,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Peter Magnus, \xe2\x80\x98but I am\r\nnaturally rather curious; what may you have come down here for?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98On a far less pleasant errand, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, the colour\r\nmounting to his face at the recollection. \xe2\x80\x98I have come down here, Sir,\r\nto expose the treachery and falsehood of an individual, upon whose truth\r\nand honour I placed implicit reliance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Peter Magnus, \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s very unpleasant. It is a lady,\r\nI presume? Eh? ah! Sly, Mr. Pickwick, sly. Well, Mr. Pickwick, sir, I\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t probe your feelings for the world. Painful subjects, these,\r\nsir, very painful. Don\xe2\x80\x99t mind me, Mr. Pickwick, if you wish to give vent\r\nto your feelings. I know what it is to be jilted, Sir; I have endured\r\nthat sort of thing three or four times.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am much obliged to you, for your condolence on what you presume to be\r\nmy melancholy case,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, winding up his watch, and laying\r\nit on the table, \xe2\x80\x98but--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Peter Magnus, \xe2\x80\x98not a word more; it\xe2\x80\x99s a painful\r\nsubject. I see, I see. What\xe2\x80\x99s the time, Mr. Pickwick?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPast twelve.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me, it\xe2\x80\x99s time to go to bed. It will never do, sitting here. I\r\nshall be pale to-morrow, Mr. Pickwick.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt the bare notion of such a calamity, Mr. Peter Magnus rang the bell\r\nfor the chambermaid; and the striped bag, the red bag, the leathern hat-\r\nbox, and the brown-paper parcel, having been conveyed to his bedroom, he\r\nretired in company with a japanned candlestick, to one side of the\r\nhouse, while Mr. Pickwick, and another japanned candlestick, were\r\nconducted through a multitude of tortuous windings, to another.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is your room, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the chambermaid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, looking round him. It was a tolerably\r\nlarge double-bedded room, with a fire; upon the whole, a more\r\ncomfortable-looking apartment than Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s short experience of\r\nthe accommodations of the Great White Horse had led him to expect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nobody sleeps in the other bed, of course,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, no, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good. Tell my servant to bring me up some hot water at half-past\r\neight in the morning, and that I shall not want him any more to-night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 and bidding Mr. Pickwick good-night, the chambermaid\r\nretired, and left him alone.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick sat himself down in a chair before the fire, and fell into\r\na train of rambling meditations. First he thought of his friends, and\r\nwondered when they would join him; then his mind reverted to Mrs. Martha\r\nBardell; and from that lady it wandered, by a natural process, to the\r\ndingy counting-house of Dodson & Fogg. From Dodson & Fogg\xe2\x80\x99s it flew off\r\nat a tangent, to the very centre of the history of the queer client; and\r\nthen it came back to the Great White Horse at Ipswich, with sufficient\r\nclearness to convince Mr. Pickwick that he was falling asleep. So he\r\nroused himself, and began to undress, when he recollected he had left\r\nhis watch on the table downstairs.\r\n\r\nNow this watch was a special favourite with Mr. Pickwick, having been\r\ncarried about, beneath the shadow of his waistcoat, for a greater number\r\nof years than we feel called upon to state at present. The possibility\r\nof going to sleep, unless it were ticking gently beneath his pillow, or\r\nin the watch-pocket over his head, had never entered Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbrain. So as it was pretty late now, and he was unwilling to ring his\r\nbell at that hour of the night, he slipped on his coat, of which he had\r\njust divested himself, and taking the japanned candlestick in his hand,\r\nwalked quietly downstairs.\r\n\r\nThe more stairs Mr. Pickwick went down, the more stairs there seemed to\r\nbe to descend, and again and again, when Mr. Pickwick got into some\r\nnarrow passage, and began to congratulate himself on having gained the\r\nground-floor, did another flight of stairs appear before his astonished\r\neyes. At last he reached a stone hall, which he remembered to have seen\r\nwhen he entered the house. Passage after passage did he explore; room\r\nafter room did he peep into; at length, as he was on the point of giving\r\nup the search in despair, he opened the door of the identical room in\r\nwhich he had spent the evening, and beheld his missing property on the\r\ntable.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick seized the watch in triumph, and proceeded to retrace his\r\nsteps to his bedchamber. If his progress downward had been attended with\r\ndifficulties and uncertainty, his journey back was infinitely more\r\nperplexing. Rows of doors, garnished with boots of every shape, make,\r\nand size, branched off in every possible direction. A dozen times did he\r\nsoftly turn the handle of some bedroom door which resembled his own,\r\nwhen a gruff cry from within of \xe2\x80\x98Who the devil\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98What do you\r\nwant here?\xe2\x80\x99 caused him to steal away, on tiptoe, with a perfectly\r\nmarvellous celerity. He was reduced to the verge of despair, when an\r\nopen door attracted his attention. He peeped in. Right at last! There\r\nwere the two beds, whose situation he perfectly remembered, and the fire\r\nstill burning. His candle, not a long one when he first received it, had\r\nflickered away in the drafts of air through which he had passed and sank\r\ninto the socket as he closed the door after him. \xe2\x80\x98No matter,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nPickwick, \xe2\x80\x98I can undress myself just as well by the light of the fire.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe bedsteads stood one on each side of the door; and on the inner side\r\nof each was a little path, terminating in a rush-bottomed chair, just\r\nwide enough to admit of a person\xe2\x80\x99s getting into or out of bed, on that\r\nside, if he or she thought proper. Having carefully drawn the curtains\r\nof his bed on the outside, Mr. Pickwick sat down on the rush-bottomed\r\nchair, and leisurely divested himself of his shoes and gaiters. He then\r\ntook off and folded up his coat, waistcoat, and neckcloth, and slowly\r\ndrawing on his tasselled nightcap, secured it firmly on his head, by\r\ntying beneath his chin the strings which he always had attached to that\r\narticle of dress. It was at this moment that the absurdity of his recent\r\nbewilderment struck upon his mind. Throwing himself back in the rush-\r\nbottomed chair, Mr. Pickwick laughed to himself so heartily, that it\r\nwould have been quite delightful to any man of well-constituted mind to\r\nhave watched the smiles that expanded his amiable features as they shone\r\nforth from beneath the nightcap.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is the best idea,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick to himself, smiling till he\r\nalmost cracked the nightcap strings--\xe2\x80\x98it is the best idea, my losing\r\nmyself in this place, and wandering about these staircases, that I ever\r\nheard of. Droll, droll, very droll.\xe2\x80\x99 Here Mr. Pickwick smiled again, a\r\nbroader smile than before, and was about to continue the process of\r\nundressing, in the best possible humour, when he was suddenly stopped by\r\na most unexpected interruption: to wit, the entrance into the room of\r\nsome person with a candle, who, after locking the door, advanced to the\r\ndressing-table, and set down the light upon it.\r\n\r\nThe smile that played on Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s features was instantaneously\r\nlost in a look of the most unbounded and wonder-stricken surprise. The\r\nperson, whoever it was, had come in so suddenly and with so little\r\nnoise, that Mr. Pickwick had had no time to call out, or oppose their\r\nentrance. Who could it be? A robber? Some evil-minded person who had\r\nseen him come upstairs with a handsome watch in his hand, perhaps. What\r\nwas he to do?\r\n\r\nThe only way in which Mr. Pickwick could catch a glimpse of his\r\nmysterious visitor with the least danger of being seen himself, was by\r\ncreeping on to the bed, and peeping out from between the curtains on the\r\nopposite side. To this manoeuvre he accordingly resorted. Keeping the\r\ncurtains carefully closed with his hand, so that nothing more of him\r\ncould be seen than his face and nightcap, and putting on his spectacles,\r\nhe mustered up courage and looked out.\r\n\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick almost fainted with horror and dismay. Standing before the\r\ndressing-glass was a middle-aged lady, in yellow curl-papers, busily\r\nengaged in brushing what ladies call their \xe2\x80\x98back-hair.\xe2\x80\x99 However the\r\nunconscious middle-aged lady came into that room, it was quite clear\r\nthat she contemplated remaining there for the night; for she had brought\r\na rushlight and shade with her, which, with praiseworthy precaution\r\nagainst fire, she had stationed in a basin on the floor, where it was\r\nglimmering away, like a gigantic lighthouse in a particularly small\r\npiece of water.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless my soul!\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98what a dreadful thing!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hem!\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady; and in went Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s head with automaton-\r\nlike rapidity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never met with anything so awful as this,\xe2\x80\x99 thought poor Mr. Pickwick,\r\nthe cold perspiration starting in drops upon his nightcap. \xe2\x80\x98Never. This\r\nis fearful.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was quite impossible to resist the urgent desire to see what was\r\ngoing forward. So out went Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s head again. The prospect was\r\nworse than before. The middle-aged lady had finished arranging her hair;\r\nhad carefully enveloped it in a muslin nightcap with a small plaited\r\nborder; and was gazing pensively on the fire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This matter is growing alarming,\xe2\x80\x99 reasoned Mr. Pickwick with himself.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t allow things to go on in this way. By the self-possession of\r\nthat lady, it is clear to me that I must have come into the wrong room.\r\nIf I call out she\xe2\x80\x99ll alarm the house; but if I remain here the\r\nconsequences will be still more frightful.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick, it is quite unnecessary to say, was one of the most modest\r\nand delicate-minded of mortals. The very idea of exhibiting his nightcap\r\nto a lady overpowered him, but he had tied those confounded strings in a\r\nknot, and, do what he would, he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get it off. The disclosure must\r\nbe made. There was only one other way of doing it. He shrunk behind the\r\ncurtains, and called out very loudly--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha-hum!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThat the lady started at this unexpected sound was evident, by her\r\nfalling up against the rushlight shade; that she persuaded herself it\r\nmust have been the effect of imagination was equally clear, for when Mr.\r\nPickwick, under the impression that she had fainted away stone-dead with\r\nfright, ventured to peep out again, she was gazing pensively on the fire\r\nas before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Most extraordinary female this,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr. Pickwick, popping in\r\nagain. \xe2\x80\x98Ha-hum!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThese last sounds, so like those in which, as legends inform us, the\r\nferocious giant Blunderbore was in the habit of expressing his opinion\r\nthat it was time to lay the cloth, were too distinctly audible to be\r\nagain mistaken for the workings of fancy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gracious Heaven!\xe2\x80\x99 said the middle-aged lady, \xe2\x80\x98what\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s--it\xe2\x80\x99s--only a gentleman, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, from behind\r\nthe curtains.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A gentleman!\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady, with a terrific scream.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s all over!\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A strange man!\xe2\x80\x99 shrieked the lady. Another instant and the house would\r\nbe alarmed. Her garments rustled as she rushed towards the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, thrusting out his head in the extremity of\r\nhis desperation, \xe2\x80\x98ma\xe2\x80\x99am!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNow, although Mr. Pickwick was not actuated by any definite object in\r\nputting out his head, it was instantaneously productive of a good\r\neffect. The lady, as we have already stated, was near the door. She must\r\npass it, to reach the staircase, and she would most undoubtedly have\r\ndone so by this time, had not the sudden apparition of Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnightcap driven her back into the remotest corner of the apartment,\r\nwhere she stood staring wildly at Mr. Pickwick, while Mr. Pickwick in\r\nhis turn stared wildly at her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wretch,\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady, covering her eyes with her hands, \xe2\x80\x98what do you\r\nwant here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; nothing whatever, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick earnestly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing!\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady, looking up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, upon my honour,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, nodding his head so\r\nenergetically, that the tassel of his nightcap danced again. \xe2\x80\x98I am\r\nalmost ready to sink, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, beneath the confusion of addressing a lady\r\nin my nightcap (here the lady hastily snatched off hers), but I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nget it off, ma\xe2\x80\x99am (here Mr. Pickwick gave it a tremendous tug, in proof\r\nof the statement). It is evident to me, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, now, that I have mistaken\r\nthis bedroom for my own. I had not been here five minutes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, when\r\nyou suddenly entered it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If this improbable story be really true, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady, sobbing\r\nviolently, \xe2\x80\x98you will leave it instantly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, with the greatest pleasure,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Instantly, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Pickwick, very quickly. \xe2\x80\x98Certainly,\r\nma\xe2\x80\x99am. I--I--am very sorry, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, making his\r\nappearance at the bottom of the bed, \xe2\x80\x98to have been the innocent occasion\r\nof this alarm and emotion; deeply sorry, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe lady pointed to the door. One excellent quality of Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncharacter was beautifully displayed at this moment, under the most\r\ntrying circumstances. Although he had hastily put on his hat over his\r\nnightcap, after the manner of the old patrol; although he carried his\r\nshoes and gaiters in his hand, and his coat and waistcoat over his arm;\r\nnothing could subdue his native politeness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am exceedingly sorry, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, bowing very low.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you are, Sir, you will at once leave the room,\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Immediately, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; this instant, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, opening\r\nthe door, and dropping both his shoes with a crash in so doing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I trust, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Mr. Pickwick, gathering up his shoes, and\r\nturning round to bow again--\xe2\x80\x98I trust, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, that my unblemished\r\ncharacter, and the devoted respect I entertain for your sex, will plead\r\nas some slight excuse for this--\xe2\x80\x99 But before Mr. Pickwick could conclude\r\nthe sentence, the lady had thrust him into the passage, and locked and\r\nbolted the door behind him.\r\n\r\nWhatever grounds of self-congratulation Mr. Pickwick might have for\r\nhaving escaped so quietly from his late awkward situation, his present\r\nposition was by no means enviable. He was alone, in an open passage, in\r\na strange house in the middle of the night, half dressed; it was not to\r\nbe supposed that he could find his way in perfect darkness to a room\r\nwhich he had been wholly unable to discover with a light, and if he made\r\nthe slightest noise in his fruitless attempts to do so, he stood every\r\nchance of being shot at, and perhaps killed, by some wakeful traveller.\r\nHe had no resource but to remain where he was until daylight appeared.\r\nSo after groping his way a few paces down the passage, and, to his\r\ninfinite alarm, stumbling over several pairs of boots in so doing, Mr.\r\nPickwick crouched into a little recess in the wall, to wait for morning,\r\nas philosophically as he might.\r\n\r\nHe was not destined, however, to undergo this additional trial of\r\npatience; for he had not been long ensconced in his present concealment\r\nwhen, to his unspeakable horror, a man, bearing a light, appeared at the\r\nend of the passage. His horror was suddenly converted into joy, however,\r\nwhen he recognised the form of his faithful attendant. It was indeed Mr.\r\nSamuel Weller, who after sitting up thus late, in conversation with the\r\nboots, who was sitting up for the mail, was now about to retire to rest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, suddenly appearing before him, \xe2\x80\x98where\xe2\x80\x99s my\r\nbedroom?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller stared at his master with the most emphatic surprise; and it\r\nwas not until the question had been repeated three several times, that\r\nhe turned round, and led the way to the long-sought apartment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, as he got into bed, \xe2\x80\x98I have made one of the\r\nmost extraordinary mistakes to-night, that ever were heard of.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery likely, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller drily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But of this I am determined, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98that if I were\r\nto stop in this house for six months, I would never trust myself about\r\nit, alone, again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s the wery prudentest resolution as you could come to, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nreplied Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98You rayther want somebody to look arter you, Sir,\r\nwhen your judgment goes out a wisitin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean by that, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. He raised himself in\r\nbed, and extended his hand, as if he were about to say something more;\r\nbut suddenly checking himself, turned round, and bade his valet \xe2\x80\x98Good-\r\nnight.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-night, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller. He paused when he got outside the\r\ndoor--shook his head--walked on--stopped--snuffed the candle--shook his\r\nhead again--and finally proceeded slowly to his chamber, apparently\r\nburied in the profoundest meditation.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIII. IN WHICH MR. SAMUEL WELLER BEGINS TO DEVOTE HIS ENERGIES\r\nTO THE RETURN MATCH BETWEEN HIMSELF AND MR. TROTTER\r\n\r\nIn a small room in the vicinity of the stableyard, betimes in the\r\nmorning, which was ushered in by Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s adventure with the\r\nmiddle--aged lady in the yellow curl-papers, sat Mr. Weller, senior,\r\npreparing himself for his journey to London. He was sitting in an\r\nexcellent attitude for having his portrait taken; and here it is.\r\n\r\nIt is very possible that at some earlier period of his career, Mr.\r\nWeller\xe2\x80\x99s profile might have presented a bold and determined outline. His\r\nface, however, had expanded under the influence of good living, and a\r\ndisposition remarkable for resignation; and its bold, fleshy curves had\r\nso far extended beyond the limits originally assigned them, that unless\r\nyou took a full view of his countenance in front, it was difficult to\r\ndistinguish more than the extreme tip of a very rubicund nose. His chin,\r\nfrom the same cause, had acquired the grave and imposing form which is\r\ngenerally described by prefixing the word \xe2\x80\x98double\xe2\x80\x99 to that expressive\r\nfeature; and his complexion exhibited that peculiarly mottled\r\ncombination of colours which is only to be seen in gentlemen of his\r\nprofession, and in underdone roast beef. Round his neck he wore a\r\ncrimson travelling-shawl, which merged into his chin by such\r\nimperceptible gradations, that it was difficult to distinguish the folds\r\nof the one, from the folds of the other. Over this, he mounted a long\r\nwaistcoat of a broad pink-striped pattern, and over that again, a wide-\r\nskirted green coat, ornamented with large brass buttons, whereof the two\r\nwhich garnished the waist, were so far apart, that no man had ever\r\nbeheld them both at the same time. His hair, which was short, sleek, and\r\nblack, was just visible beneath the capacious brim of a low-crowned\r\nbrown hat. His legs were encased in knee-cord breeches, and painted top-\r\nboots; and a copper watch-chain, terminating in one seal, and a key of\r\nthe same material, dangled loosely from his capacious waistband.\r\n\r\nWe have said that Mr. Weller was engaged in preparing for his journey to\r\nLondon--he was taking sustenance, in fact. On the table before him,\r\nstood a pot of ale, a cold round of beef, and a very respectable-looking\r\nloaf, to each of which he distributed his favours in turn, with the most\r\nrigid impartiality. He had just cut a mighty slice from the latter, when\r\nthe footsteps of somebody entering the room, caused him to raise his\r\nhead; and he beheld his son.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mornin\xe2\x80\x99, Sammy!\xe2\x80\x99 said the father.\r\n\r\nThe son walked up to the pot of ale, and nodding significantly to his\r\nparent, took a long draught by way of reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery good power o\xe2\x80\x99 suction, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller the elder, looking\r\ninto the pot, when his first-born had set it down half empty. \xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99d ha\xe2\x80\x99\r\nmade an uncommon fine oyster, Sammy, if you\xe2\x80\x99d been born in that station\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 life.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I des-say, I should ha\xe2\x80\x99 managed to pick up a respectable livin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nreplied Sam applying himself to the cold beef, with considerable vigour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m wery sorry, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said the elder Mr. Weller, shaking up the ale,\r\nby describing small circles with the pot, preparatory to drinking. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nwery sorry, Sammy, to hear from your lips, as you let yourself be\r\ngammoned by that \xe2\x80\x98ere mulberry man. I always thought, up to three days\r\nago, that the names of Veller and gammon could never come into contract,\r\nSammy, never.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Always exceptin\xe2\x80\x99 the case of a widder, of course,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Widders, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, slightly changing colour. \xe2\x80\x98Widders\r\nare \xe2\x80\x98ceptions to ev\xe2\x80\x99ry rule. I have heerd how many ordinary women one\r\nwidder\xe2\x80\x99s equal to in pint o\xe2\x80\x99 comin\xe2\x80\x99 over you. I think it\xe2\x80\x99s five-and-\r\ntwenty, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t rightly know vether it ain\xe2\x80\x99t more.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well; that\xe2\x80\x99s pretty well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Besides,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Mr. Weller, not noticing the interruption, \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na wery different thing. You know what the counsel said, Sammy, as\r\ndefended the gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n as beat his wife with the poker, venever he got\r\njolly. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd arter all, my Lord,\xe2\x80\x9d says he, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s a amiable weakness.\xe2\x80\x9d So\r\nI says respectin\xe2\x80\x99 widders, Sammy, and so you\xe2\x80\x99ll say, ven you gets as old\r\nas me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I ought to ha\xe2\x80\x99 know\xe2\x80\x99d better, I know,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ought to ha\xe2\x80\x99 know\xe2\x80\x99d better!\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr. Weller, striking the table\r\nwith his fist. \xe2\x80\x98Ought to ha\xe2\x80\x99 know\xe2\x80\x99d better! why, I know a young \xe2\x80\x98un as\r\nhasn\xe2\x80\x99t had half nor quarter your eddication--as hasn\xe2\x80\x99t slept about the\r\nmarkets, no, not six months--who\xe2\x80\x99d ha\xe2\x80\x99 scorned to be let in, in such a\r\nvay; scorned it, Sammy.\xe2\x80\x99 In the excitement of feeling produced by this\r\nagonising reflection, Mr. Weller rang the bell, and ordered an\r\nadditional pint of ale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, it\xe2\x80\x99s no use talking about it now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s over, and\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t be helped, and that\xe2\x80\x99s one consolation, as they always says in\r\nTurkey, ven they cuts the wrong man\xe2\x80\x99s head off. It\xe2\x80\x99s my innings now,\r\ngov\xe2\x80\x99nor, and as soon as I catches hold o\xe2\x80\x99 this \xe2\x80\x98ere Trotter, I\xe2\x80\x99ll have a\r\ngood \xe2\x80\x98un.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope you will, Sammy. I hope you will,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Here\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nyour health, Sammy, and may you speedily vipe off the disgrace as you\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ninflicted on the family name.\xe2\x80\x99 In honour of this toast Mr. Weller\r\nimbibed at a draught, at least two-thirds of a newly-arrived pint, and\r\nhanded it over to his son, to dispose of the remainder, which he\r\ninstantaneously did.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And now, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, consulting a large double-faced\r\nsilver watch that hung at the end of the copper chain. \xe2\x80\x98Now it\xe2\x80\x99s time I\r\nwas up at the office to get my vay-bill and see the coach loaded; for\r\ncoaches, Sammy, is like guns--they requires to be loaded with wery great\r\ncare, afore they go off.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt this parental and professional joke, Mr. Weller, junior, smiled a\r\nfilial smile. His revered parent continued in a solemn tone--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m a-goin\xe2\x80\x99 to leave you, Samivel, my boy, and there\xe2\x80\x99s no telling ven I\r\nshall see you again. Your mother-in-law may ha\xe2\x80\x99 been too much for me, or\r\na thousand things may have happened by the time you next hears any news\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 the celebrated Mr. Veller o\xe2\x80\x99 the Bell Savage. The family name depends\r\nwery much upon you, Samivel, and I hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll do wot\xe2\x80\x99s right by it.\r\nUpon all little pints o\xe2\x80\x99 breedin\xe2\x80\x99, I know I may trust you as vell as if\r\nit was my own self. So I\xe2\x80\x99ve only this here one little bit of adwice to\r\ngive you. If ever you gets to up\xe2\x80\x99ards o\xe2\x80\x99 fifty, and feels disposed to go\r\na-marryin\xe2\x80\x99 anybody--no matter who--jist you shut yourself up in your own\r\nroom, if you\xe2\x80\x99ve got one, and pison yourself off hand. Hangin\xe2\x80\x99s wulgar,\r\nso don\xe2\x80\x99t you have nothin\xe2\x80\x99 to say to that. Pison yourself, Samivel, my\r\nboy, pison yourself, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll be glad on it arterwards.\xe2\x80\x99 With these\r\naffecting words, Mr. Weller looked steadfastly on his son, and turning\r\nslowly upon his heel, disappeared from his sight.\r\n\r\nIn the contemplative mood which these words had awakened, Mr. Samuel\r\nWeller walked forth from the Great White Horse when his father had left\r\nhim; and bending his steps towards St. Clement\xe2\x80\x99s Church, endeavoured to\r\ndissipate his melancholy, by strolling among its ancient precincts. He\r\nhad loitered about, for some time, when he found himself in a retired\r\nspot--a kind of courtyard of venerable appearance--which he discovered\r\nhad no other outlet than the turning by which he had entered. He was\r\nabout retracing his steps, when he was suddenly transfixed to the spot\r\nby a sudden appearance; and the mode and manner of this appearance, we\r\nnow proceed to relate.\r\n\r\nMr. Samuel Weller had been staring up at the old brick houses now and\r\nthen, in his deep abstraction, bestowing a wink upon some healthy-\r\nlooking servant girl as she drew up a blind, or threw open a bedroom\r\nwindow, when the green gate of a garden at the bottom of the yard\r\nopened, and a man having emerged therefrom, closed the green gate very\r\ncarefully after him, and walked briskly towards the very spot where Mr.\r\nWeller was standing.\r\n\r\nNow, taking this, as an isolated fact, unaccompanied by any attendant\r\ncircumstances, there was nothing very extraordinary in it; because in\r\nmany parts of the world men do come out of gardens, close green gates\r\nafter them, and even walk briskly away, without attracting any\r\nparticular share of public observation. It is clear, therefore, that\r\nthere must have been something in the man, or in his manner, or both, to\r\nattract Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s particular notice. Whether there was, or not, we\r\nmust leave the reader to determine, when we have faithfully recorded the\r\nbehaviour of the individual in question.\r\n\r\nWhen the man had shut the green gate after him, he walked, as we have\r\nsaid twice already, with a brisk pace up the courtyard; but he no sooner\r\ncaught sight of Mr. Weller than he faltered, and stopped, as if\r\nuncertain, for the moment, what course to adopt. As the green gate was\r\nclosed behind him, and there was no other outlet but the one in front,\r\nhowever, he was not long in perceiving that he must pass Mr. Samuel\r\nWeller to get away. He therefore resumed his brisk pace, and advanced,\r\nstaring straight before him. The most extraordinary thing about the man\r\nwas, that he was contorting his face into the most fearful and\r\nastonishing grimaces that ever were beheld. Nature\xe2\x80\x99s handiwork never was\r\ndisguised with such extraordinary artificial carving, as the man had\r\noverlaid his countenance with in one moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller to himself, as the man approached. \xe2\x80\x98This is wery\r\nodd. I could ha\xe2\x80\x99 swore it was him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nUp came the man, and his face became more frightfully distorted than\r\never, as he drew nearer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I could take my oath to that \xe2\x80\x98ere black hair and mulberry suit,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98only I never see such a face as that afore.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Mr. Weller said this, the man\xe2\x80\x99s features assumed an unearthly twinge,\r\nperfectly hideous. He was obliged to pass very near Sam, however, and\r\nthe scrutinising glance of that gentleman enabled him to detect, under\r\nall these appalling twists of feature, something too like the small eyes\r\nof Mr. Job Trotter to be easily mistaken.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hollo, you Sir!\xe2\x80\x99 shouted Sam fiercely.\r\n\r\nThe stranger stopped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hollo!\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Sam, still more gruffly.\r\n\r\nThe man with the horrible face looked, with the greatest surprise, up\r\nthe court, and down the court, and in at the windows of the houses--\r\neverywhere but at Sam Weller--and took another step forward, when he was\r\nbrought to again by another shout.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hollo, you sir!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, for the third time.\r\n\r\nThere was no pretending to mistake where the voice came from now, so the\r\nstranger, having no other resource, at last looked Sam Weller full in\r\nthe face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It won\xe2\x80\x99t do, Job Trotter,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Come! None o\xe2\x80\x99 that \xe2\x80\x98ere nonsense.\r\nYou ain\xe2\x80\x99t so wery \xe2\x80\x98andsome that you can afford to throw avay many o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nyour good looks. Bring them \xe2\x80\x98ere eyes o\xe2\x80\x99 yourn back into their proper\r\nplaces, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll knock \xe2\x80\x98em out of your head. D\xe2\x80\x99ye hear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Mr. Weller appeared fully disposed to act up to the spirit of this\r\naddress, Mr. Trotter gradually allowed his face to resume its natural\r\nexpression; and then giving a start of joy, exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x98What do I see?\r\nMr. Walker!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re wery glad to see me, ain\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Glad!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Job Trotter; \xe2\x80\x98Oh, Mr. Walker, if you had but known how\r\nI have looked forward to this meeting! It is too much, Mr. Walker; I\r\ncannot bear it, indeed I cannot.\xe2\x80\x99 And with these words, Mr. Trotter\r\nburst into a regular inundation of tears, and, flinging his arms around\r\nthose of Mr. Weller, embraced him closely, in an ecstasy of joy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Get off!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Sam, indignant at this process, and vainly endeavouring\r\nto extricate himself from the grasp of his enthusiastic acquaintance.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Get off, I tell you. What are you crying over me for, you portable\r\nengine?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because I am so glad to see you,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job Trotter, gradually\r\nreleasing Mr. Weller, as the first symptoms of his pugnacity\r\ndisappeared. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, Mr. Walker, this is too much.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Too much!\xe2\x80\x99 echoed Sam, \xe2\x80\x98I think it is too much--rayther! Now, what have\r\nyou got to say to me, eh?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Trotter made no reply; for the little pink pocket-handkerchief was\r\nin full force.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What have you got to say to me, afore I knock your head off?\xe2\x80\x99 repeated\r\nMr. Weller, in a threatening manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Trotter, with a look of virtuous surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What have you got to say to me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I, Mr. Walker!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t call me Valker; my name\xe2\x80\x99s Veller; you know that vell enough. What\r\nhave you got to say to me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless you, Mr. Walker--Weller, I mean--a great many things, if you will\r\ncome away somewhere, where we can talk comfortably. If you knew how I\r\nhave looked for you, Mr. Weller--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery hard, indeed, I s\xe2\x80\x99pose?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam drily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very, very, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Trotter, without moving a muscle of his\r\nface. \xe2\x80\x98But shake hands, Mr. Weller.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSam eyed his companion for a few seconds, and then, as if actuated by a\r\nsudden impulse, complied with his request.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job Trotter, as they walked away, \xe2\x80\x98how is your dear, good\r\nmaster? Oh, he is a worthy gentleman, Mr. Weller! I hope he didn\xe2\x80\x99t catch\r\ncold, that dreadful night, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was a momentary look of deep slyness in Job Trotter\xe2\x80\x99s eye, as he\r\nsaid this, which ran a thrill through Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s clenched fist, as he\r\nburned with a desire to make a demonstration on his ribs. Sam\r\nconstrained himself, however, and replied that his master was extremely\r\nwell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I am so glad,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Trotter; \xe2\x80\x98is he here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is yourn?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Sam, by way of reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, yes, he is here, and I grieve to say, Mr. Weller, he is going on\r\nworse than ever.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, shocking--terrible!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At a boarding-school?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, not at a boarding-school,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job Trotter, with the same sly\r\nlook which Sam had noticed before; \xe2\x80\x98not at a boarding-school.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At the house with the green gate?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, eyeing his companion\r\nclosely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no--oh, not there,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job, with a quickness very unusual to\r\nhim, \xe2\x80\x98not there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What was you a-doin\xe2\x80\x99 there?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Sam, with a sharp glance. \xe2\x80\x98Got\r\ninside the gate by accident, perhaps?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job, \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind telling you my little\r\nsecrets, because, you know, we took such a fancy for each other when we\r\nfirst met. You recollect how pleasant we were that morning?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, impatiently. \xe2\x80\x98I remember. Well?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job, speaking with great precision, and in the low tone\r\nof a man who communicates an important secret; \xe2\x80\x98in that house with the\r\ngreen gate, Mr. Weller, they keep a good many servants.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So I should think, from the look on it,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Mr. Trotter, \xe2\x80\x98and one of them is a cook, who has saved\r\nup a little money, Mr. Weller, and is desirous, if she can establish\r\nherself in life, to open a little shop in the chandlery way, you see.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nYes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Mr. Weller. Well, Sir, I met her at a chapel that I go to; a very\r\nneat little chapel in this town, Mr. Weller, where they sing the number\r\nfour collection of hymns, which I generally carry about with me, in a\r\nlittle book, which you may perhaps have seen in my hand--and I got a\r\nlittle intimate with her, Mr. Weller, and from that, an acquaintance\r\nsprung up between us, and I may venture to say, Mr. Weller, that I am to\r\nbe the chandler.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, and a wery amiable chandler you\xe2\x80\x99ll make,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam, eyeing Job\r\nwith a side look of intense dislike.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The great advantage of this, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Job, his eyes\r\nfilling with tears as he spoke, \xe2\x80\x98will be, that I shall be able to leave\r\nmy present disgraceful service with that bad man, and to devote myself\r\nto a better and more virtuous life; more like the way in which I was\r\nbrought up, Mr. Weller.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You must ha\xe2\x80\x99 been wery nicely brought up,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, very, Mr. Weller, very,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job. At the recollection of the\r\npurity of his youthful days, Mr. Trotter pulled forth the pink\r\nhandkerchief, and wept copiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You must ha\xe2\x80\x99 been an uncommon nice boy, to go to school vith,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nSam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job, heaving a deep sigh; \xe2\x80\x98I was the idol of the\r\nplace.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t wonder at it. What a comfort you must ha\xe2\x80\x99 been\r\nto your blessed mother.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt these words, Mr. Job Trotter inserted an end of the pink handkerchief\r\ninto the corner of each eye, one after the other, and began to weep\r\ncopiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with the man,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, indignantly. \xe2\x80\x98Chelsea water-\r\nworks is nothin\xe2\x80\x99 to you. What are you melting vith now? The\r\nconsciousness o\xe2\x80\x99 willainy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I cannot keep my feelings down, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job, after a short\r\npause. \xe2\x80\x98To think that my master should have suspected the conversation I\r\nhad with yours, and so dragged me away in a post-chaise, and after\r\npersuading the sweet young lady to say she knew nothing of him, and\r\nbribing the school-mistress to do the same, deserted her for a better\r\nspeculation! Oh! Mr. Weller, it makes me shudder.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, that was the vay, was it?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be sure it was,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vell,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, as they had now arrived near the hotel, \xe2\x80\x98I vant to\r\nhave a little bit o\xe2\x80\x99 talk with you, Job; so if you\xe2\x80\x99re not partickler\r\nengaged, I should like to see you at the Great White Horse to-night,\r\nsomewheres about eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall be sure to come,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, you\xe2\x80\x99d better,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam, with a very meaning look, \xe2\x80\x98or else I\r\nshall perhaps be askin\xe2\x80\x99 arter you, at the other side of the green gate,\r\nand then I might cut you out, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall be sure to be with you, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Trotter; and wringing\r\nSam\xe2\x80\x99s hand with the utmost fervour, he walked away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take care, Job Trotter, take care,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, looking after him, \xe2\x80\x98or I\r\nshall be one too many for you this time. I shall, indeed.\xe2\x80\x99 Having\r\nuttered this soliloquy, and looked after Job till he was to be seen no\r\nmore, Mr. Weller made the best of his way to his master\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s all in training, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s in training, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve found \xe2\x80\x98em out, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Found out who?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That \xe2\x80\x98ere queer customer, and the melan-cholly chap with the black\r\nhair.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Impossible, Sam!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with the greatest energy. \xe2\x80\x98Where\r\nare they, Sam: where are they?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hush, hush!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller; and as he assisted Mr. Pickwick to\r\ndress, he detailed the plan of action on which he proposed to enter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But when is this to be done, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All in good time, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\nWhether it was done in good time, or not, will be seen hereafter.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIV. WHEREIN MR. PETER MAGNUS GROWS JEALOUS, AND THE MIDDLE-\r\nAGED LADY APPREHENSIVE, WHICH BRINGS THE PICKWICKIANS WITHIN THE GRASP\r\nOF THE LAW\r\n\r\nWhen Mr. Pickwick descended to the room in which he and Mr. Peter Magnus\r\nhad spent the preceding evening, he found that gentleman with the major\r\npart of the contents of the two bags, the leathern hat-box, and the\r\nbrown-paper parcel, displaying to all possible advantage on his person,\r\nwhile he himself was pacing up and down the room in a state of the\r\nutmost excitement and agitation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-morning, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Peter Magnus. \xe2\x80\x98What do you think of this,\r\nSir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very effective indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, surveying the garments of\r\nMr. Peter Magnus with a good-natured smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I think it\xe2\x80\x99ll do,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Magnus. \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pickwick, Sir, I have\r\nsent up my card.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And the waiter brought back word, that she would see me at eleven--at\r\neleven, Sir; it only wants a quarter now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very near the time,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, it is rather near,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Magnus, \xe2\x80\x98rather too near to be\r\npleasant--eh! Mr. Pickwick, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Confidence is a great thing in these cases,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I believe it is, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Peter Magnus. \xe2\x80\x98I am very confident,\r\nSir. Really, Mr. Pickwick, I do not see why a man should feel any fear\r\nin such a case as this, sir. What is it, Sir? There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing to be\r\nashamed of; it\xe2\x80\x99s a matter of mutual accommodation, nothing more. Husband\r\non one side, wife on the other. That\xe2\x80\x99s my view of the matter, Mr.\r\nPickwick.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is a very philosophical one,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98But breakfast\r\nis waiting, Mr. Magnus. Come.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDown they sat to breakfast, but it was evident, notwithstanding the\r\nboasting of Mr. Peter Magnus, that he laboured under a very considerable\r\ndegree of nervousness, of which loss of appetite, a propensity to upset\r\nthe tea-things, a spectral attempt at drollery, and an irresistible\r\ninclination to look at the clock, every other second, were among the\r\nprincipal symptoms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He-he-he,\xe2\x80\x99 tittered Mr. Magnus, affecting cheerfulness, and gasping\r\nwith agitation. \xe2\x80\x98It only wants two minutes, Mr. Pickwick. Am I pale,\r\nSir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not very,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\nThere was a brief pause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon, Mr. Pickwick; but have you ever done this sort of\r\nthing in your time?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Magnus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You mean proposing?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with great energy, \xe2\x80\x98never.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have no idea, then, how it\xe2\x80\x99s best to begin?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Magnus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98I may have formed some ideas upon the\r\nsubject, but, as I have never submitted them to the test of experience,\r\nI should be sorry if you were induced to regulate your proceedings by\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should feel very much obliged to you, for any advice, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nMagnus, taking another look at the clock, the hand of which was verging\r\non the five minutes past.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with the profound solemnity with which\r\nthat great man could, when he pleased, render his remarks so deeply\r\nimpressive. \xe2\x80\x98I should commence, sir, with a tribute to the lady\xe2\x80\x99s beauty\r\nand excellent qualities; from them, Sir, I should diverge to my own\r\nunworthiness.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Magnus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Unworthiness for _her _only, mind, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98for to\r\nshow that I was not wholly unworthy, sir, I should take a brief review\r\nof my past life, and present condition. I should argue, by analogy, that\r\nto anybody else, I must be a very desirable object. We merely record the\r\nfact that Mr. Pickwick opened the room door, and abruptly called out,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tupman, come here!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Tupman immediately presented himself, with a look of very\r\nconsiderable surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tupman,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98a secret of some delicacy, in which that\r\nlady is concerned, is the cause of a difference which has just arisen\r\nbetween this gentleman and myself. Consequently, instead of receiving Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nexplanation as he ought to have done, he forthwith proceeded to work\r\nhimself into a red-hot, scorching, consuming passion, and to talk about\r\nwhat was due to his own feelings, and all that sort of thing; adding\r\nforce to his declamation by striding to and fro, and pulling his hair--\r\namusements which he would vary occasionally, by shaking his fist in Mr.\r\nPickwick\xe2\x80\x99s philanthropic countenance.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick, in his turn, conscious of his own innocence and rectitude,\r\nand irritated by having unfortunately involved the middle-aged lady in\r\nsuch an unpleasant affair, was not so quietly disposed as was his wont.\r\nThe consequence was, that words ran high, and voices higher; and at\r\nlength Mr. Magnus told Mr. Pickwick he should hear from him; to which\r\nMr. Pickwick replied, with laudable politeness, that the sooner he heard\r\nfrom him the better; whereupon the middle-aged lady rushed in terror\r\nfrom the room, out of which Mr. Tupman dragged Mr. Pickwick, leaving Mr.\r\nPeter Magnus to himself and meditation.\r\n\r\nIf the middle-aged lady had mingled much with the busy world, or had\r\nprofited at all by the manners and customs of those who make the laws\r\nand set the fashions, she would have known that this sort of ferocity is\r\nthe most harmless thing in nature; but as she had lived for the most\r\npart in the country, and never read the parliamentary debates, she was\r\nlittle versed in these particular refinements of civilised life.\r\nAccordingly, when she had gained her bedchamber, bolted herself in, and\r\nbegan to meditate on the scene she had just witnessed, the most terrific\r\npictures of slaughter and destruction presented themselves to her\r\nimagination; among which, a full-length portrait of Mr. Peter Magnus\r\nborne home by four men, with the embellishment of a whole barrelful of\r\nbullets in his left side, was among the very least. The more the middle-\r\naged lady meditated, the more terrified she became; and at length she\r\ndetermined to repair to the house of the principal magistrate of the\r\ntown, and request him to secure the persons of Mr. Pickwick and Mr.\r\nTupman without delay.\r\n\r\nTo this decision the middle-aged lady was impelled by a variety of\r\nconsiderations, the chief of which was the incontestable proof it would\r\nafford of her devotion to Mr. Peter Magnus, and her anxiety for his\r\nsafety. She was too well acquainted with his jealous temperament to\r\nventure the slightest allusion to the real cause of her agitation on\r\nbeholding Mr. Pickwick; and she trusted to her own influence and power\r\nof persuasion with the little man, to quell his boisterous jealousy,\r\nsupposing that Mr. Pickwick were removed, and no fresh quarrel could\r\narise. Filled with these reflections, the middle-aged lady arrayed\r\nherself in her bonnet and shawl, and repaired to the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s dwelling\r\nstraightway.\r\n\r\nNow George Nupkins, Esquire, the principal magistrate aforesaid, was as\r\ngrand a personage as the fastest walker would find out, between sunrise\r\nand sunset, on the twenty-first of June, which being, according to the\r\nalmanacs, the longest day in the whole year, would naturally afford him\r\nthe longest period for his search. On this particular morning, Mr.\r\nNupkins was in a state of the utmost excitement and irritation, for\r\nthere had been a rebellion in the town; all the day-scholars at the\r\nlargest day-school had conspired to break the windows of an obnoxious\r\napple-seller, and had hooted the beadle and pelted the constabulary--an\r\nelderly gentleman in top-boots, who had been called out to repress the\r\ntumult, and who had been a peace-officer, man and boy, for half a\r\ncentury at least. and, being ordered\r\nto take the lady\xe2\x80\x99s information, shambled to a seat, and proceeded to\r\nwrite it down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This man, Pickwick, is the principal, I understand?\xe2\x80\x99 said the\r\nmagistrate, when the statement was finished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is,\xe2\x80\x99 said the middle-aged lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And the other rioter--what\xe2\x80\x99s his name, Mr. Jinks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tupman, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nTupman is the second?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The other principal, you say, has absconded, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Miss Witherfield, with a short cough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate. \xe2\x80\x98These are two cut-throats from\r\nLondon, who have come down here to destroy his Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s population,\r\nthinking that at this distance from the capital, the arm of the law is\r\nweak and paralysed. They shall be made an example of. Draw up the\r\nwarrants, Mr. Jinks. Muzzle!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, your Worship.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is Grummer downstairs?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, your Worship.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Send him up.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe obsequious Muzzle retired, and presently returned, introducing the\r\nelderly gentleman in the top-boots, who was chiefly remarkable for a\r\nbottle-nose, a hoarse voice, a snuff-coloured surtout, and a wandering\r\neye.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Grummer,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your Wash-up.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is the town quiet now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pretty well, your Wash-up,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Grummer. \xe2\x80\x98Pop\xe2\x80\x99lar feeling has in a\r\nmeasure subsided, consekens o\xe2\x80\x99 the boys having dispersed to cricket.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing but vigorous measures will do in these times, Grummer,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nthe magistrate, in a determined manner. \xe2\x80\x98If the authority of the king\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nofficers is set at naught, we must have the riot act read. If the civil\r\npower cannot protect these windows, Grummer, the military must protect\r\nthe civil power, and the windows too. I believe that is a maxim of the\r\nconstitution, Mr. Jinks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCertainly, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jinks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate, signing the warrants. \xe2\x80\x98Grummer, you\r\nwill bring these persons before me, this afternoon. You will find them\r\nat the Great White Horse. You recollect the case of the Middlesex\r\nDumpling and the Suffolk Bantam, Grummer?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Grummer intimated, by a retrospective shake of the head, that he\r\nshould never forget it--as indeed it was not likely he would, so long as\r\nit continued to be cited daily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is even more unconstitutional,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate; \xe2\x80\x98this is even\r\na greater breach of the peace, and a grosser infringement of his\r\nMajesty\xe2\x80\x99s prerogative. I believe duelling is one of his Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s most\r\nundoubted prerogatives, Mr. Jinks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Expressly stipulated in Magna Charta, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Jinks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98One of the brightest jewels in the British crown, wrung from his\r\nMajesty by the barons, I believe, Mr. Jinks?\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just so, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Jinks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate, drawing himself up proudly, \xe2\x80\x98it shall\r\nnot be violated in this portion of his dominions. Grummer, procure\r\nassistance, and execute these warrants with as little delay as possible.\r\nMuzzle!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, your Worship.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Show the lady out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMiss Witherfield retired, deeply impressed with the magistrate\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlearning and research; Mr. Nupkins retired to lunch; Mr. Jinks retired\r\nwithin himself--that being the only retirement he had, except the sofa-\r\nbedstead in the small parlour which was occupied by his landlady\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfamily in the daytime--and Mr. Grummer retired, to wipe out, by his mode\r\nof discharging his present commission, the insult which had been\r\nfastened upon himself, and the other representative of his Majesty--the\r\nbeadle--in the course of the morning.\r\n\r\nWhile these resolute and determined preparations for the conservation of\r\nthe king\xe2\x80\x99s peace were pending, Mr. Pickwick and his friends, wholly\r\nunconscious of the mighty events in progress, had sat quietly down to\r\ndinner; and very talkative and companionable they all were. Mr. Pickwick\r\nwas in the very act of relating his adventure of the preceding night, to\r\nthe great amusement of his followers, Mr. Tupman especially, when the\r\ndoor opened, and a somewhat forbidding countenance peeped into the room.\r\nThe eyes in the forbidding countenance looked very earnestly at Mr.\r\nPickwick, for several seconds, and were to all appearance satisfied with\r\ntheir investigation; for the body to which the forbidding countenance\r\nbelonged, slowly brought itself into the apartment, and presented the\r\nform of an elderly individual in top-boots--not to keep the reader any\r\nlonger in suspense, in short, the eyes were the wandering eyes of Mr.\r\nGrummer, and the body was the body of the same gentleman.\r\n\r\nMr. Grummer\xe2\x80\x99s mode of proceeding was professional, but peculiar. His\r\nfirst act was to bolt the door on the inside; his second, to polish his\r\nhead and countenance very carefully with a cotton handkerchief; his\r\nthird, to place his hat, with the cotton handkerchief in it, on the\r\nnearest chair; and his fourth, to produce from the breast-pocket of his\r\ncoat a short truncheon, surmounted by a brazen crown, with which he\r\nbeckoned to Mr. Pickwick with a grave and ghost-like air.\r\n\r\nMr. Snodgrass was the first to break the astonished silence. He looked\r\nsteadily at Mr. Grummer for a brief space, and then said emphatically,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is a private room, Sir. A private room.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Grummer shook his head, and replied, \xe2\x80\x98No room\xe2\x80\x99s private to his\r\nMajesty when the street door\xe2\x80\x99s once passed. That\xe2\x80\x99s law. Some people\r\nmaintains that an Englishman\xe2\x80\x99s house is his castle. That\xe2\x80\x99s gammon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe Pickwickians gazed on each other with wondering eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which is Mr. Tupman?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Grummer. He had an intuitive\r\nperception of Mr. Pickwick; he knew him at once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My name\xe2\x80\x99s Tupman,\xe2\x80\x99 said that gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My name\xe2\x80\x99s Law,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Grummer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Law,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Grummer--\xe2\x80\x98Law, civil power, and exekative; them\xe2\x80\x99s my\r\ntitles; here\xe2\x80\x99s my authority. Blank Tupman, blank Pickwick--against the\r\npeace of our sufferin\xe2\x80\x99 lord the king--stattit in the case made and\r\npurwided--and all regular. I apprehend you Pickwick! Tupman--the\r\naforesaid.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean by this insolence?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman, starting up;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98leave the room!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hollo,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Grummer, retreating very expeditiously to the door,\r\nand opening it an inch or two, \xe2\x80\x98Dubbley.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said a deep voice from the passage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come for\xe2\x80\x99ard, Dubbley.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt the word of command, a dirty-faced man, something over six feet high,\r\nand stout in proportion, squeezed himself through the half-open door\r\n(making his face very red in the process), and entered the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is the other specials outside, Dubbley?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Grummer.\r\n\r\nMr. Dubbley, who was a man of few words, nodded assent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Order in the diwision under your charge, Dubbley,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Grummer.\r\n\r\nMr. Dubbley did as he was desired; and half a dozen men, each with a\r\nshort truncheon and a brass crown, flocked into the room. Mr. Grummer\r\npocketed his staff, and looked at Mr. Dubbley; Mr. Dubbley pocketed his\r\nstaff and looked at the division; the division pocketed their staves and\r\nlooked at Messrs. Tupman and Pickwick.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick and his followers rose as one man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is the meaning of this atrocious intrusion upon my privacy?\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who dares apprehend me?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you want here, scoundrels?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Snodgrass.\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle said nothing, but he fixed his eyes on Grummer, and bestowed\r\na look upon him, which, if he had had any feeling, must have pierced his\r\nbrain. As it was, however, it had no visible effect on him whatever.\r\n\r\nWhen the executive perceived that Mr. Pickwick and his friends were\r\ndisposed to resist the authority of the law, they very significantly\r\nturned up their coat sleeves, as if knocking them down in the first\r\ninstance, and taking them up afterwards, were a mere professional act\r\nwhich had only to be thought of to be done, as a matter of course. This\r\ndemonstration was not lost upon Mr. Pickwick. He conferred a few moments\r\nwith Mr. Tupman apart, and then signified his readiness to proceed to\r\nthe mayor\xe2\x80\x99s residence, merely begging the parties then and there\r\nassembled, to take notice, that it was his firm intention to resent this\r\nmonstrous invasion of his privileges as an Englishman, the instant he\r\nwas at liberty; whereat the parties then and there assembled laughed\r\nvery heartily, with the single exception of Mr. Grummer, who seemed to\r\nconsider that any slight cast upon the divine right of magistrates was a\r\nspecies of blasphemy not to be tolerated.\r\n\r\nBut when Mr. Pickwick had signified his readiness to bow to the laws of\r\nhis country, and just when the waiters, and hostlers, and chambermaids,\r\nand post-boys, who had anticipated a delightful commotion from his\r\nthreatened obstinacy, began to turn away, disappointed and disgusted, a\r\ndifficulty arose which had not been foreseen. With every sentiment of\r\nveneration for the constituted authorities, Mr. Pickwick resolutely\r\nprotested against making his appearance in the public streets,\r\nsurrounded and guarded by the officers of justice, like a common\r\ncriminal. Mr. Grummer, in the then disturbed state of public feeling\r\n(for it was half-holiday, and the boys had not yet gone home), as\r\nresolutely protested against walking on the opposite side of the way,\r\nand taking Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s parole that he would go straight to the\r\nmagistrate\xe2\x80\x99s; and both Mr. Pickwick and Mr. Tupman as strenuously\r\nobjected to the expense of a post-coach, which was the only respectable\r\nconveyance that could be obtained. The dispute ran high, and the dilemma\r\nlasted long; and just as the executive were on the point of overcoming\r\nMr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s objection to walking to the magistrate\xe2\x80\x99s, by the trite\r\nexpedient of carrying him thither, it was recollected that there stood\r\nin the inn yard, an old sedan-chair, which, having been originally built\r\nfor a gouty gentleman with funded property, would hold Mr. Pickwick and\r\nMr. Tupman, at least as conveniently as a modern post-chaise. The chair\r\nwas hired, and brought into the hall; Mr. Pickwick and Mr. Tupman\r\nsqueezed themselves inside, and pulled down the blinds; a couple of\r\nchairmen were speedily found; and the procession started in grand order.\r\nThe specials surrounded the body of the vehicle; Mr. Grummer and Mr.\r\nDubbley marched triumphantly in front; Mr. Snodgrass and Mr. Winkle\r\nwalked arm-in-arm behind; and the unsoaped of Ipswich brought up the\r\nrear.\r\n\r\nThe shopkeepers of the town, although they had a very indistinct notion\r\nof the nature of the offence, could not but be much edified and\r\ngratified by this spectacle. Here was the strong arm of the law, coming\r\ndown with twenty gold-beater force, upon two offenders from the\r\nmetropolis itself; the mighty engine was directed by their own\r\nmagistrate, and worked by their own officers; and both the criminals, by\r\ntheir united efforts, were securely shut up, in the narrow compass of\r\none sedan-chair. Many were the expressions of approval and admiration\r\nwhich greeted Mr. Grummer, as he headed the cavalcade, staff in hand;\r\nloud and long were the shouts raised by the unsoaped; and amidst these\r\nunited testimonials of public approbation, the procession moved slowly\r\nand majestically along.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller, habited in his morning jacket, with the black calico\r\nsleeves, was returning in a rather desponding state from an unsuccessful\r\nsurvey of the mysterious house with the green gate, when, raising his\r\neyes, he beheld a crowd pouring down the street, surrounding an object\r\nwhich had very much the appearance of a sedan-chair.
