Willing to divert\r\nhis thoughts from the failure of his enterprise, he stepped aside to see\r\nthe crowd pass; and finding that they were cheering away, very much to\r\ntheir own satisfaction, forthwith began (by way of raising his spirits)\r\nto cheer too, with all his might and main.\r\n\r\nMr. Grummer passed, and Mr. Dubbley passed, and the sedan passed, and\r\nthe bodyguard of specials passed, and Sam was still responding to the\r\nenthusiastic cheers of the mob, and waving his hat about as if he were\r\nin the very last extreme of the wildest joy (though, of course, he had\r\nnot the faintest idea of the matter in hand), when he was suddenly\r\nstopped by the unexpected appearance of Mr. Winkle and Mr. Snodgrass.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the row, gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n? \xe2\x80\x99cried Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Who have they got in this here\r\nwatch-box in mournin\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBoth gentlemen replied together, but their words were lost in the\r\ntumult.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who is it?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Sam again.\r\n\r\nOnce more was a joint reply returned; and, though the words were\r\ninaudible, Sam saw by the motion of the two pairs of lips that they had\r\nuttered the magic word \xe2\x80\x98Pickwick.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis was enough. In another minute Mr. Weller had made his way through\r\nthe crowd, stopped the chairmen, and confronted the portly Grummer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hollo, old gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Who have you got in this here\r\nconweyance?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stand back,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Grummer, whose dignity, like the dignity of a\r\ngreat many other men, had been wondrously augmented by a little\r\npopularity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Knock him down, if he don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Dubbley.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m wery much obliged to you, old gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam, \xe2\x80\x98for\r\nconsulting my conwenience, and I\xe2\x80\x99m still more obliged to the other\r\ngen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n, who looks as if he\xe2\x80\x99d just escaped from a giant\xe2\x80\x99s carrywan,\r\nfor his wery \xe2\x80\x98andsome suggestion; but I should prefer your givin\xe2\x80\x99 me a\r\nanswer to my question, if it\xe2\x80\x99s all the same to you.--How are you, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\nThis last observation was addressed with a patronising air to Mr.\r\nPickwick, who was peeping through the front window.\r\n\r\nMr. Grummer, perfectly speechless with indignation, dragged the\r\ntruncheon with the brass crown from its particular pocket, and\r\nflourished it before Sam\xe2\x80\x99s eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s wery pretty, \xe2\x80\x98specially the crown, which is\r\nuncommon like the real one.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stand back!\xe2\x80\x99 said the outraged Mr. Grummer. By way of adding force to\r\nthe command, he thrust the brass emblem of royalty into Sam\xe2\x80\x99s neckcloth\r\nwith one hand, and seized Sam\xe2\x80\x99s collar with the other--a compliment\r\nwhich Mr. Weller returned by knocking him down out of hand, having\r\npreviously with the utmost consideration, knocked down a chairman for\r\nhim to lie upon.\r\n\r\nWhether Mr. Winkle was seized with a temporary attack of that species of\r\ninsanity which originates in a sense of injury, or animated by this\r\ndisplay of Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s valour, is uncertain; but certain it is, that he\r\nno sooner saw Mr. Grummer fall than he made a terrific onslaught on a\r\nsmall boy who stood next him; whereupon Mr. Snodgrass, in a truly\r\nChristian spirit, and in order that he might take no one unawares,\r\nannounced in a very loud tone that he was going to begin, and proceeded\r\nto take off his coat with the utmost deliberation. He was immediately\r\nsurrounded and secured; and it is but common justice both to him and Mr.\r\nWinkle to say, that they did not make the slightest attempt to rescue\r\neither themselves or Mr. Weller; who, after a most vigorous resistance,\r\nwas overpowered by numbers and taken prisoner. The procession then\r\nreformed; the chairmen resumed their stations; and the march was re-\r\ncommenced.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s indignation during the whole of this proceeding was\r\nbeyond all bounds. He could just see Sam upsetting the specials, and\r\nflying about in every direction; and that was all he could see, for the\r\nsedan doors wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t open, and the blinds wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t pull up. At length,\r\nwith the assistance of Mr. Tupman, he managed to push open the roof; and\r\nmounting on the seat, and steadying himself as well as he could, by\r\nplacing his hand on that gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder, Mr. Pickwick proceeded to\r\naddress the multitude; to dwell upon the unjustifiable manner in which\r\nhe had been treated; and to call upon them to take notice that his\r\nservant had been first assaulted. In this order they reached the\r\nmagistrate\xe2\x80\x99s house; the chairmen trotting, the prisoners following, Mr.\r\nPickwick oratorising, and the crowd shouting.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXV. SHOWING, AMONG A VARIETY OF PLEASANT MATTERS, HOW MAJESTIC\r\nAND IMPARTIAL MR. NUPKINS WAS; AND HOW MR. WELLER RETURNED MR. JOB\r\nTROTTER\xe2\x80\x99S SHUTTLECOCK AS HEAVILY AS IT CAME--WITH ANOTHER MATTER, WHICH\r\nWILL BE FOUND IN ITS PLACE\r\n\r\nViolent was Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s indignation as he was borne along; numerous\r\nwere the allusions to the personal appearance and demeanour of Mr.\r\nGrummer and his companion; and valorous were the defiances to any six of\r\nthe gentlemen present, in which he vented his dissatisfaction. Mr.\r\nSnodgrass and Mr. Winkle listened with gloomy respect to the torrent of\r\neloquence which their leader poured forth from the sedan-chair, and the\r\nrapid course of which not all Mr. Tupman\xe2\x80\x99s earnest entreaties to have\r\nthe lid of the vehicle closed, were able to check for an instant. But\r\nMr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s anger quickly gave way to curiosity when the procession\r\nturned down the identical courtyard in which he had met with the runaway\r\nJob Trotter; and curiosity was exchanged for a feeling of the most\r\ngleeful astonishment, when the all-important Mr. Grummer, commanding the\r\nsedan-bearers to halt, advanced with dignified and portentous steps to\r\nthe very green gate from which Job Trotter had emerged, and gave a\r\nmighty pull at the bell-handle which hung at the side thereof. The ring\r\nwas answered by a very smart and pretty-faced servant-girl, who, after\r\nholding up her hands in astonishment at the rebellious appearance of the\r\nprisoners, and the impassioned language of Mr. Pickwick, summoned Mr.\r\nMuzzle. Mr. Muzzle opened one half of the carriage gate, to admit the\r\nsedan, the captured ones, and the specials; and immediately slammed it\r\nin the faces of the mob, who, indignant at being excluded, and anxious\r\nto see what followed, relieved their feelings by kicking at the gate and\r\nringing the bell, for an hour or two afterwards. In this amusement they\r\nall took part by turns, except three or four fortunate individuals, who,\r\nhaving discovered a grating in the gate, which commanded a view of\r\nnothing, stared through it with the indefatigable perseverance with\r\nwhich people will flatten their noses against the front windows of a\r\nchemist\xe2\x80\x99s shop, when a drunken man, who has been run over by a dog-cart\r\nin the street, is undergoing a surgical inspection in the back-parlour.\r\n\r\nAt the foot of a flight of steps, leading to the house door, which was\r\nguarded on either side by an American aloe in a green tub, the sedan-\r\nchair stopped. Mr. Pickwick and his friends were conducted into the\r\nhall, whence, having been previously announced by Muzzle, and ordered in\r\nby Mr. Nupkins, they were ushered into the worshipful presence of that\r\npublic-spirited officer.\r\n\r\nThe scene was an impressive one, well calculated to strike terror to the\r\nhearts of culprits, and to impress them with an adequate idea of the\r\nstern majesty of the law. In front of a big book-case, in a big chair,\r\nbehind a big table, and before a big volume, sat Mr. Nupkins, looking a\r\nfull size larger than any one of them, big as they were. The table was\r\nadorned with piles of papers; and above the farther end of it, appeared\r\nthe head and shoulders of Mr. Jinks, who was busily engaged in looking\r\nas busy as possible. The party having all entered, Muzzle carefully\r\nclosed the door, and placed himself behind his master\xe2\x80\x99s chair to await\r\nhis orders. Mr. Nupkins threw himself back with thrilling solemnity, and\r\nscrutinised the faces of his unwilling visitors.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Grummer, who is that person?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins, pointing to Mr.\r\nPickwick, who, as the spokesman of his friends, stood hat in hand,\r\nbowing with the utmost politeness and respect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This here\xe2\x80\x99s Pickvick, your Wash-up,\xe2\x80\x99 said Grummer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, none o\xe2\x80\x99 that \xe2\x80\x98ere, old Strike-a-light,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Weller,\r\nelbowing himself into the front rank. \xe2\x80\x98Beg your pardon, sir, but this\r\nhere officer o\xe2\x80\x99 yourn in the gambooge tops, \xe2\x80\x98ull never earn a decent\r\nlivin\xe2\x80\x99 as a master o\xe2\x80\x99 the ceremonies any vere. This here, sir\xe2\x80\x99 continued\r\nMr. Weller, thrusting Grummer aside, and addressing the magistrate with\r\npleasant familiarity, \xe2\x80\x98this here is S. Pickvick, Esquire; this here\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nMr. Tupman; that \xe2\x80\x98ere\xe2\x80\x99s Mr. Snodgrass; and farder on, next him on the\r\nt\xe2\x80\x99other side, Mr. Winkle--all wery nice gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n, Sir, as you\xe2\x80\x99ll be\r\nwery happy to have the acquaintance on; so the sooner you commits these\r\nhere officers o\xe2\x80\x99 yourn to the tread-mill for a month or two, the sooner\r\nwe shall begin to be on a pleasant understanding. Business first,\r\npleasure arterwards, as King Richard the Third said when he stabbed the\r\nt\xe2\x80\x99other king in the Tower, afore he smothered the babbies.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt the conclusion of this address, Mr. Weller brushed his hat with his\r\nright elbow, and nodded benignly to Jinks, who had heard him throughout\r\nwith unspeakable awe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who is this man, Grummer?\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery desp\xe2\x80\x99rate ch\xe2\x80\x99racter, your Wash-up,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Grummer. \xe2\x80\x98He attempted\r\nto rescue the prisoners, and assaulted the officers; so we took him into\r\ncustody, and brought him here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You did quite right,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the magistrate. \xe2\x80\x98He is evidently a\r\ndesperate ruffian.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is my servant, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick angrily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! he is your servant, is he?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins. \xe2\x80\x98A conspiracy to\r\ndefeat the ends of justice, and murder its officers. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s servant.\r\nPut that down, Mr. Jinks.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Jinks did so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s your name, fellow?\xe2\x80\x99 thundered Mr. Nupkins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Veller,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A very good name for the Newgate Calendar,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins.\r\n\r\nThis was a joke; so Jinks, Grummer, Dubbley, all the specials, and\r\nMuzzle, went into fits of laughter of five minutes\xe2\x80\x99 duration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Put down his name, Mr. Jinks,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Two L\xe2\x80\x99s, old feller,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\nHere an unfortunate special laughed again, whereupon the magistrate\r\nthreatened to commit him instantly. It is a dangerous thing to laugh at\r\nthe wrong man, in these cases.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where do you live?\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vere ever I can,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Put down that, Mr. Jinks,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate, who was fast rising\r\ninto a rage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Score it under,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is a vagabond, Mr. Jinks,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate. \xe2\x80\x98He is a vagabond on\r\nhis own statement,--is he not, Mr. Jinks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I\xe2\x80\x99ll commit him--I\xe2\x80\x99ll commit him as such,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is a wery impartial country for justice, \xe2\x80\x98said Sam.\xe2\x80\x99 There ain\xe2\x80\x99t a\r\nmagistrate goin\xe2\x80\x99 as don\xe2\x80\x99t commit himself twice as he commits other\r\npeople.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt this sally another special laughed, and then tried to look so\r\nsupernaturally solemn, that the magistrate detected him immediately.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Grummer,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins, reddening with passion, \xe2\x80\x98how dare you\r\nselect such an inefficient and disreputable person for a special\r\nconstable, as that man? How dare you do it, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am very sorry, your Wash-up,\xe2\x80\x99 stammered Grummer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very sorry!\xe2\x80\x99 said the furious magistrate. \xe2\x80\x98You shall repent of this\r\nneglect of duty, Mr. Grummer; you shall be made an example of. Take that\r\nfellow\xe2\x80\x99s staff away. He\xe2\x80\x99s drunk. You\xe2\x80\x99re drunk, fellow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not drunk, your Worship,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You _are _drunk,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the magistrate. \xe2\x80\x98How dare you say you are\r\nnot drunk, Sir, when I say you are? Doesn\xe2\x80\x99t he smell of spirits,\r\nGrummer?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Horrid, your Wash-up,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Grummer, who had a vague impression that\r\nthere was a smell of rum somewhere.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I knew he did,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins. \xe2\x80\x98I saw he was drunk when he first\r\ncame into the room, by his excited eye. Did you observe his excited eye,\r\nMr. Jinks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I haven\xe2\x80\x99t touched a drop of spirits this morning,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man, who\r\nwas as sober a fellow as need be.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How dare you tell me a falsehood?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins. \xe2\x80\x98Isn\xe2\x80\x99t he drunk at\r\nthis moment, Mr. Jinks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jinks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Jinks,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate, \xe2\x80\x98I shall commit that man for contempt.\r\nMake out his committal, Mr. Jinks.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAnd committed the special would have been, only Jinks, who was the\r\nmagistrate\xe2\x80\x99s adviser (having had a legal education of three years in a\r\ncountry attorney\xe2\x80\x99s office), whispered the magistrate that he thought it\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do; so the magistrate made a speech, and said, that in\r\nconsideration of the special\xe2\x80\x99s family, he would merely reprimand and\r\ndischarge him. Accordingly, the special was abused, vehemently, for a\r\nquarter of an hour, and sent about his business; and Grummer, Dubbley,\r\nMuzzle, and all the other specials, murmured their admiration of the\r\nmagnanimity of Mr. Nupkins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Mr. Jinks,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate, \xe2\x80\x98swear Grummer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGrummer was sworn directly; but as Grummer wandered, and Mr. Nupkins\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndinner was nearly ready, Mr. Nupkins cut the matter short, by putting\r\nleading questions to Grummer, which Grummer answered as nearly in the\r\naffirmative as he could. So the examination went off, all very smooth\r\nand comfortable, and two assaults were proved against Mr. Weller, and a\r\nthreat against Mr. Winkle, and a push against Mr. Snodgrass. When all\r\nthis was done to the magistrate\xe2\x80\x99s satisfaction, the magistrate and Mr.\r\nJinks consulted in whispers.\r\n\r\nThe consultation having lasted about ten minutes, Mr. Jinks retired to\r\nhis end of the table; and the magistrate, with a preparatory cough, drew\r\nhimself up in his chair, and was proceeding to commence his address,\r\nwhen Mr. Pickwick interposed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon, sir, for interrupting you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98but\r\nbefore you proceed to express, and act upon, any opinion you may have\r\nformed on the statements which have been made here, I must claim my\r\nright to be heard so far as I am personally concerned.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hold your tongue, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate peremptorily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must submit to you, Sir--\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hold your tongue, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed the magistrate, \xe2\x80\x98or I shall order an\r\nofficer to remove you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You may order your officers to do whatever you please, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nPickwick; \xe2\x80\x98and I have no doubt, from the specimen I have had of the\r\nsubordination preserved amongst them, that whatever you order, they will\r\nexecute, Sir; but I shall take the liberty, Sir, of claiming my right to\r\nbe heard, until I am removed by force.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pickvick and principle!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Weller, in a very audible voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam, be quiet,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dumb as a drum vith a hole in it, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\nMr. Nupkins looked at Mr. Pickwick with a gaze of intense astonishment,\r\nat his displaying such unwonted temerity; and was apparently about to\r\nreturn a very angry reply, when Mr. Jinks pulled him by the sleeve, and\r\nwhispered something in his ear. To this, the magistrate returned a half-\r\naudible answer, and then the whispering was renewed. Jinks was evidently\r\nremonstrating.\r\n\r\nAt length the magistrate, gulping down, with a very bad grace, his\r\ndisinclination to hear anything more, turned to Mr. Pickwick, and said\r\nsharply, \xe2\x80\x98What do you want to say?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98First,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, sending a look through his spectacles, under\r\nwhich even Nupkins quailed, \xe2\x80\x98first, I wish to know what I and my friend\r\nhave been brought here for?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Must I tell him?\xe2\x80\x99 whispered the magistrate to Jinks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think you had better, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Jinks to the magistrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98An information has been sworn before me,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate, \xe2\x80\x98that it\r\nis apprehended you are going to fight a duel, and that the other man,\r\nTupman, is your aider and abettor in it. Therefore--eh, Mr. Jinks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Therefore, I call upon you both, to--I think that\xe2\x80\x99s the course, Mr.\r\nJinks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To--to--what, Mr. Jinks?\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate pettishly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To find bail, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. Therefore, I call upon you both--as I was about to say when I was\r\ninterrupted by my clerk--to find bail.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGood bail,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Mr. Jinks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall require good bail,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Town\xe2\x80\x99s-people,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Jinks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They must be townspeople,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fifty pounds each,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Jinks, \xe2\x80\x98and householders, of course.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall require two sureties of fifty pounds each,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate\r\naloud, with great dignity, \xe2\x80\x98and they must be householders, of course.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But bless my heart, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, who, together with Mr.\r\nTupman, was all amazement and indignation; \xe2\x80\x98we are perfect strangers in\r\nthis town. I have as little knowledge of any householders here, as I\r\nhave intention of fighting a duel with anybody.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I dare say,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the magistrate, \xe2\x80\x98I dare say--don\xe2\x80\x99t you, Mr.\r\nJinks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you anything more to say?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the magistrate.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick had a great deal more to say, which he would no doubt have\r\nsaid, very little to his own advantage, or the magistrate\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsatisfaction, if he had not, the moment he ceased speaking, been pulled\r\nby the sleeve by Mr. Weller, with whom he was immediately engaged in so\r\nearnest a conversation, that he suffered the magistrate\xe2\x80\x99s inquiry to\r\npass wholly unnoticed. Mr. Nupkins was not the man to ask a question of\r\nthe kind twice over; and so, with another preparatory cough, he\r\nproceeded, amidst the reverential and admiring silence of the\r\nconstables, to pronounce his decision.\r\n\r\nHe should fine Weller two pounds for the first assault, and three pounds\r\nfor the second. He should fine Winkle two pounds, and Snodgrass one\r\npound, besides requiring them to enter into their own recognisances to\r\nkeep the peace towards all his Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s subjects, and especially\r\ntowards his liege servant, Daniel Grummer. Pickwick and Tupman he had\r\nalready held to bail.\r\n\r\nImmediately on the magistrate ceasing to speak, Mr. Pickwick, with a\r\nsmile mantling on his again good-humoured countenance, stepped forward,\r\nand said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg the magistrate\xe2\x80\x99s pardon, but may I request a few minutes\xe2\x80\x99 private\r\nconversation with him, on a matter of deep importance to himself?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What?\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate. Mr. Pickwick repeated his request.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is a most extraordinary request,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate. \xe2\x80\x98A private\r\ninterview?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A private interview,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick firmly; \xe2\x80\x98only, as a part of\r\nthe information which I wish to communicate is derived from my servant,\r\nI should wish him to be present.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe magistrate looked at Mr. Jinks; Mr. Jinks looked at the magistrate;\r\nthe officers looked at each other in amazement. Mr. Nupkins turned\r\nsuddenly pale. Could the man Weller, in a moment of remorse, have\r\ndivulged some secret conspiracy for his assassination? It was a dreadful\r\nthought. He was a public man; and he turned paler, as he thought of\r\nJulius Caesar and Mr. Perceval.\r\n\r\nThe magistrate looked at Mr. Pickwick again, and beckoned Mr. Jinks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you think of this request, Mr. Jinks?\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Mr. Nupkins.\r\n\r\nMr. Jinks, who didn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly know what to think of it, and was afraid\r\nhe might offend, smiled feebly, after a dubious fashion, and, screwing\r\nup the corners of his mouth, shook his head slowly from side to side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Jinks,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate gravely, \xe2\x80\x98you are an ass.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt this little expression of opinion, Mr. Jinks smiled again--rather\r\nmore feebly than before--and edged himself, by degrees, back into his\r\nown corner.\r\n\r\nMr. Nupkins debated the matter within himself for a few seconds, and\r\nthen, rising from his chair, and requesting Mr. Pickwick and Sam to\r\nfollow him, led the way into a small room which opened into the justice-\r\nparlour. Desiring Mr. Pickwick to walk to the upper end of the little\r\napartment, and holding his hand upon the half-closed door, that he might\r\nbe able to effect an immediate escape, in case there was the least\r\ntendency to a display of hostilities, Mr. Nupkins expressed his\r\nreadiness to hear the communication, whatever it might be.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will come to the point at once, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98it affects\r\nyourself and your credit materially. I have every reason to believe,\r\nSir, that you are harbouring in your house a gross impostor!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Two,\xe2\x80\x99 interrupted Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Mulberry agin all natur, for tears and\r\nwillainny!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98if I am to render myself intelligible to this\r\ngentleman, I must beg you to control your feelings.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery sorry, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98but when I think o\xe2\x80\x99 that \xe2\x80\x98ere\r\nJob, I can\xe2\x80\x99t help opening the walve a inch or two.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In one word, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98is my servant right in\r\nsuspecting that a certain Captain Fitz-Marshall is in the habit of\r\nvisiting here? Because,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr. Pickwick, as he saw that Mr. Nupkins\r\nwas about to offer a very indignant interruption, \xe2\x80\x98because if he be, I\r\nknow that person to be a--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hush, hush,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins, closing the door. \xe2\x80\x98Know him to be what,\r\nSir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98An unprincipled adventurer--a dishonourable character--a man who preys\r\nupon society, and makes easily-deceived people his dupes, Sir; his\r\nabsurd, his foolish, his wretched dupes, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the excited Mr.\r\nPickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins, turning very red, and altering his whole\r\nmanner directly. \xe2\x80\x98Dear me, Mr.--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pickvick,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pickwick,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate, \xe2\x80\x98dear me, Mr. Pickwick--pray take a\r\nseat--you cannot mean this? Captain Fitz-Marshall!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t call him a cap\xe2\x80\x99en,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98nor Fitz-Marshall neither; he\r\nain\xe2\x80\x99t neither one nor t\xe2\x80\x99other. He\xe2\x80\x99s a strolling actor, he is, and his\r\nname\xe2\x80\x99s Jingle; and if ever there was a wolf in a mulberry suit, that\r\n\xe2\x80\x98ere Job Trotter\xe2\x80\x99s him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is very true, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, replying to the magistrate\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlook of amazement; \xe2\x80\x98my only business in this town, is to expose the\r\nperson of whom we now speak.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick proceeded to pour into the horror-stricken ear of Mr.\r\nNupkins, an abridged account of all Mr. Jingle\xe2\x80\x99s atrocities. He related\r\nhow he had first met him; how he had eloped with Miss Wardle; how he had\r\ncheerfully resigned the lady for a pecuniary consideration; how he had\r\nentrapped himself into a lady\xe2\x80\x99s boarding-school at midnight; and how he\r\n(Mr. Pickwick) now felt it his duty to expose his assumption of his\r\npresent name and rank.\r\n\r\nAs the narrative proceeded, all the warm blood in the body of Mr.\r\nNupkins tingled up into the very tips of his ears. He had picked up the\r\ncaptain at a neighbouring race-course. Charmed with his long list of\r\naristocratic acquaintance, his extensive travel, and his fashionable\r\ndemeanour, Mrs. Nupkins and Miss Nupkins had exhibited Captain Fitz-\r\nMarshall, and quoted Captain Fitz-Marshall, and hurled Captain Fitz-\r\nMarshall at the devoted heads of their select circle of acquaintance,\r\nuntil their bosom friends, Mrs. Porkenham and the Misses Porkenhams, and\r\nMr. Sidney Porkenham, were ready to burst with jealousy and despair. And\r\nnow, to hear, after all, that he was a needy adventurer, a strolling\r\nplayer, and if not a swindler, something so very like it, that it was\r\nhard to tell the difference! Heavens! what would the Porkenhams say!\r\nWhat would be the triumph of Mr. Sidney Porkenham when he found that his\r\naddresses had been slighted for such a rival! How should he, Nupkins,\r\nmeet the eye of old Porkenham at the next quarter-sessions! And what a\r\nhandle would it be for the opposition magisterial party if the story got\r\nabroad!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But after all,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins, brightening for a moment, after a\r\nlong pause; \xe2\x80\x98after all, this is a mere statement. Captain Fitz-Marshall\r\nis a man of very engaging manners, and, I dare say, has many enemies.\r\nWhat proof have you of the truth of these representations?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Confront me with him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98that is all I ask, and all I\r\nrequire. Confront him with me and my friends here; you will want no\r\nfurther proof.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins, \xe2\x80\x98that might be very easily done, for he will be\r\nhere to-night, and then there would be no occasion to make the matter\r\npublic, just--just--for the young man\xe2\x80\x99s own sake, you know. I--I--should\r\nlike to consult Mrs. Nupkins on the propriety of the step, in the first\r\ninstance, though. At all events, Mr. Pickwick, we must despatch this\r\nlegal business before we can do anything else. Pray step back into the\r\nnext room.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nInto the next room they went.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Grummer,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate, in an awful voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your Wash-up,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Grummer, with the smile of a favourite.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, come, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate sternly, \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t let me see any of\r\nthis levity here. It is very unbecoming, and I can assure you that you\r\nhave very little to smile at. Was the account you gave me just now\r\nstrictly true? Now be careful, sir!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nYour Wash-up,\xe2\x80\x99 stammered Grummer, \xe2\x80\x98I-\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, you are confused, are you?\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate. \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Jinks, you\r\nobserve this confusion?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jinks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now,\xe2\x80\x99 said the magistrate, \xe2\x80\x98repeat your statement, Grummer, and again I\r\nwarn you to be careful. Mr. Jinks, take his words down.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe unfortunate Grummer proceeded to re-state his complaint, but, what\r\nbetween Mr. Jinks\xe2\x80\x99s taking down his words, and the magistrate\xe2\x80\x99s taking\r\nthem up, his natural tendency to rambling, and his extreme confusion, he\r\nmanaged to get involved, in something under three minutes, in such a\r\nmass of entanglement and contradiction, that Mr. Nupkins at once\r\ndeclared he didn\xe2\x80\x99t believe him. So the fines were remitted, and Mr.\r\nJinks found a couple of bail in no time. And all these solemn\r\nproceedings having been satisfactorily concluded, Mr. Grummer was\r\nignominiously ordered out--an awful instance of the instability of human\r\ngreatness, and the uncertain tenure of great men\xe2\x80\x99s favour.\r\n\r\nMrs. Nupkins was a majestic female in a pink gauze turban and a light\r\nbrown wig. Miss Nupkins possessed all her mamma\xe2\x80\x99s haughtiness without\r\nthe turban, and all her ill-nature without the wig; and whenever the\r\nexercise of these two amiable qualities involved mother and daughter in\r\nsome unpleasant dilemma, as they not infrequently did, they both\r\nconcurred in laying the blame on the shoulders of Mr. Nupkins.\r\nAccordingly, when Mr. Nupkins sought Mrs. Nupkins, and detailed the\r\ncommunication which had been made by Mr. Pickwick, Mrs. Nupkins suddenly\r\nrecollected that she had always expected something of the kind; that she\r\nhad always said it would be so; that her advice was never taken; that\r\nshe really did not know what Mr. Nupkins supposed she was; and so forth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The idea!\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Nupkins, forcing a tear of very scanty proportions\r\ninto the corner of each eye; \xe2\x80\x98the idea of my being made such a fool of!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! you may thank your papa, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Nupkins; \xe2\x80\x98how I have\r\nimplored and begged that man to inquire into the captain\xe2\x80\x99s family\r\nconnections; how I have urged and entreated him to take some decisive\r\nstep! I am quite certain nobody would believe it--quite.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t talk to me, you aggravating thing, don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Nupkins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My love,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins, \xe2\x80\x98you professed yourself very fond of\r\nCaptain Fitz-Marshall. You have constantly asked him here, my dear, and\r\nyou have lost no opportunity of introducing him elsewhere.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I say so, Henrietta?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mrs. Nupkins, appealing to her\r\ndaughter with the air of a much-injured female. \xe2\x80\x98Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I say that your\r\npapa would turn round and lay all this at my door? Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I say so?\xe2\x80\x99\r\nHere Mrs. Nupkins sobbed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, pa!\xe2\x80\x99 remonstrated Miss Nupkins. And here she sobbed too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it too much, when he has brought all this disgrace and ridicule\r\nupon us, to taunt me with being the cause of it?\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mrs.\r\nNupkins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How can we ever show ourselves in society!\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Nupkins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How can we face the Porkenhams?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mrs. Nupkins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Or the Griggs!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Miss Nupkins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Or the Slummintowkens!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mrs. Nupkins. \xe2\x80\x98But what does your papa\r\ncare! What is it to _him_!\xe2\x80\x99 At this dreadful reflection, Mrs. Nupkins\r\nwept mental anguish, and Miss Nupkins followed on the same side.\r\n\r\nMrs. Nupkins\xe2\x80\x99s tears continued to gush forth, with great velocity, until\r\nshe had gained a little time to think the matter over; when she decided,\r\nin her own mind, that the best thing to do would be to ask Mr. Pickwick\r\nand his friends to remain until the captain\xe2\x80\x99s arrival, and then to give\r\nMr. Pickwick the opportunity he sought. If it appeared that he had\r\nspoken truly, the captain could be turned out of the house without\r\nnoising the matter abroad, and they could easily account to the\r\nPorkenhams for his disappearance, by saying that he had been appointed,\r\nthrough the Court influence of his family, to the governor-generalship\r\nof Sierra Leone, of Saugur Point, or any other of those salubrious\r\nclimates which enchant Europeans so much, that when they once get there,\r\nthey can hardly ever prevail upon themselves to come back again.\r\n\r\nWhen Mrs. Nupkins dried up her tears, Miss Nupkins dried up hers, and\r\nMr. Nupkins was very glad to settle the matter as Mrs. Nupkins had\r\nproposed. So Mr. Pickwick and his friends, having washed off all marks\r\nof their late encounter, were introduced to the ladies, and soon\r\nafterwards to their dinner; and Mr. Weller, whom the magistrate, with\r\nhis peculiar sagacity, had discovered in half an hour to be one of the\r\nfinest fellows alive, was consigned to the care and guardianship of Mr.\r\nMuzzle, who was specially enjoined to take him below, and make much of\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How de do, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Muzzle, as he conducted Mr. Weller down the\r\nkitchen stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, no considerable change has taken place in the state of my system,\r\nsince I see you cocked up behind your governor\xe2\x80\x99s chair in the parlour, a\r\nlittle vile ago,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will excuse my not taking more notice of you then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nMuzzle. \xe2\x80\x98You see, master hadn\xe2\x80\x99t introduced us, then. Lord, how fond he\r\nis of you, Mr. Weller, to be sure!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98what a pleasant chap he is!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ain\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Muzzle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So much humour,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And such a man to speak,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Muzzle. \xe2\x80\x98How his ideas flow, don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthey?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wonderful,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam; \xe2\x80\x98they comes a-pouring out, knocking each\r\nother\xe2\x80\x99s heads so fast, that they seems to stun one another; you hardly\r\nknow what he\xe2\x80\x99s arter, do you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s the great merit of his style of speaking,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Muzzle.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take care of the last step, Mr. Weller. Would you like to wash your\r\nhands, sir, before we join the ladies? Here\xe2\x80\x99s a sink, with the water\r\nlaid on, Sir, and a clean jack towel behind the door.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! perhaps I may as well have a rinse,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, applying\r\nplenty of yellow soap to the towel, and rubbing away till his face shone\r\nagain. \xe2\x80\x98How many ladies are there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only two in our kitchen,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Muzzle; \xe2\x80\x98cook and \xe2\x80\x98ouse-maid. We\r\nkeep a boy to do the dirty work, and a gal besides, but they dine in the\r\nwash\xe2\x80\x99us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, they dines in the wash\xe2\x80\x99us, do they?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Muzzle, \xe2\x80\x98we tried \xe2\x80\x98em at our table when they first\r\ncome, but we couldn\xe2\x80\x99t keep \xe2\x80\x98em. The gal\xe2\x80\x99s manners is dreadful vulgar;\r\nand the boy breathes so very hard while he\xe2\x80\x99s eating, that we found it\r\nimpossible to sit at table with him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Young grampus!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, dreadful,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Muzzle; \xe2\x80\x98but that is the worst of country\r\nservice, Mr. Weller; the juniors is always so very savage. This way,\r\nsir, if you please, this way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPreceding Mr. Weller, with the utmost politeness, Mr. Muzzle conducted\r\nhim into the kitchen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mary,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Muzzle to the pretty servant-girl, \xe2\x80\x98this is Mr. Weller;\r\na gentleman as master has sent down, to be made as comfortable as\r\npossible.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And your master\xe2\x80\x99s a knowin\xe2\x80\x99 hand, and has just sent me to the right\r\nplace,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, with a glance of admiration at Mary. \xe2\x80\x98If I wos\r\nmaster o\xe2\x80\x99 this here house, I should alvays find the materials for\r\ncomfort vere Mary wos.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLor, Mr. Weller!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary blushing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, I never!\xe2\x80\x99 ejaculated the cook.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless me, cook, I forgot you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Muzzle. \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Weller, let me\r\nintroduce you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How are you, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Wery glad to see you, indeed,\r\nand hope our acquaintance may be a long \xe2\x80\x98un, as the gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n said to\r\nthe fi\xe2\x80\x99 pun\xe2\x80\x99 note.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhen this ceremony of introduction had been gone through, the cook and\r\nMary retired into the back kitchen to titter, for ten minutes; then\r\nreturning, all giggles and blushes, they sat down to dinner.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s easy manners and conversational powers had such\r\nirresistible influence with his new friends, that before the dinner was\r\nhalf over, they were on a footing of perfect intimacy, and in possession\r\nof a full account of the delinquency of Job Trotter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never could a-bear that Job,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No more you never ought to, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why not?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Cos ugliness and svindlin\xe2\x80\x99 never ought to be formiliar with elegance\r\nand wirtew,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Ought they, Mr. Muzzle?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not by no means,\xe2\x80\x99 replied that gentleman.\r\n\r\n\r\nHere Mary laughed, and said the cook had made her; and the cook laughed,\r\nand said she hadn\xe2\x80\x99t.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I ha\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t got a glass,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Drink with me, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Put your lips to this here\r\ntumbler, and then I can kiss you by deputy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For shame, Mr. Weller!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s a shame, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Talkin\xe2\x80\x99 in that way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense; it ain\xe2\x80\x99t no harm. It\xe2\x80\x99s natur; ain\xe2\x80\x99t it, cook?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t ask me, imperence,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the cook, in a high state of delight;\r\nand hereupon the cook and Mary laughed again, till what between the\r\nbeer, and the cold meat, and the laughter combined, the latter young\r\nlady was brought to the verge of choking--an alarming crisis from which\r\nshe was only recovered by sundry pats on the back, and other necessary\r\nattentions, most delicately administered by Mr. Samuel Weller.\r\n\r\nIn the midst of all this jollity and conviviality, a loud ring was heard\r\nat the garden gate, to which the young gentleman who took his meals in\r\nthe wash-house, immediately responded. Mr. Weller was in the height of\r\nhis attentions to the pretty house-maid; Mr. Muzzle was busy doing the\r\nhonours of the table; and the cook had just paused to laugh, in the very\r\nact of raising a huge morsel to her lips; when the kitchen door opened,\r\nand in walked Mr. Job Trotter.\r\n\r\nWe have said in walked Mr. Job Trotter, but the statement is not\r\ndistinguished by our usual scrupulous adherence to fact. The door opened\r\nand Mr. Trotter appeared. He would have walked in, and was in the very\r\nact of doing so, indeed, when catching sight of Mr. Weller, he\r\ninvoluntarily shrank back a pace or two, and stood gazing on the\r\nunexpected scene before him, perfectly motionless with amazement and\r\nterror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here he is!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, rising with great glee. \xe2\x80\x98Why we were that wery\r\nmoment a-speaking o\xe2\x80\x99 you. How are you? Where have you been? Come in.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLaying his hand on the mulberry collar of the unresisting Job, Mr.\r\nWeller dragged him into the kitchen; and, locking the door, handed the\r\nkey to Mr. Muzzle, who very coolly buttoned it up in a side pocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, here\xe2\x80\x99s a game!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Only think o\xe2\x80\x99 my master havin\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\npleasure o\xe2\x80\x99 meeting yourn upstairs, and me havin\xe2\x80\x99 the joy o\xe2\x80\x99 meetin\xe2\x80\x99 you\r\ndown here. How are you gettin\xe2\x80\x99 on, and how is the chandlery bis\xe2\x80\x99ness\r\nlikely to do? Well, I am so glad to see you. How happy you look. It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nquite a treat to see you; ain\xe2\x80\x99t it, Mr. Muzzle?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Muzzle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So cheerful he is!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In such good spirits!\xe2\x80\x99 said Muzzle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And so glad to see us--that makes it so much more comfortable,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nSam. \xe2\x80\x98Sit down; sit down.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Trotter suffered himself to be forced into a chair by the fireside.\r\nHe cast his small eyes, first on Mr. Weller, and then on Mr. Muzzle, but\r\nsaid nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98afore these here ladies, I should jest like to\r\nask you, as a sort of curiosity, whether you don\xe2\x80\x99t consider yourself as\r\nnice and well-behaved a young gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n, as ever used a pink check\r\npocket-handkerchief, and the number four collection?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And as was ever a-going to be married to a cook,\xe2\x80\x99 said that lady\r\nindignantly. \xe2\x80\x98The willin!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And leave off his evil ways, and set up in the chandlery line\r\narterwards,\xe2\x80\x99 said the housemaid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what it is, young man,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Muzzle solemnly,\r\nenraged at the last two allusions, \xe2\x80\x98this here lady (pointing to the\r\ncook) keeps company with me; and when you presume, Sir, to talk of\r\nkeeping chandlers\xe2\x80\x99 shops with her, you injure me in one of the most\r\ndelicatest points in which one man can injure another. Do you understand\r\nthat, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere Mr. Muzzle, who had a great notion of his eloquence, in which he\r\nimitated his master, paused for a reply.\r\n\r\nBut Mr. Trotter made no reply. So Mr. Muzzle proceeded in a solemn\r\nmanner--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s very probable, sir, that you won\xe2\x80\x99t be wanted upstairs for several\r\nminutes, Sir, because _my_ master is at this moment particularly engaged\r\nin settling the hash of _your _master, Sir; and therefore you\xe2\x80\x99ll have\r\nleisure, Sir, for a little private talk with me, Sir. Do you understand\r\nthat, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Muzzle again paused for a reply; and again Mr. Trotter disappointed\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Muzzle, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m very sorry to have to explain myself\r\nbefore ladies, but the urgency of the case will be my excuse. The back\r\nkitchen\xe2\x80\x99s empty, Sir. If you will step in there, Sir, Mr. Weller will\r\nsee fair, and we can have mutual satisfaction till the bell rings.\r\nFollow me, Sir!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Mr. Muzzle uttered these words, he took a step or two towards the\r\ndoor; and, by way of saving time, began to pull off his coat as he\r\nwalked along.\r\n\r\nNow, the cook no sooner heard the concluding words of this desperate\r\nchallenge, and saw Mr. Muzzle about to put it into execution, than she\r\nuttered a loud and piercing shriek; and rushing on Mr. Job Trotter, who\r\nrose from his chair on the instant, tore and buffeted his large flat\r\nface, with an energy peculiar to excited females, and twining her hands\r\nin his long black hair, tore therefrom about enough to make five or six\r\ndozen of the very largest-sized mourning-rings. Having accomplished this\r\nfeat with all the ardour which her devoted love for Mr. Muzzle inspired,\r\nshe staggered back; and being a lady of very excitable and delicate\r\nfeelings, she instantly fell under the dresser, and fainted away.\r\n\r\nAt this moment, the bell rang.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s for you, Job Trotter,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam; and before Mr. Trotter could\r\noffer remonstrance or reply--even before he had time to stanch the\r\nwounds inflicted by the insensible lady--Sam seized one arm and Mr.\r\nMuzzle the other, and one pulling before, and the other pushing behind,\r\nthey conveyed him upstairs, and into the parlour.\r\n\r\nIt was an impressive tableau. Alfred Jingle, Esquire, alias Captain\r\nFitz-Marshall, was standing near the door with his hat in his hand, and\r\na smile on his face, wholly unmoved by his very unpleasant situation.\r\nConfronting him, stood Mr. Pickwick, who had evidently been inculcating\r\nsome high moral lesson; for his left hand was beneath his coat tail, and\r\nhis right extended in air, as was his wont when delivering himself of an\r\nimpressive address. At a little distance, stood Mr. Tupman with\r\nindignant countenance, carefully held back by his two younger friends;\r\nat the farther end of the room were Mr. Nupkins, Mrs. Nupkins, and Miss\r\nNupkins, gloomily grand and savagely vexed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What prevents me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins, with magisterial dignity, as Job\r\nwas brought in--\xe2\x80\x98what prevents me from detaining these men as rogues and\r\nimpostors? It is a foolish mercy. What prevents me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pride, old fellow, pride,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jingle, quite at his ease. \xe2\x80\x98Wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndo--no go--caught a captain, eh?--ha! ha! very good--husband for\r\ndaughter--biter bit--make it public--not for worlds--look stupid--very!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wretch,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins, \xe2\x80\x98we scorn your base insinuations.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I always hated him,\xe2\x80\x99 added Henrietta.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, of course,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jingle. \xe2\x80\x98Tall young man--old lover--Sidney\r\nPorkenham--rich--fine fellow--not so rich as captain, though, eh?--turn\r\nhim away--off with him--anything for captain--nothing like captain\r\nanywhere--all the girls--raving mad--eh, Job, eh?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere Mr. Jingle laughed very heartily; and Job, rubbing his hands with\r\ndelight, uttered the first sound he had given vent to since he entered\r\nthe house--a low, noiseless chuckle, which seemed to intimate that he\r\nenjoyed his laugh too much, to let any of it escape in sound.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Nupkins,\xe2\x80\x99 said the elder lady,\xe2\x80\x99 this is not a fit conversation for\r\nthe servants to overhear. Let these wretches be removed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 Said Mr. Nupkins. \xe2\x80\x98Muzzle!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your Worship.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Open the front door.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, your Worship.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Leave the house!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Nupkins, waving his hand emphatically.\r\n\r\nJingle smiled, and moved towards the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stay!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. Jingle stopped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I might,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98have taken a much greater revenge for the\r\ntreatment I have experienced at your hands, and that of your\r\nhypocritical friend there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJob Trotter bowed with great politeness, and laid his hand upon his\r\nheart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, growing gradually angry, \xe2\x80\x98that I might have\r\ntaken a greater revenge, but I content myself with exposing you, which I\r\nconsider a duty I owe to society. This is a leniency, Sir, which I hope\r\nyou will remember.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhen Mr. Pickwick arrived at this point, Job Trotter, with facetious\r\ngravity, applied his hand to his ear, as if desirous not to lose a\r\nsyllable he uttered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I have only to add, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, now thoroughly angry,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98that I consider you a rascal, and a--a--ruffian--and--and worse than\r\nany man I ever saw, or heard of, except that pious and sanctified\r\nvagabond in the mulberry livery.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x99 said Jingle, \xe2\x80\x98good fellow, Pickwick--fine heart--stout old\r\nboy--but must _not _be passionate--bad thing, very--bye, bye--see you\r\nagain some day--keep up your spirits--now, Job--trot!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith these words, Mr. Jingle stuck on his hat in his old fashion, and\r\nstrode out of the room. Job Trotter paused, looked round, smiled and\r\nthen with a bow of mock solemnity to Mr. Pickwick, and a wink to Mr.\r\nWeller, the audacious slyness of which baffles all description, followed\r\nthe footsteps of his hopeful master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, as Mr. Weller was following.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nStay here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller seemed uncertain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stay here,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mayn\xe2\x80\x99t I polish that \xe2\x80\x98ere Job off, in the front garden?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nWeller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly not,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mayn\xe2\x80\x99t I kick him out o\xe2\x80\x99 the gate, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not on any account,\xe2\x80\x99 replied his master.\r\n\r\nFor the first time since his engagement, Mr. Weller looked, for a\r\nmoment, discontented and unhappy. But his countenance immediately\r\ncleared up; for the wily Mr. Muzzle, by concealing himself behind the\r\nstreet door, and rushing violently out, at the right instant, contrived\r\nwith great dexterity to overturn both Mr. Jingle and his attendant, down\r\nthe flight of steps, into the American aloe tubs that stood beneath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Having discharged my duty, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick to Mr. Nupkins, \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nwill, with my friends, bid you farewell. While we thank you for such\r\nhospitality as we have received, permit me to assure you, in our joint\r\nnames, that we should not have accepted it, or have consented to\r\nextricate ourselves in this way, from our previous dilemma, had we not\r\nbeen impelled by a strong sense of duty. We return to London to-morrow.\r\nYour secret is safe with us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHaving thus entered his protest against their treatment of the morning,\r\nMr. Pickwick bowed low to the ladies, and notwithstanding the\r\nsolicitations of the family, left the room with his friends.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Get your hat, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s below stairs, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, and he ran down after it.\r\n\r\nNow, there was nobody in the kitchen, but the pretty housemaid; and as\r\nSam\xe2\x80\x99s hat was mislaid, he had to look for it, and the pretty housemaid\r\nlighted him. They had to look all over the place for the hat. The pretty\r\nhousemaid, in her anxiety to find it, went down on her knees, and turned\r\nover all the things that were heaped together in a little corner by the\r\ndoor. It was an awkward corner. You couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get at it without shutting\r\nthe door first.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here it is,\xe2\x80\x99 said the pretty housemaid. \xe2\x80\x98This is it, ain\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let me look,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\nThe pretty housemaid had stood the candle on the floor; and, as it gave\r\na very dim light, Sam was obliged to go down on _his _knees before he\r\ncould see whether it really was his own hat or not. It was a remarkably\r\nsmall corner, and so--it was nobody\xe2\x80\x99s fault but the man\xe2\x80\x99s who built the\r\nhouse--Sam and the pretty housemaid were necessarily very close\r\ntogether.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, this is it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Good-bye!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-bye!\xe2\x80\x99 said the pretty housemaid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-bye!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam; and as he said it, he dropped the hat that had\r\ncost so much trouble in looking for.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How awkward you are,\xe2\x80\x99 said the pretty housemaid. \xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ll lose it again,\r\nif you don\xe2\x80\x99t take care.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo just to prevent his losing it again, she put it on for him.\r\n\r\nWhether it was that the pretty housemaid\xe2\x80\x99s face looked prettier still,\r\nwhen it was raised towards Sam\xe2\x80\x99s, or whether it was the accidental\r\nconsequence of their being so near to each other, is matter of\r\nuncertainty to this day; but Sam kissed her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to say you did that on purpose,\xe2\x80\x99 said the pretty\r\nhousemaid, blushing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam; \xe2\x80\x98but I will now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo he kissed her again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, calling over the banisters.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Coming, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam, running upstairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How long you have been!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There was something behind the door, Sir, which perwented our getting\r\nit open, for ever so long, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\nAnd this was the first passage of Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s first love.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVI. WHICH CONTAINS A BRIEF ACCOUNT OF THE PROGRESS OF THE\r\nACTION OF BARDELL AGAINST PICKWICK\r\n\r\nHaving accomplished the main end and object of his journey, by the\r\nexposure of Jingle, Mr. Pickwick resolved on immediately returning to\r\nLondon, with the view of becoming acquainted with the proceedings which\r\nhad been taken against him, in the meantime, by Messrs. Dodson and Fogg.\r\nActing upon this resolution with all the energy and decision of his\r\ncharacter, he mounted to the back seat of the first coach which left\r\nIpswich on the morning after the memorable occurrences detailed at\r\nlength in the two preceding chapters; and accompanied by his three\r\nfriends, and Mr. Samuel Weller, arrived in the metropolis, in perfect\r\nhealth and safety, the same evening.\r\n\r\nHere the friends, for a short time, separated. Messrs. Tupman, Winkle,\r\nand Snodgrass repaired to their several homes to make such preparations\r\nas might be requisite for their forthcoming visit to Dingley Dell; and\r\nMr. Pickwick and Sam took up their present abode in very good, old-\r\nfashioned, and comfortable quarters, to wit, the George and Vulture\r\nTavern and Hotel, George Yard, Lombard Street.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick had dined, finished his second pint of particular port,\r\npulled his silk handkerchief over his head, put his feet on the fender,\r\nand thrown himself back in an easy-chair, when the entrance of Mr.\r\nWeller with his carpet-bag, aroused him from his tranquil meditation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have just been thinking, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98that having left a\r\ngood many things at Mrs. Bardell\xe2\x80\x99s, in Goswell Street, I ought to\r\narrange for taking them away, before I leave town again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery good, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I could send them to Mr. Tupman\xe2\x80\x99s, for the present, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Mr.\r\nPickwick, \xe2\x80\x98but before we take them away, it is necessary that they\r\nshould be looked up, and put together. I wish you would step up to\r\nGoswell Street, Sam, and arrange about it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At once, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At once,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98And stay, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr. Pickwick,\r\npulling out his purse, \xe2\x80\x98there is some rent to pay. The quarter is not\r\ndue till Christmas, but you may pay it, and have done with it. A month\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnotice terminates my tenancy. Here it is, written out. Give it, and tell\r\nMrs. Bardell she may put a bill up, as soon as she likes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery good, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98anythin\xe2\x80\x99 more, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing more, Sam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller stepped slowly to the door, as if he expected something more;\r\nslowly opened it, slowly stepped out, and had slowly closed it within a\r\ncouple of inches, when Mr. Pickwick called out--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, stepping quickly back, and closing the door\r\nbehind him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have no objection, Sam, to your endeavouring to ascertain how Mrs.\r\nBardell herself seems disposed towards me, and whether it is really\r\nprobable that this vile and groundless action is to be carried to\r\nextremity. I say I do not object to you doing this, if you wish it,\r\nSam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\nSam gave a short nod of intelligence, and left the room. Mr. Pickwick\r\ndrew the silk handkerchief once more over his head, And composed himself\r\nfor a nap. Mr. Weller promptly walked forth, to execute his commission.\r\n\r\nIt was nearly nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock when he reached Goswell Street. A couple of\r\ncandles were burning in the little front parlour, and a couple of caps\r\nwere reflected on the window-blind. Mrs. Bardell had got company.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller knocked at the door, and after a pretty long interval--\r\noccupied by the party without, in whistling a tune, and by the party\r\nwithin, in persuading a refractory flat candle to allow itself to be\r\nlighted--a pair of small boots pattered over the floor-cloth, and Master\r\nBardell presented himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, young townskip,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98how\xe2\x80\x99s mother?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She\xe2\x80\x99s pretty well,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Master Bardell, \xe2\x80\x98so am I.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, that\xe2\x80\x99s a mercy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam; \xe2\x80\x98tell her I want to speak to her, will\r\nyou, my hinfant fernomenon?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMaster Bardell, thus adjured, placed the refractory flat candle on the\r\nbottom stair, and vanished into the front parlour with his message.\r\n\r\nThe two caps, reflected on the window-blind, were the respective head-\r\ndresses of a couple of Mrs. Bardell\xe2\x80\x99s most particular acquaintance, who\r\nhad just stepped in, to have a quiet cup of tea, and a little warm\r\nsupper of a couple of sets of pettitoes and some toasted cheese. The\r\ncheese was simmering and browning away, most delightfully, in a little\r\nDutch oven before the fire; the pettitoes were getting on deliciously in\r\na little tin saucepan on the hob; and Mrs. Bardell and her two friends\r\nwere getting on very well, also, in a little quiet conversation about\r\nand concerning all their particular friends and acquaintance; when\r\nMaster Bardell came back from answering the door, and delivered the\r\nmessage intrusted to him by Mr. Samuel Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s servant!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell, turning pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless my soul!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Cluppins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, I raly would not ha\xe2\x80\x99 believed it, unless I had ha\xe2\x80\x99 happened to\r\nha\xe2\x80\x99 been here!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Sanders.\r\n\r\nMrs. Cluppins was a little, brisk, busy-looking woman; Mrs. Sanders was\r\na big, fat, heavy-faced personage; and the two were the company.\r\n\r\nMrs. Bardell felt it proper to be agitated; and as none of the three\r\nexactly knew whether under existing circumstances, any communication,\r\notherwise than through Dodson & Fogg, ought to be held with Mr.\r\nPickwick\xe2\x80\x99s servant, they were all rather taken by surprise. In this\r\nstate of indecision, obviously the first thing to be done, was to thump\r\nthe boy for finding Mr. Weller at the door. So his mother thumped him,\r\nand he cried melodiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hold your noise--do--you naughty creetur!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; don\xe2\x80\x99t worrit your poor mother,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Sanders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She\xe2\x80\x99s quite enough to worrit her, as it is, without you, Tommy,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMrs. Cluppins, with sympathising resignation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! worse luck, poor lamb!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Sanders.\r\n\r\nAt all which moral reflections, Master Bardell howled the louder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, what shall I do?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell to Mrs. Cluppins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think you ought to see him,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs. Cluppins. \xe2\x80\x98But on no\r\naccount without a witness.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think two witnesses would be more lawful,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Sanders, who,\r\nlike the other friend, was bursting with curiosity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps he\xe2\x80\x99d better come in here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be sure,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs. Cluppins, eagerly catching at the idea; \xe2\x80\x98walk\r\nin, young man; and shut the street door first, please.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller immediately took the hint; and presenting himself in the\r\nparlour, explained his business to Mrs. Bardell thus--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery sorry to \xe2\x80\x98casion any personal inconwenience, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, as the\r\nhousebreaker said to the old lady when he put her on the fire; but as me\r\nand my governor \xe2\x80\x98s only jest come to town, and is jest going away agin,\r\nit can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped, you see.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course, the young man can\xe2\x80\x99t help the faults of his master,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMrs. Cluppins, much struck by Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s appearance and conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly not,\xe2\x80\x99 chimed in Mrs. Sanders, who, from certain wistful\r\nglances at the little tin saucepan, seemed to be engaged in a mental\r\ncalculation of the probable extent of the pettitoes, in the event of\r\nSam\xe2\x80\x99s being asked to stop to supper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So all I\xe2\x80\x99ve come about, is jest this here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, disregarding the\r\ninterruption; \xe2\x80\x98first, to give my governor\xe2\x80\x99s notice--there it is.\r\nSecondly, to pay the rent--here it is. Thirdly, to say as all his things\r\nis to be put together, and give to anybody as we sends for \xe2\x80\x98em.\r\nFourthly, that you may let the place as soon as you like--and that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nall.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Whatever has happened,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell, \xe2\x80\x98I always have said, and\r\nalways will say, that in every respect but one, Mr. Pickwick has always\r\nbehaved himself like a perfect gentleman. His money always as good as\r\nthe bank--always.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Mrs. Bardell said this, she applied her handkerchief to her eyes, and\r\nwent out of the room to get the receipt.\r\n\r\nSam well knew that he had only to remain quiet, and the women were sure\r\nto talk; so he looked alternately at the tin saucepan, the toasted\r\ncheese, the wall, and the ceiling, in profound silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Poor dear!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Cluppins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, poor thing!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs. Sanders.\r\n\r\nSam said nothing. He saw they were coming to the subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I raly cannot contain myself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Cluppins, \xe2\x80\x98when I think of\r\nsuch perjury. I don\xe2\x80\x99t wish to say anything to make you uncomfortable,\r\nyoung man, but your master\xe2\x80\x99s an old brute, and I wish I had him here to\r\ntell him so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nI wish you had,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To see how dreadful she takes on, going moping about, and taking no\r\npleasure in nothing, except when her friends comes in, out of charity,\r\nto sit with her, and make her comfortable,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Mrs. Cluppins,\r\nglancing at the tin saucepan and the Dutch oven, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s shocking!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Barbareous,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Sanders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And your master, young man! A gentleman with money, as could never feel\r\nthe expense of a wife, no more than nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Mrs. Cluppins,\r\nwith great volubility; \xe2\x80\x98why there ain\xe2\x80\x99t the faintest shade of an excuse\r\nfor his behaviour! Why don\xe2\x80\x99t he marry her?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98to be sure; that\xe2\x80\x99s the question.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Question, indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Mrs. Cluppins, \xe2\x80\x98she\xe2\x80\x99d question him, if\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99d my spirit. Hows\xe2\x80\x99ever, there is law for us women, mis\xe2\x80\x99rable\r\ncreeturs as they\xe2\x80\x99d make us, if they could; and that your master will\r\nfind out, young man, to his cost, afore he\xe2\x80\x99s six months older.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt this consolatory reflection, Mrs. Cluppins bridled up, and smiled at\r\nMrs. Sanders, who smiled back again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The action\xe2\x80\x99s going on, and no mistake,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Sam, as Mrs. Bardell\r\nre-entered with the receipt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here\xe2\x80\x99s the receipt, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell, \xe2\x80\x98and here\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nchange, and I hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll take a little drop of something to keep the\r\ncold out, if it\xe2\x80\x99s only for old acquaintance\xe2\x80\x99 sake, Mr. Weller.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSam saw the advantage he should gain, and at once acquiesced; whereupon\r\nMrs. Bardell produced, from a small closet, a black bottle and a wine-\r\nglass; and so great was her abstraction, in her deep mental affliction,\r\nthat, after filling Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s glass, she brought out three more wine-\r\nglasses, and filled them too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lauk, Mrs. Bardell,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Cluppins, \xe2\x80\x98see what you\xe2\x80\x99ve been and\r\ndone!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, that is a good one!\xe2\x80\x99 ejaculated Mrs. Sanders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, my poor head!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell, with a faint smile.\r\n\r\nSam understood all this, of course, so he said at once, that he never\r\ncould drink before supper, unless a lady drank with him. A great deal of\r\nlaughter ensued, and Mrs. Sanders volunteered to humour him, so she took\r\na slight sip out of her glass. Then Sam said it must go all round, so\r\nthey all took a slight sip. Then little Mrs. Cluppins proposed as a\r\ntoast, \xe2\x80\x98Success to Bardell agin Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99; and then the ladies emptied\r\ntheir glasses in honour of the sentiment, and got very talkative\r\ndirectly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose you\xe2\x80\x99ve heard what\xe2\x80\x99s going forward, Mr. Weller?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs.\r\nBardell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve heerd somethin\xe2\x80\x99 on it,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a terrible thing to be dragged before the public, in that way, Mr.\r\nWeller,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell; \xe2\x80\x98but I see now, that it\xe2\x80\x99s the only thing I\r\nought to do, and my lawyers, Mr. Dodson and Fogg, tell me that, with the\r\nevidence as we shall call, we must succeed. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I should\r\ndo, Mr. Weller, if I didn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe mere idea of Mrs. Bardell\xe2\x80\x99s failing in her action, affected Mrs.\r\nSanders so deeply, that she was under the necessity of refilling and re-\r\nemptying her glass immediately; feeling, as she said afterwards, that if\r\nshe hadn\xe2\x80\x99t had the presence of mind to do so, she must have dropped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ven is it expected to come on?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Either in February or March,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs. Bardell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What a number of witnesses there\xe2\x80\x99ll be, won\xe2\x80\x99t there?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs.\r\nCluppins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! won\xe2\x80\x99t there!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs. Sanders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And won\xe2\x80\x99t Mr. Dodson and Fogg be wild if the plaintiff shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t get\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x99 added Mrs. Cluppins, \xe2\x80\x98when they do it all on speculation!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! won\xe2\x80\x99t they!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Sanders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But the plaintiff must get it,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Mrs. Cluppins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, there can\xe2\x80\x99t be any doubt about it,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mrs. Sanders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vell,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, rising and setting down his glass, \xe2\x80\x98all I can say is,\r\nthat I vish you _may _get it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell fervently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And of them Dodson and Foggs, as does these sort o\xe2\x80\x99 things on spec,\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncontinued Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98as vell as for the other kind and gen\xe2\x80\x99rous people\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 the same purfession, as sets people by the ears, free gratis for\r\nnothin\xe2\x80\x99, and sets their clerks to work to find out little disputes among\r\ntheir neighbours and acquaintances as vants settlin\xe2\x80\x99 by means of\r\nlawsuits--all I can say o\xe2\x80\x99 them is, that I vish they had the reward I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\ngive \xe2\x80\x98em.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, I wish they had the reward that every kind and generous heart would\r\nbe inclined to bestow upon them!\xe2\x80\x99 said the gratified Mrs. Bardell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Amen to that,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam, \xe2\x80\x98and a fat and happy liven\xe2\x80\x99 they\xe2\x80\x99d get out\r\nof it! Wish you good-night, ladies.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nTo the great relief of Mrs. Sanders, Sam was allowed to depart without\r\nany reference, on the part of the hostess, to the pettitoes and toasted\r\ncheese; to which the ladies, with such juvenile assistance as Master\r\nBardell could afford, soon afterwards rendered the amplest justice--\r\nindeed they wholly vanished before their strenuous exertions.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller wended his way back to the George and Vulture, and faithfully\r\nrecounted to his master, such indications of the sharp practice of\r\nDodson & Fogg, as he had contrived to pick up in his visit to Mrs.\r\nBardell\xe2\x80\x99s. An interview with Mr. Perker, next day, more than confirmed\r\nMr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s statement; and Mr. Pickwick was fain to prepare for his\r\nChristmas visit to Dingley Dell, with the pleasant anticipation that\r\nsome two or three months afterwards, an action brought against him for\r\ndamages sustained by reason of a breach of promise of marriage, would be\r\npublicly tried in the Court of Common Pleas; the plaintiff having all\r\nthe advantages derivable, not only from the force of circumstances, but\r\nfrom the sharp practice of Dodson & Fogg to boot.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVII. SAMUEL WELLER MAKES A PILGRIMAGE TO DORKING, AND BEHOLDS\r\nHIS MOTHER-IN-LAW\r\n\r\nThere still remaining an interval of two days before the time agreed\r\nupon for the departure of the Pickwickians to Dingley Dell, Mr. Weller\r\nsat himself down in a back room at the George and Vulture, after eating\r\nan early dinner, to muse on the best way of disposing of his time. It\r\nwas a remarkably fine day; and he had not turned the matter over in his\r\nmind ten minutes, when he was suddenly stricken filial and affectionate;\r\nand it occurred to him so strongly that he ought to go down and see his\r\nfather, and pay his duty to his mother-in-law, that he was lost in\r\nastonishment at his own remissness in never thinking of this moral\r\nobligation before. Anxious to atone for his past neglect without another\r\nhour\xe2\x80\x99s delay, he straightway walked upstairs to Mr. Pickwick, and\r\nrequested leave of absence for this laudable purpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, Sam, certainly,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, his eyes glistening with\r\ndelight at this manifestation of filial feeling on the part of his\r\nattendant; \xe2\x80\x98certainly, Sam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller made a grateful bow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am very glad to see that you have so high a sense of your duties as a\r\nson, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I always had, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s a very gratifying reflection, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick\r\napprovingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98if ever I wanted anythin\xe2\x80\x99 o\xe2\x80\x99 my\r\nfather, I always asked for it in a wery \xe2\x80\x98spectful and obligin\xe2\x80\x99 manner.\r\nIf he didn\xe2\x80\x99t give it me, I took it, for fear I should be led to do\r\nanythin\xe2\x80\x99 wrong, through not havin\xe2\x80\x99 it. I saved him a world o\xe2\x80\x99 trouble\r\nthis vay, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s not precisely what I meant, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, shaking his\r\nhead, with a slight smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All good feelin\xe2\x80\x99, sir--the wery best intentions, as the gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n said\r\nven he run away from his wife \xe2\x80\x98cos she seemed unhappy with him,\xe2\x80\x99 replied\r\nMr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You may go, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller; and having made his best bow, and\r\nput on his best clothes, Sam planted himself on the top of the Arundel\r\ncoach, and journeyed on to Dorking.\r\n\r\nThe Marquis of Granby, in Mrs. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s time, was quite a model of a\r\nroadside public-house of the better class--just large enough to be\r\nconvenient, and small enough to be snug. On the opposite side of the\r\nroad was a large sign-board on a high post, representing the head and\r\nshoulders of a gentleman with an apoplectic countenance, in a red coat\r\nwith deep blue facings, and a touch of the same blue over his three-\r\ncornered hat, for a sky. Over that again were a pair of flags; beneath\r\nthe last button of his coat were a couple of cannon; and the whole\r\nformed an expressive and undoubted likeness of the Marquis of Granby of\r\nglorious memory. The bar window displayed a choice collection of\r\ngeranium plants, and a well-dusted row of spirit phials. The open\r\nshutters bore a variety of golden inscriptions, eulogistic of good beds\r\nand neat wines; and the choice group of countrymen and hostlers lounging\r\nabout the stable door and horse-trough, afforded presumptive proof of\r\nthe excellent quality of the ale and spirits which were sold within. Sam\r\nWeller paused, when he dismounted from the coach, to note all these\r\nlittle indications of a thriving business, with the eye of an\r\nexperienced traveller; and having done so, stepped in at once, highly\r\nsatisfied with everything he had observed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, then!\xe2\x80\x99 said a shrill female voice the instant Sam thrust his head\r\nin at the door, \xe2\x80\x98what do you want, young man?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSam looked round in the direction whence the voice proceeded. It came\r\nfrom a rather stout lady of comfortable appearance, who was seated\r\nbeside the fireplace in the bar, blowing the fire to make the kettle\r\nboil for tea. She was not alone; for on the other side of the fireplace,\r\nsitting bolt upright in a high-backed chair, was a man in threadbare\r\nblack clothes, with a back almost as long and stiff as that of the chair\r\nitself, who caught Sam\xe2\x80\x99s most particular and especial attention at once.\r\n\r\nHe was a prim-faced, red-nosed man, with a long, thin countenance, and a\r\nsemi-rattlesnake sort of eye--rather sharp, but decidedly bad. He wore\r\nvery short trousers, and black cotton stockings, which, like the rest of\r\nhis apparel, were particularly rusty.
