I hope, gentlemen, I give\r\nsatisfaction.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, you don\xe2\x80\x99t, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tuckle. \xe2\x80\x98Very far from it, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We consider you an inattentive reskel,\xe2\x80\x99 said the gentleman in the\r\norange plush.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And a low thief,\xe2\x80\x99 added the gentleman in the green-foil smalls.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And an unreclaimable blaygaird,\xe2\x80\x99 added the gentleman in purple.\r\n\r\nThe poor greengrocer bowed very humbly while these little epithets were\r\nbestowed upon him, in the true spirit of the very smallest tyranny; and\r\nwhen everybody had said something to show his superiority, Mr. Tuckle\r\nproceeded to carve the leg of mutton, and to help the company.\r\n\r\nThis important business of the evening had hardly commenced, when the\r\ndoor was thrown briskly open, and another gentleman in a light-blue\r\nsuit, and leaden buttons, made his appearance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Against the rules,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tuckle. \xe2\x80\x98Too late, too late.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no; positively I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it,\xe2\x80\x99 said the gentleman in blue. \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nappeal to the company. An affair of gallantry now, an appointment at the\r\ntheayter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, that indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 said the gentleman in the orange plush.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; raly now, honour bright,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man in blue. \xe2\x80\x98I made a promese\r\nto fetch our youngest daughter at half-past ten, and she is such an\r\nuncauminly fine gal, that I raly hadn\xe2\x80\x99t the \xe2\x80\x98art to disappint her. No\r\noffence to the present company, Sir, but a petticut, sir--a petticut,\r\nSir, is irrevokeable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I begin to suspect there\xe2\x80\x99s something in that quarter,\xe2\x80\x99 said Tuckle, as\r\nthe new-comer took his seat next Sam, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve remarked, once or twice,\r\nthat she leans very heavy on your shoulder when she gets in and out of\r\nthe carriage.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, raly, raly, Tuckle, you shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man in blue. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s not\r\nfair. I may have said to one or two friends that she wos a very divine\r\ncreechure, and had refused one or two offers without any hobvus cause,\r\nbut--no, no, no, indeed, Tuckle--before strangers, too--it\xe2\x80\x99s not right--\r\nyou shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t. Delicacy, my dear friend, delicacy!\xe2\x80\x99 And the man in blue,\r\npulling up his neckerchief, and adjusting his coat cuffs, nodded and\r\nfrowned as if there were more behind, which he could say if he liked,\r\nbut was bound in honour to suppress.\r\n\r\nThe man in blue being a light-haired, stiff-necked, free and easy sort\r\nof footman, with a swaggering air and pert face, had attracted Mr.\r\nWeller\xe2\x80\x99s special attention at first, but when he began to come out in\r\nthis way, Sam felt more than ever disposed to cultivate his\r\nacquaintance; so he launched himself into the conversation at once, with\r\ncharacteristic independence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your health, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98I like your conversation much. I think\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s wery pretty.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt this the man in blue smiled, as if it were a compliment he was well\r\nused to; but looked approvingly on Sam at the same time, and said he\r\nhoped he should be better acquainted with him, for without any flattery\r\nat all he seemed to have the makings of a very nice fellow about him,\r\nand to be just the man after his own heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re wery good, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98What a lucky feller you are!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the gentleman in blue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That \xe2\x80\x98ere young lady,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98She knows wot\xe2\x80\x99s wot, she does. Ah!\r\nI see.\xe2\x80\x99 Mr. Weller closed one eye, and shook his head from side to side,\r\nin a manner which was highly gratifying to the personal vanity of the\r\ngentleman in blue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid you\xe2\x80\x99re a cunning fellow, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 said that individual.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98I leave all that \xe2\x80\x98ere to you. It\xe2\x80\x99s a great deal\r\nmore in your way than mine, as the gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n on the right side o\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\ngarden vall said to the man on the wrong un, ven the mad bull vos a-\r\ncomin\xe2\x80\x99 up the lane.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, well, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 said the gentleman in blue, \xe2\x80\x98I think she has\r\nremarked my air and manner, Mr. Weller.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should think she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t wery well be off o\xe2\x80\x99 that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you any little thing of that kind in hand, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the\r\nfavoured gentleman in blue, drawing a toothpick from his waistcoat\r\npocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not exactly,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s no daughters at my place, else o\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncourse I should ha\xe2\x80\x99 made up to vun on \xe2\x80\x98em. As it is, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I can\r\ndo with anythin\xe2\x80\x99 under a female markis. I might keep up with a young\r\n\xe2\x80\x98ooman o\xe2\x80\x99 large property as hadn\xe2\x80\x99t a title, if she made wery fierce love\r\nto me. Not else.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course not, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 said the gentleman in blue, \xe2\x80\x98one can\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\ntroubled, you know; and _we_ know, Mr. Weller--we, who are men of the\r\nworld--that a good uniform must work its way with the women, sooner or\r\nlater. In fact, that\xe2\x80\x99s the only thing, between you and me, that makes\r\nthe service worth entering into.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s it, o\xe2\x80\x99 course.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhen this confidential dialogue had gone thus far, glasses were placed\r\nround, and every gentleman ordered what he liked best, before the\r\npublic-house shut up. The gentleman in blue, and the man in orange, who\r\nwere the chief exquisites of the party, ordered \xe2\x80\x98cold shrub and water,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nbut with the others, gin-and-water, sweet, appeared to be the favourite\r\nbeverage. Sam called the greengrocer a \xe2\x80\x98desp\xe2\x80\x99rate willin,\xe2\x80\x99 and ordered a\r\nlarge bowl of punch--two circumstances which seemed to raise him very\r\nmuch in the opinion of the selections.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man in blue, with an air of the most consummate\r\ndandyism, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll give you the ladies; come.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hear, hear!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98The young mississes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere there was a loud cry of \xe2\x80\x98Order,\xe2\x80\x99 and Mr. John Smauker, as the\r\ngentleman who had introduced Mr. Weller into that company, begged to\r\ninform him that the word he had just made use of, was unparliamentary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which word was that \xe2\x80\x98ere, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mississes, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. John Smauker, with an alarming frown. \xe2\x80\x98We\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t recognise such distinctions here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, wery good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam; \xe2\x80\x98then I\xe2\x80\x99ll amend the obserwation and call \xe2\x80\x98em\r\nthe dear creeturs, if Blazes vill allow me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSome doubt appeared to exist in the mind of the gentleman in the green-\r\nfoil smalls, whether the chairman could be legally appealed to, as\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Blazes,\xe2\x80\x99 but as the company seemed more disposed to stand upon their\r\nown rights than his, the question was not raised. The man with the\r\ncocked hat breathed short, and looked long at Sam, but apparently\r\nthought it as well to say nothing, in case he should get the worst of\r\nit. After a short silence, a gentleman in an embroidered coat reaching\r\ndown to his heels, and a waistcoat of the same which kept one half of\r\nhis legs warm, stirred his gin-and-water with great energy, and putting\r\nhimself upon his feet, all at once by a violent effort, said he was\r\ndesirous of offering a few remarks to the company, whereupon the person\r\nin the cocked hat had no doubt that the company would be very happy to\r\nhear any remarks that the man in the long coat might wish to offer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I feel a great delicacy, gentlemen, in coming for\xe2\x80\x99ard,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man in\r\nthe long coat, \xe2\x80\x98having the misforchune to be a coachman, and being only\r\nadmitted as a honorary member of these agreeable swarrys, but I do feel\r\nmyself bound, gentlemen--drove into a corner, if I may use the\r\nexpression--to make known an afflicting circumstance which has come to\r\nmy knowledge; which has happened I may say within the soap of my\r\neveryday contemplation. Gentlemen, our friend Mr. Whiffers (everybody\r\nlooked at the individual in orange), our friend Mr. Whiffers has\r\nresigned.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nUniversal astonishment fell upon the hearers. Each gentleman looked in\r\nhis neighbour\xe2\x80\x99s face, and then transferred his glance to the upstanding\r\ncoachman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You may well be sapparised, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 said the coachman. \xe2\x80\x98I will not\r\nwenchure to state the reasons of this irrepairabel loss to the service,\r\nbut I will beg Mr. Whiffers to state them himself, for the improvement\r\nand imitation of his admiring friends.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe suggestion being loudly approved of, Mr. Whiffers explained. He said\r\nhe certainly could have wished to have continued to hold the appointment\r\nhe had just resigned. The uniform was extremely rich and expensive, the\r\nfemales of the family was most agreeable, and the duties of the\r\nsituation was not, he was bound to say, too heavy; the principal service\r\nthat was required of him, being, that he should look out of the hall\r\nwindow as much as possible, in company with another gentleman, who had\r\nalso resigned. He could have wished to have spared that company the\r\npainful and disgusting detail on which he was about to enter, but as the\r\nexplanation had been demanded of him, he had no alternative but to\r\nstate, boldly and distinctly, that he had been required to eat cold\r\nmeat.\r\n\r\nIt is impossible to conceive the disgust which this avowal awakened in\r\nthe bosoms of the hearers. Loud cries of \xe2\x80\x98Shame,\xe2\x80\x99 mingled with groans\r\nand hisses, prevailed for a quarter of an hour.\r\n\r\nMr. Whiffers then added that he feared a portion of this outrage might\r\nbe traced to his own forbearing and accommodating disposition. He had a\r\ndistinct recollection of having once consented to eat salt butter, and\r\nhe had, moreover, on an occasion of sudden sickness in the house, so far\r\nforgotten himself as to carry a coal-scuttle up to the second floor. He\r\ntrusted he had not lowered himself in the good opinion of his friends by\r\nthis frank confession of his faults; and he hoped the promptness with\r\nwhich he had resented the last unmanly outrage on his feelings, to which\r\nhe had referred, would reinstate him in their good opinion, if he had.\r\n\r\nMr. Whiffers\xe2\x80\x99s address was responded to, with a shout of admiration, and\r\nthe health of the interesting martyr was drunk in a most enthusiastic\r\nmanner; for this, the martyr returned thanks, and proposed their\r\nvisitor, Mr. Weller--a gentleman whom he had not the pleasure of an\r\nintimate acquaintance with, but who was the friend of Mr. John Smauker,\r\nwhich was a sufficient letter of recommendation to any society of\r\ngentlemen whatever, or wherever. On this account, he should have been\r\ndisposed to have given Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s health with all the honours, if his\r\nfriends had been drinking wine; but as they were taking spirits by way\r\nof a change, and as it might be inconvenient to empty a tumbler at every\r\ntoast, he should propose that the honours be understood.\r\n\r\nAt the conclusion of this speech, everybody took a sip in honour of Sam;\r\nand Sam having ladled out, and drunk, two full glasses of punch in\r\nhonour of himself, returned thanks in a neat speech.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery much obliged to you, old fellers,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, ladling away at the\r\npunch in the most unembarrassed manner possible, \xe2\x80\x98for this here\r\ncompliment; which, comin\xe2\x80\x99 from sich a quarter, is wery overvelmin\xe2\x80\x99. I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nheered a good deal on you as a body, but I will say, that I never\r\nthought you was sich uncommon nice men as I find you air. I only hope\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll take care o\xe2\x80\x99 yourselves, and not compromise nothin\xe2\x80\x99 o\xe2\x80\x99 your\r\ndignity, which is a wery charmin\xe2\x80\x99 thing to see, when one\xe2\x80\x99s out a-\r\nwalkin\xe2\x80\x99, and has always made me wery happy to look at, ever since I was\r\na boy about half as high as the brass-headed stick o\xe2\x80\x99 my wery\r\nrespectable friend, Blazes, there. As to the wictim of oppression in the\r\nsuit o\xe2\x80\x99 brimstone, all I can say of him, is, that I hope he\xe2\x80\x99ll get jist\r\nas good a berth as he deserves; in vitch case it\xe2\x80\x99s wery little cold\r\nswarry as ever he\xe2\x80\x99ll be troubled with agin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere Sam sat down with a pleasant smile, and his speech having been\r\nvociferously applauded, the company broke up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wy, you don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to say you\xe2\x80\x99re a-goin\xe2\x80\x99 old feller?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam Weller\r\nto his friend, Mr. John Smauker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must, indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Smauker; \xe2\x80\x98I promised Bantam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, wery well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam; \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s another thing. P\xe2\x80\x99raps he\xe2\x80\x99d resign if\r\nyou disappinted him. You ain\xe2\x80\x99t a-goin\xe2\x80\x99, Blazes?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I am,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man with the cocked hat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot, and leave three-quarters of a bowl of punch behind you!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98nonsense, set down agin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Tuckle was not proof against this invitation. He laid aside the\r\ncocked hat and stick which he had just taken up, and said he would have\r\none glass, for good fellowship\xe2\x80\x99s sake.\r\n\r\nAs the gentleman in blue went home the same way as Mr. Tuckle, he was\r\nprevailed upon to stop too. When the punch was about half gone, Sam\r\nordered in some oysters from the green-grocer\xe2\x80\x99s shop; and the effect of\r\nboth was so extremely exhilarating, that Mr. Tuckle, dressed out with\r\nthe cocked hat and stick, danced the frog hornpipe among the shells on\r\nthe table, while the gentleman in blue played an accompaniment upon an\r\ningenious musical instrument formed of a hair-comb upon a curl-paper. At\r\nlast, when the punch was all gone, and the night nearly so, they sallied\r\nforth to see each other home. Mr. Tuckle no sooner got into the open\r\nair, than he was seized with a sudden desire to lie on the curbstone;\r\nSam thought it would be a pity to contradict him, and so let him have\r\nhis own way. As the cocked hat would have been spoiled if left there,\r\nSam very considerately flattened it down on the head of the gentleman in\r\nblue, and putting the big stick in his hand, propped him up against his\r\nown street-door, rang the bell, and walked quietly home.\r\n\r\nAt a much earlier hour next morning than his usual time of rising, Mr.\r\nPickwick walked downstairs completely dressed, and rang the bell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, when Mr. Weller appeared in reply to the\r\nsummons, \xe2\x80\x98shut the door.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller did so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There was an unfortunate occurrence here, last night, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nPickwick, \xe2\x80\x98which gave Mr. Winkle some cause to apprehend violence from\r\nMr. Dowler.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So I\xe2\x80\x99ve heerd from the old lady downstairs, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry to say, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Mr. Pickwick, with a most\r\nperplexed countenance, \xe2\x80\x98that in dread of this violence, Mr. Winkle has\r\ngone away.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gone avay!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Left the house early this morning, without the slightest previous\r\ncommunication with me,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98And is gone, I know not\r\nwhere.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He should ha\xe2\x80\x99 stopped and fought it out, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam\r\ncontemptuously. \xe2\x80\x98It wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t take much to settle that \xe2\x80\x98ere Dowler, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98I may have my doubts of his great\r\nbravery and determination also. But however that may be, Mr. Winkle is\r\ngone. He must be found, Sam. Found and brought back to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAnd s\xe2\x80\x99pose he won\xe2\x80\x99t come back, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He must be made, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who\xe2\x80\x99s to do it, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam, with a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery good, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith these words Mr. Weller left the room, and immediately afterwards\r\nwas heard to shut the street door. In two hours\xe2\x80\x99 time he returned with\r\nso much coolness as if he had been despatched on the most ordinary\r\nmessage possible, and brought the information that an individual, in\r\nevery respect answering Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s description, had gone over to\r\nBristol that morning, by the branch coach from the Royal Hotel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, grasping his hand, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99re a capital fellow;\r\nan invaluable fellow. You must follow him, Sam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Cert\xe2\x80\x99nly, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The instant you discover him, write to me immediately, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nPickwick. \xe2\x80\x98If he attempts to run away from you, knock him down, or lock\r\nhim up. You have my full authority, Sam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll be wery careful, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ll tell him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98that I am highly excited, highly\r\ndispleased, and naturally indignant, at the very extraordinary course he\r\nhas thought proper to pursue.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ll tell him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98that if he does not come back to\r\nthis very house, with you, he will come back with me, for I will come\r\nand fetch him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll mention that \xe2\x80\x98ere, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You think you can find him, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, looking earnestly\r\nin his face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I\xe2\x80\x99ll find him if he\xe2\x80\x99s anyvere,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Sam, with great\r\nconfidence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Then the sooner you go the better.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith these instructions, Mr. Pickwick placed a sum of money in the hands\r\nof his faithful servitor, and ordered him to start for Bristol\r\nimmediately, in pursuit of the fugitive.\r\n\r\nSam put a few necessaries in a carpet-bag, and was ready for starting.\r\nHe stopped when he had got to the end of the passage, and walking\r\nquietly back, thrust his head in at the parlour door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I fully understands my instructions, do I, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s reg\xe2\x80\x99larly understood about the knockin\xe2\x80\x99 down, is it, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\ninquired Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perfectly,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Thoroughly. Do what you think necessary.\r\nYou have my orders.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSam gave a nod of intelligence, and withdrawing his head from the door,\r\nset forth on his pilgrimage with a light heart.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVIII. HOW MR. WINKLE, WHEN HE STEPPED OUT OF THE FRYING-PAN,\r\nWALKED GENTLY AND COMFORTABLY INTO THE FIRE\r\n\r\nThe ill-starred gentleman who had been the unfortunate cause of the\r\nunusual noise and disturbance which alarmed the inhabitants of the Royal\r\nCrescent in manner and form already described, after passing a night of\r\ngreat confusion and anxiety, left the roof beneath which his friends\r\nstill slumbered, bound he knew not whither. The excellent and\r\nconsiderate feelings which prompted Mr. Winkle to take this step can\r\nnever be too highly appreciated or too warmly extolled. \xe2\x80\x98If,\xe2\x80\x99 reasoned\r\nMr. Winkle with himself--\xe2\x80\x98if this Dowler attempts (as I have no doubt he\r\nwill) to carry into execution his threat of personal violence against\r\nmyself, it will be incumbent on me to call him out. He has a wife; that\r\nwife is attached to, and dependent on him. Heavens! If I should kill him\r\nin the blindness of my wrath, what would be my feelings ever\r\nafterwards!\xe2\x80\x99 This painful consideration operated so powerfully on the\r\nfeelings of the humane young man, as to cause his knees to knock\r\ntogether, and his countenance to exhibit alarming manifestations of\r\ninward emotion. Impelled by such reflections, he grasped his carpet-bag,\r\nand creeping stealthily downstairs, shut the detestable street door with\r\nas little noise as possible, and walked off. Bending his steps towards\r\nthe Royal Hotel, he found a coach on the point of starting for Bristol,\r\nand, thinking Bristol as good a place for his purpose as any other he\r\ncould go to, he mounted the box, and reached his place of destination in\r\nsuch time as the pair of horses, who went the whole stage and back\r\nagain, twice a day or more, could be reasonably supposed to arrive\r\nthere.\r\n\r\nHe took up his quarters at the Bush, and designing to postpone any\r\ncommunication by letter with Mr. Pickwick until it was probable that Mr.\r\nDowler\xe2\x80\x99s wrath might have in some degree evaporated, walked forth to\r\nview the city, which struck him as being a shade more dirty than any\r\nplace he had ever seen. Having inspected the docks and shipping, and\r\nviewed the cathedral, he inquired his way to Clifton, and being directed\r\nthither, took the route which was pointed out to him. But as the\r\npavements of Bristol are not the widest or cleanest upon earth, so its\r\nstreets are not altogether the straightest or least intricate; and Mr.\r\nWinkle, being greatly puzzled by their manifold windings and twistings,\r\nlooked about him for a decent shop in which he could apply afresh for\r\ncounsel and instruction.\r\n\r\nHis eye fell upon a newly-painted tenement which had been recently\r\nconverted into something between a shop and a private house, and which a\r\nred lamp, projecting over the fanlight of the street door, would have\r\nsufficiently announced as the residence of a medical practitioner, even\r\nif the word \xe2\x80\x98Surgery\xe2\x80\x99 had not been inscribed in golden characters on a\r\nwainscot ground, above the window of what, in times bygone, had been the\r\nfront parlour. Thinking this an eligible place wherein to make his\r\ninquiries, Mr. Winkle stepped into the little shop where the gilt-\r\nlabelled drawers and bottles were; and finding nobody there, knocked\r\nwith a half-crown on the counter, to attract the attention of anybody\r\nwho might happen to be in the back parlour, which he judged to be the\r\ninnermost and peculiar sanctum of the establishment, from the repetition\r\nof the word surgery on the door--painted in white letters this time, by\r\nway of taking off the monotony.\r\n\r\nAt the first knock, a sound, as of persons fencing with fire-irons,\r\nwhich had until now been very audible, suddenly ceased; at the second, a\r\nstudious-looking young gentleman in green spectacles, with a very large\r\nbook in his hand, glided quietly into the shop, and stepping behind the\r\ncounter, requested to know the visitor\xe2\x80\x99s pleasure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sorry to trouble you, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle, \xe2\x80\x98but will you have\r\nthe goodness to direct me to--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha! ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x99 roared the studious young gentleman, throwing the large\r\nbook up into the air, and catching it with great dexterity at the very\r\nmoment when it threatened to smash to atoms all the bottles on the\r\ncounter. \xe2\x80\x98Here\xe2\x80\x99s a start!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was, without doubt; for Mr. Winkle was so very much astonished at\r\nthe extraordinary behaviour of the medical gentleman, that he\r\ninvoluntarily retreated towards the door, and looked very much disturbed\r\nat his strange reception.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What, don\xe2\x80\x99t you know me?\xe2\x80\x99 said the medical gentleman.\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle murmured, in reply, that he had not that pleasure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, then,\xe2\x80\x99 said the medical gentleman, \xe2\x80\x98there are hopes for me yet; I\r\nmay attend half the old women in Bristol, if I\xe2\x80\x99ve decent luck. Get out,\r\nyou mouldy old villain, get out!\xe2\x80\x99 With this adjuration, which was\r\naddressed to the large book, the medical gentleman kicked the volume\r\nwith remarkable agility to the farther end of the shop, and, pulling off\r\nhis green spectacles, grinned the identical grin of Robert Sawyer,\r\nEsquire, formerly of Guy\xe2\x80\x99s Hospital in the Borough, with a private\r\nresidence in Lant Street.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to say you weren\xe2\x80\x99t down upon me?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Bob Sawyer,\r\nshaking Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s hand with friendly warmth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Upon my word I was not,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Winkle, returning his pressure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wonder you didn\xe2\x80\x99t see the name,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob Sawyer, calling his\r\nfriend\xe2\x80\x99s attention to the outer door, on which, in the same white paint,\r\nwere traced the words \xe2\x80\x98Sawyer, late Nockemorf.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It never caught my eye,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lord, if I had known who you were, I should have rushed out, and caught\r\nyou in my arms,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob Sawyer; \xe2\x80\x98but upon my life, I thought you were\r\nthe King\xe2\x80\x99s-taxes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I did, indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 responded Bob Sawyer, \xe2\x80\x98and I was just going to say that\r\nI wasn\xe2\x80\x99t at home, but if you\xe2\x80\x99d leave a message I\xe2\x80\x99d be sure to give it to\r\nmyself; for he don\xe2\x80\x99t know me; no more does the Lighting and Paving. I\r\nthink the Church-rates guesses who I am, and I know the Water-works\r\ndoes, because I drew a tooth of his when I first came down here. But\r\ncome in, come in!\xe2\x80\x99 Chattering in this way, Mr. Bob Sawyer pushed Mr.\r\nWinkle into the back room, where, amusing himself by boring little\r\ncircular caverns in the chimney-piece with a red-hot poker, sat no less\r\na person than Mr. Benjamin Allen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle. \xe2\x80\x98This is indeed a pleasure I did not expect.\r\nWhat a very nice place you have here!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pretty well, pretty well,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Bob Sawyer. \xe2\x80\x98I _passed_, soon after\r\nthat precious party, and my friends came down with the needful for this\r\nbusiness; so I put on a black suit of clothes, and a pair of spectacles,\r\nand came here to look as solemn as I could.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And a very snug little business you have, no doubt?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle\r\nknowingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Bob Sawyer. \xe2\x80\x98So snug, that at the end of a few years you\r\nmight put all the profits in a wine-glass, and cover \xe2\x80\x98em over with a\r\ngooseberry leaf.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nYou cannot surely mean that?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle. \xe2\x80\x98The stock itself--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDummies, my dear boy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob Sawyer; \xe2\x80\x98half the drawers have nothing\r\nin \xe2\x80\x98em, and the other half don\xe2\x80\x99t open.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fact--honour!\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bob Sawyer, stepping out into the shop, and\r\ndemonstrating the veracity of the assertion by divers hard pulls at the\r\nlittle gilt knobs on the counterfeit drawers. \xe2\x80\x98Hardly anything real in\r\nthe shop but the leeches, and _they _are second-hand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have thought it!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Winkle, much surprised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope not,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Bob Sawyer, \xe2\x80\x98else where\xe2\x80\x99s the use of appearances,\r\neh? But what will you take? Do as we do? That\xe2\x80\x99s right. Ben, my fine\r\nfellow, put your hand into the cupboard, and bring out the patent\r\ndigester.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Benjamin Allen smiled his readiness, and produced from the closet at\r\nhis elbow a black bottle half full of brandy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t take water, of course?\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob Sawyer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Winkle. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s rather early. I should like to\r\nqualify it, if you have no objection.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98None in the least, if you can reconcile it to your conscience,\xe2\x80\x99 replied\r\nBob Sawyer, tossing off, as he spoke, a glass of the liquor with great\r\nrelish. \xe2\x80\x98Ben, the pipkin!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Benjamin Allen drew forth, from the same hiding-place, a small brass\r\npipkin, which Bob Sawyer observed he prided himself upon, particularly\r\nbecause it looked so business-like. The water in the professional pipkin\r\nhaving been made to boil, in course of time, by various little\r\nshovelfuls of coal, which Mr. Bob Sawyer took out of a practicable\r\nwindow-seat, labelled \xe2\x80\x98Soda Water,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr. Winkle adulterated his brandy;\r\nand the conversation was becoming general, when it was interrupted by\r\nthe entrance into the shop of a boy, in a sober gray livery and a gold-\r\nlaced hat, with a small covered basket under his arm, whom Mr. Bob\r\nSawyer immediately hailed with, \xe2\x80\x98Tom, you vagabond, come here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe boy presented himself accordingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ve been stopping to \xe2\x80\x9cover\xe2\x80\x9d all the posts in Bristol, you idle young\r\nscamp!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Bob Sawyer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You had better not!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Bob Sawyer, with a threatening aspect.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who do you suppose will ever employ a professional man, when they see\r\nhis boy playing at marbles in the gutter, or flying the garter in the\r\nhorse-road? Have you no feeling for your profession, you groveller? Did\r\nyou leave all the medicine?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nYes, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The powders for the child, at the large house with the new family, and\r\nthe pills to be taken four times a day at the ill-tempered old\r\ngentleman\xe2\x80\x99s with the gouty leg?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then shut the door, and mind the shop.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle, as the boy retired, \xe2\x80\x98things are not quite so\r\nbad as you would have me believe, either. There is _some _medicine to be\r\nsent out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Bob Sawyer peeped into the shop to see that no stranger was within\r\nhearing, and leaning forward to Mr. Winkle, said, in a low tone--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He leaves it all at the wrong houses.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle looked perplexed, and Bob Sawyer and his friend laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see?\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob. \xe2\x80\x98He goes up to a house, rings the area bell,\r\npokes a packet of medicine without a direction into the servant\xe2\x80\x99s hand,\r\nand walks off. Servant takes it into the dining-parlour; master opens\r\nit, and reads the label: \xe2\x80\x9cDraught to be taken at bedtime--pills as\r\nbefore--lotion as usual--the powder. From Sawyer\xe2\x80\x99s, late Nockemorf\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\nPhysicians\xe2\x80\x99 prescriptions carefully prepared,\xe2\x80\x9d and all the rest of it.\r\nShows it to his wife--she reads the label; it goes down to the servants-\r\n-_they_ read the label. Next day, boy calls: \xe2\x80\x9cVery sorry--his mistake--\r\nimmense business--great many parcels to deliver--Mr. Sawyer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncompliments--late Nockemorf.\xe2\x80\x9d The name gets known, and that\xe2\x80\x99s the thing,\r\nmy boy, in the medical way. Bless your heart, old fellow, it\xe2\x80\x99s better\r\nthan all the advertising in the world. We have got one four-ounce bottle\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s been to half the houses in Bristol, and hasn\xe2\x80\x99t done yet.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me, I see,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Mr. Winkle; \xe2\x80\x98what an excellent plan!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Ben and I have hit upon a dozen such,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Bob Sawyer, with\r\ngreat glee. \xe2\x80\x98The lamplighter has eighteenpence a week to pull the night-\r\nbell for ten minutes every time he comes round; and my boy always rushes\r\ninto the church just before the psalms, when the people have got nothing\r\nto do but look about \xe2\x80\x98em, and calls me out, with horror and dismay\r\ndepicted on his countenance. \xe2\x80\x9cBless my soul,\xe2\x80\x9d everybody says, \xe2\x80\x9csomebody\r\ntaken suddenly ill! Sawyer, late Nockemorf, sent for. What a business\r\nthat young man has!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt the termination of this disclosure of some of the mysteries of\r\nmedicine, Mr. Bob Sawyer and his friend, Ben Allen, threw themselves\r\nback in their respective chairs, and laughed boisterously. When they had\r\nenjoyed the joke to their heart\xe2\x80\x99s content, the discourse changed to\r\ntopics in which Mr. Winkle was more immediately interested.\r\n\r\nWe think we have hinted elsewhere, that Mr. Benjamin Allen had a way of\r\nbecoming sentimental after brandy. The case is not a peculiar one, as we\r\nourself can testify, having, on a few occasions, had to deal with\r\npatients who have been afflicted in a similar manner. At this precise\r\nperiod of his existence, Mr. Benjamin Allen had perhaps a greater\r\npredisposition to maudlinism than he had ever known before; the cause of\r\nwhich malady was briefly this. He had been staying nearly three weeks\r\nwith Mr. Bob Sawyer; Mr. Bob Sawyer was not remarkable for temperance,\r\nnor was Mr. Benjamin Allen for the ownership of a very strong head; the\r\nconsequence was that, during the whole space of time just mentioned, Mr.\r\nBenjamin Allen had been wavering between intoxication partial, and\r\nintoxication complete.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear friend,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Ben Allen, taking advantage of Mr. Bob\r\nSawyer\xe2\x80\x99s temporary absence behind the counter, whither he had retired to\r\ndispense some of the second-hand leeches, previously referred to; \xe2\x80\x98my\r\ndear friend, I am very miserable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle professed his heartfelt regret to hear it, and begged to know\r\nwhether he could do anything to alleviate the sorrows of the suffering\r\nstudent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing, my dear boy, nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 said Ben. \xe2\x80\x98You recollect Arabella,\r\nWinkle? My sister Arabella--a little girl, Winkle, with black eyes--when\r\nwe were down at Wardle\xe2\x80\x99s? I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether you happened to notice\r\nher--a nice little girl, Winkle. Perhaps my features may recall her\r\ncountenance to your recollection?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle required nothing to recall the charming Arabella to his mind;\r\nand it was rather fortunate he did not, for the features of her brother\r\nBenjamin would unquestionably have proved but an indifferent refresher\r\nto his memory. He answered, with as much calmness as he could assume,\r\nthat he perfectly remembered the young lady referred to, and sincerely\r\ntrusted she was in good health.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Our friend Bob is a delightful fellow, Winkle,\xe2\x80\x99 was the only reply of\r\nMr. Ben Allen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle, not much relishing this close connection of the\r\ntwo names.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I designed \xe2\x80\x98em for each other; they were made for each other, sent into\r\nthe world for each other, born for each other, Winkle,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Ben\r\nAllen, setting down his glass with emphasis. \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s a special destiny\r\nin the matter, my dear sir; there\xe2\x80\x99s only five years\xe2\x80\x99 difference between\r\n\xe2\x80\x98em, and both their birthdays are in August.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle was too anxious to hear what was to follow to express much\r\nwonderment at this extraordinary coincidence, marvellous as it was; so\r\nMr. Ben Allen, after a tear or two, went on to say that, notwithstanding\r\nall his esteem and respect and veneration for his friend, Arabella had\r\nunaccountably and undutifully evinced the most determined antipathy to\r\nhis person.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I think,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Ben Allen, in conclusion. \xe2\x80\x98I think there\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nprior attachment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you any idea who the object of it might be?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr. Winkle,\r\nwith great trepidation.\r\n\r\nMr. Ben Allen seized the poker, flourished it in a warlike manner above\r\nhis head, inflicted a savage blow on an imaginary skull, and wound up by\r\nsaying, in a very expressive manner, that he only wished he could guess;\r\nthat was all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99d show him what I thought of him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Ben Allen. And round went\r\nthe poker again, more fiercely than before.\r\n\r\nAll this was, of course, very soothing to the feelings of Mr. Winkle,\r\nwho remained silent for a few minutes; but at length mustered up\r\nresolution to inquire whether Miss Allen was in Kent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Ben Allen, laying aside the poker, and looking very\r\ncunning; \xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t think Wardle\xe2\x80\x99s exactly the place for a headstrong\r\ngirl; so, as I am her natural protector and guardian, our parents being\r\ndead, I have brought her down into this part of the country to spend a\r\nfew months at an old aunt\xe2\x80\x99s, in a nice, dull, close place. I think that\r\nwill cure her, my boy. If it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t, I\xe2\x80\x99ll take her abroad for a little\r\nwhile, and see what that\xe2\x80\x99ll do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, the aunt\xe2\x80\x99s is in Bristol, is it?\xe2\x80\x99 faltered Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no, not in Bristol,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Ben Allen, jerking his thumb over\r\nhis right shoulder; \xe2\x80\x98over that way--down there. But, hush, here\xe2\x80\x99s Bob.\r\nNot a word, my dear friend, not a word.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShort as this conversation was, it roused in Mr. Winkle the highest\r\ndegree of excitement and anxiety. The suspected prior attachment rankled\r\nin his heart. Could he be the object of it? Could it be for him that the\r\nfair Arabella had looked scornfully on the sprightly Bob Sawyer, or had\r\nhe a successful rival? He determined to see her, cost what it might; but\r\nhere an insurmountable objection presented itself, for whether the\r\nexplanatory \xe2\x80\x98over that way,\xe2\x80\x99 and \xe2\x80\x98down there,\xe2\x80\x99 of Mr. Ben Allen, meant\r\nthree miles off, or thirty, or three hundred, he could in no wise guess.\r\n\r\nBut he had no opportunity of pondering over his love just then, for Bob\r\nSawyer\xe2\x80\x99s return was the immediate precursor of the arrival of a meat-pie\r\nfrom the baker\xe2\x80\x99s, of which that gentleman insisted on his staying to\r\npartake. The cloth was laid by an occasional charwoman, who officiated\r\nin the capacity of Mr. Bob Sawyer\xe2\x80\x99s housekeeper; and a third knife and\r\nfork having been borrowed from the mother of the boy in the gray livery\r\n(for Mr. Sawyer\xe2\x80\x99s domestic arrangements were as yet conducted on a\r\nlimited scale), they sat down to dinner; the beer being served up, as\r\nMr. Sawyer remarked, \xe2\x80\x98in its native pewter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAfter dinner, Mr. Bob Sawyer ordered in the largest mortar in the shop,\r\nand proceeded to brew a reeking jorum of rum-punch therein, stirring up\r\nand amalgamating the materials with a pestle in a very creditable and\r\napothecary-like manner. Mr. Sawyer, being a bachelor, had only one\r\ntumbler in the house, which was assigned to Mr. Winkle as a compliment\r\nto the visitor, Mr. Ben Allen being accommodated with a funnel with a\r\ncork in the narrow end, and Bob Sawyer contented himself with one of\r\nthose wide-lipped crystal vessels inscribed with a variety of cabalistic\r\ncharacters, in which chemists are wont to measure out their liquid drugs\r\nin compounding prescriptions. These preliminaries adjusted, the punch\r\nwas tasted, and pronounced excellent; and it having been arranged that\r\nBob Sawyer and Ben Allen should be considered at liberty to fill twice\r\nto Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s once, they started fair, with great satisfaction and\r\ngood-fellowship.\r\n\r\nThere was no singing, because Mr. Bob Sawyer said it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t look\r\nprofessional; but to make amends for this deprivation there was so much\r\ntalking and laughing that it might have been heard, and very likely was,\r\nat the end of the street. Which conversation materially lightened the\r\nhours and improved the mind of Mr. Bob Sawyer\xe2\x80\x99s boy, who, instead of\r\ndevoting the evening to his ordinary occupation of writing his name on\r\nthe counter, and rubbing it out again, peeped through the glass door,\r\nand thus listened and looked on at the same time.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe mirth of Mr. Bob Sawyer was rapidly ripening into the furious, Mr.\r\nBen Allen was fast relapsing into the sentimental, and the punch had\r\nwell-nigh disappeared altogether, when the boy hastily running in,\r\nannounced that a young woman had just come over, to say that Sawyer late\r\nNockemorf was wanted directly, a couple of streets off. This broke up\r\nthe party. Mr. Bob Sawyer, understanding the message, after some twenty\r\nrepetitions, tied a wet cloth round his head to sober himself, and,\r\nhaving partially succeeded, put on his green spectacles and issued\r\nforth. Resisting all entreaties to stay till he came back, and finding\r\nit quite impossible to engage Mr. Ben Allen in any intelligible\r\nconversation on the subject nearest his heart, or indeed on any other,\r\nMr. Winkle took his departure, and returned to the Bush.\r\n\r\nThe anxiety of his mind, and the numerous meditations which Arabella had\r\nawakened, prevented his share of the mortar of punch producing that\r\neffect upon him which it would have had under other circumstances. So,\r\nafter taking a glass of soda-water and brandy at the bar, he turned into\r\nthe coffee-room, dispirited rather than elevated by the occurrences of\r\nthe evening.\r\n\r\nSitting in front of the fire, with his back towards him, was a tallish\r\ngentleman in a greatcoat: the only other occupant of the room. It was\r\nrather a cool evening for the season of the year, and the gentleman drew\r\nhis chair aside to afford the new-comer a sight of the fire. What were\r\nMr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s feelings when, in doing so, he disclosed to view the face\r\nand figure of the vindictive and sanguinary Dowler!\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s first impulse was to give a violent pull at the nearest\r\nbell-handle, but that unfortunately happened to be immediately behind\r\nMr. Dowler\xe2\x80\x99s head. He had made one step towards it, before he checked\r\nhimself. As he did so, Mr. Dowler very hastily drew back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Winkle, Sir. Be calm. Don\xe2\x80\x99t strike me. I won\xe2\x80\x99t bear it. A blow!\r\nNever!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Dowler, looking meeker than Mr. Winkle had expected in\r\na gentleman of his ferocity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A blow, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 stammered Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A blow, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Dowler. \xe2\x80\x98Compose your feelings. Sit down. Hear\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle, trembling from head to foot, \xe2\x80\x98before I consent\r\nto sit down beside, or opposite you, without the presence of a waiter, I\r\nmust be secured by some further understanding. You used a threat against\r\nme last night, Sir, a dreadful threat, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99 Here Mr. Winkle turned very\r\npale indeed, and stopped short.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I did,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dowler, with a countenance almost as white as Mr.\r\nWinkle\xe2\x80\x99s. \xe2\x80\x98Circumstances were suspicious. They have been explained. I\r\nrespect your bravery. Your feeling is upright. Conscious innocence.\r\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s my hand. Grasp it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Really, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle, hesitating whether to give his hand or\r\nnot, and almost fearing that it was demanded in order that he might be\r\ntaken at an advantage, \xe2\x80\x98really, Sir, I--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know what you mean,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Dowler. \xe2\x80\x98You feel aggrieved. Very\r\nnatural. So should I. I was wrong. I beg your pardon. Be friendly.\r\nForgive me.\xe2\x80\x99 With this, Dowler fairly forced his hand upon Mr. Winkle,\r\nand shaking it with the utmost vehemence, declared he was a fellow of\r\nextreme spirit, and he had a higher opinion of him than ever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dowler, \xe2\x80\x98sit down. Relate it all. How did you find me? When\r\ndid you follow? Be frank. Tell me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s quite accidental,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Winkle, greatly perplexed by the\r\ncurious and unexpected nature of the interview. \xe2\x80\x98Quite.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Glad of it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dowler. \xe2\x80\x98I woke this morning. I had forgotten my\r\nthreat. I laughed at the accident. I felt friendly. I said so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To whom?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To Mrs. Dowler. \xe2\x80\x9cYou made a vow,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cI did,\xe2\x80\x9d said I. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was a\r\nrash one,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was,\xe2\x80\x9d said I. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll apologise. Where is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Dowler. \xe2\x80\x98I went downstairs. You were not to be found.\r\nPickwick looked gloomy. Shook his head. Hoped no violence would be\r\ncommitted. I saw it all. You felt yourself insulted. You had gone, for a\r\nfriend perhaps. Possibly for pistols. \xe2\x80\x9cHigh spirit,\xe2\x80\x9d said I. \xe2\x80\x9cI admire\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle coughed, and beginning to see how the land lay, assumed a\r\nlook of importance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I left a note for you,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Dowler. \xe2\x80\x98I said I was sorry. So I was.\r\nPressing business called me here. You were not satisfied. You followed.\r\nYou required a verbal explanation. You were right. It\xe2\x80\x99s all over now. My\r\nbusiness is finished. I go back to-morrow. Join me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Dowler progressed in his explanation, Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s countenance grew\r\nmore and more dignified. The mysterious nature of the commencement of\r\ntheir conversation was explained; Mr. Dowler had as great an objection\r\nto duelling as himself; in short, this blustering and awful personage\r\nwas one of the most egregious cowards in existence, and interpreting Mr.\r\nWinkle\xe2\x80\x99s absence through the medium of his own fears, had taken the same\r\nstep as himself, and prudently retired until all excitement of feeling\r\nshould have subsided.\r\n\r\nAs the real state of the case dawned upon Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s mind, he looked\r\nvery terrible, and said he was perfectly satisfied; but at the same\r\ntime, said so with an air that left Mr. Dowler no alternative but to\r\ninfer that if he had not been, something most horrible and destructive\r\nmust inevitably have occurred. Mr. Dowler appeared to be impressed with\r\na becoming sense of Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s magnanimity and condescension; and the\r\ntwo belligerents parted for the night, with many protestations of\r\neternal friendship.\r\n\r\nAbout half-past twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock, when Mr. Winkle had been revelling some\r\ntwenty minutes in the full luxury of his first sleep, he was suddenly\r\nawakened by a loud knocking at his chamber door, which, being repeated\r\nwith increased vehemence, caused him to start up in bed, and inquire who\r\nwas there, and what the matter was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Please, Sir, here\xe2\x80\x99s a young man which says he must see you directly,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nresponded the voice of the chambermaid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A young man!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No mistake about that \xe2\x80\x98ere, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied another voice through the\r\nkeyhole; \xe2\x80\x98and if that wery same interestin\xe2\x80\x99 young creetur ain\xe2\x80\x99t let in\r\nvithout delay, it\xe2\x80\x99s wery possible as his legs vill enter afore his\r\ncountenance.\xe2\x80\x99 The young man gave a gentle kick at one of the lower\r\npanels of the door, after he had given utterance to this hint, as if to\r\nadd force and point to the remark.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is that you, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Winkle, springing out of bed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite unpossible to identify any gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n vith any degree o\xe2\x80\x99 mental\r\nsatisfaction, vithout lookin\xe2\x80\x99 at him, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the voice\r\ndogmatically.\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle, not much doubting who the young man was, unlocked the door;\r\nwhich he had no sooner done than Mr. Samuel Weller entered with great\r\nprecipitation, and carefully relocking it on the inside, deliberately\r\nput the key in his waistcoat pocket; and, after surveying Mr. Winkle\r\nfrom head to foot, said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re a wery humorous young gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n, you air, Sir!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean by this conduct, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Winkle\r\nindignantly. \xe2\x80\x98Get out, sir, this instant. What do you mean, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do I mean,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Sam; \xe2\x80\x98come, Sir, this is rayther too rich, as\r\nthe young lady said when she remonstrated with the pastry-cook, arter\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99d sold her a pork pie as had got nothin\xe2\x80\x99 but fat inside. What do I\r\nmean! Well, that ain\xe2\x80\x99t a bad \xe2\x80\x98un, that ain\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Unlock that door, and leave this room immediately, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nWinkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall leave this here room, sir, just precisely at the wery same\r\nmoment as you leaves it,\xe2\x80\x99 responded Sam, speaking in a forcible manner,\r\nand seating himself with perfect gravity. \xe2\x80\x98If I find it necessary to\r\ncarry you away, pick-a-back, o\xe2\x80\x99 course I shall leave it the least bit o\xe2\x80\x99\r\ntime possible afore you; but allow me to express a hope as you won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nreduce me to extremities; in saying wich, I merely quote wot the\r\nnobleman said to the fractious pennywinkle, ven he vouldn\xe2\x80\x99t come out of\r\nhis shell by means of a pin, and he conseqvently began to be afeered\r\nthat he should be obliged to crack him in the parlour door.\xe2\x80\x99 At the end\r\nof this address, which was unusually lengthy for him, Mr. Weller planted\r\nhis hands on his knees, and looked full in Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s face, with an\r\nexpression of countenance which showed that he had not the remotest\r\nintention of being trifled with.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re a amiably-disposed young man, Sir, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Mr.\r\nWeller, in a tone of moral reproof, \xe2\x80\x98to go inwolving our precious\r\ngovernor in all sorts o\xe2\x80\x99 fanteegs, wen he\xe2\x80\x99s made up his mind to go\r\nthrough everythink for principle. You\xe2\x80\x99re far worse nor Dodson, Sir; and\r\nas for Fogg, I consider him a born angel to you!\xe2\x80\x99 Mr. Weller having\r\naccompanied this last sentiment with an emphatic slap on each knee,\r\nfolded his arms with a look of great disgust, and threw himself back in\r\nhis chair, as if awaiting the criminal\xe2\x80\x99s defence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My good fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle, extending his hand--his teeth\r\nchattering all the time he spoke, for he had been standing, during the\r\nwhole of Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s lecture, in his night-gear--\xe2\x80\x98my good fellow, I\r\nrespect your attachment to my excellent friend, and I am very sorry\r\nindeed to have added to his causes for disquiet. There, Sam, there!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, rather sulkily, but giving the proffered hand a\r\nrespectful shake at the same time--\xe2\x80\x98well, so you ought to be, and I am\r\nvery glad to find you air; for, if I can help it, I won\xe2\x80\x99t have him put\r\nupon by nobody, and that\xe2\x80\x99s all about it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly not, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle. \xe2\x80\x98There! Now go to bed, Sam, and\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ll talk further about this in the morning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m wery sorry,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98but I can\xe2\x80\x99t go to bed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not go to bed!\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, shaking his head. \xe2\x80\x98Can\xe2\x80\x99t be done.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to say you\xe2\x80\x99re going back to-night, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 urged Mr.\r\nWinkle, greatly surprised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not unless you particklerly wish it,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam; \xe2\x80\x98but I mustn\xe2\x80\x99t leave\r\nthis here room. The governor\xe2\x80\x99s orders wos peremptory.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle, \xe2\x80\x98I must stop here two or three days;\r\nand more than that, Sam, you must stop here too, to assist me in gaining\r\nan interview with a young lady--Miss Allen, Sam; you remember her--whom\r\nI must and will see before I leave Bristol.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut in reply to each of these positions, Sam shook his head with great\r\nfirmness, and energetically replied, \xe2\x80\x98It can\xe2\x80\x99t be done.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAfter a great deal of argument and representation on the part of Mr.\r\nWinkle, however, and a full disclosure of what had passed in the\r\ninterview with Dowler, Sam began to waver; and at length a compromise\r\nwas effected, of which the following were the main and principal\r\nconditions:--\r\n\r\nThat Sam should retire, and leave Mr. Winkle in the undisturbed\r\npossession of his apartment, on the condition that he had permission to\r\nlock the door on the outside, and carry off the key; provided always,\r\nthat in the event of an alarm of fire, or other dangerous contingency,\r\nthe door should be instantly unlocked. That a letter should be written\r\nto Mr. Pickwick early next morning, and forwarded per Dowler, requesting\r\nhis consent to Sam and Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s remaining at Bristol, for the\r\npurpose and with the object already assigned, and begging an answer by\r\nthe next coach--, if favourable, the aforesaid parties to remain\r\naccordingly, and if not, to return to Bath immediately on the receipt\r\nthereof. And, lastly, that Mr. Winkle should be understood as distinctly\r\npledging himself not to resort to the window, fireplace, or other\r\nsurreptitious mode of escape in the meanwhile. These stipulations having\r\nbeen concluded, Sam locked the door and departed.\r\n\r\nHe had nearly got downstairs, when he stopped, and drew the key from his\r\npocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I quite forgot about the knockin\xe2\x80\x99 down,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, half turning back.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The governor distinctly said it was to be done. Amazin\xe2\x80\x99 stupid o\xe2\x80\x99 me,\r\nthat \xe2\x80\x98ere! Never mind,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, brightening up, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s easily done to-\r\nmorrow, anyvays.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nApparently much consoled by this reflection, Mr. Weller once more\r\ndeposited the key in his pocket, and descending the remainder of the\r\nstairs without any fresh visitations of conscience, was soon, in common\r\nwith the other inmates of the house, buried in profound repose.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIX. MR. SAMUEL WELLER, BEING INTRUSTED WITH A MISSION OF\r\nLOVE, PROCEEDS TO EXECUTE IT; WITH WHAT SUCCESS WILL HEREINAFTER APPEAR\r\n\r\nDuring the whole of next day, Sam kept Mr. Winkle steadily in sight,\r\nfully determined not to take his eyes off him for one instant, until he\r\nshould receive express instructions from the fountain-head. However\r\ndisagreeable Sam\xe2\x80\x99s very close watch and great vigilance were to Mr.\r\nWinkle, he thought it better to bear with them, than, by any act of\r\nviolent opposition, to hazard being carried away by force, which Mr.\r\nWeller more than once strongly hinted was the line of conduct that a\r\nstrict sense of duty prompted him to pursue. There is little reason to\r\ndoubt that Sam would very speedily have quieted his scruples, by bearing\r\nMr. Winkle back to Bath, bound hand and foot, had not Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nprompt attention to the note, which Dowler had undertaken to deliver,\r\nforestalled any such proceeding. In short, at eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the\r\nevening, Mr. Pickwick himself walked into the coffee-room of the Bush\r\nTavern, and told Sam with a smile, to his very great relief, that he had\r\ndone quite right, and it was unnecessary for him to mount guard any\r\nlonger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought it better to come myself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, addressing Mr.\r\nWinkle, as Sam disencumbered him of his great-coat and travelling-shawl,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98to ascertain, before I gave my consent to Sam\xe2\x80\x99s employment in this\r\nmatter, that you are quite in earnest and serious, with respect to this\r\nyoung lady.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Serious, from my heart--from my soul!\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr. Winkle, with great\r\nenergy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Remember,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with beaming eyes, \xe2\x80\x98we met her at our\r\nexcellent and hospitable friend\xe2\x80\x99s, Winkle. It would be an ill return to\r\ntamper lightly, and without due consideration, with this young lady\xe2\x80\x99s\r\naffections. I\xe2\x80\x99ll not allow that, sir. I\xe2\x80\x99ll not allow it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have no such intention, indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Winkle warmly. \xe2\x80\x98I have\r\nconsidered the matter well, for a long time, and I feel that my\r\nhappiness is bound up in her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s wot we call tying it up in a small parcel, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr.\r\nWeller, with an agreeable smile.\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle looked somewhat stern at this interruption, and Mr. Pickwick\r\nangrily requested his attendant not to jest with one of the best\r\nfeelings of our nature; to which Sam replied, \xe2\x80\x98That he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t, if he\r\nwas aware on it; but there were so many on \xe2\x80\x98em, that he hardly know\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nwhich was the best ones wen he heerd \xe2\x80\x98em mentioned.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle then recounted what had passed between himself and Mr. Ben\r\nAllen, relative to Arabella; stated that his object was to gain an\r\ninterview with the young lady, and make a formal disclosure of his\r\npassion; and declared his conviction, founded on certain dark hints and\r\nmutterings of the aforesaid Ben, that, wherever she was at present\r\nimmured, it was somewhere near the Downs. And this was his whole stock\r\nof knowledge or suspicion on the subject.\r\n\r\nWith this very slight clue to guide him, it was determined that Mr.\r\nWeller should start next morning on an expedition of discovery; it was\r\nalso arranged that Mr. Pickwick and Mr. Winkle, who were less confident\r\nof their powers, should parade the town meanwhile, and accidentally drop\r\nin upon Mr. Bob Sawyer in the course of the day, in the hope of seeing\r\nor hearing something of the young lady\xe2\x80\x99s whereabouts.\r\n\r\nAccordingly, next morning, Sam Weller issued forth upon his quest, in no\r\nway daunted by the very discouraging prospect before him; and away he\r\nwalked, up one street and down another--we were going to say, up one\r\nhill and down another, only it\xe2\x80\x99s all uphill at Clifton--without meeting\r\nwith anything or anybody that tended to throw the faintest light on the\r\nmatter in hand. Many were the colloquies into which Sam entered with\r\ngrooms who were airing horses on roads, and nursemaids who were airing\r\nchildren in lanes; but nothing could Sam elicit from either the first-\r\nmentioned or the last, which bore the slightest reference to the object\r\nof his artfully-prosecuted inquiries. There were a great many young\r\nladies in a great many houses, the greater part whereof were shrewdly\r\nsuspected by the male and female domestics to be deeply attached to\r\nsomebody, or perfectly ready to become so, if opportunity afforded. But\r\nas none among these young ladies was Miss Arabella Allen, the\r\ninformation left Sam at exactly the old point of wisdom at which he had\r\nstood before.\r\n\r\nSam struggled across the Downs against a good high wind, wondering\r\nwhether it was always necessary to hold your hat on with both hands in\r\nthat part of the country, and came to a shady by-place, about which were\r\nsprinkled several little villas of quiet and secluded appearance.\r\nOutside a stable door at the bottom of a long back lane without a\r\nthoroughfare, a groom in undress was idling about, apparently persuading\r\nhimself that he was doing something with a spade and a wheel-barrow. We\r\nmay remark, in this place, that we have scarcely ever seen a groom near\r\na stable, in his lazy moments, who has not been, to a greater or less\r\nextent, the victim of this singular delusion.\r\n\r\nSam thought he might as well talk to this groom as to any one else,\r\nespecially as he was very tired with walking, and there was a good large\r\nstone just opposite the wheel-barrow; so he strolled down the lane, and,\r\nseating himself on the stone, opened a conversation with the ease and\r\nfreedom for which he was remarkable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mornin\xe2\x80\x99, old friend,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Arternoon, you mean,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the groom, casting a surly look at Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re wery right, old friend,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam; \xe2\x80\x98I _do_ mean arternoon. How\r\nare you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, I don\xe2\x80\x99t find myself much the better for seeing of you,\xe2\x80\x99 replied\r\nthe ill-tempered groom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s wery odd--that is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98for you look so uncommon\r\ncheerful, and seem altogether so lively, that it does vun\xe2\x80\x99s heart good\r\nto see you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe surly groom looked surlier still at this, but not sufficiently so to\r\nproduce any effect upon Sam, who immediately inquired, with a\r\ncountenance of great anxiety, whether his master\xe2\x80\x99s name was not Walker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, it ain\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 said the groom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nor Brown, I s\xe2\x80\x99pose?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, it ain\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nor Vilson?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No; nor that either,\xe2\x80\x99 said the groom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vell,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam, \xe2\x80\x98then I\xe2\x80\x99m mistaken, and he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t got the honour o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nmy acquaintance, which I thought he had. Don\xe2\x80\x99t wait here out o\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncompliment to me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, as the groom wheeled in the barrow, and\r\nprepared to shut the gate. \xe2\x80\x98Ease afore ceremony, old boy; I\xe2\x80\x99ll excuse\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99d knock your head off for half-a-crown,\xe2\x80\x99 said the surly groom,\r\nbolting one half of the gate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Couldn\xe2\x80\x99t afford to have it done on those terms,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Sam. \xe2\x80\x98It \xe2\x80\x98ud\r\nbe worth a life\xe2\x80\x99s board wages at least, to you, and \xe2\x80\x98ud be cheap at\r\nthat. Make my compliments indoors. Tell \xe2\x80\x98em not to vait dinner for me,\r\nand say they needn\xe2\x80\x99t mind puttin\xe2\x80\x99 any by, for it\xe2\x80\x99ll be cold afore I come\r\nin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn reply to this, the groom waxing very wroth, muttered a desire to\r\ndamage somebody\xe2\x80\x99s person; but disappeared without carrying it into\r\nexecution, slamming the door angrily after him, and wholly unheeding\r\nSam\xe2\x80\x99s affectionate request, that he would leave him a lock of his hair\r\nbefore he went.\r\n\r\nSam continued to sit on the large stone, meditating upon what was best\r\nto be done, and revolving in his mind a plan for knocking at all the\r\ndoors within five miles of Bristol, taking them at a hundred and fifty\r\nor two hundred a day, and endeavouring to find Miss Arabella by that\r\nexpedient, when accident all of a sudden threw in his way what he might\r\nhave sat there for a twelvemonth and yet not found without it.\r\n\r\nInto the lane where he sat, there opened three or four garden gates,\r\nbelonging to as many houses, which though detached from each other, were\r\nonly separated by their gardens. As these were large and long, and well\r\nplanted with trees, the houses were not only at some distance off, but\r\nthe greater part of them were nearly concealed from view. Sam was\r\nsitting with his eyes fixed upon the dust-heap outside the next gate to\r\nthat by which the groom had disappeared, profoundly turning over in his\r\nmind the difficulties of his present undertaking, when the gate opened,\r\nand a female servant came out into the lane to shake some bedside\r\ncarpets.\r\n\r\nSam was so very busy with his own thoughts, that it is probable he would\r\nhave taken no more notice of the young woman than just raising his head\r\nand remarking that she had a very neat and pretty figure, if his\r\nfeelings of gallantry had not been most strongly roused by observing\r\nthat she had no one to help her, and that the carpets seemed too heavy\r\nfor her single strength. Mr. Weller was a gentleman of great gallantry\r\nin his own way, and he no sooner remarked this circumstance than he\r\nhastily rose from the large stone, and advanced towards her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, sliding up with an air of great respect, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nspile that wery pretty figure out o\xe2\x80\x99 all perportion if you shake them\r\ncarpets by yourself. Let me help you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe young lady, who had been coyly affecting not to know that a\r\ngentleman was so near, turned round as Sam spoke--no doubt (indeed she\r\nsaid so, afterwards) to decline this offer from a perfect stranger--when\r\ninstead of speaking, she started back, and uttered a half-suppressed\r\nscream. Sam was scarcely less staggered, for in the countenance of the\r\nwell-shaped female servant, he beheld the very features of his\r\nvalentine, the pretty housemaid from Mr. Nupkins\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wy, Mary, my dear!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lauk, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary, \xe2\x80\x98how you do frighten one!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSam made no verbal answer to this complaint, nor can we precisely say\r\nwhat reply he did make. We merely know that after a short pause Mary\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x98Lor, do adun, Mr. Weller!\xe2\x80\x99 and that his hat had fallen off a few\r\nmoments before--from both of which tokens we should be disposed to infer\r\nthat one kiss, or more, had passed between the parties.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, how did you come here?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary, when the conversation to which\r\nthis interruption had been offered, was resumed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O\xe2\x80\x99 course I came to look arter you, my darlin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller;\r\nfor once permitting his passion to get the better of his veracity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And how did you know I was here?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mary. \xe2\x80\x98Who could have told\r\nyou that I took another service at Ipswich, and that they afterwards\r\nmoved all the way here? Who _could _have told you that, Mr. Weller?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, to be sure,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, with a cunning look, \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s the pint. Who\r\ncould ha\xe2\x80\x99 told me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t Mr. Muzzle, was it?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, no.\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam, with a solemn shake of the head, \xe2\x80\x98it warn\xe2\x80\x99t him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It must have been the cook,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O\xe2\x80\x99 course it must,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, I never heard the like of that!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No more did I,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98But Mary, my dear\xe2\x80\x99--here Sam\xe2\x80\x99s manner grew\r\nextremely affectionate--\xe2\x80\x98Mary, my dear, I\xe2\x80\x99ve got another affair in hand\r\nas is wery pressin\xe2\x80\x99. There\xe2\x80\x99s one o\xe2\x80\x99 my governor\xe2\x80\x99s friends--Mr. Winkle,\r\nyou remember him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Him in the green coat?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, yes, I remember him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98he\xe2\x80\x99s in a horrid state o\xe2\x80\x99 love; reg\xe2\x80\x99larly comfoozled,\r\nand done over vith it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lor!\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam; \xe2\x80\x98but that\xe2\x80\x99s nothin\xe2\x80\x99 if we could find out the young\r\n\xe2\x80\x98ooman;\xe2\x80\x99 and here Sam, with many digressions upon the personal beauty of\r\nMary, and the unspeakable tortures he had experienced since he last saw\r\nher, gave a faithful account of Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s present predicament.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary, \xe2\x80\x98I never did!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O\xe2\x80\x99 course not,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98and nobody never did, nor never vill\r\nneither; and here am I a-walkin\xe2\x80\x99 about like the wandering Jew--a\r\nsportin\xe2\x80\x99 character you have perhaps heerd on Mary, my dear, as vos\r\nalvays doin\xe2\x80\x99 a match agin\xe2\x80\x99 time, and never vent to sleep--looking arter\r\nthis here Miss Arabella Allen.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Miss who?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary, in great astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Miss Arabella Allen,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Goodness gracious!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary, pointing to the garden door which the\r\nsulky groom had locked after him. \xe2\x80\x98Why, it\xe2\x80\x99s that very house; she\xe2\x80\x99s been\r\nliving there these six weeks. Their upper house-maid, which is lady\xe2\x80\x99s-\r\nmaid too, told me all about it over the wash-house palin\xe2\x80\x99s before the\r\nfamily was out of bed, one mornin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot, the wery next door to you?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The very next,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mary.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller was so deeply overcome on receiving this intelligence that he\r\nfound it absolutely necessary to cling to his fair informant for\r\nsupport; and divers little love passages had passed between them, before\r\nhe was sufficiently collected to return to the subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vell,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam at length, \xe2\x80\x98if this don\xe2\x80\x99t beat cock-fightin\xe2\x80\x99 nothin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nnever vill, as the lord mayor said, ven the chief secretary o\xe2\x80\x99 state\r\nproposed his missis\xe2\x80\x99s health arter dinner. That wery next house! Wy,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve got a message to her as I\xe2\x80\x99ve been a-trying all day to deliver.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary, \xe2\x80\x98but you can\xe2\x80\x99t deliver it now, because she only walks\r\nin the garden in the evening, and then only for a very little time; she\r\nnever goes out, without the old lady.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSam ruminated for a few moments, and finally hit upon the following plan\r\nof operations; that he should return just at dusk--the time at which\r\nArabella invariably took her walk--and, being admitted by Mary into the\r\ngarden of the house to which she belonged, would contrive to scramble up\r\nthe wall, beneath the overhanging boughs of a large pear-tree, which\r\nwould effectually screen him from observation; would there deliver his\r\nmessage, and arrange, if possible, an interview on behalf of Mr. Winkle\r\nfor the ensuing evening at the same hour. Having made this arrangement\r\nwith great despatch, he assisted Mary in the long-deferred occupation of\r\nshaking the carpets.\r\n\r\nIt is not half as innocent a thing as it looks, that shaking little\r\npieces of carpet--at least, there may be no great harm in the shaking,\r\nbut the folding is a very insidious process. So long as the shaking\r\nlasts, and the two parties are kept the carpet\xe2\x80\x99s length apart, it is as\r\ninnocent an amusement as can well be devised; but when the folding\r\nbegins, and the distance between them gets gradually lessened from one\r\nhalf its former length to a quarter, and then to an eighth, and then to\r\na sixteenth, and then to a thirty-second, if the carpet be long enough,\r\nit becomes dangerous. We do not know, to a nicety, how many pieces of\r\ncarpet were folded in this instance, but we can venture to state that as\r\nmany pieces as there were, so many times did Sam kiss the pretty\r\nhousemaid.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller regaled himself with moderation at the nearest tavern until\r\nit was nearly dusk, and then returned to the lane without the\r\nthoroughfare. Having been admitted into the garden by Mary, and having\r\nreceived from that lady sundry admonitions concerning the safety of his\r\nlimbs and neck, Sam mounted into the pear-tree, to wait until Arabella\r\nshould come into sight.\r\n\r\nHe waited so long without this anxiously-expected event occurring, that\r\nhe began to think it was not going to take place at all, when he heard\r\nlight footsteps upon the gravel, and immediately afterwards beheld\r\nArabella walking pensively down the garden. As soon as she came nearly\r\nbelow the tree, Sam began, by way of gently indicating his presence, to\r\nmake sundry diabolical noises similar to those which would probably be\r\nnatural to a person of middle age who had been afflicted with a\r\ncombination of inflammatory sore throat, croup, and whooping-cough, from\r\nhis earliest infancy.\r\n\r\nUpon this, the young lady cast a hurried glance towards the spot whence\r\nthe dreadful sounds proceeded; and her previous alarm being not at all\r\ndiminished when she saw a man among the branches, she would most\r\ncertainly have decamped, and alarmed the house, had not fear fortunately\r\ndeprived her of the power of moving, and caused her to sink down on a\r\ngarden seat, which happened by good luck to be near at hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She\xe2\x80\x99s a-goin\xe2\x80\x99 off,\xe2\x80\x99 soliloquised Sam in great perplexity. \xe2\x80\x98Wot a thing\r\nit is, as these here young creeturs will go a-faintin\xe2\x80\x99 avay just ven\r\nthey oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t to. Here, young \xe2\x80\x98ooman, Miss Sawbones, Mrs. Vinkle,\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhether it was the magic of Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s name, or the coolness of the\r\nopen air, or some recollection of Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s voice, that revived\r\nArabella, matters not. She raised her head and languidly inquired,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who\xe2\x80\x99s that, and what do you want?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hush,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, swinging himself on to the wall, and crouching there\r\nin as small a compass as he could reduce himself to, \xe2\x80\x98only me, miss,\r\nonly me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s servant!\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella earnestly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The wery same, miss,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Here\xe2\x80\x99s Mr. Vinkle reg\xe2\x80\x99larly sewed\r\nup vith desperation, miss.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella, drawing nearer the wall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Ve thought ve should ha\xe2\x80\x99 been obliged to\r\nstrait-veskit him last night; he\xe2\x80\x99s been a-ravin\xe2\x80\x99 all day; and he says if\r\nhe can\xe2\x80\x99t see you afore to-morrow night\xe2\x80\x99s over, he vishes he may be\r\nsomethin\xe2\x80\x99 unpleasanted if he don\xe2\x80\x99t drownd hisself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, no, no, Mr. Weller!\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella, clasping her hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s wot he says, miss,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam coolly. \xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s a man of his word,\r\nand it\xe2\x80\x99s my opinion he\xe2\x80\x99ll do it, miss. He\xe2\x80\x99s heerd all about you from the\r\nsawbones in barnacles.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98From my brother!\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella, having some faint recognition of Sam\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndescription.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t rightly know which is your brother, miss,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Is it\r\nthe dirtiest vun o\xe2\x80\x99 the two?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, yes, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Arabella, \xe2\x80\x98go on.
