Will you have the kindness to put my\r\ncompliments into the first little parcel you\xe2\x80\x99re sending that way, sir,\r\nand say that I would have sent \xe2\x80\x98em before, only I was afraid they might\r\nbe broken in the wagon, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t overwhelm the gentlemen with ordinary civilities when you see\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s anxious to have something to drink,\xe2\x80\x99 said the gentleman with the\r\nwhiskers, with a jocose air. \xe2\x80\x98Why don\xe2\x80\x99t you ask the gentleman what he\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ntake?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me, I quite forgot,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the other. \xe2\x80\x98What will you take, sir?\r\nWill you take port wine, sir, or sherry wine, sir? I can recommend the\r\nale, sir; or perhaps you\xe2\x80\x99d like to taste the porter, sir? Allow me to\r\nhave the felicity of hanging up your nightcap, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith this, the speaker snatched that article of dress from Mr.\r\nPickwick\xe2\x80\x99s head, and fixed it in a twinkling on that of the drunken man,\r\nwho, firmly impressed with the belief that he was delighting a numerous\r\nassembly, continued to hammer away at the comic song in the most\r\nmelancholy strains imaginable.\r\n\r\nTaking a man\xe2\x80\x99s nightcap from his brow by violent means, and adjusting it\r\non the head of an unknown gentleman, of dirty exterior, however\r\ningenious a witticism in itself, is unquestionably one of those which\r\ncome under the denomination of practical jokes. Viewing the matter\r\nprecisely in this light, Mr. Pickwick, without the slightest intimation\r\nof his purpose, sprang vigorously out of bed, struck the Zephyr so smart\r\na blow in the chest as to deprive him of a considerable portion of the\r\ncommodity which sometimes bears his name, and then, recapturing his\r\nnightcap, boldly placed himself in an attitude of defence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, gasping no less from excitement than from the\r\nexpenditure of so much energy, \xe2\x80\x98come on--both of you--both of you!\xe2\x80\x99 With\r\nthis liberal invitation the worthy gentleman communicated a revolving\r\nmotion to his clenched fists, by way of appalling his antagonists with a\r\ndisplay of science.\r\n\r\nIt might have been Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s very unexpected gallantry, or it might\r\nhave been the complicated manner in which he had got himself out of bed,\r\nand fallen all in a mass upon the hornpipe man, that touched his\r\nadversaries. Touched they were; for, instead of then and there making an\r\nattempt to commit man-slaughter, as Mr. Pickwick implicitly believed\r\nthey would have done, they paused, stared at each other a short time,\r\nand finally laughed outright.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, you\xe2\x80\x99re a trump, and I like you all the better for it,\xe2\x80\x99 said the\r\nZephyr. \xe2\x80\x98Now jump into bed again, or you\xe2\x80\x99ll catch the rheumatics. No\r\nmalice, I hope?\xe2\x80\x99 said the man, extending a hand the size of the yellow\r\nclump of fingers which sometimes swings over a glover\xe2\x80\x99s door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly not,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with great alacrity; for, now that\r\nthe excitement was over, he began to feel rather cool about the legs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Allow me the H-onour,\xe2\x80\x99 said the gentleman with the whiskers, presenting\r\nhis dexter hand, and aspirating the h.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With much pleasure, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; and having executed a very\r\nlong and solemn shake, he got into bed again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My name is Smangle, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man with the whiskers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mine is Mivins,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man in the stockings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am delighted to hear it, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hem,\xe2\x80\x99 coughed Mr. Smangle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you speak, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I did not, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Smangle.\r\n\r\nAll this was very genteel and pleasant; and, to make matters still more\r\ncomfortable, Mr. Smangle assured Mr. Pickwick a great many more times\r\nthat he entertained a very high respect for the feelings of a gentleman;\r\nwhich sentiment, indeed, did him infinite credit, as he could be in no\r\nwise supposed to understand them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you going through the court, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Smangle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Through the what?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Through the court--Portugal Street--the Court for Relief of--you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, no,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98No, I am not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Going out, perhaps?\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Mr. Mivins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I fear not,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98I refuse to pay some damages, and\r\nam here in consequence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Smangle, \xe2\x80\x98paper has been my ruin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A stationer, I presume, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick innocently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stationer! No, no; confound and curse me! Not so low as that. No trade.\r\nWhen I say paper, I mean bills.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, you use the word in that sense. I see,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Damme! A gentleman must expect reverses,\xe2\x80\x99 said Smangle. \xe2\x80\x98What of that?\r\nHere am I in the Fleet Prison. Well; good. What then? I\xe2\x80\x99m none the worse\r\nfor that, am I?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a bit,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Mivins. And he was quite right; for, so far\r\nfrom Mr. Smangle being any the worse for it, he was something the\r\nbetter, inasmuch as to qualify himself for the place, he had attained\r\ngratuitous possession of certain articles of jewellery, which, long\r\nbefore that, had found their way to the pawnbroker\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well; but come,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Smangle; \xe2\x80\x98this is dry work. Let\xe2\x80\x99s rinse our\r\nmouths with a drop of burnt sherry; the last-comer shall stand it,\r\nMivins shall fetch it, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll help to drink it. That\xe2\x80\x99s a fair and\r\ngentlemanlike division of labour, anyhow. Curse me!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nUnwilling to hazard another quarrel, Mr. Pickwick gladly assented to the\r\nproposition, and consigned the money to Mr. Mivins, who, as it was\r\nnearly eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, lost no time in repairing to the coffee-room on\r\nhis errand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Smangle, the moment his friend had left the room;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98what did you give him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Half a sovereign,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s a devilish pleasant gentlemanly dog,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Smangle;--\xe2\x80\x98infernal\r\npleasant. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know anybody more so; but--\xe2\x80\x99 Here Mr. Smangle stopped\r\nshort, and shook his head dubiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t think there is any probability of his appropriating the money\r\nto his own use?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, no! Mind, I don\xe2\x80\x99t say that; I expressly say that he\xe2\x80\x99s a devilish\r\ngentlemanly fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Smangle. \xe2\x80\x98But I think, perhaps, if\r\nsomebody went down, just to see that he didn\xe2\x80\x99t dip his beak into the jug\r\nby accident, or make some confounded mistake in losing the money as he\r\ncame upstairs, it would be as well. Here, you sir, just run downstairs,\r\nand look after that gentleman, will you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis request was addressed to a little timid-looking, nervous man, whose\r\nappearance bespoke great poverty, and who had been crouching on his\r\nbedstead all this while, apparently stupefied by the novelty of his\r\nsituation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You know where the coffee-room is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Smangle; \xe2\x80\x98just run down, and\r\ntell that gentleman you\xe2\x80\x99ve come to help him up with the jug. Or--stop--\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what--I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you how we\xe2\x80\x99ll do him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Smangle, with\r\na cunning look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Send down word that he\xe2\x80\x99s to spend the change in cigars. Capital\r\nthought. Run and tell him that; d\xe2\x80\x99ye hear? They shan\xe2\x80\x99t be wasted,\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncontinued Smangle, turning to Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98_I\xe2\x80\x99ll_ smoke \xe2\x80\x98em.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis manoeuvring was so exceedingly ingenious and, withal, performed\r\nwith such immovable composure and coolness, that Mr. Pickwick would have\r\nhad no wish to disturb it, even if he had had the power. In a short time\r\nMr. Mivins returned, bearing the sherry, which Mr. Smangle dispensed in\r\ntwo little cracked mugs; considerately remarking, with reference to\r\nhimself, that a gentleman must not be particular under such\r\ncircumstances, and that, for his part, he was not too proud to drink out\r\nof the jug. In which, to show his sincerity, he forthwith pledged the\r\ncompany in a draught which half emptied it.\r\n\r\nAn excellent understanding having been by these means promoted, Mr.\r\nSmangle proceeded to entertain his hearers with a relation of divers\r\nromantic adventures in which he had been from time to time engaged,\r\ninvolving various interesting anecdotes of a thoroughbred horse, and a\r\nmagnificent Jewess, both of surpassing beauty, and much coveted by the\r\nnobility and gentry of these kingdoms.\r\n\r\nLong before these elegant extracts from the biography of a gentleman\r\nwere concluded, Mr. Mivins had betaken himself to bed, and had set in\r\nsnoring for the night, leaving the timid stranger and Mr. Pickwick to\r\nthe full benefit of Mr. Smangle\xe2\x80\x99s experiences.\r\n\r\nNor were the two last-named gentlemen as much edified as they might have\r\nbeen by the moving passages narrated. Mr. Pickwick had been in a state\r\nof slumber for some time, when he had a faint perception of the drunken\r\nman bursting out afresh with the comic song, and receiving from Mr.\r\nSmangle a gentle intimation, through the medium of the water-jug, that\r\nhis audience was not musically disposed. Mr. Pickwick then once again\r\ndropped off to sleep, with a confused consciousness that Mr. Smangle was\r\nstill engaged in relating a long story, the chief point of which\r\nappeared to be that, on some occasion particularly stated and set forth,\r\nhe had \xe2\x80\x98done\xe2\x80\x99 a bill and a gentleman at the same time.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLII. ILLUSTRATIVE, LIKE THE PRECEDING ONE, OF THE OLD PROVERB,\r\nTHAT ADVERSITY BRINGS A MAN ACQUAINTED WITH STRANGE BEDFELLOWS--\r\nLIKEWISE CONTAINING MR. PICKWICK\xe2\x80\x99S EXTRAORDINARY AND STARTLING\r\nANNOUNCEMENT TO MR. SAMUEL WELLER\r\n\r\nWhen Mr. Pickwick opened his eyes next morning, the first object upon\r\nwhich they rested was Samuel Weller, seated upon a small black\r\nportmanteau, intently regarding, apparently in a condition of profound\r\nabstraction, the stately figure of the dashing Mr. Smangle; while Mr.\r\nSmangle himself, who was already partially dressed, was seated on his\r\nbedstead, occupied in the desperately hopeless attempt of staring Mr.\r\nWeller out of countenance. We say desperately hopeless, because Sam,\r\nwith a comprehensive gaze which took in Mr. Smangle\xe2\x80\x99s cap, feet, head,\r\nface, legs, and whiskers, all at the same time, continued to look\r\nsteadily on, with every demonstration of lively satisfaction, but with\r\nno more regard to Mr. Smangle\xe2\x80\x99s personal sentiments on the subject than\r\nhe would have displayed had he been inspecting a wooden statue, or a\r\nstraw-embowelled Guy Fawkes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well; will you know me again?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Smangle, with a frown.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99d svear to you anyveres, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam cheerfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t be impertinent to a gentleman, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Smangle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not on no account,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98If you\xe2\x80\x99ll tell me wen he wakes, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nbe upon the wery best extra-super behaviour!\xe2\x80\x99 This observation, having a\r\nremote tendency to imply that Mr. Smangle was no gentleman, kindled his\r\nire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mivins!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Smangle, with a passionate air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the office?\xe2\x80\x99 replied that gentleman from his couch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who the devil is this fellow?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Gad,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Mivins, looking lazily out from under the bed-clothes,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I ought to ask _you _that. Hasn\xe2\x80\x99t he any business here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Smangle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then knock him downstairs, and tell him not to presume to get up till I\r\ncome and kick him,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Mivins; with this prompt advice that\r\nexcellent gentleman again betook himself to slumber.\r\n\r\nThe conversation exhibiting these unequivocal symptoms of verging on the\r\npersonal, Mr. Pickwick deemed it a fit point at which to interpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined that gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Has anything new occurred since last night?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothin\xe2\x80\x99 partickler, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam, glancing at Mr. Smangle\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwhiskers; \xe2\x80\x98the late prewailance of a close and confined atmosphere has\r\nbeen rayther favourable to the growth of veeds, of an alarmin\xe2\x80\x99 and\r\nsangvinary natur; but vith that \xe2\x80\x98ere exception things is quiet enough.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall get up,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98give me some clean things.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhatever hostile intentions Mr. Smangle might have entertained, his\r\nthoughts were speedily diverted by the unpacking of the portmanteau; the\r\ncontents of which appeared to impress him at once with a most favourable\r\nopinion, not only of Mr. Pickwick, but of Sam also, who, he took an\r\nearly opportunity of declaring in a tone of voice loud enough for that\r\neccentric personage to overhear, was a regular thoroughbred original,\r\nand consequently the very man after his own heart. As to Mr. Pickwick,\r\nthe affection he conceived for him knew no limits.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now is there anything I can do for you, my dear Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 said Smangle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing that I am aware of, I am obliged to you,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No linen that you want sent to the washerwoman\xe2\x80\x99s? I know a delightful\r\nwasherwoman outside, that comes for my things twice a week; and, by\r\nJove!--how devilish lucky!--this is the day she calls. Shall I put any\r\nof those little things up with mine? Don\xe2\x80\x99t say anything about the\r\ntrouble. Confound and curse it! if one gentleman under a cloud is not to\r\nput himself a little out of the way to assist another gentleman in the\r\nsame condition, what\xe2\x80\x99s human nature?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThus spake Mr. Smangle, edging himself meanwhile as near as possible to\r\nthe portmanteau, and beaming forth looks of the most fervent and\r\ndisinterested friendship.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing you want to give out for the man to brush, my dear\r\ncreature, is there?\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Smangle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothin\xe2\x80\x99 whatever, my fine feller,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Sam, taking the reply into\r\nhis own mouth. \xe2\x80\x98P\xe2\x80\x99raps if vun of us wos to brush, without troubling the\r\nman, it \xe2\x80\x98ud be more agreeable for all parties, as the schoolmaster said\r\nwhen the young gentleman objected to being flogged by the butler.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing I can send in my little box to the washer-woman\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nis there?\xe2\x80\x99 said Smangle, turning from Sam to Mr. Pickwick, with an air\r\nof some discomfiture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothin\xe2\x80\x99 whatever, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Sam; \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afeered the little box must\r\nbe chock full o\xe2\x80\x99 your own as it is.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis speech was accompanied with such a very expressive look at that\r\nparticular portion of Mr. Smangle\xe2\x80\x99s attire, by the appearance of which\r\nthe skill of laundresses in getting up gentlemen\xe2\x80\x99s linen is generally\r\ntested, that he was fain to turn upon his heel, and, for the present at\r\nany rate, to give up all design on Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s purse and wardrobe. He\r\naccordingly retired in dudgeon to the racket-ground, where he made a\r\nlight and whole-some breakfast on a couple of the cigars which had been\r\npurchased on the previous night.\r\n\r\nMr. Mivins, who was no smoker, and whose account for small articles of\r\nchandlery had also reached down to the bottom of the slate, and been\r\n\xe2\x80\x98carried over\xe2\x80\x99 to the other side, remained in bed, and, in his own\r\nwords, \xe2\x80\x98took it out in sleep.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAfter breakfasting in a small closet attached to the coffee-room, which\r\nbore the imposing title of the Snuggery, the temporary inmate of which,\r\nin consideration of a small additional charge, had the unspeakable\r\nadvantage of overhearing all the conversation in the coffee-room\r\naforesaid; and, after despatching Mr. Weller on some necessary errands,\r\nMr. Pickwick repaired to the lodge, to consult Mr. Roker concerning his\r\nfuture accommodation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Accommodation, eh?\xe2\x80\x99 said that gentleman, consulting a large book.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Plenty of that, Mr. Pickwick. Your chummage ticket will be on twenty-\r\nseven, in the third.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98My what, did you say?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your chummage ticket,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Roker; \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99re up to that?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not quite,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, with a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Roker, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s as plain as Salisbury. You\xe2\x80\x99ll have a\r\nchummage ticket upon twenty-seven in the third, and them as is in the\r\nroom will be your chums.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are there many of them?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick dubiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Three,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Roker.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick coughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98One of \xe2\x80\x98em\xe2\x80\x99s a parson,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Roker, filling up a little piece of\r\npaper as he spoke; \xe2\x80\x98another\xe2\x80\x99s a butcher.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh?\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A butcher,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr. Roker, giving the nib of his pen a tap on the\r\ndesk to cure it of a disinclination to mark. \xe2\x80\x98What a thorough-paced goer\r\nhe used to be sure-ly! You remember Tom Martin, Neddy?\xe2\x80\x99 said Roker,\r\nappealing to another man in the lodge, who was paring the mud off his\r\nshoes with a five-and-twenty-bladed pocket-knife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should think so,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the party addressed, with a strong emphasis\r\non the personal pronoun.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless my dear eyes!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Roker, shaking his head slowly from side\r\nto side, and gazing abstractedly out of the grated windows before him,\r\nas if he were fondly recalling some peaceful scene of his early youth;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98it seems but yesterday that he whopped the coal-heaver down Fox-under-\r\nthe-Hill by the wharf there. I think I can see him now, a-coming up the\r\nStrand between the two street-keepers, a little sobered by the bruising,\r\nwith a patch o\xe2\x80\x99 winegar and brown paper over his right eyelid, and that\r\n\xe2\x80\x98ere lovely bulldog, as pinned the little boy arterwards, a-following at\r\nhis heels. What a rum thing time is, ain\xe2\x80\x99t it, Neddy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe gentleman to whom these observations were addressed, who appeared of\r\na taciturn and thoughtful cast, merely echoed the inquiry; Mr. Roker,\r\nshaking off the poetical and gloomy train of thought into which he had\r\nbeen betrayed, descended to the common business of life, and resumed his\r\npen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you know what the third gentlemen is?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick, not\r\nvery much gratified by this description of his future associates.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is that Simpson, Neddy?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Roker, turning to his companion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What Simpson?\xe2\x80\x99 said Neddy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, him in twenty-seven in the third, that this gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s going to\r\nbe chummed on.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, him!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Neddy; \xe2\x80\x98he\xe2\x80\x99s nothing exactly. He _was _a horse\r\nchaunter: he\xe2\x80\x99s a leg now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, so I thought,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Roker, closing the book, and placing\r\nthe small piece of paper in Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s hands. \xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s the ticket,\r\nsir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nVery much perplexed by this summary disposition of this person, Mr.\r\nPickwick walked back into the prison, revolving in his mind what he had\r\nbetter do. Convinced, however, that before he took any other steps it\r\nwould be advisable to see, and hold personal converse with, the three\r\ngentlemen with whom it was proposed to quarter him, he made the best of\r\nhis way to the third flight.\r\n\r\nAfter groping about in the gallery for some time, attempting in the dim\r\nlight to decipher the numbers on the different doors, he at length\r\nappealed to a pot-boy, who happened to be pursuing his morning\r\noccupation of gleaning for pewter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which is twenty-seven, my good fellow?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Five doors farther on,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the pot-boy. \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s the likeness of a\r\nman being hung, and smoking the while, chalked outside the door.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGuided by this direction, Mr. Pickwick proceeded slowly along the\r\ngallery until he encountered the \xe2\x80\x98portrait of a gentleman,\xe2\x80\x99 above\r\ndescribed, upon whose countenance he tapped, with the knuckle of his\r\nforefinger--gently at first, and then audibly. After repeating this\r\nprocess several times without effect, he ventured to open the door and\r\npeep in.\r\n\r\nThere was only one man in the room, and he was leaning out of window as\r\nfar as he could without overbalancing himself, endeavouring, with great\r\nperseverance, to spit upon the crown of the hat of a personal friend on\r\nthe parade below. As neither speaking, coughing, sneezing, knocking, nor\r\nany other ordinary mode of attracting attention, made this person aware\r\nof the presence of a visitor, Mr. Pickwick, after some delay, stepped up\r\nto the window, and pulled him gently by the coat tail. The individual\r\nbrought in his head and shoulders with great swiftness, and surveying\r\nMr. Pickwick from head to foot, demanded in a surly tone what the--\r\nsomething beginning with a capital H--he wanted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I believe,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, consulting his ticket--\xe2\x80\x98I believe this\r\nis twenty-seven in the third?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99 replied the gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have come here in consequence of receiving this bit of paper,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nrejoined Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hand it over,\xe2\x80\x99 said the gentleman.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick complied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think Roker might have chummed you somewhere else,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Simpson\r\n(for it was the leg), after a very discontented sort of a pause.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick thought so also; but, under all the circumstances, he\r\nconsidered it a matter of sound policy to be silent.\r\n\r\nMr. Simpson mused for a few moments after this, and then, thrusting his\r\nhead out of the window, gave a shrill whistle, and pronounced some word\r\naloud, several times. What the word was, Mr. Pickwick could not\r\ndistinguish; but he rather inferred that it must be some nickname which\r\ndistinguished Mr. Martin, from the fact of a great number of gentlemen\r\non the ground below, immediately proceeding to cry \xe2\x80\x98Butcher!\xe2\x80\x99 in\r\nimitation of the tone in which that useful class of society are wont,\r\ndiurnally, to make their presence known at area railings.\r\n\r\nSubsequent occurrences confirmed the accuracy of Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nimpression; for, in a few seconds, a gentleman, prematurely broad for\r\nhis years, clothed in a professional blue jean frock and top-boots with\r\ncircular toes, entered the room nearly out of breath, closely followed\r\nby another gentleman in very shabby black, and a sealskin cap. The\r\nlatter gentleman, who fastened his coat all the way up to his chin by\r\nmeans of a pin and a button alternately, had a very coarse red face, and\r\nlooked like a drunken chaplain; which, indeed, he was.\r\n\r\nThese two gentlemen having by turns perused Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s billet, the\r\none expressed his opinion that it was \xe2\x80\x98a rig,\xe2\x80\x99 and the other his\r\nconviction that it was \xe2\x80\x98a go.\xe2\x80\x99 Having recorded their feelings in these\r\nvery intelligible terms, they looked at Mr. Pickwick and each other in\r\nawkward silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s an aggravating thing, just as we got the beds so snug,\xe2\x80\x99 said the\r\nchaplain, looking at three dirty mattresses, each rolled up in a\r\nblanket; which occupied one corner of the room during the day, and\r\nformed a kind of slab, on which were placed an old cracked basin, ewer,\r\nand soap-dish, of common yellow earthenware, with a blue flower--\xe2\x80\x98very\r\naggravating.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Martin expressed the same opinion in rather stronger terms; Mr.\r\nSimpson, after having let a variety of expletive adjectives loose upon\r\nsociety without any substantive to accompany them, tucked up his\r\nsleeves, and began to wash the greens for dinner.\r\n\r\nWhile this was going on, Mr. Pickwick had been eyeing the room, which\r\nwas filthily dirty, and smelt intolerably close. There was no vestige of\r\neither carpet, curtain, or blind. There was not even a closet in it.\r\nUnquestionably there were but few things to put away, if there had been\r\none; but, however few in number, or small in individual amount, still,\r\nremnants of loaves and pieces of cheese, and damp towels, and scrags of\r\nmeat, and articles of wearing apparel, and mutilated crockery, and\r\nbellows without nozzles, and toasting-forks without prongs, do present\r\nsomewhat of an uncomfortable appearance when they are scattered about\r\nthe floor of a small apartment, which is the common sitting and sleeping\r\nroom of three idle men.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose this can be managed somehow,\xe2\x80\x99 said the butcher, after a\r\npretty long silence. \xe2\x80\x98What will you take to go out?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nI beg your pardon,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98What did you say? I hardly\r\nunderstand you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What will you take to be paid out?\xe2\x80\x99 said the butcher. \xe2\x80\x98The regular\r\nchummage is two-and-six. Will you take three bob?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And a bender,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested the clerical gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind that; it\xe2\x80\x99s only twopence a piece more,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nMartin. \xe2\x80\x98What do you say, now? We\xe2\x80\x99ll pay you out for three-and-sixpence\r\na week. Come!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And stand a gallon of beer down,\xe2\x80\x99 chimed in Mr. Simpson. \xe2\x80\x98There!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And drink it on the spot,\xe2\x80\x99 said the chaplain. \xe2\x80\x98Now!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I really am so wholly ignorant of the rules of this place,\xe2\x80\x99 returned\r\nMr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98that I do not yet comprehend you. Can I live anywhere\r\nelse? I thought I could not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt this inquiry Mr. Martin looked, with a countenance of excessive\r\nsurprise, at his two friends, and then each gentleman pointed with his\r\nright thumb over his left shoulder. This action imperfectly described in\r\nwords by the very feeble term of \xe2\x80\x98over the left,\xe2\x80\x99 when performed by any\r\nnumber of ladies or gentlemen who are accustomed to act in unison, has a\r\nvery graceful and airy effect; its expression is one of light and\r\nplayful sarcasm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98_Can _you!\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr. Martin, with a smile of pity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, if I knew as little of life as that, I\xe2\x80\x99d eat my hat and swallow\r\nthe buckle whole,\xe2\x80\x99 said the clerical gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So would I,\xe2\x80\x99 added the sporting one solemnly.\r\n\r\nAfter this introductory preface, the three chums informed Mr. Pickwick,\r\nin a breath, that money was, in the Fleet, just what money was out of\r\nit; that it would instantly procure him almost anything he desired; and\r\nthat, supposing he had it, and had no objection to spend it, if he only\r\nsignified his wish to have a room to himself, he might take possession\r\nof one, furnished and fitted to boot, in half an hour\xe2\x80\x99s time.\r\n\r\nWith this the parties separated, very much to their common satisfaction;\r\nMr. Pickwick once more retracing his steps to the lodge, and the three\r\ncompanions adjourning to the coffee-room, there to spend the five\r\nshillings which the clerical gentleman had, with admirable prudence and\r\nforesight, borrowed of him for the purpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I knowed it!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Roker, with a chuckle, when Mr. Pickwick stated\r\nthe object with which he had returned. \xe2\x80\x98Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I say so, Neddy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe philosophical owner of the universal penknife growled an\r\naffirmative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I knowed you\xe2\x80\x99d want a room for yourself, bless you!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Roker.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let me see. You\xe2\x80\x99ll want some furniture. You\xe2\x80\x99ll hire that of me, I\r\nsuppose? That\xe2\x80\x99s the reg\xe2\x80\x99lar thing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With great pleasure,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s a capital room up in the coffee-room flight, that belongs to a\r\nChancery prisoner,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Roker. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99ll stand you in a pound a week.\r\nI suppose you don\xe2\x80\x99t mind that?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just step there with me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Roker, taking up his hat with great\r\nalacrity; \xe2\x80\x98the matter\xe2\x80\x99s settled in five minutes. Lord! why didn\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nsay at first that you was willing to come down handsome?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe matter was soon arranged, as the turnkey had foretold. The Chancery\r\nprisoner had been there long enough to have lost his friends, fortune,\r\nhome, and happiness, and to have acquired the right of having a room to\r\nhimself. As he laboured, however, under the inconvenience of often\r\nwanting a morsel of bread, he eagerly listened to Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nproposal to rent the apartment, and readily covenanted and agreed to\r\nyield him up the sole and undisturbed possession thereof, in\r\nconsideration of the weekly payment of twenty shillings; from which fund\r\nhe furthermore contracted to pay out any person or persons that might be\r\nchummed upon it.\r\n\r\nAs they struck the bargain, Mr. Pickwick surveyed him with a painful\r\ninterest. He was a tall, gaunt, cadaverous man, in an old greatcoat and\r\nslippers, with sunken cheeks, and a restless, eager eye. His lips were\r\nbloodless, and his bones sharp and thin. God help him! the iron teeth of\r\nconfinement and privation had been slowly filing him down for twenty\r\nyears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And where will you live meanwhile, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, as he laid\r\nthe amount of the first week\xe2\x80\x99s rent, in advance, on the tottering table.\r\n\r\nThe man gathered up the money with a trembling hand, and replied that he\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t know yet; he must go and see where he could move his bed to.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am afraid, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, laying his hand gently and\r\ncompassionately on his arm--\xe2\x80\x98I am afraid you will have to live in some\r\nnoisy, crowded place. Now, pray, consider this room your own when you\r\nwant quiet, or when any of your friends come to see you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Friends!\xe2\x80\x99 interposed the man, in a voice which rattled in his throat.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98if I lay dead at the bottom of the deepest mine in the world; tight\r\nscrewed down and soldered in my coffin; rotting in the dark and filthy\r\nditch that drags its slime along, beneath the foundations of this\r\nprison; I could not be more forgotten or unheeded than I am here. I am a\r\ndead man; dead to society, without the pity they bestow on those whose\r\nsouls have passed to judgment. Friends to see me! My God! I have sunk,\r\nfrom the prime of life into old age, in this place, and there is not one\r\nto raise his hand above my bed when I lie dead upon it, and say, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is\r\na blessing he is gone!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe excitement, which had cast an unwonted light over the man\xe2\x80\x99s face,\r\nwhile he spoke, subsided as he concluded; and pressing his withered\r\nhands together in a hasty and disordered manner, he shuffled from the\r\nroom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Rides rather rusty,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Roker, with a smile. \xe2\x80\x98Ah! they\xe2\x80\x99re like\r\nthe elephants. They feel it now and then, and it makes \xe2\x80\x98em wild!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHaving made this deeply-sympathising remark, Mr. Roker entered upon his\r\narrangements with such expedition, that in a short time the room was\r\nfurnished with a carpet, six chairs, a table, a sofa bedstead, a tea-\r\nkettle, and various small articles, on hire, at the very reasonable rate\r\nof seven-and-twenty shillings and sixpence per week.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, is there anything more we can do for you?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Roker,\r\nlooking round with great satisfaction, and gaily chinking the first\r\nweek\xe2\x80\x99s hire in his closed fist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, who had been musing deeply for some time.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are there any people here who run on errands, and so forth?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Outside, do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Roker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. I mean who are able to go outside. Not prisoners.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, there is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Roker. \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s an unfortunate devil, who has got\r\na friend on the poor side, that\xe2\x80\x99s glad to do anything of that sort. He\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbeen running odd jobs, and that, for the last two months. Shall I send\r\nhim?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you please,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Stay; no. The poor side, you\r\nsay? I should like to see it. I\xe2\x80\x99ll go to him myself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe poor side of a debtor\xe2\x80\x99s prison is, as its name imports, that in\r\nwhich the most miserable and abject class of debtors are confined. A\r\nprisoner having declared upon the poor side, pays neither rent nor\r\nchummage. His fees, upon entering and leaving the jail, are reduced in\r\namount, and he becomes entitled to a share of some small quantities of\r\nfood: to provide which, a few charitable persons have, from time to\r\ntime, left trifling legacies in their wills. Most of our readers will\r\nremember, that, until within a very few years past, there was a kind of\r\niron cage in the wall of the Fleet Prison, within which was posted some\r\nman of hungry looks, who, from time to time, rattled a money-box, and\r\nexclaimed in a mournful voice, \xe2\x80\x98Pray, remember the poor debtors; pray\r\nremember the poor debtors.\xe2\x80\x99 The receipts of this box, when there were\r\nany, were divided among the poor prisoners; and the men on the poor side\r\nrelieved each other in this degrading office.\r\n\r\nAlthough this custom has been abolished, and the cage is now boarded up,\r\nthe miserable and destitute condition of these unhappy persons remains\r\nthe same. We no longer suffer them to appeal at the prison gates to the\r\ncharity and compassion of the passersby; but we still leave unblotted\r\nthe leaves of our statute book, for the reverence and admiration of\r\nsucceeding ages, the just and wholesome law which declares that the\r\nsturdy felon shall be fed and clothed, and that the penniless debtor\r\nshall be left to die of starvation and nakedness. This is no fiction.\r\nNot a week passes over our head, but, in every one of our prisons for\r\ndebt, some of these men must inevitably expire in the slow agonies of\r\nwant, if they were not relieved by their fellow-prisoners.\r\n\r\nTurning these things in his mind, as he mounted the narrow staircase at\r\nthe foot of which Roker had left him, Mr. Pickwick gradually worked\r\nhimself to the boiling-over point; and so excited was he with his\r\nreflections on this subject, that he had burst into the room to which he\r\nhad been directed, before he had any distinct recollection, either of\r\nthe place in which he was, or of the object of his visit.\r\n\r\nThe general aspect of the room recalled him to himself at once; but he\r\nhad no sooner cast his eye on the figure of a man who was brooding over\r\nthe dusty fire, than, letting his hat fall on the floor, he stood\r\nperfectly fixed and immovable with astonishment.\r\n\r\nYes; in tattered garments, and without a coat; his common calico shirt,\r\nyellow and in rags; his hair hanging over his face; his features changed\r\nwith suffering, and pinched with famine--there sat Mr. Alfred Jingle;\r\nhis head resting on his hands, his eyes fixed upon the fire, and his\r\nwhole appearance denoting misery and dejection!\r\n\r\nNear him, leaning listlessly against the wall, stood a strong-built\r\ncountryman, flicking with a worn-out hunting-whip the top-boot that\r\nadorned his right foot; his left being thrust into an old slipper.\r\nHorses, dogs, and drink had brought him there, pell-mell. There was a\r\nrusty spur on the solitary boot, which he occasionally jerked into the\r\nempty air, at the same time giving the boot a smart blow, and muttering\r\nsome of the sounds by which a sportsman encourages his horse. He was\r\nriding, in imagination, some desperate steeplechase at that moment. Poor\r\nwretch! He never rode a match on the swiftest animal in his costly stud,\r\nwith half the speed at which he had torn along the course that ended in\r\nthe Fleet.\r\n\r\nOn the opposite side of the room an old man was seated on a small wooden\r\nbox, with his eyes riveted on the floor, and his face settled into an\r\nexpression of the deepest and most hopeless despair. A young girl--his\r\nlittle grand-daughter--was hanging about him, endeavouring, with a\r\nthousand childish devices, to engage his attention; but the old man\r\nneither saw nor heard her. The voice that had been music to him, and the\r\neyes that had been light, fell coldly on his senses. His limbs were\r\nshaking with disease, and the palsy had fastened on his mind.\r\n\r\n\r\nThere were two or three other men in the room, congregated in a little\r\nknot, and noiselessly talking among themselves. There was a lean and\r\nhaggard woman, too--a prisoner\xe2\x80\x99s wife--who was watering, with great\r\nsolicitude, the wretched stump of a dried-up, withered plant, which, it\r\nwas plain to see, could never send forth a green leaf again--too true an\r\nemblem, perhaps, of the office she had come there to discharge.\r\n\r\nSuch were the objects which presented themselves to Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s view,\r\nas he looked round him in amazement. The noise of some one stumbling\r\nhastily into the room, roused him. Turning his eyes towards the door,\r\nthey encountered the new-comer; and in him, through his rags and dirt,\r\nhe recognised the familiar features of Mr. Job Trotter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pickwick!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Job aloud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh?\xe2\x80\x99 said Jingle, starting from his seat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr ----! So it is--queer place--strange things--serves me right--very.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nMr. Jingle thrust his hands into the place where his trousers pockets\r\nused to be, and, dropping his chin upon his breast, sank back into his\r\nchair.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick was affected; the two men looked so very miserable. The\r\nsharp, involuntary glance Jingle had cast at a small piece of raw loin\r\nof mutton, which Job had brought in with him, said more of their reduced\r\nstate than two hours\xe2\x80\x99 explanation could have done. Mr. Pickwick looked\r\nmildly at Jingle, and said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should like to speak to you in private. Will you step out for an\r\ninstant?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jingle, rising hastily. \xe2\x80\x98Can\xe2\x80\x99t step far--no danger of\r\noverwalking yourself here--spike park--grounds pretty--romantic, but not\r\nextensive--open for public inspection--family always in town--\r\nhousekeeper desperately careful--very.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have forgotten your coat,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, as they walked out to\r\nthe staircase, and closed the door after them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh?\xe2\x80\x99 said Jingle. \xe2\x80\x98Spout--dear relation--uncle Tom--couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it--\r\nmust eat, you know. Wants of nature--and all that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gone, my dear sir--last coat--can\xe2\x80\x99t help it. Lived on a pair of boots,\r\nwhole fortnight. Silk umbrella--ivory handle--week--fact--honour--ask\r\nJob--knows it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lived for three weeks upon a pair of boots, and a silk umbrella with an\r\nivory handle!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick, who had only heard of such things\r\nin shipwrecks or read of them in Constable\xe2\x80\x99s Miscellany.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98True,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jingle, nodding his head. \xe2\x80\x98Pawnbroker\xe2\x80\x99s shop--duplicates\r\nhere--small sums--mere nothing--all rascals.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, much relieved by this explanation; \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nunderstand you. You have pawned your wardrobe.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Everything--Job\xe2\x80\x99s too--all shirts gone--never mind--saves washing.\r\nNothing soon--lie in bed--starve--die--inquest--little bone-house--poor\r\nprisoner--common necessaries--hush it up--gentlemen of the jury--\r\nwarden\xe2\x80\x99s tradesmen--keep it snug--natural death--coroner\xe2\x80\x99s order--\r\nworkhouse funeral--serve him right--all over--drop the curtain.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJingle delivered this singular summary of his prospects in life, with\r\nhis accustomed volubility, and with various twitches of the countenance\r\nto counterfeit smiles. Mr. Pickwick easily perceived that his\r\nrecklessness was assumed, and looking him full, but not unkindly, in the\r\nface, saw that his eyes were moist with tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jingle, pressing his hand, and turning his head\r\naway. \xe2\x80\x98Ungrateful dog--boyish to cry--can\xe2\x80\x99t help it--bad fever--weak--\r\nill--hungry. Deserved it all--but suffered much--very.\xe2\x80\x99 Wholly unable to\r\nkeep up appearances any longer, and perhaps rendered worse by the effort\r\nhe had made, the dejected stroller sat down on the stairs, and, covering\r\nhis face with his hands, sobbed like a child.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, come,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with considerable emotion, \xe2\x80\x98we will see\r\nwhat can be done, when I know all about the matter. Here, Job; where is\r\nthat fellow?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job, presenting himself on the staircase. We have\r\ndescribed him, by the bye, as having deeply-sunken eyes, in the best of\r\ntimes. In his present state of want and distress, he looked as if those\r\nfeatures had gone out of town altogether.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Job.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come here, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, trying to look stern, with four\r\nlarge tears running down his waistcoat. \xe2\x80\x98Take that, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nTake what? In the ordinary acceptation of such language, it should have\r\nbeen a blow. As the world runs, it ought to have been a sound, hearty\r\ncuff; for Mr. Pickwick had been duped, deceived, and wronged by the\r\ndestitute outcast who was now wholly in his power. Must we tell the\r\ntruth? It was something from Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s waistcoat pocket, which\r\nchinked as it was given into Job\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and the giving of which,\r\nsomehow or other imparted a sparkle to the eye, and a swelling to the\r\nheart, of our excellent old friend, as he hurried away.\r\n\r\nSam had returned when Mr. Pickwick reached his own room, and was\r\ninspecting the arrangements that had been made for his comfort, with a\r\nkind of grim satisfaction which was very pleasant to look upon. Having a\r\ndecided objection to his master\xe2\x80\x99s being there at all, Mr. Weller\r\nappeared to consider it a high moral duty not to appear too much pleased\r\nwith anything that was done, said, suggested, or proposed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pretty comfortable now, eh, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pretty vell, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 responded Sam, looking round him in a disparaging\r\nmanner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you seen Mr. Tupman and our other friends?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I _have _seen \xe2\x80\x98em, sir, and they\xe2\x80\x99re a-comin\xe2\x80\x99 to-morrow, and wos\r\nwery much surprised to hear they warn\xe2\x80\x99t to come to-day,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have brought the things I wanted?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller in reply pointed to various packages which he had arranged,\r\nas neatly as he could, in a corner of the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, after a little hesitation; \xe2\x80\x98listen\r\nto what I am going to say, Sam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Cert\xe2\x80\x99nly, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98fire away, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have felt from the first, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with much\r\nsolemnity, \xe2\x80\x98that this is not the place to bring a young man to.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nor an old \xe2\x80\x98un neither, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re quite right, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98but old men may come here\r\nthrough their own heedlessness and unsuspicion, and young men may be\r\nbrought here by the selfishness of those they serve. It is better for\r\nthose young men, in every point of view, that they should not remain\r\nhere. Do you understand me, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vy no, Sir, I do _not_,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller doggedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Try, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vell, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Sam, after a short pause, \xe2\x80\x98I think I see your\r\ndrift; and if I do see your drift, it\xe2\x80\x99s my \xe2\x80\x98pinion that you\xe2\x80\x99re a-comin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nit a great deal too strong, as the mail-coachman said to the snowstorm,\r\nven it overtook him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see you comprehend me, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Independently of my\r\nwish that you should not be idling about a place like this, for years to\r\ncome, I feel that for a debtor in the Fleet to be attended by his\r\nmanservant is a monstrous absurdity. Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98for a\r\ntime you must leave me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, for a time, eh, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Weller rather sarcastically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, for the time that I remain here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Your wages I\r\nshall continue to pay. Any one of my three friends will be happy to take\r\nyou, were it only out of respect to me. And if I ever do leave this\r\nplace, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr. Pickwick, with assumed cheerfulness--\xe2\x80\x98if I do, I\r\npledge you my word that you shall return to me instantly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you wot it is, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, in a grave and\r\nsolemn voice. \xe2\x80\x98This here sort o\xe2\x80\x99 thing won\xe2\x80\x99t do at all, so don\xe2\x80\x99t let\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhear no more about it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nI am serious, and resolved, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You air, air you, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Weller firmly. \xe2\x80\x98Wery good, Sir;\r\nthen so am I.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThus speaking, Mr. Weller fixed his hat on his head with great\r\nprecision, and abruptly left the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr. Pickwick, calling after him, \xe2\x80\x98Sam! Here!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut the long gallery ceased to re-echo the sound of footsteps. Sam\r\nWeller was gone.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLIII. SHOWING HOW MR. SAMUEL WELLER GOT INTO DIFFICULTIES\r\n\r\nIn a lofty room, ill-lighted and worse ventilated, situated in Portugal\r\nStreet, Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s Inn Fields, there sit nearly the whole year round,\r\none, two, three, or four gentlemen in wigs, as the case may be, with\r\nlittle writing-desks before them, constructed after the fashion of those\r\nused by the judges of the land, barring the French polish. There is a\r\nbox of barristers on their right hand; there is an enclosure of\r\ninsolvent debtors on their left; and there is an inclined plane of most\r\nespecially dirty faces in their front. These gentlemen are the\r\nCommissioners of the Insolvent Court, and the place in which they sit,\r\nis the Insolvent Court itself.\r\n\r\nIt is, and has been, time out of mind, the remarkable fate of this court\r\nto be, somehow or other, held and understood, by the general consent of\r\nall the destitute shabby-genteel people in London, as their common\r\nresort, and place of daily refuge. It is always full. The steams of beer\r\nand spirits perpetually ascend to the ceiling, and, being condensed by\r\nthe heat, roll down the walls like rain; there are more old suits of\r\nclothes in it at one time, than will be offered for sale in all\r\nHoundsditch in a twelvemonth; more unwashed skins and grizzly beards\r\nthan all the pumps and shaving-shops between Tyburn and Whitechapel\r\ncould render decent, between sunrise and sunset.\r\n\r\nIt must not be supposed that any of these people have the least shadow\r\nof business in, or the remotest connection with, the place they so\r\nindefatigably attend. If they had, it would be no matter of surprise,\r\nand the singularity of the thing would cease. Some of them sleep during\r\nthe greater part of the sitting; others carry small portable dinners\r\nwrapped in pocket-handkerchiefs or sticking out of their worn-out\r\npockets, and munch and listen with equal relish; but no one among them\r\nwas ever known to have the slightest personal interest in any case that\r\nwas ever brought forward. Whatever they do, there they sit from the\r\nfirst moment to the last. When it is heavy, rainy weather, they all come\r\nin, wet through; and at such times the vapours of the court are like\r\nthose of a fungus-pit.\r\n\r\nA casual visitor might suppose this place to be a temple dedicated to\r\nthe Genius of Seediness. There is not a messenger or process-server\r\nattached to it, who wears a coat that was made for him; not a tolerably\r\nfresh, or wholesome-looking man in the whole establishment, except a\r\nlittle white-headed apple-faced tipstaff, and even he, like an ill-\r\nconditioned cherry preserved in brandy, seems to have artificially dried\r\nand withered up into a state of preservation to which he can lay no\r\nnatural claim. The very barristers\xe2\x80\x99 wigs are ill-powdered, and their\r\ncurls lack crispness.\r\n\r\nBut the attorneys, who sit at a large bare table below the\r\ncommissioners, are, after all, the greatest curiosities. The\r\nprofessional establishment of the more opulent of these gentlemen,\r\nconsists of a blue bag and a boy; generally a youth of the Jewish\r\npersuasion. They have no fixed offices, their legal business being\r\ntransacted in the parlours of public-houses, or the yards of prisons,\r\nwhither they repair in crowds, and canvass for customers after the\r\nmanner of omnibus cads. They are of a greasy and mildewed appearance;\r\nand if they can be said to have any vices at all, perhaps drinking and\r\ncheating are the most conspicuous among them. Their residences are\r\nusually on the outskirts of \xe2\x80\x98the Rules,\xe2\x80\x99 chiefly lying within a circle\r\nof one mile from the obelisk in St. George\xe2\x80\x99s Fields. Their looks are not\r\nprepossessing, and their manners are peculiar.\r\n\r\nMr. Solomon Pell, one of this learned body, was a fat, flabby, pale man,\r\nin a surtout which looked green one minute, and brown the next, with a\r\nvelvet collar of the same chameleon tints. His forehead was narrow, his\r\nface wide, his head large, and his nose all on one side, as if Nature,\r\nindignant with the propensities she observed in him in his birth, had\r\ngiven it an angry tweak which it had never recovered. Being short-necked\r\nand asthmatic, however, he respired principally through this feature;\r\nso, perhaps, what it wanted in ornament, it made up in usefulness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m sure to bring him through it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you, though?\xe2\x80\x99 replied the person to whom the assurance was pledged.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certain sure,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Pell; \xe2\x80\x98but if he\xe2\x80\x99d gone to any irregular\r\npractitioner, mind you, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have answered for the consequences.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said the other, with open mouth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, that I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pell; and he pursed up his lips,\r\nfrowned, and shook his head mysteriously.\r\n\r\nNow, the place where this discourse occurred was the public-house just\r\nopposite to the Insolvent Court; and the person with whom it was held\r\nwas no other than the elder Mr. Weller, who had come there, to comfort\r\nand console a friend, whose petition to be discharged under the act, was\r\nto be that day heard, and whose attorney he was at that moment\r\nconsulting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And vere is George?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the old gentleman.\r\n\r\nMr. Pell jerked his head in the direction of a back parlour, whither Mr.\r\nWeller at once repairing, was immediately greeted in the warmest and\r\nmost flattering manner by some half-dozen of his professional brethren,\r\nin token of their gratification at his arrival. The insolvent gentleman,\r\nwho had contracted a speculative but imprudent passion for horsing long\r\nstages, which had led to his present embarrassments, looked extremely\r\nwell, and was soothing the excitement of his feelings with shrimps and\r\nporter.\r\n\r\nThe salutation between Mr. Weller and his friends was strictly confined\r\nto the freemasonry of the craft; consisting of a jerking round of the\r\nright wrist, and a tossing of the little finger into the air at the same\r\ntime. We once knew two famous coachmen (they are dead now, poor fellows)\r\nwho were twins, and between whom an unaffected and devoted attachment\r\nexisted. They passed each other on the Dover road, every day, for\r\ntwenty-four years, never exchanging any other greeting than this; and\r\nyet, when one died, the other pined away, and soon afterwards followed\r\nhim!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vell, George,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller senior, taking off his upper coat, and\r\nseating himself with his accustomed gravity. \xe2\x80\x98How is it? All right\r\nbehind, and full inside?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All right, old feller,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the embarrassed gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is the gray mare made over to anybody?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Weller anxiously.\r\n\r\nGeorge nodded in the affirmative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vell, that\xe2\x80\x99s all right,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Coach taken care on, also?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Con-signed in a safe quarter,\xe2\x80\x99 replied George, wringing the heads off\r\nhalf a dozen shrimps, and swallowing them without any more ado.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery good, wery good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Alvays see to the drag ven you\r\ngo downhill. Is the vay-bill all clear and straight for\xe2\x80\x99erd?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The schedule, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pell, guessing at Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s meaning, \xe2\x80\x98the\r\nschedule is as plain and satisfactory as pen and ink can make it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller nodded in a manner which bespoke his inward approval of these\r\narrangements; and then, turning to Mr. Pell, said, pointing to his\r\nfriend George--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ven do you take his cloths off?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pell, \xe2\x80\x98he stands third on the opposed list, and I\r\nshould think it would be his turn in about half an hour. I told my clerk\r\nto come over and tell us when there was a chance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller surveyed the attorney from head to foot with great\r\nadmiration, and said emphatically--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what\xe2\x80\x99ll you take, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, really,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pell, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99re very--. Upon my word and\r\nhonour, I\xe2\x80\x99m not in the habit of--. It\xe2\x80\x99s so very early in the morning,\r\nthat, actually, I am almost--. Well, you may bring me threepenn\xe2\x80\x99orth of\r\nrum, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe officiating damsel, who had anticipated the order before it was\r\ngiven, set the glass of spirits before Pell, and retired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pell, looking round upon the company, \xe2\x80\x98success to\r\nyour friend! Hem!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis last sound was a solemn and dignified cough, in which Mr. Pell,\r\nobserving an indecent tendency to mirth in some of his auditors,\r\nconsidered it due to himself to indulge.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The late Lord Chancellor, gentlemen, was very fond of me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nPell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And wery creditable in him, too,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hear, hear,\xe2\x80\x99 assented Mr. Pell\xe2\x80\x99s client. \xe2\x80\x98Why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t he be?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! Observations have already\r\nbeen made, in this room, injurious to the reputation of my noble friend.\r\nYou will excuse me, gentlemen; I was imprudent. The intelligence\r\nwas no sooner received than the whole party hurried across the street,\r\nand began to fight their way into court--a preparatory ceremony, which\r\nhas been calculated to occupy, in ordinary cases, from twenty-five\r\nminutes to thirty.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller, being stout, cast himself at once into the crowd, with the\r\ndesperate hope of ultimately turning up in some place which would suit\r\nhim. It mayn\xe2\x80\x99t be altogether safe, vith reference to gettin\xe2\x80\x99 out\r\nagin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDeferring to his son\xe2\x80\x99s feeling upon this point, Mr. Weller at once\r\nsought the erudite Solomon Pell, and acquainted him with his desire to\r\nissue a writ, instantly, for the _sum _of twenty-five pounds, and costs\r\nof process; to be executed without delay upon the body of one Samuel\r\nWeller; the charges thereby incurred, to be paid in advance to Solomon\r\nPell.\r\n\r\nThe attorney was in high glee, for the embarrassed coach-horser was\r\nordered to be discharged forthwith. He highly approved of Sam\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nattachment to his master; declared that it strongly reminded him of his\r\nown feelings of devotion to his friend, the Chancellor; and at once led\r\nthe elder Mr. Weller down to the Temple, to swear the affidavit of debt,\r\nwhich the boy, with the assistance of the blue bag, had drawn up on the\r\nspot.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, Sam, having been formally introduced to the whitewashed\r\ngentleman and his friends, as the offspring of Mr. Weller, of the Belle\r\nSavage, was treated with marked distinction, and invited to regale\r\nhimself with them in honour of the occasion--an invitation which he was\r\nby no means backward in accepting.\r\n\r\nThe mirth of gentlemen of this class is of a grave and quiet character,\r\nusually; but the present instance was one of peculiar festivity, and\r\nthey relaxed in proportion. After some rather tumultuous toasting of the\r\nChief Commissioner and Mr. Solomon Pell, who had that day displayed such\r\ntranscendent abilities, a mottled-faced gentleman in a blue shawl\r\nproposed that somebody should sing a song. The obvious suggestion was,\r\nthat the mottled-faced gentleman, being anxious for a song, should sing\r\nit himself; but this the mottled-faced gentleman sturdily, and somewhat\r\noffensively, declined to do. Upon which, as is not unusual in such\r\ncases, a rather angry colloquy ensued.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 said the coach-horser, \xe2\x80\x98rather than disturb the harmony of\r\nthis delightful occasion, perhaps Mr. Samuel Weller will oblige the\r\ncompany.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Raly, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m not wery much in the habit o\xe2\x80\x99 singin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwithout the instrument; but anythin\xe2\x80\x99 for a quiet life, as the man said\r\nwen he took the sitivation at the lighthouse.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith this prelude, Mr. Samuel Weller burst at once into the following\r\nwild and beautiful legend, which, under the impression that it is not\r\ngenerally known, we take the liberty of quoting. We would beg to call\r\nparticular attention to the monosyllable at the end of the second and\r\nfourth lines, which not only enables the singer to take breath at those\r\npoints, but greatly assists the metre.\r\n\r\n\r\nROMANCE\r\n\r\nI\r\n\r\nBold Turpin vunce, on Hounslow Heath, His bold mare Bess bestrode--er;\r\nVen there he see\xe2\x80\x99d the Bishop\xe2\x80\x99s coach A-coming along the road--er. So he\r\ngallops close to the \xe2\x80\x98orse\xe2\x80\x99s legs, And he claps his head vithin; And the\r\nBishop says, \xe2\x80\x98Sure as eggs is eggs, This here\xe2\x80\x99s the bold Turpin!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCHORUS\r\n\r\nAnd the Bishop says, \xe2\x80\x98Sure as eggs is eggs, This here\xe2\x80\x99s the bold\r\nTurpin!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nII\r\n\r\nSays Turpin, \xe2\x80\x98You shall eat your words, With a sarse of leaden bul--\r\nlet;\xe2\x80\x99 So he puts a pistol to his mouth, And he fires it down his gul--\r\nlet. The coachman he not likin\xe2\x80\x99 the job, Set off at full gal-lop, But\r\nDick put a couple of balls in his nob, And perwailed on him to stop.\r\n\r\nCHORUS (sarcastically)\r\n\r\nBut Dick put a couple of balls in his nob, And perwailed on him to stop.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I maintain that that \xe2\x80\x98ere song\xe2\x80\x99s personal to the cloth,\xe2\x80\x99 said the\r\nmottled-faced gentleman, interrupting it at this point. \xe2\x80\x98I demand the\r\nname o\xe2\x80\x99 that coachman.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nobody know\xe2\x80\x99d,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98He hadn\xe2\x80\x99t got his card in his pocket.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I object to the introduction o\xe2\x80\x99 politics,\xe2\x80\x99 said the mottled-faced\r\ngentleman. \xe2\x80\x98I submit that, in the present company, that \xe2\x80\x98ere song\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npolitical; and, wot\xe2\x80\x99s much the same, that it ain\xe2\x80\x99t true. I say that that\r\ncoachman did not run away; but that he died game--game as pheasants; and\r\nI won\xe2\x80\x99t hear nothin\xe2\x80\x99 said to the contrairey.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs the mottled-faced gentleman spoke with great energy and\r\ndetermination, and as the opinions of the company seemed divided on the\r\nsubject, it threatened to give rise to fresh altercation, when Mr.\r\nWeller and Mr. Pell most opportunely arrived.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All right, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The officer will be here at four o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pell. \xe2\x80\x98I suppose\r\nyou won\xe2\x80\x99t run away meanwhile, eh? Ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98P\xe2\x80\x99raps my cruel pa \xe2\x80\x98ull relent afore then,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam, with a broad\r\ngrin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not I,\xe2\x80\x99 said the elder Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not on no account,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the inexorable creditor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll give bills for the amount, at sixpence a month,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I won\xe2\x80\x99t take \xe2\x80\x98em,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha, ha, ha! very good, very good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Solomon Pell, who was\r\nmaking out his little bill of costs; \xe2\x80\x98a very amusing incident indeed!\r\nBenjamin, copy that.\xe2\x80\x99 And Mr. Pell smiled again, as he called Mr.\r\nWeller\xe2\x80\x99s attention to the amount.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you, thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 said the professional gentleman, taking up\r\nanother of the greasy notes as Mr. Weller took it from the pocket-book.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Three ten and one ten is five. Much obliged to you, Mr. Weller. Your\r\nson is a most deserving young man, very much so indeed, Sir. It\xe2\x80\x99s a very\r\npleasant trait in a young man\xe2\x80\x99s character, very much so,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr.\r\nPell, smiling smoothly round, as he buttoned up the money.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot a game it is!\xe2\x80\x99 said the elder Mr. Weller, with a chuckle. \xe2\x80\x98A\r\nreg\xe2\x80\x99lar prodigy son!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Prodigal--prodigal son, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Mr. Pell, mildly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never mind, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, with dignity. \xe2\x80\x98I know wot\xe2\x80\x99s o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\r\nSir. Wen I don\xe2\x80\x99t, I\xe2\x80\x99ll ask you, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBy the time the officer arrived, Sam had made himself so extremely\r\npopular, that the congregated gentlemen determined to see him to prison\r\nin a body. So off they set; the plaintiff and defendant walking arm in\r\narm, the officer in front, and eight stout coachmen bringing up the\r\nrear. At Serjeant\xe2\x80\x99s Inn Coffee-house the whole party halted to refresh,\r\nand, the legal arrangements being completed, the procession moved on\r\nagain.\r\n\r\nSome little commotion was occasioned in Fleet Street, by the pleasantry\r\nof the eight gentlemen in the flank, who persevered in walking four\r\nabreast; it was also found necessary to leave the mottled-faced\r\ngentleman behind, to fight a ticket-porter, it being arranged that his\r\nfriends should call for him as they came back. Nothing but these little\r\nincidents occurred on the way. When they reached the gate of the Fleet,\r\nthe cavalcade, taking the time from the plaintiff, gave three tremendous\r\ncheers for the defendant, and, after having shaken hands all round, left\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nSam, having been formally delivered into the warder\xe2\x80\x99s custody, to the\r\nintense astonishment of Roker, and to the evident emotion of even the\r\nphlegmatic Neddy, passed at once into the prison, walked straight to his\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s room, and knocked at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come in,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\nSam appeared, pulled off his hat, and smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, Sam, my good lad!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, evidently delighted to see\r\nhis humble friend again; \xe2\x80\x98I had no intention of hurting your feelings\r\nyesterday, my faithful fellow, by what I said. Put down your hat, Sam,\r\nand let me explain my meaning, a little more at length.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Won\xe2\x80\x99t presently do, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98but why not now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99d rayther not now, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Cause--\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, hesitating.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because of what?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick, alarmed at his follower\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmanner. \xe2\x80\x98Speak out, Sam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Cause,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Sam--\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99cause I\xe2\x80\x99ve got a little bisness as I want to\r\ndo.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What business?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick, surprised at Sam\xe2\x80\x99s confused\r\nmanner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothin\xe2\x80\x99 partickler, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, if it\xe2\x80\x99s nothing particular,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with a smile, \xe2\x80\x98you\r\ncan speak with me first.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think I\xe2\x80\x99d better see arter it at once,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, still hesitating.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick looked amazed, but said nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The fact is--\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, stopping short.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Speak out, Sam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, the fact is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, with a desperate effort, \xe2\x80\x98perhaps I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nbetter see arter my bed afore I do anythin\xe2\x80\x99 else.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98_Your bed!_\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick, in astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, my bed, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m a prisoner. I was arrested this\r\nhere wery arternoon for debt.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You arrested for debt!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick, sinking into a chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, for debt, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98And the man as puts me in, \xe2\x80\x98ull\r\nnever let me out till you go yourself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless my heart and soul!\xe2\x80\x99 ejaculated Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot I say, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Sam. \xe2\x80\x98If it\xe2\x80\x99s forty years to come, I shall be\r\na prisoner, and I\xe2\x80\x99m very glad on it; and if it had been Newgate, it\r\nwould ha\xe2\x80\x99 been just the same. Now the murder\xe2\x80\x99s out, and, damme, there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nan end on it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith these words, which he repeated with great emphasis and violence,\r\nSam Weller dashed his hat upon the ground, in a most unusual state of\r\nexcitement; and then, folding his arms, looked firmly and fixedly in his\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXIV. TREATS OF DIVERS LITTLE MATTERS WHICH OCCURRED IN THE\r\nFLEET, AND OF MR. WINKLE\xe2\x80\x99S MYSTERIOUS BEHAVIOUR; AND SHOWS HOW THE POOR\r\nCHANCERY PRISONER OBTAINED HIS RELEASE AT LAST\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick felt a great deal too much touched by the warmth of Sam\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nattachment, to be able to exhibit any manifestation of anger or\r\ndispleasure at the precipitate course he had adopted, in voluntarily\r\nconsigning himself to a debtor\xe2\x80\x99s prison for an indefinite period. The\r\nonly point on which he persevered in demanding an explanation, was, the\r\nname of Sam\xe2\x80\x99s detaining creditor; but this Mr. Weller as perseveringly\r\nwithheld.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It ain\xe2\x80\x99t o\xe2\x80\x99 no use, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, again and again; \xe2\x80\x98he\xe2\x80\x99s a malicious,\r\nbad-disposed, vorldly-minded, spiteful, windictive creetur, with a hard\r\nheart as there ain\xe2\x80\x99t no soft\xe2\x80\x99nin\xe2\x80\x99, as the wirtuous clergyman remarked of\r\nthe old gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n with the dropsy, ven he said, that upon the whole he\r\nthought he\xe2\x80\x99d rayther leave his property to his vife than build a chapel\r\nvith it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But consider, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr. Pickwick remonstrated, \xe2\x80\x98the sum is so small\r\nthat it can very easily be paid; and having made up my mind that you\r\nshall stop with me, you should recollect how much more useful you would\r\nbe, if you could go outside the walls.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWery much obliged to you, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller gravely;
