One\r\nnight he wos took very ill; sends for a doctor; doctor comes in a green\r\nfly, with a kind o\xe2\x80\x99 Robinson Crusoe set o\xe2\x80\x99 steps, as he could let down\r\nwen he got out, and pull up arter him wen he got in, to perwent the\r\nnecessity o\xe2\x80\x99 the coachman\xe2\x80\x99s gettin\xe2\x80\x99 down, and thereby undeceivin\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\npublic by lettin\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98em see that it wos only a livery coat as he\xe2\x80\x99d got on,\r\nand not the trousers to match. \xe2\x80\x9cWot\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d says the doctor.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWery ill,\xe2\x80\x9d says the patient. \xe2\x80\x9cWot have you been a-eatin\xe2\x80\x99 on?\xe2\x80\x9d says the\r\ndoctor. \xe2\x80\x9cRoast weal,\xe2\x80\x9d says the patient. \xe2\x80\x9cWot\xe2\x80\x99s the last thing you\r\ndewoured?\xe2\x80\x9d says the doctor. \xe2\x80\x9cCrumpets,\xe2\x80\x9d says the patient. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n says the doctor. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll send you a box of pills directly, and don\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nnever take no more of \xe2\x80\x98em,\xe2\x80\x9d he says. \xe2\x80\x9cNo more o\xe2\x80\x99 wot?\xe2\x80\x9d says the patient-\r\n-\xe2\x80\x9cpills?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cNo; crumpets,\xe2\x80\x9d says the doctor. \xe2\x80\x9cWy?\xe2\x80\x9d says the patient,\r\nstarting up in bed; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve eat four crumpets, ev\xe2\x80\x99ry night for fifteen\r\nyear, on principle.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, you\xe2\x80\x99d better leave \xe2\x80\x98em off, on\r\nprinciple,\xe2\x80\x9d says the doctor. \xe2\x80\x9cCrumpets is _not _wholesome, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d says\r\nthe doctor, wery fierce. \xe2\x80\x9cBut they\xe2\x80\x99re so cheap,\xe2\x80\x9d says the patient,\r\ncomin\xe2\x80\x99 down a little, \xe2\x80\x9cand so wery fillin\xe2\x80\x99 at the price.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99d be\r\ndear to you, at any price; dear if you wos paid to eat \xe2\x80\x98em,\xe2\x80\x9d says the\r\ndoctor. \xe2\x80\x9cFour crumpets a night,\xe2\x80\x9d he says, \xe2\x80\x9cvill do your business in six\r\nmonths!\xe2\x80\x9d The patient looks him full in the face, and turns it over in\r\nhis mind for a long time, and at last he says, \xe2\x80\x9cAre you sure o\xe2\x80\x99 that\r\n\xe2\x80\x98ere, Sir?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll stake my professional reputation on it,\xe2\x80\x9d says the\r\ndoctor. \xe2\x80\x9cHow many crumpets, at a sittin\xe2\x80\x99, do you think \xe2\x80\x98ud kill me off\r\nat once?\xe2\x80\x9d says the patient. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d says the doctor. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you\r\nthink half-a-crown\xe2\x80\x99s wurth \xe2\x80\x98ud do it?\xe2\x80\x9d says the patient. \xe2\x80\x9cI think it\r\nmight,\xe2\x80\x9d says the doctor. \xe2\x80\x9cThree shillins\xe2\x80\x99 wurth \xe2\x80\x98ud be sure to do it, I\r\ns\xe2\x80\x99pose?\xe2\x80\x9d says the patient. \xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d says the doctor. \xe2\x80\x9cWery good,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n says the patient; \xe2\x80\x9cgood-night.\xe2\x80\x9d Next mornin\xe2\x80\x99 he gets up, has a fire lit,\r\norders in three shillins\xe2\x80\x99 wurth o\xe2\x80\x99 crumpets, toasts \xe2\x80\x98em all, eats \xe2\x80\x98em\r\nall, and blows his brains out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What did he do that for?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick abruptly; for he was\r\nconsiderably startled by this tragical termination of the narrative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot did he do it for, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 reiterated Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Wy, in support of his\r\ngreat principle that crumpets wos wholesome, and to show that he\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be put out of his way for nobody!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith such like shiftings and changings of the discourse, did Mr. Weller\r\nmeet his master\xe2\x80\x99s questioning on the night of his taking up his\r\nresidence in the Fleet. Finding all gentle remonstrance useless, Mr.\r\nPickwick at length yielded a reluctant consent to his taking lodgings by\r\nthe week, of a bald-headed cobbler, who rented a small slip room in one\r\nof the upper galleries. To this humble apartment Mr. Weller moved a\r\nmattress and bedding, which he hired of Mr. Roker; and, by the time he\r\nlay down upon it at night, was as much at home as if he had been bred in\r\nthe prison, and his whole family had vegetated therein for three\r\ngenerations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you always smoke arter you goes to bed, old cock?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr.\r\nWeller of his landlord, when they had both retired for the night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I does, young bantam,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the cobbler.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you allow me to in-quire wy you make up your bed under that \xe2\x80\x98ere\r\ndeal table?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Cause I was always used to a four-poster afore I came here, and I find\r\nthe legs of the table answer just as well,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the cobbler.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re a character, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I haven\xe2\x80\x99t got anything of the kind belonging to me,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined the\r\ncobbler, shaking his head; \xe2\x80\x98and if you want to meet with a good one, I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nafraid you\xe2\x80\x99ll find some difficulty in suiting yourself at this register\r\noffice.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe above short dialogue took place as Mr. Weller lay extended on his\r\nmattress at one end of the room, and the cobbler on his, at the other;\r\nthe apartment being illumined by the light of a rush-candle, and the\r\ncobbler\xe2\x80\x99s pipe, which was glowing below the table, like a red-hot coal.\r\nThe conversation, brief as it was, predisposed Mr. Weller strongly in\r\nhis landlord\xe2\x80\x99s favour; and, raising himself on his elbow, he took a more\r\nlengthened survey of his appearance than he had yet had either time or\r\ninclination to make.\r\n\r\nHe was a sallow man--all cobblers are; and had a strong bristly beard--\r\nall cobblers have. His face was a queer, good-tempered, crooked-featured\r\npiece of workmanship, ornamented with a couple of eyes that must have\r\nworn a very joyous expression at one time, for they sparkled yet. The\r\nman was sixty, by years, and Heaven knows how old by imprisonment, so\r\nthat his having any look approaching to mirth or contentment, was\r\nsingular enough. He was a little man, and, being half doubled up as he\r\nlay in bed, looked about as long as he ought to have been without his\r\nlegs. He had a great red pipe in his mouth, and was smoking, and staring\r\nat the rush-light, in a state of enviable placidity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you been here long?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam, breaking the silence which had\r\nlasted for some time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Twelve year,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the cobbler, biting the end of his pipe as he\r\nspoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Contempt?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam.\r\n\r\nThe cobbler nodded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, with some sternness, \xe2\x80\x98wot do you persevere in\r\nbein\xe2\x80\x99 obstinit for, vastin\xe2\x80\x99 your precious life away, in this here\r\nmagnified pound? Wy don\xe2\x80\x99t you give in, and tell the Chancellorship that\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99re wery sorry for makin\xe2\x80\x99 his court contemptible, and you won\xe2\x80\x99t do so\r\nno more?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe cobbler put his pipe in the corner of his mouth, while he smiled,\r\nand then brought it back to its old place again; but said nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wy don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, urging his question strenuously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 said the cobbler, \xe2\x80\x98you don\xe2\x80\x99t quite understand these matters. What\r\ndo you suppose ruined me, now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, trimming the rush-light, \xe2\x80\x98I s\xe2\x80\x99pose the beginnin\xe2\x80\x99 wos,\r\nthat you got into debt, eh?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never owed a farden,\xe2\x80\x99 said the cobbler; \xe2\x80\x98try again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98you bought houses, wich is delicate English\r\nfor goin\xe2\x80\x99 mad; or took to buildin\xe2\x80\x99, wich is a medical term for bein\xe2\x80\x99\r\nincurable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe cobbler shook his head and said, \xe2\x80\x98Try again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You didn\xe2\x80\x99t go to law, I hope?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam suspiciously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never in my life,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the cobbler. \xe2\x80\x98The fact is, I was ruined by\r\nhaving money left me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, come,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98that von\xe2\x80\x99t do. I wish some rich enemy \xe2\x80\x98ud try\r\nto vork my destruction in that \xe2\x80\x98ere vay. I\xe2\x80\x99d let him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I dare say you don\xe2\x80\x99t believe it,\xe2\x80\x99 said the cobbler, quietly smoking\r\nhis pipe. \xe2\x80\x98I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t if I was you; but it\xe2\x80\x99s true for all that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How wos it?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam, half induced to believe the fact already, by\r\nthe look the cobbler gave him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just this,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the cobbler; \xe2\x80\x98an old gentleman that I worked for,\r\ndown in the country, and a humble relation of whose I married--she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndead, God bless her, and thank Him for it!--was seized with a fit and\r\nwent off.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam, who was growing sleepy after the numerous events\r\nof the day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How should I know where he went?\xe2\x80\x99 said the cobbler, speaking through\r\nhis nose in an intense enjoyment of his pipe. \xe2\x80\x98He went off dead.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, that indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said the cobbler, \xe2\x80\x98he left five thousand pound behind him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And wery gen-teel in him so to do,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98One of which,\xe2\x80\x99 continued the cobbler, \xe2\x80\x98he left to me, \xe2\x80\x98cause I married\r\nhis relation, you see.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery good,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And being surrounded by a great number of nieces and nevys, as was\r\nalways quarrelling and fighting among themselves for the property, he\r\nmakes me his executor, and leaves the rest to me in trust, to divide it\r\namong \xe2\x80\x98em as the will prowided.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot do you mean by leavin\xe2\x80\x99 it on trust?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam, waking up a\r\nlittle. \xe2\x80\x98If it ain\xe2\x80\x99t ready-money, were\xe2\x80\x99s the use on it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a law term, that\xe2\x80\x99s all,\xe2\x80\x99 said the cobbler.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, shaking his head. \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s wery little\r\ntrust at that shop. Hows\xe2\x80\x99ever, go on.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWell,\xe2\x80\x99 said the cobbler, \xe2\x80\x98when I was going to take out a probate of the\r\nwill, the nieces and nevys, who was desperately disappointed at not\r\ngetting all the money, enters a caveat against it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A legal instrument, which is as much as to say, it\xe2\x80\x99s no go,\xe2\x80\x99 replied\r\nthe cobbler.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98a sort of brother-in-law o\xe2\x80\x99 the have-his-carcass.\r\nWell.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But,\xe2\x80\x99 continued the cobbler, \xe2\x80\x98finding that they couldn\xe2\x80\x99t agree among\r\nthemselves, and consequently couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get up a case against the will,\r\nthey withdrew the caveat, and I paid all the legacies. I\xe2\x80\x99d hardly done\r\nit, when one nevy brings an action to set the will aside. The case comes\r\non, some months afterwards, afore a deaf old gentleman, in a back room\r\nsomewhere down by Paul\xe2\x80\x99s Churchyard; and arter four counsels had taken a\r\nday a-piece to bother him regularly, he takes a week or two to consider,\r\nand read the evidence in six volumes, and then gives his judgment that\r\nhow the testator was not quite right in his head, and I must pay all the\r\nmoney back again, and all the costs. I appealed; the case come on before\r\nthree or four very sleepy gentlemen, who had heard it all before in the\r\nother court, where they\xe2\x80\x99re lawyers without work; the only difference\r\nbeing, that, there, they\xe2\x80\x99re called doctors, and in the other place\r\ndelegates, if you understand that; and they very dutifully confirmed the\r\ndecision of the old gentleman below. After that, we went into Chancery,\r\nwhere we are still, and where I shall always be. My lawyers have had all\r\nmy thousand pound long ago; and what between the estate, as they call\r\nit, and the costs, I\xe2\x80\x99m here for ten thousand, and shall stop here, till\r\nI die, mending shoes. Some gentlemen have talked of bringing it before\r\nParliament, and I dare say would have done it, only they hadn\xe2\x80\x99t time to\r\ncome to me, and I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t power to go to them, and they got tired of my\r\nlong letters, and dropped the business. And this is God\xe2\x80\x99s truth, without\r\none word of suppression or exaggeration, as fifty people, both in this\r\nplace and out of it, very well know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe cobbler paused to ascertain what effect his story had produced on\r\nSam; but finding that he had dropped asleep, knocked the ashes out of\r\nhis pipe, sighed, put it down, drew the bed-clothes over his head, and\r\nwent to sleep, too.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick was sitting at breakfast, alone, next morning (Sam being\r\nbusily engaged in the cobbler\xe2\x80\x99s room, polishing his master\xe2\x80\x99s shoes and\r\nbrushing the black gaiters) when there came a knock at the door, which,\r\nbefore Mr. Pickwick could cry \xe2\x80\x98Come in!\xe2\x80\x99 was followed by the appearance\r\nof a head of hair and a cotton-velvet cap, both of which articles of\r\ndress he had no difficulty in recognising as the personal property of\r\nMr. Smangle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How are you?\xe2\x80\x99 said that worthy, accompanying the inquiry with a score\r\nor two of nods; \xe2\x80\x98I say--do you expect anybody this morning? Three men--\r\ndevilish gentlemanly fellows--have been asking after you downstairs, and\r\nknocking at every door on the hall flight; for which they\xe2\x80\x99ve been most\r\ninfernally blown up by the collegians that had the trouble of opening\r\n\xe2\x80\x98em.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me! Curse me, they\xe2\x80\x99re friends of mine from this minute, and\r\nfriends of Mivins\xe2\x80\x99s, too. Infernal pleasant, gentlemanly dog, Mivins,\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x99 said Smangle, with great feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know so little of the gentleman,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, hesitating,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98that I--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know you do,\xe2\x80\x99 interrupted Smangle, clasping Mr. Pickwick by the\r\nshoulder. \xe2\x80\x98You shall know him better. Now\r\nyou know that\xe2\x80\x99s infernal clever! Damme, you can\xe2\x80\x99t help liking a man,\r\nwhen you see these traits about him. He\xe2\x80\x99s only one fault--that little\r\nfailing I mentioned to you, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Mr. Smangle shook his head in a confidential and sympathising manner\r\nat this juncture, Mr. Pickwick felt that he was expected to say\r\nsomething, so he said, \xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 and looked restlessly at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 echoed Mr. Smangle, with a long-drawn sigh. \xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s delightful\r\ncompany, that man is, sir. By the bye--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Smangle pronounced the last three words, he stopped suddenly,\r\nreclosed the door which he had opened, and, walking softly back to Mr.\r\nPickwick, stepped close up to him on tiptoe, and said, in a very soft\r\nwhisper--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You couldn\xe2\x80\x99t make it convenient to lend me half-a-crown till the latter\r\nend of next week, could you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick could scarcely forbear smiling, but managing to preserve\r\nhis gravity, he drew forth the coin, and placed it in Mr. Smangle\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npalm; upon which, that gentleman, with many nods and winks, implying\r\nprofound mystery, disappeared in quest of the three strangers, with whom\r\nhe presently returned; and having coughed thrice, and nodded as many\r\ntimes, as an assurance to Mr. Pickwick that he would not forget to pay,\r\nhe shook hands all round, in an engaging manner, and at length took\r\nhimself off.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear friends,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, shaking hands alternately with Mr.\r\nTupman, Mr. Winkle, and Mr. Snodgrass, who were the three visitors in\r\nquestion, \xe2\x80\x98I am delighted to see you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe triumvirate were much affected. Mr. Tupman shook his head\r\ndeploringly, Mr. Snodgrass drew forth his handkerchief, with undisguised\r\nemotion; and Mr. Winkle retired to the window, and sniffed aloud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mornin\xe2\x80\x99, gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, entering at the moment with the shoes\r\nand gaiters. \xe2\x80\x98Avay vith melincholly, as the little boy said ven his\r\nschoolmissus died. Velcome to the college, gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This foolish fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, tapping Sam on the head as he\r\nknelt down to button up his master\xe2\x80\x99s gaiters--\xe2\x80\x98this foolish fellow has\r\ngot himself arrested, in order to be near me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed the three friends.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m a--stand steady, sir, if you please--\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m a prisoner, gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n. Con-fined, as the lady said.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A prisoner!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Winkle, with unaccountable vehemence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hollo, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 responded Sam, looking up. \xe2\x80\x98Wot\xe2\x80\x99s the matter, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I had hoped, Sam, that--Nothing, nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle\r\nprecipitately.\r\n\r\nThere was something so very abrupt and unsettled in Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s manner,\r\nthat Mr. Pickwick involuntarily looked at his two friends for an\r\nexplanation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman, answering this mute appeal aloud. \xe2\x80\x98He\r\nhas been much excited for two days past, and his whole demeanour very\r\nunlike what it usually is. We feared there must be something the matter,\r\nbut he resolutely denies it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle, colouring beneath Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s gaze; \xe2\x80\x98there\r\nis really nothing. I assure you there is nothing, my dear sir. It will\r\nbe necessary for me to leave town, for a short time, on private\r\nbusiness, and I had hoped to have prevailed upon you to allow Sam to\r\naccompany me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick looked more astonished than before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think,\xe2\x80\x99 faltered Mr. Winkle, \xe2\x80\x98that Sam would have had no objection to\r\ndo so; but, of course, his being a prisoner here, renders it impossible.\r\nSo I must go alone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Mr. Winkle said these words, Mr. Pickwick felt, with some\r\nastonishment, that Sam\xe2\x80\x99s fingers were trembling at the gaiters, as if he\r\nwere rather surprised or startled. Sam looked up at Mr. Winkle, too,\r\nwhen he had finished speaking; and though the glance they exchanged was\r\ninstantaneous, they seemed to understand each other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you know anything of this, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick sharply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I don\xe2\x80\x99t, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, beginning to button with\r\nextraordinary assiduity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you sure, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wy, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 responded Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m sure so far, that I\xe2\x80\x99ve never heerd\r\nanythin\xe2\x80\x99 on the subject afore this moment. If I makes any guess about\r\nit,\xe2\x80\x99 added Sam, looking at Mr. Winkle, \xe2\x80\x98I haven\xe2\x80\x99t got any right to say\r\nwhat it is, \xe2\x80\x98fear it should be a wrong \xe2\x80\x98un.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have no right to make any further inquiry into the private affairs of\r\na friend, however intimate a friend,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, after a short\r\nsilence; \xe2\x80\x98at present let me merely say, that I do not understand this at\r\nall. There. We have had quite enough of the subject.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThus expressing himself, Mr. Pickwick led the conversation to different\r\ntopics, and Mr. Winkle gradually appeared more at ease, though still\r\nvery far from being completely so. They had all so much to converse\r\nabout, that the morning very quickly passed away; and when, at three\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock, Mr. Weller produced upon the little dining-table, a roast leg\r\nof mutton and an enormous meat-pie, with sundry dishes of vegetables,\r\nand pots of porter, which stood upon the chairs or the sofa bedstead, or\r\nwhere they could, everybody felt disposed to do justice to the meal,\r\nnotwithstanding that the meat had been purchased, and dressed, and the\r\npie made, and baked, at the prison cookery hard by.\r\n\r\nTo these succeeded a bottle or two of very good wine, for which a\r\nmessenger was despatched by Mr. Pickwick to the Horn Coffee-house, in\r\nDoctors\xe2\x80\x99 Commons. The bottle or two, indeed, might be more properly\r\ndescribed as a bottle or six, for by the time it was drunk, and tea\r\nover, the bell began to ring for strangers to withdraw.\r\n\r\nBut, if Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s behaviour had been unaccountable in the morning, it\r\nbecame perfectly unearthly and solemn when, under the influence of his\r\nfeelings, and his share of the bottle or six, he prepared to take leave\r\nof his friend. He lingered behind, until Mr. Tupman and Mr. Snodgrass\r\nhad disappeared, and then fervently clenched Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s hand, with\r\nan expression of face in which deep and mighty resolve was fearfully\r\nblended with the very concentrated essence of gloom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-night, my dear Sir!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle between his set teeth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless you, my dear fellow!\xe2\x80\x99 replied the warm-hearted Mr. Pickwick, as\r\nhe returned the pressure of his young friend\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now then!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr. Tupman from the gallery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, yes, directly,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Winkle. \xe2\x80\x98Good-night!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-night,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\nThere was another good-night, and another, and half a dozen more after\r\nthat, and still Mr. Winkle had fast hold of his friend\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and was\r\nlooking into his face with the same strange expression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is anything the matter?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick at last, when his arm was\r\nquite sore with shaking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well then, good-night,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, attempting to disengage his\r\nhand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My friend, my benefactor, my honoured companion,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Mr. Winkle,\r\ncatching at his wrist. \xe2\x80\x98Do not judge me harshly; do not, when you hear\r\nthat, driven to extremity by hopeless obstacles, I--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Tupman, reappearing at the door. \xe2\x80\x98Are you coming,\r\nor are we to be locked in?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, yes, I am ready,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Winkle. And with a violent effort he\r\ntore himself away.\r\n\r\nAs Mr. Pickwick was gazing down the passage after them in silent\r\nastonishment, Sam Weller appeared at the stair-head, and whispered for\r\none moment in Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s ear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, certainly, depend upon me,\xe2\x80\x99 said that gentleman aloud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, sir. You won\xe2\x80\x99t forget, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course not,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Winkle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wish you luck, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, touching his hat. \xe2\x80\x98I should very much\r\nliked to ha\xe2\x80\x99 joined you, Sir; but the gov\xe2\x80\x99nor, o\xe2\x80\x99 course, is paramount.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is very much to your credit that you remain here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle.\r\nWith these words they disappeared down the stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very extraordinary,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, going back into his room, and\r\nseating himself at the table in a musing attitude. \xe2\x80\x98What can that young\r\nman be going to do?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe had sat ruminating about the matter for some time, when the voice of\r\nRoker, the turnkey, demanded whether he might come in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By all means,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve brought you a softer pillow, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Roker, \xe2\x80\x98instead of the\r\ntemporary one you had last night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Will you take a glass of wine?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re wery good, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Roker, accepting the proffered\r\nglass. \xe2\x80\x98Yours, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry to say that your landlord\xe2\x80\x99s wery bad to-night, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nRoker, setting down the glass, and inspecting the lining of his hat\r\npreparatory to putting it on again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What! The Chancery prisoner!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He won\xe2\x80\x99t be a Chancery prisoner wery long, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Roker, turning\r\nhis hat round, so as to get the maker\xe2\x80\x99s name right side upwards, as he\r\nlooked into it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You make my blood run cold,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s been consumptive for a long time past,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Roker, \xe2\x80\x98and he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntaken wery bad in the breath to-night. The doctor said, six months ago,\r\nthat nothing but change of air could save him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Great Heaven!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98has this man been slowly\r\nmurdered by the law for six months?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know about that,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Roker, weighing the hat by the brim\r\nin both hands. \xe2\x80\x98I suppose he\xe2\x80\x99d have been took the same, wherever he was.\r\nHe went into the infirmary, this morning; the doctor says his strength\r\nis to be kept up as much as possible; and the warden\xe2\x80\x99s sent him wine and\r\nbroth and that, from his own house. It\xe2\x80\x99s not the warden\xe2\x80\x99s fault, you\r\nknow, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course not,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick hastily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid, however,\xe2\x80\x99 said Roker, shaking his head, \xe2\x80\x98that it\xe2\x80\x99s all up\r\nwith him. I offered Neddy two six-penn\xe2\x80\x99orths to one upon it just now,\r\nbut he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t take it, and quite right. Thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, Sir. Good-night,\r\nsir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stay,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick earnestly. \xe2\x80\x98Where is this infirmary?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just over where you slept, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Roker. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll show you, if you\r\nlike to come.\xe2\x80\x99 Mr. Pickwick snatched up his hat without speaking, and\r\nfollowed at once.\r\n\r\nThe turnkey led the way in silence; and gently raising the latch of the\r\nroom door, motioned Mr. Pickwick to enter. It was a large, bare,\r\ndesolate room, with a number of stump bedsteads made of iron, on one of\r\nwhich lay stretched the shadow of a man--wan, pale, and ghastly. His\r\nbreathing was hard and thick, and he moaned painfully as it came and\r\nwent. At the bedside sat a short old man in a cobbler\xe2\x80\x99s apron, who, by\r\nthe aid of a pair of horn spectacles, was reading from the Bible aloud.\r\nIt was the fortunate legatee.\r\n\r\nThe sick man laid his hand upon his attendant\xe2\x80\x99s arm, and motioned him to\r\nstop. He closed the book, and laid it on the bed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Open the window,\xe2\x80\x99 said the sick man.\r\n\r\nHe did so. The noise of carriages and carts, the rattle of wheels, the\r\ncries of men and boys, all the busy sounds of a mighty multitude\r\ninstinct with life and occupation, blended into one deep murmur, floated\r\ninto the room. Above the hoarse loud hum, arose, from time to time, a\r\nboisterous laugh; or a scrap of some jingling song, shouted forth, by\r\none of the giddy crowd, would strike upon the ear, for an instant, and\r\nthen be lost amidst the roar of voices and the tramp of footsteps; the\r\nbreaking of the billows of the restless sea of life, that rolled heavily\r\non, without. These are melancholy sounds to a quiet listener at any\r\ntime; but how melancholy to the watcher by the bed of death!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is no air here,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man faintly. \xe2\x80\x98The place pollutes it. It\r\nwas fresh round about, when I walked there, years ago; but it grows hot\r\nand heavy in passing these walls. I cannot breathe it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We have breathed it together, for a long time,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old man.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, come.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was a short silence, during which the two spectators approached\r\nthe bed. The sick man drew a hand of his old fellow-prisoner towards\r\nhim, and pressing it affectionately between both his own, retained it in\r\nhis grasp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope,\xe2\x80\x99 he gasped after a while, so faintly that they bent their ears\r\nclose over the bed to catch the half-formed sounds his pale lips gave\r\nvent to--\xe2\x80\x98I hope my merciful Judge will bear in mind my heavy punishment\r\non earth. Twenty years, my friend, twenty years in this hideous grave!\r\nMy heart broke when my child died, and I could not even kiss him in his\r\nlittle coffin. My loneliness since then, in all this noise and riot, has\r\nbeen very dreadful. May God forgive me! He has seen my solitary,\r\nlingering death.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe folded his hands, and murmuring something more they could not hear,\r\nfell into a sleep--only a sleep at first, for they saw him smile.\r\n\r\nThey whispered together for a little time, and the turnkey, stooping\r\nover the pillow, drew hastily back. \xe2\x80\x98He has got his discharge, by G--!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid the man.\r\n\r\nHe had. But he had grown so like death in life, that they knew not when\r\nhe died.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLIV. DESCRIPTIVE OF AN AFFECTING INTERVIEW BETWEEN MR. SAMUEL\r\nWELLER AND A FAMILY PARTY. MR. PICKWICK MAKES A TOUR OF THE DIMINUTIVE\r\nWORLD HE INHABITS, AND RESOLVES TO MIX WITH IT, IN FUTURE, AS LITTLE AS\r\nPOSSIBLE\r\n\r\nA few mornings after his incarceration, Mr. Samuel Weller, having\r\narranged his master\xe2\x80\x99s room with all possible care, and seen him\r\ncomfortably seated over his books and papers, withdrew to employ himself\r\nfor an hour or two to come, as he best could. It was a fine morning, and\r\nit occurred to Sam that a pint of porter in the open air would lighten\r\nhis next quarter of an hour or so, as well as any little amusement in\r\nwhich he could indulge.\r\n\r\nHaving arrived at this conclusion, he betook himself to the tap. Having\r\npurchased the beer, and obtained, moreover, the day-but-one-before-\r\nyesterday\xe2\x80\x99s paper, he repaired to the skittle-ground, and seating\r\nhimself on a bench, proceeded to enjoy himself in a very sedate and\r\nmethodical manner.\r\n\r\nFirst of all, he took a refreshing draught of the beer, and then he\r\nlooked up at a window, and bestowed a platonic wink on a young lady who\r\nwas peeling potatoes thereat. Then he opened the paper, and folded it so\r\nas to get the police reports outwards; and this being a vexatious and\r\ndifficult thing to do, when there is any wind stirring, he took another\r\ndraught of the beer when he had accomplished it. Then, he read two lines\r\nof the paper, and stopped short to look at a couple of men who were\r\nfinishing a game at rackets, which, being concluded, he cried out \xe2\x80\x98wery\r\ngood,\xe2\x80\x99 in an approving manner, and looked round upon the spectators, to\r\nascertain whether their sentiments coincided with his own. This involved\r\nthe necessity of looking up at the windows also; and as the young lady\r\nwas still there, it was an act of common politeness to wink again, and\r\nto drink to her good health in dumb show, in another draught of the\r\nbeer, which Sam did; and having frowned hideously upon a small boy who\r\nhad noted this latter proceeding with open eyes, he threw one leg over\r\nthe other, and, holding the newspaper in both hands, began to read in\r\nreal earnest.\r\n\r\nHe had hardly composed himself into the needful state of abstraction,\r\nwhen he thought he heard his own name proclaimed in some distant\r\npassage. Nor was he mistaken, for it quickly passed from mouth to mouth,\r\nand in a few seconds the air teemed with shouts of \xe2\x80\x98Weller!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere!\xe2\x80\x99 roared Sam, in a stentorian voice. \xe2\x80\x98Wot\xe2\x80\x99s the matter? Who wants\r\nhim? Has an express come to say that his country house is afire?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Somebody wants you in the hall,\xe2\x80\x99 said a man who was standing by.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just mind that \xe2\x80\x98ere paper and the pot, old feller, will you?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m a-comin\xe2\x80\x99. Blessed, if they was a-callin\xe2\x80\x99 me to the bar, they\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t make more noise about it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAccompanying these words with a gentle rap on the head of the young\r\ngentleman before noticed, who, unconscious of his close vicinity to the\r\nperson in request, was screaming \xe2\x80\x98Weller!\xe2\x80\x99 with all his might, Sam\r\nhastened across the ground, and ran up the steps into the hall. Here,\r\nthe first object that met his eyes was his beloved father sitting on a\r\nbottom stair, with his hat in his hand, shouting out \xe2\x80\x98Weller!\xe2\x80\x99 in his\r\nvery loudest tone, at half-minute intervals.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot are you a-roarin\xe2\x80\x99 at?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam impetuously, when the old gentleman\r\nhad discharged himself of another shout; \xe2\x80\x98making yourself so precious\r\nhot that you looks like a aggrawated glass-blower. Wot\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Aha!\xe2\x80\x99 replied the old gentleman, \xe2\x80\x98I began to be afeerd that you\xe2\x80\x99d gone\r\nfor a walk round the Regency Park, Sammy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98none o\xe2\x80\x99 them taunts agin the wictim o\xe2\x80\x99 avarice, and\r\ncome off that \xe2\x80\x98ere step. Wot are you a-settin\xe2\x80\x99 down there for? I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlive there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve got such a game for you, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said the elder Mr. Weller,\r\nrising.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop a minit,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99re all vite behind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s right, Sammy, rub it off,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, as his son dusted\r\nhim. \xe2\x80\x98It might look personal here, if a man walked about with vitevash\r\non his clothes, eh, Sammy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Mr. Weller exhibited in this place unequivocal symptoms of an\r\napproaching fit of chuckling, Sam interposed to stop it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Keep quiet, do,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98there never vos such a old picter-card\r\nborn. Wot are you bustin\xe2\x80\x99 vith, now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, wiping his forehead, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afeerd that vun o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthese days I shall laugh myself into a appleplexy, my boy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vell, then, wot do you do it for?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Now, then, wot have you\r\ngot to say?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who do you think\xe2\x80\x99s come here with me, Samivel?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller,\r\ndrawing back a pace or two, pursing up his mouth, and extending his\r\neyebrows.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pell?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller shook his head, and his red cheeks expanded with the laughter\r\nthat was endeavouring to find a vent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mottled-faced man, p\xe2\x80\x99raps?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Sam.\r\n\r\nAgain Mr. Weller shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who then?\xe2\x80\x99asked Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your mother-in-law,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller; and it was lucky he did say it,\r\nor his cheeks must inevitably have cracked, from their most unnatural\r\ndistension.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your mother-in-law, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98and the red-nosed man, my\r\nboy; and the red-nosed man. Ho! ho! ho!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith this, Mr. Weller launched into convulsions of laughter, while Sam\r\nregarded him with a broad grin gradually over-spreading his whole\r\ncountenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They\xe2\x80\x99ve come to have a little serious talk with you, Samivel,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nWeller, wiping his eyes. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t let out nothin\xe2\x80\x99 about the unnat\xe2\x80\x99ral\r\ncreditor, Sammy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot, don\xe2\x80\x99t they know who it is?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a bit on it,\xe2\x80\x99 replied his father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vere are they?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, reciprocating all the old gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s grins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the snuggery,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Catch the red-nosed man a-goin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nanyvere but vere the liquors is; not he, Samivel, not he. Ve\xe2\x80\x99d a wery\r\npleasant ride along the road from the Markis this mornin\xe2\x80\x99, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMr. Weller, when he felt himself equal to the task of speaking in an\r\narticulate manner. \xe2\x80\x98I drove the old piebald in that \xe2\x80\x98ere little chay-\r\ncart as belonged to your mother-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s first wenter, into vich a harm-\r\ncheer wos lifted for the shepherd; and I\xe2\x80\x99m blessed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller,\r\nwith a look of deep scorn--\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m blessed if they didn\xe2\x80\x99t bring a portable\r\nflight o\xe2\x80\x99 steps out into the road a-front o\xe2\x80\x99 our door for him, to get up\r\nby.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t mean that?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I do mean that, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 replied his father, \xe2\x80\x98and I vish you could ha\xe2\x80\x99\r\nseen how tight he held on by the sides wen he did get up, as if he wos\r\nafeerd o\xe2\x80\x99 being precipitayted down full six foot, and dashed into a\r\nmillion hatoms. He tumbled in at last, however, and avay ve vent; and I\r\nrayther think--I say I rayther think, Samivel--that he found his-self a\r\nlittle jolted ven ve turned the corners.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot, I s\xe2\x80\x99pose you happened to drive up agin a post or two?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afeerd,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, in a rapture of winks--\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afeerd I\r\ntook vun or two on \xe2\x80\x98em, Sammy; he wos a-flyin\xe2\x80\x99 out o\xe2\x80\x99 the arm-cheer all\r\nthe way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere the old gentleman shook his head from side to side, and was seized\r\nwith a hoarse internal rumbling, accompanied with a violent swelling of\r\nthe countenance, and a sudden increase in the breadth of all his\r\nfeatures; symptoms which alarmed his son not a little.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t be frightened, Sammy, don\xe2\x80\x99t be frightened,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old\r\ngentleman, when by dint of much struggling, and various convulsive\r\nstamps upon the ground, he had recovered his voice. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s only a kind o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nquiet laugh as I\xe2\x80\x99m a-tryin\xe2\x80\x99 to come, Sammy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, if that\xe2\x80\x99s wot it is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99d better not try to come it\r\nagin. You\xe2\x80\x99ll find it rayther a dangerous inwention.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you like it, Sammy?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the old gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, with the tears still running down his cheeks,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98it \xe2\x80\x98ud ha\xe2\x80\x99 been a wery great accommodation to me if I could ha\xe2\x80\x99 done\r\nit, and \xe2\x80\x98ud ha\xe2\x80\x99 saved a good many vords atween your mother-in-law and\r\nme, sometimes; but I\xe2\x80\x99m afeerd you\xe2\x80\x99re right, Sammy, it\xe2\x80\x99s too much in the\r\nappleplexy line--a deal too much, Samivel.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis conversation brought them to the door of the snuggery, into which\r\nSam--pausing for an instant to look over his shoulder, and cast a sly\r\nleer at his respected progenitor, who was still giggling behind--at once\r\nled the way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mother-in-law,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, politely saluting the lady, \xe2\x80\x98wery much\r\nobliged to you for this here wisit.--Shepherd, how air you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Samuel!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98This is dreadful.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a bit on it, mum,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.--\xe2\x80\x98Is it, shepherd?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Stiggins raised his hands, and turned up his eyes, until the whites-\r\n-or rather the yellows--were alone visible; but made no reply in words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is this here gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n troubled with any painful complaint?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam,\r\nlooking to his mother-in-law for explanation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The good man is grieved to see you here, Samuel,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, that\xe2\x80\x99s it, is it?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98I was afeerd, from his manner, that\r\nhe might ha\xe2\x80\x99 forgotten to take pepper vith that \xe2\x80\x98ere last cowcumber he\r\neat. Set down, Sir, ve make no extra charge for settin\xe2\x80\x99 down, as the\r\nking remarked wen he blowed up his ministers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Young man,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Stiggins ostentatiously, \xe2\x80\x98I fear you are not\r\nsoftened by imprisonment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Beg your pardon, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam; \xe2\x80\x98wot wos you graciously pleased to\r\nhobserve?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I apprehend, young man, that your nature is no softer for this\r\nchastening,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Stiggins, in a loud voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99re wery kind to say so. I hope my natur is _NOT\r\n_ a soft vun, Sir. Wery much obliged to you for your good opinion, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt this point of the conversation, a sound, indecorously approaching to\r\na laugh, was heard to proceed from the chair in which the elder Mr.\r\nWeller was seated; upon which Mrs. Weller, on a hasty consideration of\r\nall the circumstances of the case, considered it her bounden duty to\r\nbecome gradually hysterical.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. W. (the old gentleman was seated in a corner);\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Weller! Come forth.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery much obleeged to you, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98but I\xe2\x80\x99m quite\r\ncomfortable vere I am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nUpon this, Mrs. Weller burst into tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot\xe2\x80\x99s gone wrong, mum?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Samuel!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98your father makes me wretched. Will\r\nnothing do him good?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you hear this here?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Lady vants to know vether nothin\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\xe2\x80\x98ull do you good.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery much indebted to Mrs. Weller for her po-lite inquiries, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nreplied the old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98I think a pipe vould benefit me a good deal.\r\nCould I be accommodated, Sammy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere Mrs. Weller let fall some more tears, and Mr. Stiggins groaned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hollo! Here\xe2\x80\x99s this unfortunate gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n took ill agin,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam,\r\nlooking round. \xe2\x80\x98Vere do you feel it now, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the same place, young man,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Stiggins, \xe2\x80\x98in the same\r\nplace.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vere may that be, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam, with great outward simplicity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the buzzim, young man,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Stiggins, placing his umbrella\r\non his waistcoat.\r\n\r\nAt this affecting reply, Mrs. Weller, being wholly unable to suppress\r\nher feelings, sobbed aloud, and stated her conviction that the red-nosed\r\nman was a saint; whereupon Mr. Weller, senior, ventured to suggest, in\r\nan undertone, that he must be the representative of the united parishes\r\nof St. Simon Without and St. Walker Within.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afeered, mum,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98that this here gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n, with the twist\r\nin his countenance, feels rather thirsty, with the melancholy spectacle\r\nafore him. Is it the case, mum?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe worthy lady looked at Mr. Stiggins for a reply; that gentleman, with\r\nmany rollings of the eye, clenched his throat with his right hand, and\r\nmimicked the act of swallowing, to intimate that he was athirst.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am afraid, Samuel, that his feelings have made him so indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMrs. Weller mournfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot\xe2\x80\x99s your usual tap, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, my dear young friend,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Stiggins, \xe2\x80\x98all taps is\r\nvanities!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Too true, too true, indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Weller, murmuring a groan, and\r\nshaking her head assentingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98I des-say they may be, sir; but wich is your\r\npartickler wanity? Wich wanity do you like the flavour on best, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, my dear young friend,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Stiggins, \xe2\x80\x98I despise them all.\r\nIf,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Stiggins--\xe2\x80\x98if there is any one of them less odious than\r\nanother, it is the liquor called rum. Warm, my dear young friend, with\r\nthree lumps of sugar to the tumbler.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery sorry to say, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98that they don\xe2\x80\x99t allow that\r\nparticular wanity to be sold in this here establishment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, the hardness of heart of these inveterate men!\xe2\x80\x99 ejaculated Mr.\r\nStiggins. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, the accursed cruelty of these inhuman persecutors!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith these words, Mr. Stiggins again cast up his eyes, and rapped his\r\nbreast with his umbrella; and it is but justice to the reverend\r\ngentleman to say, that his indignation appeared very real and unfeigned\r\nindeed.\r\n\r\nAfter Mrs. Weller and the red-nosed gentleman had commented on this\r\ninhuman usage in a very forcible manner, and had vented a variety of\r\npious and holy execrations against its authors, the latter recommended a\r\nbottle of port wine, warmed with a little water, spice, and sugar, as\r\nbeing grateful to the stomach, and savouring less of vanity than many\r\nother compounds. It was accordingly ordered to be prepared, and pending\r\nits preparation the red-nosed man and Mrs. Weller looked at the elder W.\r\nand groaned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said the gentleman, \xe2\x80\x98I hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll find your spirits rose\r\nby this here lively wisit. Wery cheerful and improvin\xe2\x80\x99 conwersation,\r\nain\xe2\x80\x99t it, Sammy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re a reprobate,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam; \xe2\x80\x98and I desire you won\xe2\x80\x99t address no\r\nmore o\xe2\x80\x99 them ungraceful remarks to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo far from being edified by this very proper reply, the elder Mr.\r\nWeller at once relapsed into a broad grin; and this inexorable conduct\r\ncausing the lady and Mr. Stiggins to close their eyes, and rock\r\nthemselves to and fro on their chairs, in a troubled manner, he\r\nfurthermore indulged in several acts of pantomime, indicative of a\r\ndesire to pummel and wring the nose of the aforesaid Stiggins, the\r\nperformance of which, appeared to afford him great mental relief. The\r\nold gentleman very narrowly escaped detection in one instance; for Mr.\r\nStiggins happening to give a start on the arrival of the negus, brought\r\nhis head in smart contact with the clenched fist with which Mr. Weller\r\nhad been describing imaginary fireworks in the air, within two inches of\r\nhis ear, for some minutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot are you a-reachin\xe2\x80\x99 out, your hand for the tumbler in that \xe2\x80\x98ere\r\nsawage way for?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, with great promptitude. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see you\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nhit the gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t go to do it, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, in some degree abashed\r\nby the very unexpected occurrence of the incident.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Try an in\xe2\x80\x99ard application, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, as the red-nosed gentleman\r\nrubbed his head with a rueful visage. \xe2\x80\x98Wot do you think o\xe2\x80\x99 that, for a\r\ngo o\xe2\x80\x99 wanity, warm, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Stiggins made no verbal answer, but his manner was expressive. He\r\ntasted the contents of the glass which Sam had placed in his hand, put\r\nhis umbrella on the floor, and tasted it again, passing his hand\r\nplacidly across his stomach twice or thrice; he then drank the whole at\r\na breath, and smacking his lips, held out the tumbler for more.\r\n\r\nNor was Mrs. Weller behind-hand in doing justice to the composition. The\r\ngood lady began by protesting that she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t touch a drop--then took\r\na small drop--then a large drop--then a great many drops; and her\r\nfeelings being of the nature of those substances which are powerfully\r\naffected by the application of strong waters, she dropped a tear with\r\nevery drop of negus, and so got on, melting the feelings down, until at\r\nlength she had arrived at a very pathetic and decent pitch of misery.\r\n\r\nThe elder Mr. Weller observed these signs and tokens with many\r\nmanifestations of disgust, and when, after a second jug of the same, Mr.\r\nStiggins began to sigh in a dismal manner, he plainly evinced his\r\ndisapprobation of the whole proceedings, by sundry incoherent ramblings\r\nof speech, among which frequent angry repetitions of the word \xe2\x80\x98gammon\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwere alone distinguishable to the ear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you wot it is, Samivel, my boy,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered the old gentleman\r\ninto his son\xe2\x80\x99s ear, after a long and steadfast contemplation of his lady\r\nand Mr. Stiggins; \xe2\x80\x98I think there must be somethin\xe2\x80\x99 wrong in your mother-\r\nin-law\xe2\x80\x99s inside, as vell as in that o\xe2\x80\x99 the red-nosed man.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I mean this here, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the old gentleman, \xe2\x80\x98that wot they\r\ndrink, don\xe2\x80\x99t seem no nourishment to \xe2\x80\x98em; it all turns to warm water, and\r\ncomes a-pourin\xe2\x80\x99 out o\xe2\x80\x99 their eyes. \xe2\x80\x98Pend upon it, Sammy, it\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nconstitootional infirmity.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\nMr. Weller delivered this scientific opinion with many confirmatory\r\nfrowns and nods; which, Mrs. Weller remarking, and concluding that they\r\nbore some disparaging reference either to herself or to Mr. Stiggins, or\r\nto both, was on the point of becoming infinitely worse, when Mr.\r\nStiggins, getting on his legs as well as he could, proceeded to deliver\r\nan edifying discourse for the benefit of the company, but more\r\nespecially of Mr. Samuel, whom he adjured in moving terms to be upon his\r\nguard in that sink of iniquity into which he was cast; to abstain from\r\nall hypocrisy and pride of heart; and to take in all things exact\r\npattern and copy by him (Stiggins), in which case he might calculate on\r\narriving, sooner or later at the comfortable conclusion, that, like him,\r\nhe was a most estimable and blameless character, and that all his\r\nacquaintances and friends were hopelessly abandoned and profligate\r\nwretches. Which consideration, he said, could not but afford him the\r\nliveliest satisfaction.\r\n\r\nHe furthermore conjured him to avoid, above all things, the vice of\r\nintoxication, which he likened unto the filthy habits of swine, and to\r\nthose poisonous and baleful drugs which being chewed in the mouth, are\r\nsaid to filch away the memory. At this point of his discourse, the\r\nreverend and red-nosed gentleman became singularly incoherent, and\r\nstaggering to and fro in the excitement of his eloquence, was fain to\r\ncatch at the back of a chair to preserve his perpendicular.\r\n\r\nMr. Stiggins did not desire his hearers to be upon their guard against\r\nthose false prophets and wretched mockers of religion, who, without\r\nsense to expound its first doctrines, or hearts to feel its first\r\nprinciples, are more dangerous members of society than the common\r\ncriminal; imposing, as they necessarily do, upon the weakest and worst\r\ninformed, casting scorn and contempt on what should be held most sacred,\r\nand bringing into partial disrepute large bodies of virtuous and well-\r\nconducted persons of many excellent sects and persuasions. But as he\r\nleaned over the back of the chair for a considerable time, and closing\r\none eye, winked a good deal with the other, it is presumed that he\r\nthought all this, but kept it to himself.\r\n\r\nDuring the delivery of the oration, Mrs. Weller sobbed and wept at the\r\nend of the paragraphs; while Sam, sitting cross-legged on a chair and\r\nresting his arms on the top rail, regarded the speaker with great\r\nsuavity and blandness of demeanour; occasionally bestowing a look of\r\nrecognition on the old gentleman, who was delighted at the beginning,\r\nand went to sleep about half-way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Brayvo; wery pretty!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, when the red-nosed man having finished,\r\npulled his worn gloves on, thereby thrusting his fingers through the\r\nbroken tops till the knuckles were disclosed to view. \xe2\x80\x98Wery pretty.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope it may do you good, Samuel,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Weller solemnly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think it vill, mum,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish I could hope that it would do your father good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs.\r\nWeller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, senior. \xe2\x80\x98How do you find yourself\r\narter it, my love?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Scoffer!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mrs. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Benighted man!\xe2\x80\x99 said the Reverend Mr. Stiggins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I don\xe2\x80\x99t get no better light than that \xe2\x80\x98ere moonshine o\xe2\x80\x99 yourn, my\r\nworthy creetur,\xe2\x80\x99 said the elder Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s wery likely as I shall\r\ncontiney to be a night coach till I\xe2\x80\x99m took off the road altogether. Now,\r\nMrs. We, if the piebald stands at livery much longer, he\xe2\x80\x99ll stand at\r\nnothin\xe2\x80\x99 as we go back, and p\xe2\x80\x99raps that \xe2\x80\x98ere harm-cheer \xe2\x80\x98ull be tipped\r\nover into some hedge or another, with the shepherd in it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt this supposition, the Reverend Mr. Stiggins, in evident\r\nconsternation, gathered up his hat and umbrella, and proposed an\r\nimmediate departure, to which Mrs. Weller assented. Sam walked with them\r\nto the lodge gate, and took a dutiful leave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A-do, Samivel,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot\xe2\x80\x99s a-do?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sammy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, good-bye, then,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, that\xe2\x80\x99s wot you\xe2\x80\x99re aimin\xe2\x80\x99 at, is it?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Good-bye!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Mr. Weller, looking cautiously round; \xe2\x80\x98my duty to\r\nyour gov\xe2\x80\x99nor, and tell him if he thinks better o\xe2\x80\x99 this here bis\xe2\x80\x99ness, to\r\ncom-moonicate vith me. Me and a cab\xe2\x80\x99net-maker has dewised a plan for\r\ngettin\xe2\x80\x99 him out. A pianner, Samivel--a pianner!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller,\r\nstriking his son on the chest with the back of his hand, and falling\r\nback a step or two.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A pianner-forty, Samivel,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Weller, in a still more\r\nmysterious manner, \xe2\x80\x98as he can have on hire; vun as von\xe2\x80\x99t play, Sammy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And wot \xe2\x80\x98ud be the good o\xe2\x80\x99 that?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let him send to my friend, the cabinet-maker, to fetch it back, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nreplied Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Are you avake, now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There ain\xe2\x80\x99t no vurks in it,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered his father. \xe2\x80\x98It \xe2\x80\x98ull hold him\r\neasy, vith his hat and shoes on, and breathe through the legs, vich his\r\nholler. Have a passage ready taken for \xe2\x80\x98Merriker. The \xe2\x80\x98Merrikin gov\xe2\x80\x99ment\r\nwill never give him up, ven vunce they find as he\xe2\x80\x99s got money to spend,\r\nSammy. Let the gov\xe2\x80\x99nor stop there, till Mrs. Bardell\xe2\x80\x99s dead, or Mr.\r\nDodson and Fogg\xe2\x80\x99s hung (wich last ewent I think is the most likely to\r\nhappen first, Sammy), and then let him come back and write a book about\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x98Merrikins as\xe2\x80\x99ll pay all his expenses and more, if he blows \xe2\x80\x98em up\r\nenough.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller delivered this hurried abstract of his plot with great\r\nvehemence of whisper; and then, as if fearful of weakening the effect of\r\nthe tremendous communication by any further dialogue, he gave the\r\ncoachman\xe2\x80\x99s salute, and vanished.\r\n\r\nSam had scarcely recovered his usual composure of countenance, which had\r\nbeen greatly disturbed by the secret communication of his respected\r\nrelative, when Mr. Pickwick accosted him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said that gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am going for a walk round the prison, and I wish you to attend me. I\r\nsee a prisoner we know coming this way, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick,\r\nsmiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wich, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98the gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n vith the head o\xe2\x80\x99 hair,\r\nor the interestin\xe2\x80\x99 captive in the stockin\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Neither,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98He is an older friend of yours, Sam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O\xe2\x80\x99 mine, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You recollect the gentleman very well, I dare say, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr.\r\nPickwick, \xe2\x80\x98or else you are more unmindful of your old acquaintances than\r\nI think you are. Hush! not a word, Sam; not a syllable. Here he is.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Mr. Pickwick spoke, Jingle walked up. He looked less miserable than\r\nbefore, being clad in a half-worn suit of clothes, which, with Mr.\r\nPickwick\xe2\x80\x99s assistance, had been released from the pawnbroker\xe2\x80\x99s. He wore\r\nclean linen too, and had had his hair cut. He was very pale and thin,\r\nhowever; and as he crept slowly up, leaning on a stick, it was easy to\r\nsee that he had suffered severely from illness and want, and was still\r\nvery weak. He took off his hat as Mr. Pickwick saluted him, and seemed\r\nmuch humbled and abashed at the sight of Sam Weller.\r\n\r\nFollowing close at his heels, came Mr. Job Trotter, in the catalogue of\r\nwhose vices, want of faith and attachment to his companion could at all\r\nevents find no place. He was still ragged and squalid, but his face was\r\nnot quite so hollow as on his first meeting with Mr. Pickwick, a few\r\ndays before. As he took off his hat to our benevolent old friend, he\r\nmurmured some broken expressions of gratitude, and muttered something\r\nabout having been saved from starving.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, impatiently interrupting him, \xe2\x80\x98you can\r\nfollow with Sam. I want to speak to you, Mr. Jingle. Can you walk\r\nwithout his arm?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, sir--all ready--not too fast--legs shaky--head queer--round\r\nand round--earthquaky sort of feeling--very.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here, give me your arm,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jingle; \xe2\x80\x98won\xe2\x80\x99t indeed--rather not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98lean upon me, I desire, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSeeing that he was confused and agitated, and uncertain what to do, Mr.\r\nPickwick cut the matter short by drawing the invalided stroller\xe2\x80\x99s arm\r\nthrough his, and leading him away, without saying another word about it.\r\n\r\nDuring the whole of this time the countenance of Mr. Samuel Weller had\r\nexhibited an expression of the most overwhelming and absorbing\r\nastonishment that the imagination can portray. After looking from Job to\r\nJingle, and from Jingle to Job in profound silence, he softly ejaculated\r\nthe words, \xe2\x80\x98Well, I _am_ damn\xe2\x80\x99d!\xe2\x80\x99 which he repeated at least a score of\r\ntimes; after which exertion, he appeared wholly bereft of speech, and\r\nagain cast his eyes, first upon the one and then upon the other, in mute\r\nperplexity and bewilderment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Sam!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, looking back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m a-comin\xe2\x80\x99, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, mechanically following his\r\nmaster; and still he lifted not his eyes from Mr. Job Trotter, who\r\nwalked at his side in silence.\r\n\r\nJob kept his eyes fixed on the ground for some time. Sam, with his glued\r\nto Job\xe2\x80\x99s countenance, ran up against the people who were walking about,\r\nand fell over little children, and stumbled against steps and railings,\r\nwithout appearing at all sensible of it, until Job, looking stealthily\r\nup, said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How do you do, Mr. Weller?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It _is_ him!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Sam; and having established Job\xe2\x80\x99s identity\r\nbeyond all doubt, he smote his leg, and vented his feelings in a long,\r\nshrill whistle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Things has altered with me, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should think they had,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Weller, surveying his\r\ncompanion\xe2\x80\x99s rags with undisguised wonder. \xe2\x80\x98This is rayther a change for\r\nthe worse, Mr. Trotter, as the gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n said, wen he got two doubtful\r\nshillin\xe2\x80\x99s and sixpenn\xe2\x80\x99orth o\xe2\x80\x99 pocket-pieces for a good half-crown.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job, shaking his head. \xe2\x80\x98There is no deception\r\nnow, Mr. Weller. Tears,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job, with a look of momentary slyness--\r\n\xe2\x80\x98tears are not the only proofs of distress, nor the best ones.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, they ain\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam expressively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They may be put on, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know they may,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam; \xe2\x80\x98some people, indeed, has \xe2\x80\x98em always ready\r\nlaid on, and can pull out the plug wenever they likes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job; \xe2\x80\x98but these sort of things are not so easily\r\ncounterfeited, Mr. Weller, and it is a more painful process to get them\r\nup.\xe2\x80\x99 As he spoke, he pointed to his sallow, sunken cheeks, and, drawing\r\nup his coat sleeve, disclosed an arm which looked as if the bone could\r\nbe broken at a touch, so sharp and brittle did it appear, beneath its\r\nthin covering of flesh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot have you been a-doin\xe2\x80\x99 to yourself?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, recoiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothin\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x99 echoed Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have been doin\xe2\x80\x99 nothing for many weeks past,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job; and eating\r\nand drinking almost as little.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSam took one comprehensive glance at Mr. Trotter\xe2\x80\x99s thin face and\r\nwretched apparel; and then, seizing him by the arm, commenced dragging\r\nhim away with great violence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where are you going, Mr. Weller?\xe2\x80\x99 said Job, vainly struggling in the\r\npowerful grasp of his old enemy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come on,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam; \xe2\x80\x98come on!\xe2\x80\x99 He deigned no further explanation till\r\nthey reached the tap, and then called for a pot of porter, which was\r\nspeedily produced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98drink that up, ev\xe2\x80\x99ry drop on it, and then turn the pot\r\nupside down, to let me see as you\xe2\x80\x99ve took the medicine.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, my dear Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 remonstrated Job.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Down vith it!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam peremptorily.\r\n\r\nThus admonished, Mr. Trotter raised the pot to his lips, and, by gentle\r\nand almost imperceptible degrees, tilted it into the air. He paused\r\nonce, and only once, to draw a long breath, but without raising his face\r\nfrom the vessel, which, in a few moments thereafter, he held out at\r\narm\xe2\x80\x99s length, bottom upward. Nothing fell upon the ground but a few\r\nparticles of froth, which slowly detached themselves from the rim, and\r\ntrickled lazily down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well done!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98How do you find yourself arter it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Better, Sir. I think I am better,\xe2\x80\x99 responded Job.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O\xe2\x80\x99 course you air,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam argumentatively. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s like puttin\xe2\x80\x99 gas in\r\na balloon. I can see with the naked eye that you gets stouter under the\r\noperation. Wot do you say to another o\xe2\x80\x99 the same dimensions?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I would rather not, I am much obliged to you, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job--\xe2\x80\x98much\r\nrather not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vell, then, wot do you say to some wittles?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thanks to your worthy governor, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Trotter, \xe2\x80\x98we have half a\r\nleg of mutton, baked, at a quarter before three, with the potatoes under\r\nit to save boiling.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot! Has _he_ been a-purwidin\xe2\x80\x99 for you?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Sam emphatically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He has, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job. \xe2\x80\x98More than that, Mr. Weller; my master being\r\nvery ill, he got us a room--we were in a kennel before--and paid for it,\r\nSir; and come to look at us, at night, when nobody should know. Mr.\r\nWeller,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job, with real tears in his eyes, for once, \xe2\x80\x98I could serve\r\nthat gentleman till I fell down dead at his feet.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll trouble you, my friend! None o\xe2\x80\x99 that!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJob Trotter looked amazed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98None o\xe2\x80\x99 that, I say, young feller,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Sam firmly. \xe2\x80\x98No man serves\r\nhim but me. And now we\xe2\x80\x99re upon it, I\xe2\x80\x99ll let you into another secret\r\nbesides that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, as he paid for the beer. \xe2\x80\x98I never heerd, mind\r\nyou, or read of in story-books, nor see in picters, any angel in tights\r\nand gaiters--not even in spectacles, as I remember, though that may ha\xe2\x80\x99\r\nbeen done for anythin\xe2\x80\x99 I know to the contrairey--but mark my vords, Job\r\nTrotter, he\xe2\x80\x99s a reg\xe2\x80\x99lar thoroughbred angel for all that; and let me see\r\nthe man as wenturs to tell me he knows a better vun.\xe2\x80\x99 With this\r\ndefiance, Mr. Weller buttoned up his change in a side pocket, and, with\r\nmany confirmatory nods and gestures by the way, proceeded in search of\r\nthe subject of discourse.\r\n\r\nThey found Mr. Pickwick, in company with Jingle, talking very earnestly,\r\nand not bestowing a look on the groups who were congregated on the\r\nracket-ground; they were very motley groups too, and worth the looking\r\nat, if it were only in idle curiosity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, as Sam and his companion drew nigh, \xe2\x80\x98you will\r\nsee how your health becomes, and think about it meanwhile. Make the\r\nstatement out for me when you feel yourself equal to the task, and I\r\nwill discuss the subject with you when I have considered it. Now, go to\r\nyour room. You are tired, and not strong enough to be out long.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Alfred Jingle, without one spark of his old animation--with nothing\r\neven of the dismal gaiety which he had assumed when Mr. Pickwick first\r\nstumbled on him in his misery--bowed low without speaking, and,\r\nmotioning to Job not to follow him just yet, crept slowly away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Curious scene this, is it not, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, looking good-\r\nhumouredly round.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery much so, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Wonders \xe2\x80\x98ull never cease,\xe2\x80\x99 added Sam,\r\nspeaking to himself. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m wery much mistaken if that \xe2\x80\x98ere Jingle worn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\na-doin somethin\xe2\x80\x99 in the water-cart way!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe area formed by the wall in that part of the Fleet in which Mr.\r\nPickwick stood was just wide enough to make a good racket-court; one\r\nside being formed, of course, by the wall itself, and the other by that\r\nportion of the prison which looked (or rather would have looked, but for\r\nthe wall) towards St. Paul\xe2\x80\x99s Cathedral. Sauntering or sitting about, in\r\nevery possible attitude of listless idleness, were a great number of\r\ndebtors, the major part of whom were waiting in prison until their day\r\nof \xe2\x80\x98going up\xe2\x80\x99 before the Insolvent Court should arrive; while others had\r\nbeen remanded for various terms, which they were idling away as they\r\nbest could. Some were shabby, some were smart, many dirty, a few clean;\r\nbut there they all lounged, and loitered, and slunk about with as little\r\nspirit or purpose as the beasts in a menagerie.\r\n\r\nLolling from the windows which commanded a view of this promenade were a\r\nnumber of persons, some in noisy conversation with their acquaintance\r\nbelow, others playing at ball with some adventurous throwers outside,\r\nothers looking on at the racket-players, or watching the boys as they\r\ncried the game. Dirty, slipshod women passed and repassed, on their way\r\nto the cooking-house in one corner of the yard; children screamed, and\r\nfought, and played together, in another; the tumbling of the skittles,\r\nand the shouts of the players, mingled perpetually with these and a\r\nhundred other sounds; and all was noise and tumult--save in a little\r\nmiserable shed a few yards off, where lay, all quiet and ghastly, the\r\nbody of the Chancery prisoner who had died the night before, awaiting\r\nthe mockery of an inquest. The body! It is the lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s term for the\r\nrestless, whirling mass of cares and anxieties, affections, hopes, and\r\ngriefs, that make up the living man. The law had his body; and there it\r\nlay, clothed in grave-clothes, an awful witness to its tender mercy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Would you like to see a whistling-shop, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Job Trotter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 was Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s counter inquiry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A vistlin\xe2\x80\x99 shop, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is that, Sam?--A bird-fancier\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless your heart, no, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job; \xe2\x80\x98a whistling-shop, Sir, is\r\nwhere they sell spirits.\xe2\x80\x99 Mr. Job Trotter briefly explained here, that\r\nall persons, being prohibited under heavy penalties from conveying\r\nspirits into debtors\xe2\x80\x99 prisons, and such commodities being highly prized\r\nby the ladies and gentlemen confined therein, it had occurred to some\r\nspeculative turnkey to connive, for certain lucrative considerations, at\r\ntwo or three prisoners retailing the favourite article of gin, for their\r\nown profit and advantage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This plan, you see, Sir, has been gradually introduced into all the\r\nprisons for debt,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Trotter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And it has this wery great advantage,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, \xe2\x80\x98that the turnkeys\r\ntakes wery good care to seize hold o\xe2\x80\x99 ev\xe2\x80\x99rybody but them as pays \xe2\x80\x98em,\r\nthat attempts the willainy, and wen it gets in the papers they\xe2\x80\x99re\r\napplauded for their wigilance; so it cuts two ways--frightens other\r\npeople from the trade, and elewates their own characters.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Exactly so, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Job.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, but are these rooms never searched to ascertain whether any\r\nspirits are concealed in them?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Cert\xe2\x80\x99nly they are, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam; \xe2\x80\x98but the turnkeys knows\r\nbeforehand, and gives the word to the wistlers, and you may wistle for\r\nit wen you go to look.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBy this time, Job had tapped at a door, which was opened by a gentleman\r\nwith an uncombed head, who bolted it after them when they had walked in,\r\nand grinned; upon which Job grinned, and Sam also; whereupon Mr.\r\nPickwick, thinking it might be expected of him, kept on smiling to the\r\nend of the interview.\r\n\r\nThe gentleman with the uncombed head appeared quite satisfied with this\r\nmute announcement of their business, and, producing a flat stone bottle,\r\nwhich might hold about a couple of quarts, from beneath his bedstead,\r\nfilled out three glasses of gin, which Job Trotter and Sam disposed of\r\nin a most workmanlike manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Any more?\xe2\x80\x99 said the whistling gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No more,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job Trotter.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick paid, the door was unbolted, and out they came; the\r\nuncombed gentleman bestowing a friendly nod upon Mr. Roker, who happened\r\nto be passing at the moment.\r\n\r\nFrom this spot, Mr. Pickwick wandered along all the galleries, up and\r\ndown all the staircases, and once again round the whole area of the\r\nyard. The great body of the prison population appeared to be Mivins, and\r\nSmangle, and the parson, and the butcher, and the leg, over and over,\r\nand over again. There were the same squalor, the same turmoil and noise,\r\nthe same general characteristics, in every corner; in the best and the\r\nworst alike. The whole place seemed restless and troubled; and the\r\npeople were crowding and flitting to and fro, like the shadows in an\r\nuneasy dream.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have seen enough,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, as he threw himself into a\r\nchair in his little apartment. \xe2\x80\x98My head aches with these scenes, and my\r\nheart too. Henceforth I will be a prisoner in my own room.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAnd Mr. Pickwick steadfastly adhered to this determination. For three\r\nlong months he remained shut up, all day; only stealing out at night to\r\nbreathe the air, when the greater part of his fellow-prisoners were in\r\nbed or carousing in their rooms. His health was beginning to suffer from\r\nthe closeness of the confinement, but neither the often-repeated\r\nentreaties of Perker and his friends, nor the still more frequently-\r\nrepeated warnings and admonitions of Mr. Samuel Weller, could induce him\r\nto alter one jot of his inflexible resolution.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLVI. RECORDS A TOUCHING ACT OF DELICATE FEELING, NOT UNMIXED\r\nWITH PLEASANTRY, ACHIEVED AND PERFORMED BY Messrs. DODSON AND FOGG\r\n\r\nIt was within a week of the close of the month of July, that a hackney\r\ncabriolet, number unrecorded, was seen to proceed at a rapid pace up\r\nGoswell Street; three people were squeezed into it besides the driver,\r\nwho sat in his own particular little dickey at the side; over the apron\r\nwere hung two shawls, belonging to two small vixenish-looking ladies\r\nunder the apron; between whom, compressed into a very small compass, was\r\nstowed away, a gentleman of heavy and subdued demeanour, who, whenever\r\nhe ventured to make an observation, was snapped up short by one of the\r\nvixenish ladies before-mentioned. Lastly, the two vixenish ladies and\r\nthe heavy gentleman were giving the driver contradictory directions, all\r\ntending to the one point, that he should stop at Mrs. Bardell\xe2\x80\x99s door;\r\nwhich the heavy gentleman, in direct opposition to, and defiance of, the\r\nvixenish ladies, contended was a green door and not a yellow one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop at the house with a green door, driver,\xe2\x80\x99 said the heavy gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh!
