You perwerse creetur!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed one of the vixenish ladies. \xe2\x80\x98Drive\r\nto the \xe2\x80\x98ouse with the yellow door, cabmin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nUpon this the cabman, who in a sudden effort to pull up at the house\r\nwith the green door, had pulled the horse up so high that he nearly\r\npulled him backward into the cabriolet, let the animal\xe2\x80\x99s fore-legs down\r\nto the ground again, and paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now vere am I to pull up?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the driver. \xe2\x80\x98Settle it among\r\nyourselves. All I ask is, vere?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere the contest was renewed with increased violence; and the horse\r\nbeing troubled with a fly on his nose, the cabman humanely employed his\r\nleisure in lashing him about on the head, on the counter-irritation\r\nprinciple.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Most wotes carries the day!\xe2\x80\x99 said one of the vixenish ladies at length.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The \xe2\x80\x98ouse with the yellow door, cabman.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut after the cabriolet had dashed up, in splendid style, to the house\r\nwith the yellow door, \xe2\x80\x98making,\xe2\x80\x99 as one of the vixenish ladies\r\ntriumphantly said, \xe2\x80\x98acterrally more noise than if one had come in one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nown carriage,\xe2\x80\x99 and after the driver had dismounted to assist the ladies\r\nin getting out, the small round head of Master Thomas Bardell was thrust\r\nout of the one-pair window of a house with a red door, a few numbers\r\noff.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Aggrawatin\xe2\x80\x99 thing!\xe2\x80\x99 said the vixenish lady last-mentioned, darting a\r\nwithering glance at the heavy gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear, it\xe2\x80\x99s not my fault,\xe2\x80\x99 said the gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t talk to me, you creetur, don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted the lady. \xe2\x80\x98The house\r\nwith the red door, cabmin. Oh! If ever a woman was troubled with a\r\nruffinly creetur, that takes a pride and a pleasure in disgracing his\r\nwife on every possible occasion afore strangers, I am that woman!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You ought to be ashamed of yourself, Raddle,\xe2\x80\x99 said the other little\r\nwoman, who was no other than Mrs. Cluppins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What have I been a-doing of?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr. Raddle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t talk to me, don\xe2\x80\x99t, you brute, for fear I should be perwoked to\r\nforgit my sect and strike you!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Raddle.\r\n\r\nWhile this dialogue was going on, the driver was most ignominiously\r\nleading the horse, by the bridle, up to the house with the red door,\r\nwhich Master Bardell had already opened. Here was a mean and low way of\r\narriving at a friend\xe2\x80\x99s house! No dashing up, with all the fire and fury\r\nof the animal; no jumping down of the driver; no loud knocking at the\r\ndoor; no opening of the apron with a crash at the very last moment, for\r\nfear of the ladies sitting in a draught; and then the man handing the\r\nshawls out, afterwards, as if he were a private coachman! The whole edge\r\nof the thing had been taken off--it was flatter than walking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Tommy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Cluppins, \xe2\x80\x98how\xe2\x80\x99s your poor dear mother?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, she\xe2\x80\x99s very well,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Master Bardell. \xe2\x80\x98She\xe2\x80\x99s in the front\r\nparlour, all ready. I\xe2\x80\x99m ready too, I am.\xe2\x80\x99 Here Master Bardell put his\r\nhands in his pockets, and jumped off and on the bottom step of the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is anybody else a-goin\xe2\x80\x99, Tommy?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Cluppins, arranging her\r\npelerine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Sanders is going, she is,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Tommy; \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m going too, I am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Drat the boy,\xe2\x80\x99 said little Mrs. Cluppins. \xe2\x80\x98He thinks of nobody but\r\nhimself. Here, Tommy, dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Master Bardell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who else is a-goin\xe2\x80\x99, lovey?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Cluppins, in an insinuating\r\nmanner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! Mrs. Rogers is a-goin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Master Bardell, opening his eyes\r\nvery wide as he delivered the intelligence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What? The lady as has taken the lodgings!\xe2\x80\x99 ejaculated Mrs. Cluppins.\r\n\r\nMaster Bardell put his hands deeper down into his pockets, and nodded\r\nexactly thirty-five times, to imply that it was the lady-lodger, and no\r\nother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless us!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Cluppins. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s quite a party!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, if you knew what was in the cupboard, you\xe2\x80\x99d say so,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Master\r\nBardell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is there, Tommy?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Cluppins coaxingly. \xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ll tell _me_,\r\nTommy, I know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNo, I won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Master Bardell, shaking his head, and applying\r\nhimself to the bottom step again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Drat the child!\xe2\x80\x99 muttered Mrs. Cluppins. \xe2\x80\x98What a prowokin\xe2\x80\x99 little\r\nwretch it is! Come, Tommy, tell your dear Cluppy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mother said I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t to,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Master Bardell, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m a-goin\xe2\x80\x99 to have\r\nsome, I am.\xe2\x80\x99 Cheered by this prospect, the precocious boy applied\r\nhimself to his infantile treadmill, with increased vigour.\r\n\r\nThe above examination of a child of tender years took place while Mr.\r\nand Mrs. Raddle and the cab-driver were having an altercation concerning\r\nthe fare, which, terminating at this point in favour of the cabman, Mrs.\r\nRaddle came up tottering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lauk, Mary Ann! what\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Cluppins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s put me all over in such a tremble, Betsy,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs. Raddle.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Raddle ain\xe2\x80\x99t like a man; he leaves everythink to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis was scarcely fair upon the unfortunate Mr. Raddle, who had been\r\nthrust aside by his good lady in the commencement of the dispute, and\r\nperemptorily commanded to hold his tongue. He had no opportunity of\r\ndefending himself, however, for Mrs. Raddle gave unequivocal signs of\r\nfainting; which, being perceived from the parlour window, Mrs. Bardell,\r\nMrs. Sanders, the lodger, and the lodger\xe2\x80\x99s servant, darted precipitately\r\nout, and conveyed her into the house, all talking at the same time, and\r\ngiving utterance to various expressions of pity and condolence, as if\r\nshe were one of the most suffering mortals on earth. Being conveyed into\r\nthe front parlour, she was there deposited on a sofa; and the lady from\r\nthe first floor running up to the first floor, returned with a bottle of\r\nsal-volatile, which, holding Mrs. Raddle tight round the neck, she\r\napplied in all womanly kindness and pity to her nose, until that lady\r\nwith many plunges and struggles was fain to declare herself decidedly\r\nbetter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, poor thing!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Rogers, \xe2\x80\x98I know what her feelin\xe2\x80\x99s is, too\r\nwell.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAh, poor thing! so do I,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Sanders; and then all the ladies\r\nmoaned in unison, and said they knew what it was, and they pitied her\r\nfrom their hearts, they did. Even the lodger\xe2\x80\x99s little servant, who was\r\nthirteen years old and three feet high, murmured her sympathy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But what\xe2\x80\x99s been the matter?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, what has decomposed you, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mrs. Rogers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have been a good deal flurried,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs. Raddle, in a\r\nreproachful manner. Thereupon the ladies cast indignant glances at Mr.\r\nRaddle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, the fact is,\xe2\x80\x99 said that unhappy gentleman, stepping forward, \xe2\x80\x98when\r\nwe alighted at this door, a dispute arose with the driver of the\r\ncabrioily--\xe2\x80\x99 A loud scream from his wife, at the mention of this word,\r\nrendered all further explanation inaudible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99d better leave us to bring her round, Raddle,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Cluppins.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She\xe2\x80\x99ll never get better as long as you\xe2\x80\x99re here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAll the ladies concurred in this opinion; so Mr. Raddle was pushed out\r\nof the room, and requested to give himself an airing in the back yard.\r\nWhich he did for about a quarter of an hour, when Mrs. Bardell announced\r\nto him with a solemn face that he might come in now, but that he must be\r\nvery careful how he behaved towards his wife. She knew he didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean to\r\nbe unkind; but Mary Ann was very far from strong, and, if he didn\xe2\x80\x99t take\r\ncare, he might lose her when he least expected it, which would be a very\r\ndreadful reflection for him afterwards; and so on. All this, Mr. Raddle\r\nheard with great submission, and presently returned to the parlour in a\r\nmost lamb-like manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, Mrs. Rogers, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99ve never been\r\nintroduced, I declare! Mr. Raddle, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; Mrs. Cluppins, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; Mrs.\r\nRaddle, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which is Mrs. Cluppins\xe2\x80\x99s sister,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Mrs. Sanders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, indeed!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Rogers graciously; for she was the lodger, and\r\nher servant was in waiting, so she was more gracious than intimate, in\r\nright of her position. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, indeed!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs. Raddle smiled sweetly, Mr. Raddle bowed, and Mrs. Cluppins said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98she was sure she was very happy to have an opportunity of being known\r\nto a lady which she had heerd so much in favour of, as Mrs. Rogers.\xe2\x80\x99 A\r\ncompliment which the last-named lady acknowledged with graceful\r\ncondescension.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Mr. Raddle,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell; \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you ought to feel very\r\nmuch honoured at you and Tommy being the only gentlemen to escort so\r\nmany ladies all the way to the Spaniards, at Hampstead. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you think\r\nhe ought, Mrs. Rogers, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOh, certainly, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs. Rogers; after whom all the other\r\nladies responded, \xe2\x80\x98Oh, certainly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course I feel it, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Raddle, rubbing his hands, and\r\nevincing a slight tendency to brighten up a little. \xe2\x80\x98Indeed, to tell you\r\nthe truth, I said, as we was a-coming along in the cabrioily--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt the recapitulation of the word which awakened so many painful\r\nrecollections, Mrs. Raddle applied her handkerchief to her eyes again,\r\nand uttered a half-suppressed scream; so that Mrs. Bardell frowned upon\r\nMr. Raddle, to intimate that he had better not say anything more, and\r\ndesired Mrs. Rogers\xe2\x80\x99s servant, with an air, to \xe2\x80\x98put the wine on.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis was the signal for displaying the hidden treasures of the closet,\r\nwhich comprised sundry plates of oranges and biscuits, and a bottle of\r\nold crusted port--that at one-and-nine--with another of the celebrated\r\nEast India sherry at fourteen-pence, which were all produced in honour\r\nof the lodger, and afforded unlimited satisfaction to everybody. After\r\ngreat consternation had been excited in the mind of Mrs. Cluppins, by an\r\nattempt on the part of Tommy to recount how he had been cross-examined\r\nregarding the cupboard then in action (which was fortunately nipped in\r\nthe bud by his imbibing half a glass of the old crusted \xe2\x80\x98the wrong way,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nand thereby endangering his life for some seconds), the party walked\r\nforth in quest of a Hampstead stage. This was soon found, and in a\r\ncouple of hours they all arrived safely in the Spaniards Tea-gardens,\r\nwhere the luckless Mr. Raddle\xe2\x80\x99s very first act nearly occasioned his\r\ngood lady a relapse; it being neither more nor less than to order tea\r\nfor seven, whereas (as the ladies one and all remarked), what could have\r\nbeen easier than for Tommy to have drank out of anybody\xe2\x80\x99s cup--or\r\neverybody\xe2\x80\x99s, if that was all--when the waiter wasn\xe2\x80\x99t looking, which\r\nwould have saved one head of tea, and the tea just as good!\r\n\r\nHowever, there was no help for it, and the tea-tray came, with seven\r\ncups and saucers, and bread-and-butter on the same scale. Mrs. Bardell\r\nwas unanimously voted into the chair, and Mrs. Rogers being stationed on\r\nher right hand, and Mrs. Raddle on her left, the meal proceeded with\r\ngreat merriment and success.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How sweet the country is, to be sure!\xe2\x80\x99 sighed Mrs. Rogers; \xe2\x80\x98I almost\r\nwish I lived in it always.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t like that, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs. Bardell, rather\r\nhastily; for it was not at all advisable, with reference to the\r\nlodgings, to encourage such notions; \xe2\x80\x98you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t like it, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! I should think you was a deal too lively and sought after, to be\r\ncontent with the country, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said little Mrs. Cluppins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps I am, ma\xe2\x80\x99am. Perhaps I am,\xe2\x80\x99 sighed the first-floor lodger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For lone people as have got nobody to care for them, or take care of\r\nthem, or as have been hurt in their mind, or that kind of thing,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nobserved Mr. Raddle, plucking up a little cheerfulness, and looking\r\nround, \xe2\x80\x98the country is all very well. The country for a wounded spirit,\r\nthey say.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNow, of all things in the world that the unfortunate man could have\r\nsaid, any would have been preferable to this. Of course Mrs. Bardell\r\nburst into tears, and requested to be led from the table instantly; upon\r\nwhich the affectionate child began to cry too, most dismally.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Would anybody believe, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mrs. Raddle, turning fiercely\r\nto the first-floor lodger, \xe2\x80\x98that a woman could be married to such a\r\nunmanly creetur, which can tamper with a woman\xe2\x80\x99s feelings as he does,\r\nevery hour in the day, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear,\xe2\x80\x99 remonstrated Mr. Raddle, \xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean anything, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean!\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mrs. Raddle, with great scorn and contempt.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Go away. I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear the sight on you, you brute.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You must not flurry yourself, Mary Ann,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mrs. Cluppins. \xe2\x80\x98You\r\nreally must consider yourself, my dear, which you never do. Now go away,\r\nRaddle, there\xe2\x80\x99s a good soul, or you\xe2\x80\x99ll only aggravate her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You had better take your tea by yourself, Sir, indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs.\r\nRogers, again applying the smelling-bottle.\r\n\r\nMrs. Sanders, who, according to custom, was very busy with the bread-\r\nand-butter, expressed the same opinion, and Mr. Raddle quietly retired.\r\n\r\nAfter this, there was a great hoisting up of Master Bardell, who was\r\nrather a large size for hugging, into his mother\xe2\x80\x99s arms, in which\r\noperation he got his boots in the tea-board, and occasioned some\r\nconfusion among the cups and saucers. But that description of fainting\r\nfits, which is contagious among ladies, seldom lasts long; so when he\r\nhad been well kissed, and a little cried over, Mrs. Bardell recovered,\r\nset him down again, wondering how she could have been so foolish, and\r\npoured out some more tea.\r\n\r\nIt was at this moment, that the sound of approaching wheels was heard,\r\nand that the ladies, looking up, saw a hackney-coach stop at the garden\r\ngate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98More company!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Sanders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a gentleman,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Raddle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, if it ain\xe2\x80\x99t Mr. Jackson, the young man from Dodson and Fogg\xe2\x80\x99s!\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncried Mrs. Bardell. \xe2\x80\x98Why, gracious! Surely Mr. Pickwick can\xe2\x80\x99t have paid\r\nthe damages.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Or hoffered marriage!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Cluppins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me, how slow the gentleman is,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mrs. Rogers. \xe2\x80\x98Why\r\ndoesn\xe2\x80\x99t he make haste!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs the lady spoke these words, Mr. Jackson turned from the coach where\r\nhe had been addressing some observations to a shabby man in black\r\nleggings, who had just emerged from the vehicle with a thick ash stick\r\nin his hand, and made his way to the place where the ladies were seated;\r\nwinding his hair round the brim of his hat, as he came along.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is anything the matter? Has anything taken place, Mr. Jackson?\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMrs. Bardell eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing whatever, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Jackson. \xe2\x80\x98How de do, ladies? I\r\nhave to ask pardon, ladies, for intruding--but the law, ladies--the\r\nlaw.\xe2\x80\x99 With this apology Mr. Jackson smiled, made a comprehensive bow,\r\nand gave his hair another wind. Mrs. Rogers whispered Mrs. Raddle that\r\nhe was really an elegant young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I called in Goswell Street,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Mr. Jackson, \xe2\x80\x98and hearing that you\r\nwere here, from the slavey, took a coach and came on. Our people want\r\nyou down in the city directly, Mrs. Bardell.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lor!\xe2\x80\x99 ejaculated that lady, starting at the sudden nature of the\r\ncommunication.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Jackson, biting his lip. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s very important and\r\npressing business, which can\xe2\x80\x99t be postponed on any account. Indeed,\r\nDodson expressly said so to me, and so did Fogg. I\xe2\x80\x99ve kept the coach on\r\npurpose for you to go back in.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How very strange!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mrs. Bardell.\r\n\r\nThe ladies agreed that it _was _ very strange, but were unanimously of\r\nopinion that it must be very important, or Dodson & Fogg would never\r\nhave sent; and further, that the business being urgent, she ought to\r\nrepair to Dodson & Fogg\xe2\x80\x99s without any delay.\r\n\r\nThere was a certain degree of pride and importance about being wanted by\r\none\xe2\x80\x99s lawyers in such a monstrous hurry, that was by no means\r\ndispleasing to Mrs. Bardell, especially as it might be reasonably\r\nsupposed to enhance her consequence in the eyes of the first-floor\r\nlodger. She simpered a little, affected extreme vexation and hesitation,\r\nand at last arrived at the conclusion that she supposed she must go.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But won\xe2\x80\x99t you refresh yourself after your walk, Mr. Jackson?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs.\r\nBardell persuasively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, really there ain\xe2\x80\x99t much time to lose,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jackson; \xe2\x80\x98and I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ngot a friend here,\xe2\x80\x99 he continued, looking towards the man with the ash\r\nstick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, ask your friend to come here, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell. \xe2\x80\x98Pray ask\r\nyour friend here, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, I\xe2\x80\x99d rather not,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Jackson, with some\r\nembarrassment of manner. \xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s not much used to ladies\xe2\x80\x99 society, and it\r\nmakes him bashful. If you\xe2\x80\x99ll order the waiter to deliver him anything\r\nshort, he won\xe2\x80\x99t drink it off at once, won\xe2\x80\x99t he!--only try him!\xe2\x80\x99 Mr.\r\nJackson\xe2\x80\x99s fingers wandered playfully round his nose at this portion of\r\nhis discourse, to warn his hearers that he was speaking ironically.\r\n\r\nThe waiter was at once despatched to the bashful gentleman, and the\r\nbashful gentleman took something; Mr. Jackson also took something, and\r\nthe ladies took something, for hospitality\xe2\x80\x99s sake. Mr. Jackson then said\r\nhe was afraid it was time to go; upon which, Mrs. Sanders, Mrs.\r\nCluppins, and Tommy (who it was arranged should accompany Mrs. Bardell,\r\nleaving the others to Mr. Raddle\xe2\x80\x99s protection), got into the coach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Isaac,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jackson, as Mrs. Bardell prepared to get in, looking up at\r\nthe man with the ash stick, who was seated on the box, smoking a cigar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is Mrs. Bardell.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I know\xe2\x80\x99d that long ago,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man.\r\n\r\nMrs. Bardell got in, Mr. Jackson got in after her, and away they drove.\r\nMrs. Bardell could not help ruminating on what Mr. Jackson\xe2\x80\x99s friend had\r\nsaid. Shrewd creatures, those lawyers. Lord bless us, how they find\r\npeople out!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sad thing about these costs of our people\xe2\x80\x99s, ain\xe2\x80\x99t it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jackson,\r\nwhen Mrs. Cluppins and Mrs. Sanders had fallen asleep; \xe2\x80\x98your bill of\r\ncosts, I mean.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m very sorry they can\xe2\x80\x99t get them,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs. Bardell. \xe2\x80\x98But if you\r\nlaw gentlemen do these things on speculation, why you must get a loss\r\nnow and then, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You gave them a _cognovit _for the amount of your costs, after the\r\ntrial, I\xe2\x80\x99m told!\xe2\x80\x99 said Jackson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. Just as a matter of form,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs. Bardell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jackson drily. \xe2\x80\x98Quite a matter of form. Quite.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOn they drove, and Mrs. Bardell fell asleep. She was awakened, after\r\nsome time, by the stopping of the coach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless us!\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady. \xe2\x80\x98Are we at Freeman\xe2\x80\x99s Court?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We\xe2\x80\x99re not going quite so far,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jackson. \xe2\x80\x98Have the goodness to\r\nstep out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs. Bardell, not yet thoroughly awake, complied. It was a curious\r\nplace: a large wall, with a gate in the middle, and a gas-light burning\r\ninside.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, ladies,\xe2\x80\x99 cried the man with the ash stick, looking into the coach,\r\nand shaking Mrs. Sanders to wake her, \xe2\x80\x98Come!\xe2\x80\x99 Rousing her friend, Mrs.\r\nSanders alighted. Mrs. Bardell, leaning on Jackson\xe2\x80\x99s arm, and leading\r\nTommy by the hand, had already entered the porch. They followed.\r\n\r\nThe room they turned into was even more odd-looking than the porch. Such\r\na number of men standing about! And they stared so!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What place is this?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mrs. Bardell, pausing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only one of our public offices,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jackson, hurrying her through\r\na door, and looking round to see that the other women were following.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look sharp, Isaac!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Safe and sound,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the man with the ash stick. The door swung\r\nheavily after them, and they descended a small flight of steps.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here we are at last. All right and tight, Mrs. Bardell!\xe2\x80\x99 said Jackson,\r\nlooking exultingly round.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Bardell, with a palpitating heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just this,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jackson, drawing her a little on one side; \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbe frightened, Mrs. Bardell. There never was a more delicate man than\r\nDodson, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, or a more humane man than Fogg. It was their duty in the\r\nway of business, to take you in execution for them costs; but they were\r\nanxious to spare your feelings as much as they could. What a comfort it\r\nmust be, to you, to think how it\xe2\x80\x99s been done! This is the Fleet, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\r\nWish you good-night, Mrs. Bardell. Good-night, Tommy!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Jackson hurried away in company with the man with the ash stick\r\nanother man, with a key in his hand, who had been looking on, led the\r\nbewildered female to a second short flight of steps leading to a\r\ndoorway. Mrs. Bardell screamed violently; Tommy roared; Mrs. Cluppins\r\nshrunk within herself; and Mrs. Sanders made off, without more ado. For\r\nthere stood the injured Mr. Pickwick, taking his nightly allowance of\r\nair; and beside him leant Samuel Weller, who, seeing Mrs. Bardell, took\r\nhis hat off with mock reverence, while his master turned indignantly on\r\nhis heel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t bother the woman,\xe2\x80\x99 said the turnkey to Weller; \xe2\x80\x98she\xe2\x80\x99s just come\r\nin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A prisoner!\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, quickly replacing his hat. \xe2\x80\x98Who\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nplaintives? What for? Speak up, old feller.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dodson and Fogg,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the man; \xe2\x80\x98execution on _cognovit _for costs.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here, Job, Job!\xe2\x80\x99 shouted Sam, dashing into the passage. \xe2\x80\x98Run to Mr.\r\nPerker\xe2\x80\x99s, Job. I want him directly. I see some good in this. Here\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\ngame. Hooray! vere\xe2\x80\x99s the gov\xe2\x80\x99nor?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut there was no reply to these inquiries, for Job had started furiously\r\noff, the instant he received his commission, and Mrs. Bardell had\r\nfainted in real downright earnest.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLVII. IS CHIEFLY DEVOTED TO MATTERS OF BUSINESS, AND THE\r\nTEMPORAL ADVANTAGE OF DODSON AND FOGG--MR. WINKLE REAPPEARS UNDER\r\nEXTRAORDINARY CIRCUMSTANCES--MR. PICKWICK\xe2\x80\x99S BENEVOLENCE PROVES STRONGER\r\nTHAN HIS OBSTINACY\r\n\r\nJob Trotter, abating nothing of his speed, ran up Holborn, sometimes in\r\nthe middle of the road, sometimes on the pavement, sometimes in the\r\ngutter, as the chances of getting along varied with the press of men,\r\nwomen, children, and coaches, in each division of the thoroughfare, and,\r\nregardless of all obstacles stopped not for an instant until he reached\r\nthe gate of Gray\xe2\x80\x99s Inn. Notwithstanding all the expedition he had used,\r\nhowever, the gate had been closed a good half-hour when he reached it,\r\nand by the time he had discovered Mr. Perker\xe2\x80\x99s laundress, who lived with\r\na married daughter, who had bestowed her hand upon a non-resident\r\nwaiter, who occupied the one-pair of some number in some street closely\r\nadjoining to some brewery somewhere behind Gray\xe2\x80\x99s Inn Lane, it was\r\nwithin fifteen minutes of closing the prison for the night. Mr. Lowten\r\nhad still to be ferreted out from the back parlour of the Magpie and\r\nStump; and Job had scarcely accomplished this object, and communicated\r\nSam Weller\xe2\x80\x99s message, when the clock struck ten.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lowten, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s too late now. You can\xe2\x80\x99t get in to-night;\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ve got the key of the street, my friend.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never mind me,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job. \xe2\x80\x98I can sleep anywhere. But won\xe2\x80\x99t it be\r\nbetter to see Mr. Perker to-night, so that we may be there, the first\r\nthing in the morning?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why,\xe2\x80\x99 responded Lowten, after a little consideration, \xe2\x80\x98if it was in\r\nanybody else\xe2\x80\x99s case, Perker wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be best pleased at my going up to\r\nhis house; but as it\xe2\x80\x99s Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s, I think I may venture to take a\r\ncab and charge it to the office.\xe2\x80\x99 Deciding on this line of conduct, Mr.\r\nLowten took up his hat, and begging the assembled company to appoint a\r\ndeputy-chairman during his temporary absence, led the way to the nearest\r\ncoach-stand. Summoning the cab of most promising appearance, he directed\r\nthe driver to repair to Montague Place, Russell Square.\r\n\r\nMr. Perker had had a dinner-party that day, as was testified by the\r\nappearance of lights in the drawing-room windows, the sound of an\r\nimproved grand piano, and an improvable cabinet voice issuing therefrom,\r\nand a rather overpowering smell of meat which pervaded the steps and\r\nentry. In fact, a couple of very good country agencies happening to come\r\nup to town, at the same time, an agreeable little party had been got\r\ntogether to meet them, comprising Mr. Snicks, the Life Office Secretary,\r\nMr. Prosee, the eminent counsel, three solicitors, one commissioner of\r\nbankrupts, a special pleader from the Temple, a small-eyed peremptory\r\nyoung gentleman, his pupil, who had written a lively book about the law\r\nof demises, with a vast quantity of marginal notes and references; and\r\nseveral other eminent and distinguished personages. From this society,\r\nlittle Mr. Perker detached himself, on his clerk being announced in a\r\nwhisper; and repairing to the dining-room, there found Mr. Lowten and\r\nJob Trotter looking very dim and shadowy by the light of a kitchen\r\ncandle, which the gentleman who condescended to appear in plush shorts\r\nand cottons for a quarterly stipend, had, with a becoming contempt for\r\nthe clerk and all things appertaining to \xe2\x80\x98the office,\xe2\x80\x99 placed upon the\r\ntable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Lowten,\xe2\x80\x99 said little Mr. Perker, shutting the door, \xe2\x80\x98what\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nmatter? No important letter come in a parcel, is there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Lowten. \xe2\x80\x98This is a messenger from Mr. Pickwick, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98From Pickwick, eh?\xe2\x80\x99 said the little man, turning quickly to Job. \xe2\x80\x98Well,\r\nwhat is it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dodson and Fogg have taken Mrs. Bardell in execution for her costs,\r\nSir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Perker, putting his hands in his pockets, and reclining\r\nagainst the sideboard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job. \xe2\x80\x98It seems they got a cognovit out of her, for the\r\namount of \xe2\x80\x98em, directly after the trial.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By Jove!\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker, taking both hands out of his pockets, and\r\nstriking the knuckles of his right against the palm of his left,\r\nemphatically, \xe2\x80\x98those are the cleverest scamps I ever had anything to do\r\nwith!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The sharpest practitioners I ever knew, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Lowten.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sharp!\xe2\x80\x99 echoed Perker. \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s no knowing where to have them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very true, Sir, there is not,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Lowten; and then, both master\r\nand man pondered for a few seconds, with animated countenances, as if\r\nthey were reflecting upon one of the most beautiful and ingenious\r\ndiscoveries that the intellect of man had ever made. When they had in\r\nsome measure recovered from their trance of admiration, Job Trotter\r\ndischarged himself of the rest of his commission. Perker nodded his head\r\nthoughtfully, and pulled out his watch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At ten precisely, I will be there,\xe2\x80\x99 said the little man. \xe2\x80\x98Sam is quite\r\nright. Tell him so. Will you take a glass of wine, Lowten?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNo, thank you, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You mean yes, I think,\xe2\x80\x99 said the little man, turning to the sideboard\r\nfor a decanter and glasses.\r\n\r\nAs Lowten _did _mean yes, he said no more on the subject, but inquired\r\nof Job, in an audible whisper, whether the portrait of Perker, which\r\nhung opposite the fireplace, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a wonderful likeness, to which Job\r\nof course replied that it was. The wine being by this time poured out,\r\nLowten drank to Mrs. Perker and the children, and Job to Perker. The\r\ngentleman in the plush shorts and cottons considering it no part of his\r\nduty to show the people from the office out, consistently declined to\r\nanswer the bell, and they showed themselves out. The attorney betook\r\nhimself to his drawing-room, the clerk to the Magpie and Stump, and Job\r\nto Covent Garden Market to spend the night in a vegetable basket.\r\n\r\nPunctually at the appointed hour next morning, the good-humoured little\r\nattorney tapped at Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s door, which was opened with great\r\nalacrity by Sam Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Perker, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, announcing the visitor to Mr. Pickwick, who\r\nwas sitting at the window in a thoughtful attitude. \xe2\x80\x98Wery glad you\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nlooked in accidentally, Sir. I rather think the gov\xe2\x80\x99nor wants to have a\r\nword and a half with you, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPerker bestowed a look of intelligence on Sam, intimating that he\r\nunderstood he was not to say he had been sent for; and beckoning him to\r\napproach, whispered briefly in his ear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t mean that \xe2\x80\x98ere, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, starting back in excessive\r\nsurprise.\r\n\r\nPerker nodded and smiled.\r\n\r\nMr. Samuel Weller looked at the little lawyer, then at Mr. Pickwick,\r\nthen at the ceiling, then at Perker again; grinned, laughed outright,\r\nand finally, catching up his hat from the carpet, without further\r\nexplanation, disappeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What does this mean?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick, looking at Perker with\r\nastonishment. \xe2\x80\x98What has put Sam into this extraordinary state?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, nothing, nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Perker. \xe2\x80\x98Come, my dear Sir, draw up your\r\nchair to the table. I have a good deal to say to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What papers are those?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick, as the little man\r\ndeposited on the table a small bundle of documents tied with red tape.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The papers in Bardell and Pickwick,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Perker, undoing the knot\r\nwith his teeth.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick grated the legs of his chair against the ground; and\r\nthrowing himself into it, folded his hands and looked sternly--if Mr.\r\nPickwick ever could look sternly--at his legal friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t like to hear the name of the cause?\xe2\x80\x99 said the little man,\r\nstill busying himself with the knot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I do not indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sorry for that,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Perker, \xe2\x80\x98because it will form the subject of\r\nour conversation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I would rather that the subject should be never mentioned between us,\r\nPerker,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Pickwick hastily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pooh, pooh, my dear Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the little man, untying the bundle, and\r\nglancing eagerly at Mr. Pickwick out of the corners of his eyes. \xe2\x80\x98It\r\nmust be mentioned. I have come here on purpose. Now, are you ready to\r\nhear what I have to say, my dear Sir? No hurry; if you are not, I can\r\nwait. I have this morning\xe2\x80\x99s paper here. Your time shall be mine. There!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nHereupon, the little man threw one leg over the other, and made a show\r\nof beginning to read with great composure and application.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with a sigh, but softening into a smile\r\nat the same time. \xe2\x80\x98Say what you have to say; it\xe2\x80\x99s the old story, I\r\nsuppose?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With a difference, my dear Sir; with a difference,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Perker,\r\ndeliberately folding up the paper and putting it into his pocket again.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Bardell, the plaintiff in the action, is within these walls, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know it,\xe2\x80\x99 was Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Perker. \xe2\x80\x98And you know how she comes here, I\r\nsuppose; I mean on what grounds, and at whose suit?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; at least I have heard Sam\xe2\x80\x99s account of the matter,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nPickwick, with affected carelessness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam\xe2\x80\x99s account of the matter,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Perker, \xe2\x80\x98is, I will venture to\r\nsay, a perfectly correct one. Well now, my dear Sir, the first question\r\nI have to ask, is, whether this woman is to remain here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To remain here!\xe2\x80\x99 echoed Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To remain here, my dear Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Perker, leaning back in his\r\nchair and looking steadily at his client.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How can you ask me?\xe2\x80\x99 said that gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98It rests with Dodson and\r\nFogg; you know that very well.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know nothing of the kind,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Perker firmly. \xe2\x80\x98It does _not\r\n_rest with Dodson and Fogg; you know the men, my dear Sir, as well as I\r\ndo. It rests solely, wholly, and entirely with you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With me!\xe2\x80\x99 ejaculated Mr. Pickwick, rising nervously from his chair, and\r\nreseating himself directly afterwards.\r\n\r\nThe little man gave a double-knock on the lid of his snuff-box, opened\r\nit, took a great pinch, shut it up again, and repeated the words, \xe2\x80\x98With\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say, my dear Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed the little man, who seemed to gather\r\nconfidence from the snuff--\xe2\x80\x98I say, that her speedy liberation or\r\nperpetual imprisonment rests with you, and with you alone. Hear me out,\r\nmy dear Sir, if you please, and do not be so very energetic, for it will\r\nonly put you into a perspiration and do no good whatever. I say,\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncontinued Perker, checking off each position on a different finger, as\r\nhe laid it down--\xe2\x80\x98I say that nobody but you can rescue her from this den\r\nof wretchedness; and that you can only do that, by paying the costs of\r\nthis suit--both of plaintive and defendant--into the hands of these\r\nFreeman Court sharks. Now pray be quiet, my dear sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick, whose face had been undergoing most surprising changes\r\nduring this speech, and was evidently on the verge of a strong burst of\r\nindignation, calmed his wrath as well as he could. Perker, strengthening\r\nhis argumentative powers with another pinch of snuff, proceeded--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have seen the woman, this morning. By paying the costs, you can\r\nobtain a full release and discharge from the damages; and further--this\r\nI know is a far greater object of consideration with you, my dear sir--a\r\nvoluntary statement, under her hand, in the form of a letter to me, that\r\nthis business was, from the very first, fomented, and encouraged, and\r\nbrought about, by these men, Dodson and Fogg; that she deeply regrets\r\never having been the instrument of annoyance or injury to you; and that\r\nshe entreats me to intercede with you, and implore your pardon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I pay her costs for her,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick indignantly. \xe2\x80\x98A valuable\r\ndocument, indeed!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No \xe2\x80\x9cif\xe2\x80\x9d in the case, my dear Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker triumphantly. \xe2\x80\x98There is\r\nthe very letter I speak of. Brought to my office by another woman at\r\nnine o\xe2\x80\x99clock this morning, before I had set foot in this place, or held\r\nany communication with Mrs. Bardell, upon my honour.\xe2\x80\x99 Selecting the\r\nletter from the bundle, the little lawyer laid it at Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nelbow, and took snuff for two consecutive minutes, without winking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is this all you have to say to me?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick mildly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not quite,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Perker. \xe2\x80\x98I cannot undertake to say, at this moment,\r\nwhether the wording of the cognovit, the nature of the ostensible\r\nconsideration, and the proof we can get together about the whole conduct\r\nof the suit, will be sufficient to justify an indictment for conspiracy.\r\nI fear not, my dear Sir; they are too clever for that, I doubt. I do\r\nmean to say, however, that the whole facts, taken together, will be\r\nsufficient to justify you, in the minds of all reasonable men. And now,\r\nmy dear Sir, I put it to you. This one hundred and fifty pounds, or\r\nwhatever it may be--take it in round numbers--is nothing to you. A jury\r\nhad decided against you; well, their verdict is wrong, but still they\r\ndecided as they thought right, and it _is_ against you. You have now an\r\nopportunity, on easy terms, of placing yourself in a much higher\r\nposition than you ever could, by remaining here; which would only be\r\nimputed, by people who didn\xe2\x80\x99t know you, to sheer dogged, wrongheaded,\r\nbrutal obstinacy; nothing else, my dear Sir, believe me. Can you\r\nhesitate to avail yourself of it, when it restores you to your friends,\r\nyour old pursuits, your health and amusements; when it liberates your\r\nfaithful and attached servant, whom you otherwise doom to imprisonment\r\nfor the whole of your life; and above all, when it enables you to take\r\nthe very magnanimous revenge--which I know, my dear sir, is one after\r\nyour own heart--of releasing this woman from a scene of misery and\r\ndebauchery, to which no man should ever be consigned, if I had my will,\r\nbut the infliction of which on any woman, is even more frightful and\r\nbarbarous. Now I ask you, my dear sir, not only as your legal adviser,\r\nbut as your very true friend, will you let slip the occasion of\r\nattaining all these objects, and doing all this good, for the paltry\r\nconsideration of a few pounds finding their way into the pockets of a\r\ncouple of rascals, to whom it makes no manner of difference, except that\r\nthe more they gain, the more they\xe2\x80\x99ll seek, and so the sooner be led into\r\nsome piece of knavery that must end in a crash? I have put these\r\nconsiderations to you, my dear Sir, very feebly and imperfectly, but I\r\nask you to think of them. Turn them over in your mind as long as you\r\nplease. I wait here most patiently for your answer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\nBefore Mr. Pickwick could reply, before Mr. Perker had taken one\r\ntwentieth part of the snuff with which so unusually long an address\r\nimperatively required to be followed up, there was a low murmuring of\r\nvoices outside, and then a hesitating knock at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear, dear,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick, who had been evidently roused by\r\nhis friend\xe2\x80\x99s appeal; \xe2\x80\x98what an annoyance that door is! Who is that?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Me, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam Weller, putting in his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t speak to you just now, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98I am engaged\r\nat this moment, Sam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Beg your pardon, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98But here\xe2\x80\x99s a lady here,\r\nSir, as says she\xe2\x80\x99s somethin\xe2\x80\x99 wery partickler to disclose.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t see any lady,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, whose mind was filled with\r\nvisions of Mrs. Bardell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t make too sure o\xe2\x80\x99 that, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 urged Mr. Weller, shaking his\r\nhead. \xe2\x80\x98If you know\xe2\x80\x99d who was near, sir, I rayther think you\xe2\x80\x99d change\r\nyour note; as the hawk remarked to himself vith a cheerful laugh, ven he\r\nheerd the robin-redbreast a-singin\xe2\x80\x99 round the corner.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who is it?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you see her, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr. Weller, holding the door in his hand\r\nas if he had some curious live animal on the other side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose I must,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, looking at Perker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well then, all in to begin!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Sound the gong, draw up the\r\ncurtain, and enter the two conspiraytors.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Sam Weller spoke, he threw the door open, and there rushed\r\ntumultuously into the room, Mr. Nathaniel Winkle, leading after him by\r\nthe hand, the identical young lady who at Dingley Dell had worn the\r\nboots with the fur round the tops, and who, now a very pleasing compound\r\nof blushes and confusion, and lilac silk, and a smart bonnet, and a rich\r\nlace veil, looked prettier than ever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Miss Arabella Allen!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick, rising from his chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Winkle, dropping on his knees. \xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Winkle. Pardon,\r\nmy dear friend, pardon!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick could scarcely believe the evidence of his senses, and\r\nperhaps would not have done so, but for the corroborative testimony\r\nafforded by the smiling countenance of Perker, and the bodily presence,\r\nin the background, of Sam and the pretty housemaid; who appeared to\r\ncontemplate the proceedings with the liveliest satisfaction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Mr. Pickwick!\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella, in a low voice, as if alarmed at the\r\nsilence. \xe2\x80\x98Can you forgive my imprudence?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick returned no verbal response to this appeal; but he took off\r\nhis spectacles in great haste, and seizing both the young lady\xe2\x80\x99s hands\r\nin his, kissed her a great number of times--perhaps a greater number\r\nthan was absolutely necessary--and then, still retaining one of her\r\nhands, told Mr. Winkle he was an audacious young dog, and bade him get\r\nup. This, Mr. Winkle, who had been for some seconds scratching his nose\r\nwith the brim of his hat, in a penitent manner, did; whereupon Mr.\r\nPickwick slapped him on the back several times, and then shook hands\r\nheartily with Perker, who, not to be behind-hand in the compliments of\r\nthe occasion, saluted both the bride and the pretty housemaid with right\r\ngood-will, and, having wrung Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s hand most cordially, wound up\r\nhis demonstrations of joy by taking snuff enough to set any half-dozen\r\nmen with ordinarily-constructed noses, a-sneezing for life.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, my dear girl,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98how has all this come about?\r\nCome! Sit down, and let me hear it all. How well she looks, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t she,\r\nPerker?\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr. Pickwick, surveying Arabella\xe2\x80\x99s face with a look of as\r\nmuch pride and exultation, as if she had been his daughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Delightful, my dear Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the little man. \xe2\x80\x98If I were not a\r\nmarried man myself, I should be disposed to envy you, you dog.\xe2\x80\x99 Thus\r\nexpressing himself, the little lawyer gave Mr. Winkle a poke in the\r\nchest, which that gentleman reciprocated; after which they both laughed\r\nvery loudly, but not so loudly as Mr. Samuel Weller, who had just\r\nrelieved his feelings by kissing the pretty housemaid under cover of the\r\ncupboard door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can never be grateful enough to you, Sam, I am sure,\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella,\r\nwith the sweetest smile imaginable. \xe2\x80\x98I shall not forget your exertions\r\nin the garden at Clifton.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t say nothin\xe2\x80\x99 wotever about it, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98I only\r\nassisted natur, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; as the doctor said to the boy\xe2\x80\x99s mother, after\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99d bled him to death.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mary, my dear, sit down,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, cutting short these\r\ncompliments. \xe2\x80\x98Now then; how long have you been married, eh?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nArabella looked bashfully at her lord and master, who replied, \xe2\x80\x98Only\r\nthree days.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only three days, eh?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Why, what have you been doing\r\nthese three months?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, to be sure!\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Perker; \xe2\x80\x98come, account for this idleness.\r\nYou see Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s only astonishment is, that it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t all over,\r\nmonths ago.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why the fact is,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Winkle, looking at his blushing young\r\nwife, \xe2\x80\x98that I could not persuade Bella to run away, for a long time. And\r\nwhen I had persuaded her, it was a long time more before we could find\r\nan opportunity. Mary had to give a month\xe2\x80\x99s warning, too, before she\r\ncould leave her place next door, and we couldn\xe2\x80\x99t possibly have done it\r\nwithout her assistance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nUpon my word,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick, who by this time had resumed his\r\nspectacles, and was looking from Arabella to Winkle, and from Winkle to\r\nArabella, with as much delight depicted in his countenance as\r\nwarmheartedness and kindly feeling can communicate to the human face--\r\n\xe2\x80\x98upon my word! you seem to have been very systematic in your\r\nproceedings. And is your brother acquainted with all this, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, no, no,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Arabella, changing colour. \xe2\x80\x98Dear Mr. Pickwick, he\r\nmust only know it from you--from your lips alone. He is so violent, so\r\nprejudiced, and has been so--so anxious in behalf of his friend, Mr.\r\nSawyer,\xe2\x80\x99 added Arabella, looking down, \xe2\x80\x98that I fear the consequences\r\ndreadfully.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, to be sure,\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker gravely. \xe2\x80\x98You must take this matter in\r\nhand for them, my dear sir. These young men will respect you, when they\r\nwould listen to nobody else. You must prevent mischief, my dear Sir. Hot\r\nblood, hot blood.\xe2\x80\x99 And the little man took a warning pinch, and shook\r\nhis head doubtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You forget, my love,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick gently, \xe2\x80\x98you forget that I am a\r\nprisoner.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, indeed I do not, my dear Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Arabella. \xe2\x80\x98I never have\r\nforgotten it. I have never ceased to think how great your sufferings\r\nmust have been in this shocking place. But I hoped that what no\r\nconsideration for yourself would induce you to do, a regard to our\r\nhappiness might. If my brother hears of this, first, from you, I feel\r\ncertain we shall be reconciled. He is my only relation in the world, Mr.\r\nPickwick, and unless you plead for me, I fear I have lost even him. I\r\nhave done wrong, very, very wrong, I know.\xe2\x80\x99 Here poor Arabella hid her\r\nface in her handkerchief, and wept bitterly.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s nature was a good deal worked upon, by these same tears;\r\nbut when Mrs. Winkle, drying her eyes, took to coaxing and entreating in\r\nthe sweetest tones of a very sweet voice, he became particularly\r\nrestless, and evidently undecided how to act, as was evinced by sundry\r\nnervous rubbings of his spectacle-glasses, nose, tights, head, and\r\ngaiters.\r\n\r\nTaking advantage of these symptoms of indecision, Mr. Perker (to whom,\r\nit appeared, the young couple had driven straight that morning) urged\r\nwith legal point and shrewdness that Mr. Winkle, senior, was still\r\nunacquainted with the important rise in life\xe2\x80\x99s flight of steps which his\r\nson had taken; that the future expectations of the said son depended\r\nentirely upon the said Winkle, senior, continuing to regard him with\r\nundiminished feelings of affection and attachment, which it was very\r\nunlikely he would, if this great event were long kept a secret from him;\r\nthat Mr. Pickwick, repairing to Bristol to seek Mr. Allen, might, with\r\nequal reason, repair to Birmingham to seek Mr. Winkle, senior; lastly,\r\nthat Mr. Winkle, senior, had good right and title to consider Mr.\r\nPickwick as in some degree the guardian and adviser of his son, and that\r\nit consequently behoved that gentleman, and was indeed due to his\r\npersonal character, to acquaint the aforesaid Winkle, senior,\r\npersonally, and by word of mouth, with the whole circumstances of the\r\ncase, and with the share he had taken in the transaction.\r\n\r\nMr. Tupman and Mr. Snodgrass arrived, most opportunely, in this stage of\r\nthe pleadings, and as it was necessary to explain to them all that had\r\noccurred, together with the various reasons pro and con, the whole of\r\nthe arguments were gone over again, after which everybody urged every\r\nargument in his own way, and at his own length. And, at last, Mr.\r\nPickwick, fairly argued and remonstrated out of all his resolutions, and\r\nbeing in imminent danger of being argued and remonstrated out of his\r\nwits, caught Arabella in his arms, and declaring that she was a very\r\namiable creature, and that he didn\xe2\x80\x99t know how it was, but he had always\r\nbeen very fond of her from the first, said he could never find it in his\r\nheart to stand in the way of young people\xe2\x80\x99s happiness, and they might do\r\nwith him as they pleased.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s first act, on hearing this concession, was to despatch Job\r\nTrotter to the illustrious Mr. Pell, with an authority to deliver to the\r\nbearer the formal discharge which his prudent parent had had the\r\nforesight to leave in the hands of that learned gentleman, in case it\r\nshould be, at any time, required on an emergency; his next proceeding\r\nwas, to invest his whole stock of ready-money in the purchase of five-\r\nand-twenty gallons of mild porter, which he himself dispensed on the\r\nracket-ground to everybody who would partake of it; this done, he\r\nhurra\xe2\x80\x99d in divers parts of the building until he lost his voice, and\r\nthen quietly relapsed into his usual collected and philosophical\r\ncondition.\r\n\r\nAt three o\xe2\x80\x99clock that afternoon, Mr. Pickwick took a last look at his\r\nlittle room, and made his way, as well as he could, through the throng\r\nof debtors who pressed eagerly forward to shake him by the hand, until\r\nhe reached the lodge steps. He turned here, to look about him, and his\r\neye lightened as he did so. In all the crowd of wan, emaciated faces, he\r\nsaw not one which was not happier for his sympathy and charity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perker,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, beckoning one young man towards him, \xe2\x80\x98this\r\nis Mr. Jingle, whom I spoke to you about.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good, my dear Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Perker, looking hard at Jingle. \xe2\x80\x98You\r\nwill see me again, young man, to-morrow. I hope you may live to remember\r\nand feel deeply, what I shall have to communicate, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJingle bowed respectfully, trembled very much as he took Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nproffered hand, and withdrew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Job you know, I think?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, presenting that gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know the rascal,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Perker good-humouredly. \xe2\x80\x98See after your\r\nfriend, and be in the way to-morrow at one. Do you hear? Now, is there\r\nanything more?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98You have delivered the little parcel\r\nI gave you for your old landlord, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98He bust out a-cryin\xe2\x80\x99, Sir, and said you wos\r\nwery gen\xe2\x80\x99rous and thoughtful, and he only wished you could have him\r\ninnockilated for a gallopin\xe2\x80\x99 consumption, for his old friend as had\r\nlived here so long wos dead, and he\xe2\x80\x99d noweres to look for another.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPoor fellow, poor fellow!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98God bless you, my\r\nfriends!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Mr. Pickwick uttered this adieu, the crowd raised a loud shout. Many\r\namong them were pressing forward to shake him by the hand again, when he\r\ndrew his arm through Perker\xe2\x80\x99s, and hurried from the prison, far more sad\r\nand melancholy, for the moment, than when he had first entered it. Alas!\r\nhow many sad and unhappy beings had he left behind!\r\n\r\nA happy evening was that for at least one party in the George and\r\nVulture; and light and cheerful were two of the hearts that emerged from\r\nits hospitable door next morning. The owners thereof were Mr. Pickwick\r\nand Sam Weller, the former of whom was speedily deposited inside a\r\ncomfortable post-coach, with a little dickey behind, in which the latter\r\nmounted with great agility.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 called out Mr. Weller to his master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, thrusting his head out of the window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish them horses had been three months and better in the Fleet, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, Sam?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wy, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Weller, rubbing his hands, \xe2\x80\x98how they would go\r\nif they had been!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLVIII. RELATES HOW MR. PICKWICK, WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF SAMUEL\r\nWELLER, ESSAYED TO SOFTEN THE HEART OF MR. BENJAMIN ALLEN, AND TO\r\nMOLLIFY THE WRATH OF MR. ROBERT SAWYER\r\n\r\nMr. Ben Allen and Mr. Bob Sawyer sat together in the little surgery\r\nbehind the shop, discussing minced veal and future prospects, when the\r\ndiscourse, not unnaturally, turned upon the practice acquired by Bob the\r\naforesaid, and his present chances of deriving a competent independence\r\nfrom the honourable profession to which he had devoted himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which, I think,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Mr. Bob Sawyer, pursuing the thread of the\r\nsubject--\xe2\x80\x98which, I think, Ben, are rather dubious.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s rather dubious?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Ben Allen, at the same time\r\nsharpening his intellect with a draught of beer. \xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s dubious?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, the chances,\xe2\x80\x99 responded Mr. Bob Sawyer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I forgot,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Ben Allen. \xe2\x80\x98The beer has reminded me that I forgot,\r\nBob--yes; they _are _dubious.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s wonderful how the poor people patronise me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Bob Sawyer\r\nreflectively. \xe2\x80\x98They knock me up, at all hours of the night; they take\r\nmedicine to an extent which I should have conceived impossible; they put\r\non blisters and leeches with a perseverance worthy of a better cause;\r\nthey make additions to their families, in a manner which is quite awful.\r\nSix of those last-named little promissory notes, all due on the same\r\nday, Ben, and all intrusted to me!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s very gratifying, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Ben Allen, holding his plate\r\nfor some more minced veal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, very,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Bob; \xe2\x80\x98only not quite so much so as the confidence of\r\npatients with a shilling or two to spare would be. This business was\r\ncapitally described in the advertisement, Ben. It is a practice, a very\r\nextensive practice--and that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bob,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Ben Allen, laying down his knife and fork, and fixing\r\nhis eyes on the visage of his friend, \xe2\x80\x98Bob, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what it is.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is it?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Bob Sawyer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You must make yourself, with as little delay as possible, master of\r\nArabella\xe2\x80\x99s one thousand pounds.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Three per cent. consolidated bank annuities, now standing in her name\r\nin the book or books of the governor and company of the Bank of\r\nEngland,\xe2\x80\x99 added Bob Sawyer, in legal phraseology.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Exactly so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Ben. \xe2\x80\x98She has it when she comes of age, or marries.\r\nShe wants a year of coming of age, and if you plucked up a spirit she\r\nneedn\xe2\x80\x99t want a month of being married.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She\xe2\x80\x99s a very charming and delightful creature,\xe2\x80\x99 quoth Mr. Robert\r\nSawyer, in reply; \xe2\x80\x98and has only one fault that I know of, Ben. It\r\nhappens, unfortunately, that that single blemish is a want of taste. She\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t like me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s my opinion that she don\xe2\x80\x99t know what she does like,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Ben\r\nAllen contemptuously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps not,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Mr. Bob Sawyer. \xe2\x80\x98But it\xe2\x80\x99s my opinion that she\r\ndoes know what she doesn\xe2\x80\x99t like, and that\xe2\x80\x99s of more importance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Ben Allen, setting his teeth together, and speaking\r\nmore like a savage warrior who fed on raw wolf\xe2\x80\x99s flesh which he carved\r\nwith his fingers, than a peaceable young gentleman who ate minced veal\r\nwith a knife and fork--\xe2\x80\x98I wish I knew whether any rascal really has been\r\ntampering with her, and attempting to engage her affections. I think I\r\nshould assassinate him, Bob.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99d put a bullet in him, if I found him out,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Sawyer, stopping\r\nin the course of a long draught of beer, and looking malignantly out of\r\nthe porter pot. \xe2\x80\x98If that didn\xe2\x80\x99t do his business, I\xe2\x80\x99d extract it\r\nafterwards, and kill him that way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Benjamin Allen gazed abstractedly on his friend for some minutes in\r\nsilence, and then said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have never proposed to her, point-blank, Bob?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. Because I saw it would be of no use,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Robert Sawyer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You shall do it, before you are twenty-four hours older,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Ben,\r\nwith desperate calmness. \xe2\x80\x98She shall have you, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll know the reason\r\nwhy. I\xe2\x80\x99ll exert my authority.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Bob Sawyer, \xe2\x80\x98we shall see.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We shall see, my friend,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Ben Allen fiercely. He paused for\r\na few seconds, and added in a voice broken by emotion, \xe2\x80\x98You have loved\r\nher from a child, my friend. You loved her when we were boys at school\r\ntogether, and, even then, she was wayward and slighted your young\r\nfeelings. Do you recollect, with all the eagerness of a child\xe2\x80\x99s love,\r\none day pressing upon her acceptance, two small caraway-seed biscuits\r\nand one sweet apple, neatly folded into a circular parcel with the leaf\r\nof a copy-book?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I do,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Bob Sawyer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She slighted that, I think?\xe2\x80\x99 said Ben Allen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She did,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Bob. \xe2\x80\x98She said I had kept the parcel so long in the\r\npockets of my corduroys, that the apple was unpleasantly warm.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I remember,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Allen gloomily. \xe2\x80\x98Upon which we ate it ourselves,\r\nin alternate bites.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBob Sawyer intimated his recollection of the circumstance last alluded\r\nto, by a melancholy frown; and the two friends remained for some time\r\nabsorbed, each in his own meditations.\r\n\r\nWhile these observations were being exchanged between Mr. Bob Sawyer and\r\nMr. Benjamin Allen; and while the boy in the gray livery, marvelling at\r\nthe unwonted prolongation of the dinner, cast an anxious look, from time\r\nto time, towards the glass door, distracted by inward misgivings\r\nregarding the amount of minced veal which would be ultimately reserved\r\nfor his individual cravings; there rolled soberly on through the streets\r\nof Bristol, a private fly, painted of a sad green colour, drawn by a\r\nchubby sort of brown horse, and driven by a surly-looking man with his\r\nlegs dressed like the legs of a groom, and his body attired in the coat\r\nof a coachman. Such appearances are common to many vehicles belonging\r\nto, and maintained by, old ladies of economic habits; and in this\r\nvehicle sat an old lady who was its mistress and proprietor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Martin!\xe2\x80\x99 said the old lady, calling to the surly man, out of the front\r\nwindow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99 said the surly man, touching his hat to the old lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Sawyer\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was going there,\xe2\x80\x99 said the surly man.\r\n\r\nThe old lady nodded the satisfaction which this proof of the surly man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nforesight imparted to her feelings; and the surly man giving a smart\r\nlash to the chubby horse, they all repaired to Mr. Bob Sawyer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntogether.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Martin!\xe2\x80\x99 said the old lady, when the fly stopped at the door of Mr.\r\nRobert Sawyer, late Nockemorf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99 said Martin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ask the lad to step out, and mind the horse.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m going to mind the horse myself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Martin, laying his whip on\r\nthe roof of the fly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t permit it, on any account,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old lady; \xe2\x80\x98your testimony\r\nwill be very important, and I must take you into the house with me. You\r\nmust not stir from my side during the whole interview. Do you hear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hear,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Martin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well; what are you stopping for?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Martin. So saying, the surly man leisurely descended\r\nfrom the wheel, on which he had been poising himself on the tops of the\r\ntoes of his right foot, and having summoned the boy in the gray livery,\r\nopened the coach door, flung down the steps, and thrusting in a hand\r\nenveloped in a dark wash-leather glove, pulled out the old lady with as\r\nmuch unconcern in his manner as if she were a bandbox.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed the old lady. \xe2\x80\x98I am so flurried, now I have got\r\nhere, Martin, that I\xe2\x80\x99m all in a tremble.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Martin coughed behind the dark wash-leather gloves, but expressed no\r\nsympathy; so the old lady, composing herself, trotted up Mr. Bob\r\nSawyer\xe2\x80\x99s steps, and Mr. Martin followed. Immediately on the old lady\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nentering the shop, Mr. Benjamin Allen and Mr. Bob Sawyer, who had been\r\nputting the spirits-and-water out of sight, and upsetting nauseous drugs\r\nto take off the smell of the tobacco smoke, issued hastily forth in a\r\ntransport of pleasure and affection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear aunt,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Ben Allen, \xe2\x80\x98how kind of you to look in\r\nupon us! Mr. Sawyer, aunt; my friend Mr. Bob Sawyer whom I have spoken\r\nto you about, regarding--you know, aunt.\xe2\x80\x99 And here Mr. Ben Allen, who\r\nwas not at the moment extraordinarily sober, added the word \xe2\x80\x98Arabella,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nin what was meant to be a whisper, but which was an especially audible\r\nand distinct tone of speech which nobody could avoid hearing, if anybody\r\nwere so disposed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear Benjamin,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old lady, struggling with a great shortness\r\nof breath, and trembling from head to foot, \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t be alarmed, my dear,\r\nbut I think I had better speak to Mr. Sawyer, alone, for a moment. Only\r\nfor one moment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bob,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Allen, \xe2\x80\x98will you take my aunt into the surgery?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly,\xe2\x80\x99 responded Bob, in a most professional voice. \xe2\x80\x98Step this\r\nway, my dear ma\xe2\x80\x99am. Don\xe2\x80\x99t be frightened, ma\xe2\x80\x99am. We shall be able to set\r\nyou to rights in a very short time, I have no doubt, ma\xe2\x80\x99am. Here, my\r\ndear ma\xe2\x80\x99am. Now then!\xe2\x80\x99 With this, Mr. Bob Sawyer having handed the old\r\nlady to a chair, shut the door, drew another chair close to her, and\r\nwaited to hear detailed the symptoms of some disorder from which he saw\r\nin perspective a long train of profits and advantages.\r\n\r\nThe first thing the old lady did, was to shake her head a great many\r\ntimes, and began to cry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nervous,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob Sawyer complacently. \xe2\x80\x98Camphor-julep and water three\r\ntimes a day, and composing draught at night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how to begin, Mr. Sawyer,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old lady. \xe2\x80\x98It is so\r\nvery painful and distressing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You need not begin, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Bob Sawyer. \xe2\x80\x98I can anticipate\r\nall you would say. The head is in fault.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should be very sorry to think it was the heart,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old lady,\r\nwith a slight groan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not the slightest danger of that, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Bob Sawyer. \xe2\x80\x98The\r\nstomach is the primary cause.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Sawyer!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed the old lady, starting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not the least doubt of it, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Bob, looking wondrous wise.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Medicine, in time, my dear ma\xe2\x80\x99am, would have prevented it all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Sawyer,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old lady, more flurried than before, \xe2\x80\x98this\r\nconduct is either great impertinence to one in my situation, Sir, or it\r\narises from your not understanding the object of my visit. If it had\r\nbeen in the power of medicine, or any foresight I could have used, to\r\nprevent what has occurred, I should certainly have done so. I had better\r\nsee my nephew at once,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old lady, twirling her reticule\r\nindignantly, and rising as she spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop a moment, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob Sawyer; \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid I have not\r\nunderstood you. What _is_ the matter, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My niece, Mr. Sawyer,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old lady: \xe2\x80\x98your friend\xe2\x80\x99s sister.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob, all impatience; for the old lady, although much\r\nagitated, spoke with the most tantalising deliberation, as old ladies\r\noften do. \xe2\x80\x98Yes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Left my home, Mr. Sawyer, three days ago, on a pretended visit to my\r\nsister, another aunt of hers, who keeps the large boarding-school, just\r\nbeyond the third mile-stone, where there is a very large laburnum-tree\r\nand an oak gate,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old lady, stopping in this place to dry her\r\neyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, devil take the laburnum-tree, ma\xe2\x80\x99am!\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob, quite forgetting\r\nhis professional dignity in his anxiety. \xe2\x80\x98Get on a little faster; put a\r\nlittle more steam on, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, pray.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This morning,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old lady slowly--\xe2\x80\x98this morning, she--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She came back, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob, with great animation. \xe2\x80\x98Did\r\nshe come back?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, she did not; she wrote,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the old lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What did she say?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Bob eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She said, Mr. Sawyer,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the old lady--\xe2\x80\x98and it is this I want to\r\nprepare Benjamin\xe2\x80\x99s mind for, gently and by degrees; she said that she\r\nwas--I have got the letter in my pocket, Mr. Sawyer, but my glasses are\r\nin the carriage, and I should only waste your time if I attempted to\r\npoint out the passage to you, without them; she said, in short, Mr.\r\nSawyer, that she was married.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhat!\xe2\x80\x99 said, or rather shouted, Mr. Bob Sawyer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Married,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated the old lady.\r\n\r\nMr. Bob Sawyer stopped to hear no more; but darting from the surgery\r\ninto the outer shop, cried in a stentorian voice, \xe2\x80\x98Ben, my boy, she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbolted!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Ben Allen, who had been slumbering behind the counter, with his head\r\nhalf a foot or so below his knees, no sooner heard this appalling\r\ncommunication, than he made a precipitate rush at Mr. Martin, and,\r\ntwisting his hand in the neck-cloth of that taciturn servitor, expressed\r\nan obliging intention of choking him where he stood. This intention,\r\nwith a promptitude often the effect of desperation, he at once commenced\r\ncarrying into execution, with much vigour and surgical skill.\r\n\r\nMr. Martin, who was a man of few words and possessed but little power of\r\neloquence or persuasion, submitted to this operation with a very calm\r\nand agreeable expression of countenance, for some seconds; finding,\r\nhowever, that it threatened speedily to lead to a result which would\r\nplace it beyond his power to claim any wages, board or otherwise, in all\r\ntime to come, he muttered an inarticulate remonstrance and felled Mr.\r\nBenjamin Allen to the ground. As that gentleman had his hands entangled\r\nin his cravat, he had no alternative but to follow him to the floor.\r\nThere they both lay struggling, when the shop door opened, and the party\r\nwas increased by the arrival of two most unexpected visitors, to wit,\r\nMr. Pickwick and Mr. Samuel Weller.\r\n\r\nThe impression at once produced on Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s mind by what he saw,\r\nwas, that Mr. Martin was hired by the establishment of Sawyer, late\r\nNockemorf, to take strong medicine, or to go into fits and be\r\nexperimentalised upon, or to swallow poison now and then with the view\r\nof testing the efficacy of some new antidotes, or to do something or\r\nother to promote the great science of medicine, and gratify the ardent\r\nspirit of inquiry burning in the bosoms of its two young professors. So,\r\nwithout presuming to interfere, Sam stood perfectly still, and looked\r\non, as if he were mightily interested in the result of the then pending\r\nexperiment. Not so, Mr. Pickwick. He at once threw himself on the\r\nastonished combatants, with his accustomed energy, and loudly called\r\nupon the bystanders to interpose.\r\n\r\nThis roused Mr. Bob Sawyer, who had been hitherto quite paralysed by the\r\nfrenzy of his companion. With that gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s assistance, Mr. Pickwick\r\nraised Ben Allen to his feet. Mr. Martin finding himself alone on the\r\nfloor, got up, and looked about him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Allen,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98what is the matter, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never mind, Sir!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Allen, with haughty defiance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is it?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick, looking at Bob Sawyer. \xe2\x80\x98Is he\r\nunwell?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBefore Bob could reply, Mr. Ben Allen seized Mr. Pickwick by the hand,\r\nand murmured, in sorrowful accents, \xe2\x80\x98My sister, my dear Sir; my sister.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, is that all!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98We shall easily arrange that\r\nmatter, I hope. Your sister is safe and well, and I am here, my dear\r\nSir, to--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sorry to do anythin\xe2\x80\x99 as may cause an interruption to such wery pleasant\r\nproceedin\xe2\x80\x99s, as the king said wen he dissolved the parliament,\xe2\x80\x99\r\ninterposed Mr. Weller, who had been peeping through the glass door; \xe2\x80\x98but\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s another experiment here, sir. Here\xe2\x80\x99s a wenerable old lady a--\r\nlyin\xe2\x80\x99 on the carpet waitin\xe2\x80\x99 for dissection, or galwinism, or some other\r\nrewivin\xe2\x80\x99 and scientific inwention.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I forgot,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Ben Allen. \xe2\x80\x98It is my aunt.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Poor lady! Gently Sam, gently.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Strange sitivation for one o\xe2\x80\x99 the family,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Sam Weller,\r\nhoisting the aunt into a chair. \xe2\x80\x98Now depitty sawbones, bring out the\r\nwollatilly!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe latter observation was addressed to the boy in gray, who, having\r\nhanded over the fly to the care of the street-keeper, had come back to\r\nsee what all the noise was about. Between the boy in gray, and Mr. Bob\r\nSawyer, and Mr. Benjamin Allen (who having frightened his aunt into a\r\nfainting fit, was affectionately solicitous for her recovery) the old\r\nlady was at length restored to consciousness; then Mr. Ben Allen,\r\nturning with a puzzled countenance to Mr. Pickwick, asked him what he\r\nwas about to say, when he had been so alarmingly interrupted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We are all friends here, I presume?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, clearing his\r\nvoice, and looking towards the man of few words with the surly\r\ncountenance, who drove the fly with the chubby horse.\r\n\r\nThis reminded Mr. Bob Sawyer that the boy in gray was looking on, with\r\neyes wide open, and greedy ears. The incipient chemist having been\r\nlifted up by his coat collar, and dropped outside the door, Bob Sawyer\r\nassured Mr. Pickwick that he might speak without reserve.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your sister, my dear Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, turning to Benjamin\r\nAllen, \xe2\x80\x98is in London; well and happy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Her happiness is no object to me, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Benjamin Allen, with a\r\nflourish of the hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Her husband _is_ an object to _me_, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob Sawyer. \xe2\x80\x98He shall be\r\nan object to me, sir, at twelve paces, and a pretty object I\xe2\x80\x99ll make of\r\nhim, sir--a mean-spirited scoundrel!\xe2\x80\x99 This, as it stood, was a very\r\npretty denunciation, and magnanimous withal; but Mr. Bob Sawyer rather\r\nweakened its effect, by winding up with some general observations\r\nconcerning the punching of heads and knocking out of eyes, which were\r\ncommonplace by comparison.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stay, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick;
