We might live very comfortably together now, Mr. Samuel, eh?\r\nI could take care of his property when you are away--good care, you\r\nsee.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHeaving a long-drawn sigh, Mr. Stiggins paused for a response. Sam\r\nnodded, and Mr. Weller the elder gave vent to an extraordinary sound,\r\nwhich, being neither a groan, nor a grunt, nor a gasp, nor a growl,\r\nseemed to partake in some degree of the character of all four.\r\n\r\nMr. Stiggins, encouraged by this sound, which he understood to betoken\r\nremorse or repentance, looked about him, rubbed his hands, wept, smiled,\r\nwept again, and then, walking softly across the room to a well-\r\nremembered shelf in one corner, took down a tumbler, and with great\r\ndeliberation put four lumps of sugar in it. Having got thus far, he\r\nlooked about him again, and sighed grievously; with that, he walked\r\nsoftly into the bar, and presently returning with the tumbler half full\r\nof pine-apple rum, advanced to the kettle which was singing gaily on the\r\nhob, mixed his grog, stirred it, sipped it, sat down, and taking a long\r\nand hearty pull at the rum-and-water, stopped for breath.\r\n\r\nThe elder Mr. Weller, who still continued to make various strange and\r\nuncouth attempts to appear asleep, offered not a single word during\r\nthese proceedings; but when Stiggins stopped for breath, he darted upon\r\nhim, and snatching the tumbler from his hand, threw the remainder of the\r\nrum-and-water in his face, and the glass itself into the grate. Then,\r\nseizing the reverend gentleman firmly by the collar, he suddenly fell to\r\nkicking him most furiously, accompanying every application of his top-\r\nboot to Mr. Stiggins\xe2\x80\x99s person, with sundry violent and incoherent\r\nanathemas upon his limbs, eyes, and body.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98put my hat on tight for me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSam dutifully adjusted the hat with the long hatband more firmly on his\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s head, and the old gentleman, resuming his kicking with greater\r\nagility than before, tumbled with Mr. Stiggins through the bar, and\r\nthrough the passage, out at the front door, and so into the street--the\r\nkicking continuing the whole way, and increasing in vehemence, rather\r\nthan diminishing, every time the top-boot was lifted.\r\n\r\nIt was a beautiful and exhilarating sight to see the red-nosed man\r\nwrithing in Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s grasp, and his whole frame quivering with\r\nanguish as kick followed kick in rapid succession; it was a still more\r\nexciting spectacle to behold Mr. Weller, after a powerful struggle,\r\nimmersing Mr. Stiggins\xe2\x80\x99s head in a horse-trough full of water, and\r\nholding it there, until he was half suffocated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, throwing all his energy into one most\r\ncomplicated kick, as he at length permitted Mr. Stiggins to withdraw his\r\nhead from the trough, \xe2\x80\x98send any vun o\xe2\x80\x99 them lazy shepherds here, and\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll pound him to a jelly first, and drownd him artervards! Sammy, help\r\nme in, and fill me a small glass of brandy. I\xe2\x80\x99m out o\xe2\x80\x99 breath, my boy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LIII. COMPRISING THE FINAL EXIT OF MR. JINGLE AND JOB TROTTER,\r\nWITH A GREAT MORNING OF BUSINESS IN GRAY\xe2\x80\x99S INN SQUARE--CONCLUDING WITH A\r\nDOUBLE KNOCK AT MR. PERKER\xe2\x80\x99S DOOR\r\n\r\nWhen Arabella, after some gentle preparation and many assurances that\r\nthere was not the least occasion for being low-spirited, was at length\r\nmade acquainted by Mr. Pickwick with the unsatisfactory result of his\r\nvisit to Birmingham, she burst into tears, and sobbing aloud, lamented\r\nin moving terms that she should have been the unhappy cause of any\r\nestrangement between a father and his son.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear girl,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick kindly, \xe2\x80\x98it is no fault of yours. It\r\nwas impossible to foresee that the old gentleman would be so strongly\r\nprepossessed against his son\xe2\x80\x99s marriage, you know. I am sure,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr.\r\nPickwick, glancing at her pretty face, \xe2\x80\x98he can have very little idea of\r\nthe pleasure he denies himself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, my dear Mr. Pickwick,\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella, \xe2\x80\x98what shall we do, if he\r\ncontinues to be angry with us?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, wait patiently, my dear, until he thinks better of it,\xe2\x80\x99 replied\r\nMr. Pickwick cheerfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, dear Mr. Pickwick, what is to become of Nathaniel if his father\r\nwithdraws his assistance?\xe2\x80\x99 urged Arabella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In that case, my love,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98I will venture to\r\nprophesy that he will find some other friend who will not be backward in\r\nhelping him to start in the world.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe significance of this reply was not so well disguised by Mr. Pickwick\r\nbut that Arabella understood it. So, throwing her arms round his neck,\r\nand kissing him affectionately, she sobbed louder than before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, come,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick taking her hand, \xe2\x80\x98we will wait here a\r\nfew days longer, and see whether he writes or takes any other notice of\r\nyour husband\xe2\x80\x99s communication. If not, I have thought of half a dozen\r\nplans, any one of which would make you happy at once. There, my dear,\r\nthere!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith these words, Mr. Pickwick gently pressed Arabella\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and bade\r\nher dry her eyes, and not distress her husband. Upon which, Arabella,\r\nwho was one of the best little creatures alive, put her handkerchief in\r\nher reticule, and by the time Mr. Winkle joined them, exhibited in full\r\nlustre the same beaming smiles and sparkling eyes that had originally\r\ncaptivated him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is a distressing predicament for these young people,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr.\r\nPickwick, as he dressed himself next morning. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll walk up to Perker\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nand consult him about the matter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Mr. Pickwick was further prompted to betake himself to Gray\xe2\x80\x99s Inn\r\nSquare by an anxious desire to come to a pecuniary settlement with the\r\nkind-hearted little attorney without further delay, he made a hurried\r\nbreakfast, and executed his intention so speedily, that ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock had\r\nnot struck when he reached Gray\xe2\x80\x99s Inn.\r\n\r\nIt still wanted ten minutes to the hour when he had ascended the\r\nstaircase on which Perker\xe2\x80\x99s chambers were. The clerks had not arrived\r\nyet, and he beguiled the time by looking out of the staircase window.\r\n\r\nThe healthy light of a fine October morning made even the dingy old\r\nhouses brighten up a little; some of the dusty windows actually looking\r\nalmost cheerful as the sun\xe2\x80\x99s rays gleamed upon them. Clerk after clerk\r\nhastened into the square by one or other of the entrances, and looking\r\nup at the Hall clock, accelerated or decreased his rate of walking\r\naccording to the time at which his office hours nominally commenced; the\r\nhalf-past nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock people suddenly becoming very brisk, and the ten\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock gentlemen falling into a pace of most aristocratic slowness. The\r\nclock struck ten, and clerks poured in faster than ever, each one in a\r\ngreater perspiration than his predecessor. The noise of unlocking and\r\nopening doors echoed and re-echoed on every side; heads appeared as if\r\nby magic in every window; the porters took up their stations for the\r\nday; the slipshod laundresses hurried off; the postman ran from house to\r\nhouse; and the whole legal hive was in a bustle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re early, Mr. Pickwick,\xe2\x80\x99 said a voice behind him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, Mr. Lowten,\xe2\x80\x99 replied that gentleman, looking round, and recognising\r\nhis old acquaintance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Precious warm walking, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99 said Lowten, drawing a Bramah key\r\nfrom his pocket, with a small plug therein, to keep the dust out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You appear to feel it so,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Pickwick, smiling at the clerk,\r\nwho was literally red-hot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve come along, rather, I can tell you,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Lowten. \xe2\x80\x98It went the\r\nhalf hour as I came through the Polygon. I\xe2\x80\x99m here before him, though, so\r\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t mind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nComforting himself with this reflection, Mr. Lowten extracted the plug\r\nfrom the door-key; having opened the door, replugged and repocketed his\r\nBramah, and picked up the letters which the postman had dropped through\r\nthe box, he ushered Mr. Pickwick into the office. Here, in the twinkling\r\nof an eye, he divested himself of his coat, put on a threadbare garment,\r\nwhich he took out of a desk, hung up his hat, pulled forth a few sheets\r\nof cartridge and blotting-paper in alternate layers, and, sticking a pen\r\nbehind his ear, rubbed his hands with an air of great satisfaction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There, you see, Mr. Pickwick,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98now I\xe2\x80\x99m complete. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got my\r\noffice coat on, and my pad out, and let him come as soon as he likes.\r\nYou haven\xe2\x80\x99t got a pinch of snuff about you, have you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I have not,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry for it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lowten. \xe2\x80\x98Never mind. I\xe2\x80\x99ll run out presently,\r\nand get a bottle of soda. Don\xe2\x80\x99t I look rather queer about the eyes, Mr.\r\nPickwick?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe individual appealed to, surveyed Mr. Lowten\xe2\x80\x99s eyes from a distance,\r\nand expressed his opinion that no unusual queerness was perceptible in\r\nthose features.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m glad of it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lowten. \xe2\x80\x98We were keeping it up pretty tolerably\r\nat the Stump last night, and I\xe2\x80\x99m rather out of sorts this morning.\r\nPerker\xe2\x80\x99s been about that business of yours, by the bye.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What business?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Bardell\xe2\x80\x99s costs?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean that,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Lowten. \xe2\x80\x98About getting that\r\ncustomer that we paid the ten shillings in the pound to the bill-\r\ndiscounter for, on your account--to get him out of the Fleet, you know--\r\nabout getting him to Demerara.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Mr. Jingle,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick hastily. \xe2\x80\x98Yes. Well?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, it\xe2\x80\x99s all arranged,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lowten, mending his pen. \xe2\x80\x98The agent at\r\nLiverpool said he had been obliged to you many times when you were in\r\nbusiness, and he would be glad to take him on your recommendation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98I am delighted to hear it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I say,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Lowten, scraping the back of the pen preparatory to\r\nmaking a fresh split, \xe2\x80\x98what a soft chap that other is!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which other?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, that servant, or friend, or whatever he is; you know, Trotter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with a smile. \xe2\x80\x98I always thought him the\r\nreverse.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, and so did I, from what little I saw of him,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Lowten, \xe2\x80\x98it\r\nonly shows how one may be deceived. What do you think of his going to\r\nDemerara, too?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What! And giving up what was offered him here!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Treating Perker\xe2\x80\x99s offer of eighteen bob a week, and a rise if he\r\nbehaved himself, like dirt,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Lowten. \xe2\x80\x98He said he must go along\r\nwith the other one, and so they persuaded Perker to write again, and\r\nthey\xe2\x80\x99ve got him something on the same estate; not near so good, Perker\r\nsays, as a convict would get in New South Wales, if he appeared at his\r\ntrial in a new suit of clothes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Foolish fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, with glistening eyes. \xe2\x80\x98Foolish\r\nfellow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, it\xe2\x80\x99s worse than foolish; it\xe2\x80\x99s downright sneaking, you know,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nreplied Lowten, nibbing the pen with a contemptuous face. \xe2\x80\x98He says that\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s the only friend he ever had, and he\xe2\x80\x99s attached to him, and all\r\nthat. Friendship\xe2\x80\x99s a very good thing in its way--we are all very\r\nfriendly and comfortable at the Stump, for instance, over our grog,\r\nwhere every man pays for himself; but damn hurting yourself for anybody\r\nelse, you know! No man should have more than two attachments--the first,\r\nto number one, and the second to the ladies; that\xe2\x80\x99s what I say--ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nMr. Lowten concluded with a loud laugh, half in jocularity, and half in\r\nderision, which was prematurely cut short by the sound of Perker\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfootsteps on the stairs, at the first approach of which, he vaulted on\r\nhis stool with an agility most remarkable, and wrote intensely.\r\n\r\nThe greeting between Mr. Pickwick and his professional adviser was warm\r\nand cordial; the client was scarcely ensconced in the attorney\xe2\x80\x99s arm-\r\nchair, however, when a knock was heard at the door, and a voice inquired\r\nwhether Mr. Perker was within.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hark!\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker, \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s one of our vagabond friends--Jingle\r\nhimself, my dear Sir. Will you see him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you think?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick, hesitating.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I think you had better. Here, you Sir, what\xe2\x80\x99s your name, walk in,\r\nwill you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn compliance with this unceremonious invitation, Jingle and Job walked\r\ninto the room, but, seeing Mr. Pickwick, stopped short in some\r\nconfusion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker, \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t you know that gentleman?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good reason to,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Jingle, stepping forward. \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pickwick--\r\ndeepest obligations--life preserver--made a man of me--you shall never\r\nrepent it, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am happy to hear you say so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98You look much\r\nbetter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thanks to you, sir--great change--Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s Fleet--unwholesome place--\r\nvery,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jingle, shaking his head. He was decently and cleanly\r\ndressed, and so was Job, who stood bolt upright behind him, staring at\r\nMr. Pickwick with a visage of iron.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When do they go to Liverpool?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick, half aside to\r\nPerker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This evening, Sir, at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job, taking one step\r\nforward. \xe2\x80\x98By the heavy coach from the city, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are your places taken?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They are, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have fully made up your mind to go?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have sir,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Job.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With regard to such an outfit as was indispensable for Jingle,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nPerker, addressing Mr. Pickwick aloud. \xe2\x80\x98I have taken upon myself to make\r\nan arrangement for the deduction of a small sum from his quarterly\r\nsalary, which, being made only for one year, and regularly remitted,\r\nwill provide for that expense. I entirely disapprove of your doing\r\nanything for him, my dear sir, which is not dependent on his own\r\nexertions and good conduct.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Jingle, with great firmness. \xe2\x80\x98Clear head--man of\r\nthe world--quite right--perfectly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By compounding with his creditor, releasing his clothes from the\r\npawnbroker\xe2\x80\x99s, relieving him in prison, and paying for his passage,\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncontinued Perker, without noticing Jingle\xe2\x80\x99s observation, \xe2\x80\x98you have\r\nalready lost upwards of fifty pounds.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not lost,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jingle hastily, \xe2\x80\x98Pay it all--stick to business--cash\r\nup--every farthing. Yellow fever, perhaps--can\xe2\x80\x99t help that--if not--\xe2\x80\x99\r\nHere Mr. Jingle paused, and striking the crown of his hat with great\r\nviolence, passed his hand over his eyes, and sat down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He means to say,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job, advancing a few paces, \xe2\x80\x98that if he is not\r\ncarried off by the fever, he will pay the money back again. If he lives,\r\nhe will, Mr. Pickwick. I will see it done. I know he will, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nJob, with energy. \xe2\x80\x98I could undertake to swear it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, who had been bestowing a score or two\r\nof frowns upon Perker, to stop his summary of benefits conferred, which\r\nthe little attorney obstinately disregarded, \xe2\x80\x98you must be careful not to\r\nplay any more desperate cricket matches, Mr. Jingle, or to renew your\r\nacquaintance with Sir Thomas Blazo, and I have little doubt of your\r\npreserving your health.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Jingle smiled at this sally, but looked rather foolish\r\nnotwithstanding; so Mr. Pickwick changed the subject by saying--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t happen to know, do you, what has become of another friend of\r\nyours--a more humble one, whom I saw at Rochester?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dismal Jemmy?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Jingle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJingle shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Clever rascal--queer fellow, hoaxing genius--Job\xe2\x80\x99s brother.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Job\xe2\x80\x99s brother!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Well, now I look at him\r\nclosely, there _is_ a likeness.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We were always considered like each other, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job, with a\r\ncunning look just lurking in the corners of his eyes, \xe2\x80\x98only I was really\r\nof a serious nature, and he never was. He emigrated to America, Sir, in\r\nconsequence of being too much sought after here, to be comfortable; and\r\nhas never been heard of since.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That accounts for my not having received the \xe2\x80\x9cpage from the romance of\r\nreal life,\xe2\x80\x9d which he promised me one morning when he appeared to be\r\ncontemplating suicide on Rochester Bridge, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nPickwick, smiling. \xe2\x80\x98I need not inquire whether his dismal behaviour was\r\nnatural or assumed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He could assume anything, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Job. \xe2\x80\x98You may consider yourself\r\nvery fortunate in having escaped him so easily. On intimate terms he\r\nwould have been even a more dangerous acquaintance than--\xe2\x80\x99 Job looked at\r\nJingle, hesitated, and finally added, \xe2\x80\x98than--than-myself even.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A hopeful family yours, Mr. Trotter,\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker, sealing a letter\r\nwhich he had just finished writing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Job. \xe2\x80\x98Very much so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said the little man, laughing, \xe2\x80\x98I hope you are going to disgrace\r\nit. Deliver this letter to the agent when you reach Liverpool, and let\r\nme advise you, gentlemen, not to be too knowing in the West Indies. If\r\nyou throw away this chance, you will both richly deserve to be hanged,\r\nas I sincerely trust you will be. And now you had better leave Mr.\r\nPickwick and me alone, for we have other matters to talk over, and time\r\nis precious.\xe2\x80\x99 As Perker said this, he looked towards the door, with an\r\nevident desire to render the leave-taking as brief as possible.\r\n\r\nIt was brief enough on Mr. Jingle\xe2\x80\x99s part. He thanked the little attorney\r\nin a few hurried words for the kindness and promptitude with which he\r\nhad rendered his assistance, and, turning to his benefactor, stood for a\r\nfew seconds as if irresolute what to say or how to act. Job Trotter\r\nrelieved his perplexity; for, with a humble and grateful bow to Mr.\r\nPickwick, he took his friend gently by the arm, and led him away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A worthy couple!\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker, as the door closed behind them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope they may become so,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98What do you think?\r\nIs there any chance of their permanent reformation?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPerker shrugged his shoulders doubtfully, but observing Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nanxious and disappointed look, rejoined--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course there is a chance. I hope it may prove a good one. They are\r\nunquestionably penitent now; but then, you know, they have the\r\nrecollection of very recent suffering fresh upon them. What they may\r\nbecome, when that fades away, is a problem that neither you nor I can\r\nsolve. However, my dear Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 added Perker, laying his hand on Mr.\r\nPickwick\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder, \xe2\x80\x98your object is equally honourable, whatever the\r\nresult is. Whether that species of benevolence which is so very cautious\r\nand long-sighted that it is seldom exercised at all, lest its owner\r\nshould be imposed upon, and so wounded in his self-love, be real charity\r\nor a worldly counterfeit, I leave to wiser heads than mine to determine.\r\nBut if those two fellows were to commit a burglary to-morrow, my opinion\r\nof this action would be equally high.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith these remarks, which were delivered in a much more animated and\r\nearnest manner than is usual in legal gentlemen, Perker drew his chair\r\nto his desk, and listened to Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s recital of old Mr. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nobstinacy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Give him a week,\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker, nodding his head prophetically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think he will come round?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think he will,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Perker. \xe2\x80\x98If not, we must try the young\r\nlady\xe2\x80\x99s persuasion; and that is what anybody but you would have done at\r\nfirst.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Perker was taking a pinch of snuff with various grotesque\r\ncontractions of countenance, eulogistic of the persuasive powers\r\nappertaining unto young ladies, when the murmur of inquiry and answer\r\nwas heard in the outer office, and Lowten tapped at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come in!\xe2\x80\x99 cried the little man.\r\n\r\nThe clerk came in, and shut the door after him, with great mystery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Perker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re wanted, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who wants me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLowten looked at Mr. Pickwick, and coughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who wants me? Can\xe2\x80\x99t you speak, Mr. Lowten?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Lowten, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s Dodson; and Fogg is with him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless my life!\xe2\x80\x99 said the little man, looking at his watch, \xe2\x80\x98I appointed\r\nthem to be here at half-past eleven, to settle that matter of yours,\r\nPickwick. I gave them an undertaking on which they sent down your\r\ndischarge; it\xe2\x80\x99s very awkward, my dear Sir; what will you do? Would you\r\nlike to step into the next room?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe next room being the identical room in which Messrs. Dodson & Fogg\r\nwere, Mr. Pickwick replied that he would remain where he was: the more\r\nespecially as Messrs. Dodson & Fogg ought to be ashamed to look him in\r\nthe face, instead of his being ashamed to see them. Which latter\r\ncircumstance he begged Mr. Perker to note, with a glowing countenance\r\nand many marks of indignation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well, my dear Sir, very well,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Perker, \xe2\x80\x98I can only say\r\nthat if you expect either Dodson or Fogg to exhibit any symptom of shame\r\nor confusion at having to look you, or anybody else, in the face, you\r\nare the most sanguine man in your expectations that I ever met with.\r\nShow them in, Mr. Lowten.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Lowten disappeared with a grin, and immediately returned ushering in\r\nthe firm, in due form of precedence--Dodson first, and Fogg afterwards.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have seen Mr. Pickwick, I believe?\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker to Dodson,\r\ninclining his pen in the direction where that gentleman was seated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How do you do, Mr. Pickwick?\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson, in a loud voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Fogg, \xe2\x80\x98how do you do, Mr. Pickwick? I hope you are\r\nwell, Sir. I thought I knew the face,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg, drawing up a chair,\r\nand looking round him with a smile.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick bent his head very slightly, in answer to these\r\nsalutations, and, seeing Fogg pull a bundle of papers from his coat\r\npocket, rose and walked to the window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s no occasion for Mr. Pickwick to move, Mr. Perker,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg,\r\nuntying the red tape which encircled the little bundle, and smiling\r\nagain more sweetly than before. \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pickwick is pretty well acquainted\r\nwith these proceedings. There are no secrets between us, I think. He!\r\nhe! he!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not many, I think,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson. \xe2\x80\x98Ha! ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x99 Then both the partners\r\nlaughed together--pleasantly and cheerfully, as men who are going to\r\nreceive money often do.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We shall make Mr. Pickwick pay for peeping,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg, with\r\nconsiderable native humour, as he unfolded his papers. \xe2\x80\x98The amount of\r\nthe taxed costs is one hundred and thirty-three, six, four, Mr. Perker.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was a great comparing of papers, and turning over of leaves, by\r\nFogg and Perker, after this statement of profit and loss. Meanwhile,\r\nDodson said, in an affable manner, to Mr. Pickwick--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think you are looking quite so stout as when I had the pleasure\r\nof seeing you last, Mr. Pickwick.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Possibly not, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, who had been flashing forth\r\nlooks of fierce indignation, without producing the smallest effect on\r\neither of the sharp practitioners; \xe2\x80\x98I believe I am not, Sir. I have been\r\npersecuted and annoyed by scoundrels of late, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPerker coughed violently, and asked Mr. Pickwick whether he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlike to look at the morning paper. To which inquiry Mr. Pickwick\r\nreturned a most decided negative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98True,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson, \xe2\x80\x98I dare say you have been annoyed in the Fleet;\r\nthere are some odd gentry there. Whereabouts were your apartments, Mr.\r\nPickwick?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My one room,\xe2\x80\x99 replied that much-injured gentleman, \xe2\x80\x98was on the coffee-\r\nroom flight.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, indeed!\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson. \xe2\x80\x98I believe that is a very pleasant part of\r\nthe establishment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick drily.\r\n\r\nThere was a coolness about all this, which, to a gentleman of an\r\nexcitable temperament, had, under the circumstances, rather an\r\nexasperating tendency. Mr. Pickwick restrained his wrath by gigantic\r\nefforts; but when Perker wrote a cheque for the whole amount, and Fogg\r\ndeposited it in a small pocket-book, with a triumphant smile playing\r\nover his pimply features, which communicated itself likewise to the\r\nstern countenance of Dodson, he felt the blood in his cheeks tingling\r\nwith indignation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Mr. Dodson,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg, putting up the pocket-book and drawing on\r\nhis gloves, \xe2\x80\x98I am at your service.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson, rising; \xe2\x80\x98I am quite ready.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am very happy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg, softened by the cheque, \xe2\x80\x98to have had the\r\npleasure of making Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s acquaintance. I hope you don\xe2\x80\x99t think\r\nquite so ill of us, Mr. Pickwick, as when we first had the pleasure of\r\nseeing you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope not,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson, with the high tone of calumniated virtue.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pickwick now knows us better, I trust; whatever your opinion of\r\ngentlemen of our profession may be, I beg to assure you, sir, that I\r\nbear no ill-will or vindictive feeling towards you for the sentiments\r\nyou thought proper to express in our office in Freeman\xe2\x80\x99s Court,\r\nCornhill, on the occasion to which my partner has referred.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, no, no; nor I,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg, in a most forgiving manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Our conduct, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson, \xe2\x80\x98will speak for itself, and justify\r\nitself, I hope, upon every occasion. We have been in the profession some\r\nyears, Mr. Pickwick, and have been honoured with the confidence of many\r\nexcellent clients. I wish you good-morning, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-morning, Mr. Pickwick,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg. So saying, he put his umbrella\r\nunder his arm, drew off his right glove, and extended the hand of\r\nreconciliation to that most indignant gentleman; who, thereupon, thrust\r\nhis hands beneath his coat tails, and eyed the attorney with looks of\r\nscornful amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lowten!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Perker, at this moment. \xe2\x80\x98Open the door.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wait one instant,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Perker, I _will _speak.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear Sir, pray let the matter rest where it is,\xe2\x80\x99 said the little\r\nattorney, who had been in a state of nervous apprehension during the\r\nwhole interview; \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pickwick, I beg--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will not be put down, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick hastily. \xe2\x80\x98Mr.\r\nDodson, you have addressed some remarks to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDodson turned round, bent his head meekly, and smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Some remarks to me,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr. Pickwick, almost breathless; \xe2\x80\x98and\r\nyour partner has tendered me his hand, and you have both assumed a tone\r\nof forgiveness and high-mindedness, which is an extent of impudence that\r\nI was not prepared for, even in you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Dodson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 reiterated Fogg.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you know that I have been the victim of your plots and\r\nconspiracies?\xe2\x80\x99 continued Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Do you know that I am the man\r\nwhom you have been imprisoning and robbing? Do you know that you were\r\nthe attorneys for the plaintiff, in Bardell and Pickwick?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, sir, we do know it,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Dodson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course we know it, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Fogg, slapping his pocket--perhaps\r\nby accident.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see that you recollect it with satisfaction,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick,\r\nattempting to call up a sneer for the first time in his life, and\r\nfailing most signally in so doing. \xe2\x80\x98Although I have long been anxious to\r\ntell you, in plain terms, what my opinion of you is, I should have let\r\neven this opportunity pass, in deference to my friend Perker\xe2\x80\x99s wishes,\r\nbut for the unwarrantable tone you have assumed, and your insolent\r\nfamiliarity. I say insolent familiarity, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick,\r\nturning upon Fogg with a fierceness of gesture which caused that person\r\nto retreat towards the door with great expedition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take care, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson, who, though he was the biggest man of the\r\nparty, had prudently entrenched himself behind Fogg, and was speaking\r\nover his head with a very pale face. \xe2\x80\x98Let him assault you, Mr. Fogg;\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t return it on any account.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no, I won\xe2\x80\x99t return it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg, falling back a little more as he\r\nspoke; to the evident relief of his partner, who by these means was\r\ngradually getting into the outer office.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Mr. Pickwick, resuming the thread of his discourse-\r\n-\xe2\x80\x99you are a well-matched pair of mean, rascally, pettifogging robbers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Perker, \xe2\x80\x98is that all?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is all summed up in that,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98they are mean,\r\nrascally, pettifogging robbers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There!\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker, in a most conciliatory tone. \xe2\x80\x98My dear sirs, he has\r\nsaid all he has to say. Now pray go. Lowten, is that door open?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Lowten, with a distant giggle, replied in the affirmative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There, there--good-morning--good-morning--now pray, my dear sirs--Mr.\r\nLowten, the door!\xe2\x80\x99 cried the little man, pushing Dodson & Fogg, nothing\r\nloath, out of the office; \xe2\x80\x98this way, my dear sirs--now pray don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nprolong this--Dear me--Mr. Lowten--the door, sir--why don\xe2\x80\x99t you attend?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If there\xe2\x80\x99s law in England, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dodson, looking towards Mr.\r\nPickwick, as he put on his hat, \xe2\x80\x98you shall smart for this.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are a couple of mean--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Remember, sir, you pay dearly for this,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fogg.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--Rascally, pettifogging robbers!\xe2\x80\x99 continued Mr. Pickwick, taking not\r\nthe least notice of the threats that were addressed to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Robbers!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr. Pickwick, running to the stair-head, as the two\r\nattorneys descended.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Robbers!\xe2\x80\x99 shouted Mr. Pickwick, breaking from Lowten and Perker, and\r\nthrusting his head out of the staircase window.\r\n\r\nWhen Mr. Pickwick drew in his head again, his countenance was smiling\r\nand placid; and, walking quietly back into the office, he declared that\r\nhe had now removed a great weight from his mind, and that he felt\r\nperfectly comfortable and happy.\r\n\r\nPerker said nothing at all until he had emptied his snuff-box, and sent\r\nLowten out to fill it, when he was seized with a fit of laughing, which\r\nlasted five minutes; at the expiration of which time he said that he\r\nsupposed he ought to be very angry, but he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t think of the\r\nbusiness seriously yet--when he could, he would be.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98let me have a settlement with you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOf the same kind as the last?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Perker, with another laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not exactly,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Pickwick, drawing out his pocket-book, and\r\nshaking the little man heartily by the hand, \xe2\x80\x98I only mean a pecuniary\r\nsettlement. You have done me many acts of kindness that I can never\r\nrepay, and have no wish to repay, for I prefer continuing the\r\nobligation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith this preface, the two friends dived into some very complicated\r\naccounts and vouchers, which, having been duly displayed and gone\r\nthrough by Perker, were at once discharged by Mr. Pickwick with many\r\nprofessions of esteem and friendship.\r\n\r\nThey had no sooner arrived at this point, than a most violent and\r\nstartling knocking was heard at the door; it was not an ordinary double-\r\nknock, but a constant and uninterrupted succession of the loudest single\r\nraps, as if the knocker were endowed with the perpetual motion, or the\r\nperson outside had forgotten to leave off.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me, what\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Perker, starting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think it is a knock at the door,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, as if there\r\ncould be the smallest doubt of the fact.\r\n\r\nThe knocker made a more energetic reply than words could have yielded,\r\nfor it continued to hammer with surprising force and noise, without a\r\nmoment\xe2\x80\x99s cessation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me!\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker, ringing his bell, \xe2\x80\x98we shall alarm the inn. Mr.\r\nLowten, don\xe2\x80\x99t you hear a knock?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll answer the door in one moment, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the clerk.\r\n\r\nThe knocker appeared to hear the response, and to assert that it was\r\nquite impossible he could wait so long. It made a stupendous uproar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s quite dreadful,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, stopping his ears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Make haste, Mr. Lowten,\xe2\x80\x99 Perker called out; \xe2\x80\x98we shall have the panels\r\nbeaten in.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Lowten, who was washing his hands in a dark closet, hurried to the\r\ndoor, and turning the handle, beheld the appearance which is described\r\nin the next chapter.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LIV. CONTAINING SOME PARTICULARS RELATIVE TO THE DOUBLE KNOCK,\r\nAND OTHER MATTERS: AMONG WHICH CERTAIN INTERESTING DISCLOSURES RELATIVE\r\nTO MR. SNODGRASS AND A YOUNG LADY ARE BY NO MEANS IRRELEVANT TO THIS\r\nHISTORY\r\n\r\nThe object that presented itself to the eyes of the astonished clerk,\r\nwas a boy--a wonderfully fat boy--habited as a serving lad, standing\r\nupright on the mat, with his eyes closed as if in sleep. He had never\r\nseen such a fat boy, in or out of a travelling caravan; and this,\r\ncoupled with the calmness and repose of his appearance, so very\r\ndifferent from what was reasonably to have been expected of the\r\ninflicter of such knocks, smote him with wonder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the clerk.\r\n\r\nThe extraordinary boy replied not a word; but he nodded once, and\r\nseemed, to the clerk\xe2\x80\x99s imagination, to snore feebly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where do you come from?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the clerk.\r\n\r\nThe boy made no sign. He breathed heavily, but in all other respects was\r\nmotionless.\r\n\r\nThe clerk repeated the question thrice, and receiving no answer,\r\nprepared to shut the door, when the boy suddenly opened his eyes, winked\r\nseveral times, sneezed once, and raised his hand as if to repeat the\r\nknocking. Finding the door open, he stared about him with astonishment,\r\nand at length fixed his eyes on Mr. Lowten\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What the devil do you knock in that way for?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the clerk\r\nangrily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which way?\xe2\x80\x99 said the boy, in a slow and sleepy voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, like forty hackney-coachmen,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the clerk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because master said, I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t to leave off knocking till they opened\r\nthe door, for fear I should go to sleep,\xe2\x80\x99 said the boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said the clerk, \xe2\x80\x98what message have you brought?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s downstairs,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined the boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Master. He wants to know whether you\xe2\x80\x99re at home.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Lowten bethought himself, at this juncture, of looking out of the\r\nwindow. Seeing an open carriage with a hearty old gentleman in it,\r\nlooking up very anxiously, he ventured to beckon him; on which, the old\r\ngentleman jumped out directly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s your master in the carriage, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x99 said Lowten.\r\n\r\nThe boy nodded.\r\n\r\nAll further inquiries were superseded by the appearance of old Wardle,\r\nwho, running upstairs and just recognising Lowten, passed at once into\r\nMr. Perker\xe2\x80\x99s room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pickwick!\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98Your hand, my boy! Why have I never\r\nheard until the day before yesterday of your suffering yourself to be\r\ncooped up in jail? And why did you let him do it, Perker?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it, my dear Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Perker, with a smile and a\r\npinch of snuff; \xe2\x80\x98you know how obstinate he is?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course I do; of course I do,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98I am\r\nheartily glad to see him, notwithstanding. I will not lose sight of him\r\nagain, in a hurry.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith these words, Wardle shook Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s hand once more, and,\r\nhaving done the same by Perker, threw himself into an arm-chair, his\r\njolly red face shining again with smiles and health.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98Here are pretty goings on--a pinch of your snuff,\r\nPerker, my boy--never were such times, eh?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mean!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98Why, I think the girls are all running mad;\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s no news, you\xe2\x80\x99ll say? Perhaps it\xe2\x80\x99s not; but it\xe2\x80\x99s true, for all\r\nthat.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have not come up to London, of all places in the world, to tell us\r\nthat, my dear Sir, have you?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Perker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, not altogether,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wardle; \xe2\x80\x98though it was the main cause of\r\nmy coming. How\xe2\x80\x99s Arabella?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98and will be delighted to see you, I\r\nam sure.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Black-eyed little jilt!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98I had a great idea of\r\nmarrying her myself, one of these odd days. But I am glad of it too,\r\nvery glad.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How did the intelligence reach you?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, it came to my girls, of course,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98Arabella wrote,\r\nthe day before yesterday, to say she had made a stolen match without her\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s father\xe2\x80\x99s consent, and so you had gone down to get it when his\r\nrefusing it couldn\xe2\x80\x99t prevent the match, and all the rest of it. I\r\nthought it a very good time to say something serious to my girls; so I\r\nsaid what a dreadful thing it was that children should marry without\r\ntheir parents\xe2\x80\x99 consent, and so forth; but, bless your hearts, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmake the least impression upon them. They thought it such a much more\r\ndreadful thing that there should have been a wedding without\r\nbridesmaids, that I might as well have preached to Joe himself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere the old gentleman stopped to laugh; and having done so to his\r\nheart\xe2\x80\x99s content, presently resumed--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But this is not the best of it, it seems. This is only half the love-\r\nmaking and plotting that have been going forward. We have been walking\r\non mines for the last six months, and they\xe2\x80\x99re sprung at last.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick, turning pale; \xe2\x80\x98no other\r\nsecret marriage, I hope?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no,\xe2\x80\x99 replied old Wardle; \xe2\x80\x98not so bad as that; no.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What then?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98am I interested in it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shall I answer that question, Perker?\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you don\xe2\x80\x99t commit yourself by doing so, my dear Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well then, you are,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr. Pickwick anxiously. \xe2\x80\x98In what way?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Really,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wardle, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99re such a fiery sort of a young fellow\r\nthat I am almost afraid to tell you; but, however, if Perker will sit\r\nbetween us to prevent mischief, I\xe2\x80\x99ll venture.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHaving closed the room door, and fortified himself with another\r\napplication to Perker\xe2\x80\x99s snuff-box, the old gentleman proceeded with his\r\ngreat disclosure in these words--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The fact is, that my daughter Bella--Bella, who married young Trundle,\r\nyou know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, yes, we know,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick impatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t alarm me at the very beginning. My daughter Bella--Emily having\r\ngone to bed with a headache after she had read Arabella\xe2\x80\x99s letter to me--\r\nsat herself down by my side the other evening, and began to talk over\r\nthis marriage affair. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, pa,\xe2\x80\x9d she says, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you think of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose it\xe2\x80\x99s all very well; I hope it\xe2\x80\x99s for\r\nthe best.\xe2\x80\x9d I answered in this way because I was sitting before the fire\r\nat the time, drinking my grog rather thoughtfully, and I knew my\r\nthrowing in an undecided word now and then, would induce her to continue\r\ntalking. Both my girls are pictures of their dear mother, and as I grow\r\nold I like to sit with only them by me; for their voices and looks carry\r\nme back to the happiest period of my life, and make me, for the moment,\r\nas young as I used to be then, though not quite so light-hearted. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nquite a marriage of affection, pa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bella, after a short silence.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cbut such marriages do not always turn out the\r\nhappiest.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I question that, mind!\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Pickwick warmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good,\xe2\x80\x99 responded Wardle, \xe2\x80\x98question anything you like when it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nyour turn to speak, but don\xe2\x80\x99t interrupt me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Granted,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry to hear you express your opinion\r\nagainst marriages of affection, pa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bella, colouring a little. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwas wrong; I ought not to have said so, my dear, either,\xe2\x80\x9d said I,\r\npatting her cheek as kindly as a rough old fellow like me could pat it,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfor your mother\xe2\x80\x99s was one, and so was yours.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not that I meant,\r\npa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bella. \xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is, pa, I wanted to speak to you about\r\nEmily.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick started.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter now?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Wardle, stopping in his narrative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Pray go on.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never could spin out a story,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle abruptly. \xe2\x80\x98It must come\r\nout, sooner or later, and it\xe2\x80\x99ll save us all a great deal of time if it\r\ncomes at once. The long and the short of it is, then, that Bella at last\r\nmustered up courage to tell me that Emily was very unhappy; that she and\r\nyour young friend Snodgrass had been in constant correspondence and\r\ncommunication ever since last Christmas; that she had very dutifully\r\nmade up her mind to run away with him, in laudable imitation of her old\r\nfriend and school-fellow; but that having some compunctions of\r\nconscience on the subject, inasmuch as I had always been rather kindly\r\ndisposed to both of them, they had thought it better in the first\r\ninstance to pay me the compliment of asking whether I would have any\r\nobjection to their being married in the usual matter-of-fact manner.\r\nThere now, Mr. Pickwick, if you can make it convenient to reduce your\r\neyes to their usual size again, and to let me hear what you think we\r\nought to do, I shall feel rather obliged to you!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe testy manner in which the hearty old gentleman uttered this last\r\nsentence was not wholly unwarranted; for Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s face had settled\r\ndown into an expression of blank amazement and perplexity, quite curious\r\nto behold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Snodgrass!--since last Christmas!\xe2\x80\x99 were the first broken words that\r\nissued from the lips of the confounded gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Since last Christmas,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wardle; \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s plain enough, and very\r\nbad spectacles we must have worn, not to have discovered it before.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, ruminating; \xe2\x80\x98I cannot really\r\nunderstand it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s easy enough to understand it,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the choleric old gentleman.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you had been a younger man, you would have been in the secret long\r\nago; and besides,\xe2\x80\x99 added Wardle, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s hesitation, \xe2\x80\x98the truth\r\nis, that, knowing nothing of this matter, I have rather pressed Emily\r\nfor four or five months past, to receive favourably (if she could; I\r\nwould never attempt to force a girl\xe2\x80\x99s inclinations) the addresses of a\r\nyoung gentleman down in our neighbourhood. I have no doubt that, girl-\r\nlike, to enhance her own value and increase the ardour of Mr. Snodgrass,\r\nshe has represented this matter in very glowing colours, and that they\r\nhave both arrived at the conclusion that they are a terribly-persecuted\r\npair of unfortunates, and have no resource but clandestine matrimony, or\r\ncharcoal. Now the question is, what\xe2\x80\x99s to be done?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What have _you _done?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98_I!_\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I mean what did you do when your married daughter told you this?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I made a fool of myself of course,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Wardle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just so,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Perker, who had accompanied this dialogue with\r\nsundry twitchings of his watch-chain, vindictive rubbings of his nose,\r\nand other symptoms of impatience. \xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s very natural; but how?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I went into a great passion and frightened my mother into a fit,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nWardle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That was judicious,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Perker; \xe2\x80\x98and what else?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I fretted and fumed all next day, and raised a great disturbance,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nrejoined the old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98At last I got tired of rendering myself\r\nunpleasant and making everybody miserable; so I hired a carriage at\r\nMuggleton, and, putting my own horses in it, came up to town, under\r\npretence of bringing Emily to see Arabella.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Miss Wardle is with you, then?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be sure she is,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98She is at Osborne\xe2\x80\x99s Hotel in the\r\nAdelphi at this moment, unless your enterprising friend has run away\r\nwith her since I came out this morning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are reconciled then?\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a bit of it,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Wardle; \xe2\x80\x98she has been crying and moping ever\r\nsince, except last night, between tea and supper, when she made a great\r\nparade of writing a letter that I pretended to take no notice of.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You want my advice in this matter, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker, looking\r\nfrom the musing face of Mr. Pickwick to the eager countenance of Wardle,\r\nand taking several consecutive pinches of his favourite stimulant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle, looking at Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly,\xe2\x80\x99 replied that gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Perker, rising and pushing his chair back, \xe2\x80\x98my advice\r\nis, that you both walk away together, or ride away, or get away by some\r\nmeans or other, for I\xe2\x80\x99m tired of you, and just talk this matter over\r\nbetween you. If you have not settled it by the next time I see you, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ntell you what to do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is satisfactory,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle, hardly knowing whether to smile or\r\nbe offended.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pooh, pooh, my dear Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Perker. \xe2\x80\x98I know you both a great\r\ndeal better than you know yourselves. You have settled it already, to\r\nall intents and purposes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThus expressing himself, the little gentleman poked his snuff-box first\r\ninto the chest of Mr. Pickwick, and then into the waistcoat of Mr.\r\nWardle, upon which they all three laughed, especially the two last-named\r\ngentlemen, who at once shook hands again, without any obvious or\r\nparticular reason.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You dine with me to-day,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle to Perker, as he showed them out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can\xe2\x80\x99t promise, my dear Sir, can\xe2\x80\x99t promise,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Perker. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll look\r\nin, in the evening, at all events.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall expect you at five,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98Now, Joe!\xe2\x80\x99 And Joe having\r\nbeen at length awakened, the two friends departed in Mr. Wardle\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncarriage, which in common humanity had a dickey behind for the fat boy,\r\nwho, if there had been a footboard instead, would have rolled off and\r\nkilled himself in his very first nap.\r\n\r\nDriving to the George and Vulture, they found that Arabella and her maid\r\nhad sent for a hackney-coach immediately on the receipt of a short note\r\nfrom Emily announcing her arrival in town, and had proceeded straight to\r\nthe Adelphi. As Wardle had business to transact in the city, they sent\r\nthe carriage and the fat boy to his hotel, with the information that he\r\nand Mr. Pickwick would return together to dinner at five o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\r\n\r\nCharged with this message, the fat boy returned, slumbering as peaceably\r\nin his dickey, over the stones, as if it had been a down bed on watch\r\nsprings. By some extraordinary miracle he awoke of his own accord, when\r\nthe coach stopped, and giving himself a good shake to stir up his\r\nfaculties, went upstairs to execute his commission.\r\n\r\nNow, whether the shake had jumbled the fat boy\xe2\x80\x99s faculties together,\r\ninstead of arranging them in proper order, or had roused such a quantity\r\nof new ideas within him as to render him oblivious of ordinary forms and\r\nceremonies, or (which is also possible) had proved unsuccessful in\r\npreventing his falling asleep as he ascended the stairs, it is an\r\nundoubted fact that he walked into the sitting-room without previously\r\nknocking at the door; and so beheld a gentleman with his arms clasping\r\nhis young mistress\xe2\x80\x99s waist, sitting very lovingly by her side on a sofa,\r\nwhile Arabella and her pretty handmaid feigned to be absorbed in looking\r\nout of a window at the other end of the room. At the sight of this\r\nphenomenon, the fat boy uttered an interjection, the ladies a scream,\r\nand the gentleman an oath, almost simultaneously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wretched creature, what do you want here?\xe2\x80\x99 said the gentleman, who it\r\nis needless to say was Mr. Snodgrass.\r\n\r\nTo this the fat boy, considerably terrified, briefly responded,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Missis.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you want me for,\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Emily, turning her head aside, \xe2\x80\x98you\r\nstupid creature?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Master and Mr. Pickwick is a-going to dine here at five,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the\r\nfat boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Leave the room!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Snodgrass, glaring upon the bewildered youth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no, no,\xe2\x80\x99 added Emily hastily. \xe2\x80\x98Bella, dear, advise me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nUpon this, Emily and Mr. Snodgrass, and Arabella and Mary, crowded into\r\na corner, and conversed earnestly in whispers for some minutes, during\r\nwhich the fat boy dozed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Joe,\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella, at length, looking round with a most bewitching\r\nsmile, \xe2\x80\x98how do you do, Joe?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Joe,\xe2\x80\x99 said Emily, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99re a very good boy; I won\xe2\x80\x99t forget you, Joe.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Joe,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Snodgrass, advancing to the astonished youth, and\r\nseizing his hand, \xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know you before. There\xe2\x80\x99s five shillings for\r\nyou, Joe!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll owe you five, Joe,\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella, \xe2\x80\x98for old acquaintance sake, you\r\nknow;\xe2\x80\x99 and another most captivating smile was bestowed upon the\r\ncorpulent intruder.\r\n\r\nThe fat boy\xe2\x80\x99s perception being slow, he looked rather puzzled at first\r\nto account for this sudden prepossession in his favour, and stared about\r\nhim in a very alarming manner. At length his broad face began to show\r\nsymptoms of a grin of proportionately broad dimensions; and then,\r\nthrusting half-a-crown into each of his pockets, and a hand and wrist\r\nafter it, he burst into a horse laugh: being for the first and only time\r\nin his existence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He understands us, I see,\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He had better have something to eat, immediately,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Emily.\r\n\r\nThe fat boy almost laughed again when he heard this suggestion. Mary,\r\nafter a little more whispering, tripped forth from the group and said--\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am going to dine with you to-day, sir, if you have no objection.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This way,\xe2\x80\x99 said the fat boy eagerly. \xe2\x80\x98There is such a jolly meat-pie!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith these words, the fat boy led the way downstairs; his pretty\r\ncompanion captivating all the waiters and angering all the chambermaids\r\nas she followed him to the eating-room.\r\n\r\nThere was the meat-pie of which the youth had spoken so feelingly, and\r\nthere were, moreover, a steak, and a dish of potatoes, and a pot of\r\nporter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sit down,\xe2\x80\x99 said the fat boy. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, my eye, how prime! I am _so_ hungry.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHaving apostrophised his eye, in a species of rapture, five or six\r\ntimes, the youth took the head of the little table, and Mary seated\r\nherself at the bottom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you have some of this?\xe2\x80\x99 said the fat boy, plunging into the pie up\r\nto the very ferules of the knife and fork.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A little, if you please,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mary.\r\n\r\nThe fat boy assisted Mary to a little, and himself to a great deal, and\r\nwas just going to begin eating when he suddenly laid down his knife and\r\nfork, leaned forward in his chair, and letting his hands, with the knife\r\nand fork in them, fall on his knees, said, very slowly--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say! How nice you look!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis was said in an admiring manner, and was, so far, gratifying; but\r\nstill there was enough of the cannibal in the young gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s eyes to\r\nrender the compliment a double one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me, Joseph,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary, affecting to blush, \xe2\x80\x98what do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe fat boy, gradually recovering his former position, replied with a\r\nheavy sigh, and, remaining thoughtful for a few moments, drank a long\r\ndraught of the porter. Having achieved this feat, he sighed again, and\r\napplied himself assiduously to the pie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What a nice young lady Miss Emily is!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary, after a long silence.\r\n\r\nThe fat boy had by this time finished the pie. He fixed his eyes on\r\nMary, and replied--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I knows a nicerer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, indeed!\xe2\x80\x99 replied the fat boy, with unwonted vivacity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s her name?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s yours?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mary.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So\xe2\x80\x99s hers,\xe2\x80\x99 said the fat boy. \xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re her.\xe2\x80\x99 The boy grinned to add\r\npoint to the compliment, and put his eyes into something between a\r\nsquint and a cast, which there is reason to believe he intended for an\r\nogle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You mustn\xe2\x80\x99t talk to me in that way,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary; \xe2\x80\x98you don\xe2\x80\x99t mean it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t I, though?\xe2\x80\x99 replied the fat boy. \xe2\x80\x98I say?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you going to come here regular?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mary, shaking her head, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m going away again to-night.\r\nWhy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh,\xe2\x80\x99 said the fat boy, in a tone of strong feeling; \xe2\x80\x98how we should have\r\nenjoyed ourselves at meals, if you had been!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I might come here sometimes, perhaps, to see you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary, plaiting\r\nthe table-cloth in assumed coyness, \xe2\x80\x98if you would do me a favour.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe fat boy looked from the pie-dish to the steak, as if he thought a\r\nfavour must be in a manner connected with something to eat; and then\r\ntook out one of the half-crowns and glanced at it nervously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you understand me?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary, looking slily in his fat face.\r\n\r\nAgain he looked at the half-crown, and said faintly, \xe2\x80\x98No.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The ladies want you not to say anything to the old gentleman about the\r\nyoung gentleman having been upstairs; and I want you too.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is that all?\xe2\x80\x99 said the fat boy, evidently very much relieved, as he\r\npocketed the half-crown again. \xe2\x80\x98Of course I ain\xe2\x80\x99t a-going to.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You see,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary, \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Snodgrass is very fond of Miss Emily, and\r\nMiss Emily\xe2\x80\x99s very fond of him, and if you were to tell about it, the old\r\ngentleman would carry you all away miles into the country, where you\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nsee nobody.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no, I won\xe2\x80\x99t tell,\xe2\x80\x99 said the fat boy stoutly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s a dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary. \xe2\x80\x98Now it\xe2\x80\x99s time I went upstairs, and got my\r\nlady ready for dinner.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t go yet,\xe2\x80\x99 urged the fat boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mary. \xe2\x80\x98Good-bye, for the present.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe fat boy, with elephantine playfulness, stretched out his arms to\r\nravish a kiss; but as it required no great agility to elude him, his\r\nfair enslaver had vanished before he closed them again; upon which the\r\napathetic youth ate a pound or so of steak with a sentimental\r\ncountenance, and fell fast asleep.\r\n\r\nThere was so much to say upstairs, and there were so many plans to\r\nconcert for elopement and matrimony in the event of old Wardle\r\ncontinuing to be cruel, that it wanted only half an hour of dinner when\r\nMr. Snodgrass took his final adieu. The ladies ran to Emily\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom to\r\ndress, and the lover, taking up his hat, walked out of the room. He had\r\nscarcely got outside the door, when he heard Wardle\xe2\x80\x99s voice talking\r\nloudly, and looking over the banisters beheld him, followed by some\r\nother gentlemen, coming straight upstairs. Knowing nothing of the house,\r\nMr. Snodgrass in his confusion stepped hastily back into the room he had\r\njust quitted, and passing thence into an inner apartment (Mr. Wardle\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbedchamber), closed the door softly, just as the persons he had caught a\r\nglimpse of entered the sitting-room. These were Mr. Wardle, Mr.\r\nPickwick, Mr. Nathaniel Winkle, and Mr. Benjamin Allen, whom he had no\r\ndifficulty in recognising by their voices.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very lucky I had the presence of mind to avoid them,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr.\r\nSnodgrass with a smile, and walking on tiptoe to another door near the\r\nbedside; \xe2\x80\x98this opens into the same passage, and I can walk quietly and\r\ncomfortably away.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was only one obstacle to his walking quietly and comfortably away,\r\nwhich was that the door was locked and the key gone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let us have some of your best wine to-day, waiter,\xe2\x80\x99 said old Wardle,\r\nrubbing his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You shall have some of the very best, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the waiter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let the ladies know we have come in.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDevoutly and ardently did Mr. Snodgrass wish that the ladies could know\r\nhe had come in. He ventured once to whisper, \xe2\x80\x98Waiter!\xe2\x80\x99 through the\r\nkeyhole, but the probability of the wrong waiter coming to his relief,\r\nflashed upon his mind, together with a sense of the strong resemblance\r\nbetween his own situation and that in which another gentleman had been\r\nrecently found in a neighbouring hotel (an account of whose misfortunes\r\nhad appeared under the head of \xe2\x80\x98Police\xe2\x80\x99 in that morning\xe2\x80\x99s paper), he sat\r\nhimself on a portmanteau, and trembled violently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We won\xe2\x80\x99t wait a minute for Perker,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle, looking at his watch;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98he is always exact. He will be here, in time, if he means to come; and\r\nif he does not, it\xe2\x80\x99s of no use waiting. Ha! Arabella!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My sister!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Benjamin Allen, folding her in a most\r\nromantic embrace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Ben, dear, how you do smell of tobacco,\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella, rather\r\novercome by this mark of affection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do I?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Benjamin Allen. \xe2\x80\x98Do I, Bella? Well, perhaps I do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPerhaps he did, having just left a pleasant little smoking-party of\r\ntwelve medical students, in a small back parlour with a large fire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I am delighted to see you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Ben Allen. \xe2\x80\x98Bless you, Bella!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There,\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella, bending forward to kiss her brother; \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t take\r\nhold of me again, Ben, dear, because you tumble me so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt this point of the reconciliation, Mr. Ben Allen allowed his feelings\r\nand the cigars and porter to overcome him, and looked round upon the\r\nbeholders with damp spectacles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is nothing to be said to me?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Wardle, with open arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A great deal,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Arabella, as she received the old gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhearty caress and congratulation. \xe2\x80\x98You are a hard-hearted, unfeeling,\r\ncruel monster.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are a little rebel,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wardle, in the same tone, \xe2\x80\x98and I am\r\nafraid I shall be obliged to forbid you the house. People like you, who\r\nget married in spite of everybody, ought not to be let loose on society.\r\nBut come!\xe2\x80\x99 added the old gentleman aloud, \xe2\x80\x98here\xe2\x80\x99s the dinner; you shall\r\nsit by me. Joe; why, damn the boy, he\xe2\x80\x99s awake!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nTo the great distress of his master, the fat boy was indeed in a state\r\nof remarkable vigilance, his eyes being wide open, and looking as if\r\nthey intended to remain so. There was an alacrity in his manner, too,\r\nwhich was equally unaccountable; every time his eyes met those of Emily\r\nor Arabella, he smirked and grinned; once, Wardle could have sworn, he\r\nsaw him wink.\r\n\r\nThis alteration in the fat boy\xe2\x80\x99s demeanour originated in his increased\r\nsense of his own importance, and the dignity he acquired from having\r\nbeen taken into the confidence of the young ladies; and the smirks, and\r\ngrins, and winks were so many condescending assurances that they might\r\ndepend upon his fidelity. As these tokens were rather calculated to\r\nawaken suspicion than allay it, and were somewhat embarrassing besides,\r\nthey were occasionally answered by a frown or shake of the head from\r\nArabella, which the fat boy, considering as hints to be on his guard,\r\nexpressed his perfect understanding of, by smirking, grinning, and\r\nwinking, with redoubled assiduity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Joe,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Wardle, after an unsuccessful search in all his pockets,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98is my snuff-box on the sofa?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the fat boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I recollect; I left it on my dressing-table this morning,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nWardle. \xe2\x80\x98Run into the next room and fetch it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe fat boy went into the next room; and, having been absent about a\r\nminute, returned with the snuff-box, and the palest face that ever a fat\r\nboy wore.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with the boy?\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Wardle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothen\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with me,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Joe nervously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you been seeing any spirits?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the old gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Or taking any?\xe2\x80\x99 added Ben Allen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think you\xe2\x80\x99re right,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Wardle across the table. \xe2\x80\x98He is\r\nintoxicated, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBen Allen replied that he thought he was; and, as that gentleman had\r\nseen a vast deal of the disease in question, Wardle was confirmed in an\r\nimpression which had been hovering about his mind for half an hour, and\r\nat once arrived at the conclusion that the fat boy was drunk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just keep your eye upon him for a few minutes,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98We\r\nshall soon find out whether he is or not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe unfortunate youth had only interchanged a dozen words with Mr.\r\nSnodgrass, that gentleman having implored him to make a private appeal\r\nto some friend to release him, and then pushed him out with the snuff-\r\nbox, lest his prolonged absence should lead to a discovery. He ruminated\r\na little with a most disturbed expression of face, and left the room in\r\nsearch of Mary.\r\n\r\nBut Mary had gone home after dressing her mistress, and the fat boy came\r\nback again more disturbed than before.\r\n\r\nWardle and Mr. Ben Allen exchanged glances.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Joe!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What did you go away for?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe fat boy looked hopelessly in the face of everybody at table, and\r\nstammered out that he didn\xe2\x80\x99t know.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle, \xe2\x80\x98you don\xe2\x80\x99t know, eh? Take this cheese to Mr.\r\nPickwick.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNow, Mr. Pickwick being in the very best health and spirits, had been\r\nmaking himself perfectly delightful all dinner-time, and was at this\r\nmoment engaged in an energetic conversation with Emily and Mr. Winkle;\r\nbowing his head, courteously, in the emphasis of his discourse, gently\r\nwaving his left hand to lend force to his observations, and all glowing\r\nwith placid smiles. He took a piece of cheese from the plate, and was on\r\nthe point of turning round to renew the conversation, when the fat boy,\r\nstooping so as to bring his head on a level with that of Mr. Pickwick,\r\npointed with his thumb over his shoulder, and made the most horrible and\r\nhideous face that was ever seen out of a Christmas pantomime.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, starting, \xe2\x80\x98what a very--Eh?\xe2\x80\x99 He stopped,\r\nfor the fat boy had drawn himself up, and was, or pretended to be, fast\r\nasleep.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Wardle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is such an extremely singular lad!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, looking\r\nuneasily at the boy. \xe2\x80\x98It seems an odd thing to say, but upon my word I\r\nam afraid that, at times, he is a little deranged.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! Mr. Pickwick, pray don\xe2\x80\x99t say so,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Emily and Arabella, both at\r\nonce.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not certain, of course,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, amidst profound\r\nsilence and looks of general dismay; \xe2\x80\x98but his manner to me this moment\r\nreally was very alarming. Oh!\xe2\x80\x99 ejaculated Mr. Pickwick, suddenly jumping\r\nup with a short scream. \xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon, ladies, but at that moment\r\nhe ran some sharp instrument into my leg. Really, he is not safe.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s drunk,\xe2\x80\x99 roared old Wardle passionately. \xe2\x80\x98Ring the bell! Call the\r\nwaiters! He\xe2\x80\x99s drunk.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I ain\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 said the fat boy, falling on his knees as his master seized\r\nhim by the collar. \xe2\x80\x98I ain\xe2\x80\x99t drunk.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you\xe2\x80\x99re mad; that\xe2\x80\x99s worse. Call the waiters,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old\r\ngentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I ain\xe2\x80\x99t mad; I\xe2\x80\x99m sensible,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined the fat boy, beginning to cry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then, what the devil did you run sharp instruments into Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlegs for?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Wardle angrily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t look at me,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the boy. \xe2\x80\x98I wanted to speak to him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What did you want to say?\xe2\x80\x99 asked half a dozen voices at once.\r\n\r\nThe fat boy gasped, looked at the bedroom door, gasped again, and wiped\r\ntwo tears away with the knuckle of each of his forefingers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What did you want to say?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded Wardle, shaking him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98allow me. What did you wish to communicate\r\nto me, my poor boy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I want to whisper to you,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the fat boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You want to bite his ear off, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t come near\r\nhim; he\xe2\x80\x99s vicious; ring the bell, and let him be taken downstairs.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJust as Mr. Winkle caught the bell-rope in his hand, it was arrested by\r\na general expression of astonishment; the captive lover, his face\r\nburning with confusion, suddenly walked in from the bedroom, and made a\r\ncomprehensive bow to the company.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hollo!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Wardle, releasing the fat boy\xe2\x80\x99s collar, and staggering\r\nback. \xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s this?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have been concealed in the next room, sir, since you returned,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nexplained Mr. Snodgrass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Emily, my girl,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle reproachfully, \xe2\x80\x98I detest meanness and\r\ndeceit; this is unjustifiable and indelicate in the highest degree. I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t deserve this at your hands, Emily, indeed!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear papa,\xe2\x80\x99 said Emily, \xe2\x80\x98Arabella knows--everybody here knows--Joe\r\nknows--that I was no party to this concealment. Augustus, for Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsake, explain it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Snodgrass, who had only waited for a hearing, at once recounted how\r\nhe had been placed in his then distressing predicament; how the fear of\r\ngiving rise to domestic dissensions had alone prompted him to avoid Mr.\r\nWardle on his entrance; how he merely meant to depart by another door,\r\nbut, finding it locked, had been compelled to stay against his will. It\r\nwas a painful situation to be placed in; but he now regretted it the\r\nless, inasmuch as it afforded him an opportunity of acknowledging,\r\nbefore their mutual friends, that he loved Mr. Wardle\xe2\x80\x99s daughter deeply\r\nand sincerely; that he was proud to avow that the feeling was mutual;\r\nand that if thousands of miles were placed between them, or oceans\r\nrolled their waters, he could never for an instant forget those happy\r\ndays, when first--et cetera, et cetera.\r\n\r\nHaving delivered himself to this effect, Mr. Snodgrass bowed again,\r\nlooked into the crown of his hat, and stepped towards the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop!\xe2\x80\x99 shouted Wardle. \xe2\x80\x98Why, in the name of all that\xe2\x80\x99s--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Inflammable,\xe2\x80\x99 mildly suggested Mr. Pickwick, who thought something\r\nworse was coming.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well--that\xe2\x80\x99s inflammable,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wardle, adopting the substitute;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98couldn\xe2\x80\x99t you say all this to me in the first instance?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Or confide in me?\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear, dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella, taking up the defence, \xe2\x80\x98what is the use of\r\nasking all that now, especially when you know you had set your covetous\r\nold heart on a richer son-in-law, and are so wild and fierce besides,\r\nthat everybody is afraid of you, except me? Shake hands with him, and\r\norder him some dinner, for goodness gracious\xe2\x80\x99 sake, for he looks half\r\nstarved; and pray have your wine up at once, for you\xe2\x80\x99ll not be tolerable\r\nuntil you have taken two bottles at least.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe worthy old gentleman pulled Arabella\xe2\x80\x99s ear, kissed her without the\r\nsmallest scruple, kissed his daughter also with great affection, and\r\nshook Mr. Snodgrass warmly by the hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She is right on one point at all events,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman\r\ncheerfully. \xe2\x80\x98Ring for the wine!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe wine came, and Perker came upstairs at the same moment. Mr.\r\nSnodgrass had dinner at a side table, and, when he had despatched it,\r\ndrew his chair next Emily, without the smallest opposition on the old\r\ngentleman\xe2\x80\x99s part.\r\n\r\nThe evening was excellent.
