Little Mr. Perker came out wonderfully, told\r\nvarious comic stories, and sang a serious song which was almost as funny\r\nas the anecdotes. Arabella was very charming, Mr. Wardle very jovial,\r\nMr. Pickwick very harmonious, Mr. Ben Allen very uproarious, the lovers\r\nvery silent, Mr. Winkle very talkative, and all of them very happy.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LV. MR. SOLOMON PELL, ASSISTED BY A SELECT COMMITTEE OF\r\nCOACHMEN, ARRANGES THE AFFAIRS OF THE ELDER MR. WELLER\r\n\r\nSamivel,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, accosting his son on the morning after the\r\nfuneral, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve found it, Sammy. I thought it wos there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thought wot wos there?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your mother-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s vill, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98In wirtue o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nvich, them arrangements is to be made as I told you on, last night,\r\nrespectin\xe2\x80\x99 the funs.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot, didn\xe2\x80\x99t she tell you were it wos?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a bit on it, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98We wos a adjestin\xe2\x80\x99 our\r\nlittle differences, and I wos a-cheerin\xe2\x80\x99 her spirits and bearin\xe2\x80\x99 her up,\r\nso that I forgot to ask anythin\xe2\x80\x99 about it. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know as I should ha\xe2\x80\x99\r\ndone it, indeed, if I had remembered it,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98for it\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nrum sort o\xe2\x80\x99 thing, Sammy, to go a-hankerin\xe2\x80\x99 arter anybody\xe2\x80\x99s property,\r\nven you\xe2\x80\x99re assistin\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98em in illness. It\xe2\x80\x99s like helping an outside\r\npassenger up, ven he\xe2\x80\x99s been pitched off a coach, and puttin\xe2\x80\x99 your hand\r\nin his pocket, vile you ask him, vith a sigh, how he finds his-self,\r\nSammy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith this figurative illustration of his meaning, Mr. Weller unclasped\r\nhis pocket-book, and drew forth a dirty sheet of letter-paper, on which\r\nwere inscribed various characters crowded together in remarkable\r\nconfusion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This here is the dockyment, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98I found it in the\r\nlittle black tea-pot, on the top shelf o\xe2\x80\x99 the bar closet. She used to\r\nkeep bank-notes there, \xe2\x80\x98fore she vos married, Samivel. I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen her\r\ntake the lid off, to pay a bill, many and many a time. Poor creetur, she\r\nmight ha\xe2\x80\x99 filled all the tea-pots in the house vith vills, and not have\r\ninconwenienced herself neither, for she took wery little of anythin\xe2\x80\x99 in\r\nthat vay lately, \xe2\x80\x98cept on the temperance nights, ven they just laid a\r\nfoundation o\xe2\x80\x99 tea to put the spirits atop on!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What does it say?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Jist vot I told you, my boy,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined his parent. \xe2\x80\x98Two hundred pound\r\nvurth o\xe2\x80\x99 reduced counsels to my son-in-law, Samivel, and all the rest o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nmy property, of ev\xe2\x80\x99ry kind and description votsoever, to my husband, Mr.\r\nTony Veller, who I appint as my sole eggzekiter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s all, is it?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s all,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98And I s\xe2\x80\x99pose as it\xe2\x80\x99s all right and\r\nsatisfactory to you and me as is the only parties interested, ve may as\r\nvell put this bit o\xe2\x80\x99 paper into the fire.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot are you a-doin\xe2\x80\x99 on, you lunatic?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, snatching the paper\r\naway, as his parent, in all innocence, stirred the fire preparatory to\r\nsuiting the action to the word. \xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re a nice eggzekiter, you are.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vy not?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Weller, looking sternly round, with the poker in\r\nhis hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vy not?\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Sam. \xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Cos it must be proved, and probated, and\r\nswore to, and all manner o\xe2\x80\x99 formalities.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t mean that?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, laying down the poker.\r\n\r\nSam buttoned the will carefully in a side pocket; intimating by a look,\r\nmeanwhile, that he did mean it, and very seriously too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you wot it is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, after a short\r\nmeditation, \xe2\x80\x98this is a case for that \xe2\x80\x98ere confidential pal o\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\nChancellorship\xe2\x80\x99s. Pell must look into this, Sammy. He\xe2\x80\x99s the man for a\r\ndifficult question at law. Ve\xe2\x80\x99ll have this here brought afore the\r\nSolvent Court, directly, Samivel.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never did see such a addle-headed old creetur!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Sam\r\nirritably; \xe2\x80\x98Old Baileys, and Solvent Courts, and alleybis, and ev\xe2\x80\x99ry\r\nspecies o\xe2\x80\x99 gammon alvays a-runnin\xe2\x80\x99 through his brain. You\xe2\x80\x99d better get\r\nyour out o\xe2\x80\x99 door clothes on, and come to town about this bisness, than\r\nstand a-preachin\xe2\x80\x99 there about wot you don\xe2\x80\x99t understand nothin\xe2\x80\x99 on.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery good, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m quite agreeable to anythin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nas vill hexpedite business, Sammy. But mind this here, my boy, nobody\r\nbut Pell--nobody but Pell as a legal adwiser.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t want anybody else,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Now, are you a-comin\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vait a minit, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, who, having tied his shawl\r\nwith the aid of a small glass that hung in the window, was now, by dint\r\nof the most wonderful exertions, struggling into his upper garments.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vait a minit\xe2\x80\x99 Sammy; ven you grow as old as your father, you von\xe2\x80\x99t get\r\ninto your veskit quite as easy as you do now, my boy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get into it easier than that, I\xe2\x80\x99m blessed if I\xe2\x80\x99d vear vun\r\nat all,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined his son.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You think so now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, with the gravity of age, \xe2\x80\x98but\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll find that as you get vider, you\xe2\x80\x99ll get viser. Vidth and visdom,\r\nSammy, alvays grows together.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Mr. Weller delivered this infallible maxim--the result of many years\xe2\x80\x99\r\npersonal experience and observation--he contrived, by a dexterous twist\r\nof his body, to get the bottom button of his coat to perform its office.\r\nHaving paused a few seconds to recover breath, he brushed his hat with\r\nhis elbow, and declared himself ready.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As four heads is better than two, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, as they\r\ndrove along the London Road in the chaise-cart, \xe2\x80\x98and as all this here\r\nproperty is a wery great temptation to a legal gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n, ve\xe2\x80\x99ll take a\r\ncouple o\xe2\x80\x99 friends o\xe2\x80\x99 mine vith us, as\xe2\x80\x99ll be wery soon down upon him if\r\nhe comes anythin\xe2\x80\x99 irreg\xe2\x80\x99lar; two o\xe2\x80\x99 them as saw you to the Fleet that\r\nday. They\xe2\x80\x99re the wery best judges,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr. Weller, in a half-whisper-\r\n-\xe2\x80\x99the wery best judges of a horse, you ever know\xe2\x80\x99d.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And of a lawyer too?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The man as can form a ackerate judgment of a animal, can form a\r\nackerate judgment of anythin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x99 replied his father, so dogmatically,\r\nthat Sam did not attempt to controvert the position.\r\n\r\nIn pursuance of this notable resolution, the services of the mottled-\r\nfaced gentleman and of two other very fat coachmen--selected by Mr.\r\nWeller, probably, with a view to their width and consequent wisdom--were\r\nput into requisition; and this assistance having been secured, the party\r\nproceeded to the public-house in Portugal Street, whence a messenger was\r\ndespatched to the Insolvent Court over the way, requiring Mr. Solomon\r\nPell\xe2\x80\x99s immediate attendance.\r\n\r\nThe messenger fortunately found Mr. Solomon Pell in court, regaling\r\nhimself, business being rather slack, with a cold collation of an\r\nAbernethy biscuit and a saveloy. The message was no sooner whispered in\r\nhis ear than he thrust them in his pocket among various professional\r\ndocuments, and hurried over the way with such alacrity that he reached\r\nthe parlour before the messenger had even emancipated himself from the\r\ncourt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pell, touching his hat, \xe2\x80\x98my service to you all. I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t say it to flatter you, gentlemen, but there are not five other men\r\nin the world, that I\xe2\x80\x99d have come out of that court for, to-day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So busy, eh?\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Busy!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Pell; \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m completely sewn up, as my friend the late\r\nLord Chancellor many a time used to say to me, gentlemen, when he came\r\nout from hearing appeals in the House of Lords. Poor fellow; he was very\r\nsusceptible to fatigue; he used to feel those appeals uncommonly. I\r\nactually thought more than once that he\xe2\x80\x99d have sunk under \xe2\x80\x98em; I did,\r\nindeed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere Mr. Pell shook his head and paused; on which, the elder Mr. Weller,\r\nnudging his neighbour, as begging him to mark the attorney\xe2\x80\x99s high\r\nconnections, asked whether the duties in question produced any permanent\r\nill effects on the constitution of his noble friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think he ever quite recovered them,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Pell; \xe2\x80\x98in fact I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nsure he never did. \xe2\x80\x9cPell,\xe2\x80\x9d he used to say to me many a time, \xe2\x80\x9chow the\r\nblazes you can stand the head-work you do, is a mystery to me.\xe2\x80\x9d--\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n I used to answer, \xe2\x80\x9cI hardly know how I do it, upon my life.\xe2\x80\x9d--\xe2\x80\x9cPell,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n he\xe2\x80\x99d add, sighing, and looking at me with a little envy--friendly envy,\r\nyou know, gentlemen, mere friendly envy; I never minded it--\xe2\x80\x9cPell,\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99re a wonder; a wonder.\xe2\x80\x9d Ah! you\xe2\x80\x99d have liked him very much if you\r\nhad known him, gentlemen. Bring me three-penn\xe2\x80\x99orth of rum, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAddressing this latter remark to the waitress, in a tone of subdued\r\ngrief, Mr. Pell sighed, looked at his shoes and the ceiling; and, the\r\nrum having by that time arrived, drank it up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98However,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pell, drawing a chair to the table, \xe2\x80\x98a professional man\r\nhas no right to think of his private friendships when his legal\r\nassistance is wanted. By the bye, gentlemen, since I saw you here\r\nbefore, we have had to weep over a very melancholy occurrence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pell drew out a pocket-handkerchief, when he came to the word weep,\r\nbut he made no further use of it than to wipe away a slight tinge of rum\r\nwhich hung upon his upper lip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I saw it in the ADVERTISER, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Pell. \xe2\x80\x98Bless my\r\nsoul, not more than fifty-two! Dear me--only think.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThese indications of a musing spirit were addressed to the mottled-faced\r\nman, whose eyes Mr. Pell had accidentally caught; on which, the mottled-\r\nfaced man, whose apprehension of matters in general was of a foggy\r\nnature, moved uneasily in his seat, and opined that, indeed, so far as\r\nthat went, there was no saying how things was brought about; which\r\nobservation, involving one of those subtle propositions which it is\r\ndifficult to encounter in argument, was controverted by nobody.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have heard it remarked that she was a very fine woman, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Pell, in a sympathising manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, sir, she wos,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the elder Mr. Weller, not much relishing\r\nthis mode of discussing the subject, and yet thinking that the attorney,\r\nfrom his long intimacy with the late Lord Chancellor, must know best on\r\nall matters of polite breeding. \xe2\x80\x98She wos a wery fine \xe2\x80\x98ooman, sir, ven I\r\nfirst know\xe2\x80\x99d her. She wos a widder, sir, at that time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, it\xe2\x80\x99s curious,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pell, looking round with a sorrowful smile;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Pell was a widow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s very extraordinary,\xe2\x80\x99 said the mottled-faced man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, it is a curious coincidence,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all,\xe2\x80\x99 gruffly remarked the elder Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98More widders is\r\nmarried than single wimin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good, very good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pell, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99re quite right, Mr. Weller. Mrs.\r\nPell was a very elegant and accomplished woman; her manners were the\r\ntheme of universal admiration in our neighbourhood. I was proud to see\r\nthat woman dance; there was something so firm and dignified, and yet\r\nnatural, in her motion. Her cutting, gentlemen, was simplicity itself.\r\nAh! well, well! Excuse my asking the question, Mr. Samuel,\xe2\x80\x99 continued\r\nthe attorney in a lower voice, \xe2\x80\x98was your mother-in-law tall?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not wery,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Pell was a tall figure,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pell, \xe2\x80\x98a splendid woman, with a\r\nnoble shape, and a nose, gentlemen, formed to command and be majestic.\r\nShe was very much attached to me--very much--highly connected, too. Her\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s brother, gentlemen, failed for eight hundred pounds, as a law\r\nstationer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vell,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, who had grown rather restless during this\r\ndiscussion, \xe2\x80\x98vith regard to bis\xe2\x80\x99ness.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe word was music to Pell\xe2\x80\x99s ears. He had been revolving in his mind\r\nwhether any business was to be transacted, or whether he had been merely\r\ninvited to partake of a glass of brandy-and-water, or a bowl of punch,\r\nor any similar professional compliment, and now the doubt was set at\r\nrest without his appearing at all eager for its solution. His eyes\r\nglistened as he laid his hat on the table, and said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is the business upon which--um? Either of these gentlemen wish to\r\ngo through the court? We require an arrest; a friendly arrest will do,\r\nyou know; we are all friends here, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Give me the dockyment, Sammy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, taking the will from\r\nhis son, who appeared to enjoy the interview amazingly. \xe2\x80\x98Wot we rekvire,\r\nsir, is a probe o\xe2\x80\x99 this here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Probate, my dear Sir, probate,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller sharply, \xe2\x80\x98probe and probe it, is wery\r\nmuch the same; if you don\xe2\x80\x99t understand wot I mean, sir, I des-say I can\r\nfind them as does.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No offence, I hope, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pell meekly. \xe2\x80\x98You are the\r\nexecutor, I see,\xe2\x80\x99 he added, casting his eyes over the paper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98These other gentlemen, I presume, are legatees, are they?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired\r\nPell, with a congratulatory smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sammy is a leg-at-ease,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98these other gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n is\r\nfriends o\xe2\x80\x99 mine, just come to see fair; a kind of umpires.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99 said Pell, \xe2\x80\x98very good. I have no objections, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure. I shall\r\nwant a matter of five pound of you before I begin, ha! ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt being decided by the committee that the five pound might be advanced,\r\nMr. Weller produced that sum; after which, a long consultation about\r\nnothing particular took place, in the course whereof Mr. Pell\r\ndemonstrated to the perfect satisfaction of the gentlemen who saw fair,\r\nthat unless the management of the business had been intrusted to him, it\r\nmust all have gone wrong, for reasons not clearly made out, but no doubt\r\nsufficient. This important point being despatched, Mr. Pell refreshed\r\nhimself with three chops, and liquids both malt and spirituous, at the\r\nexpense of the estate; and then they all went away to Doctors\xe2\x80\x99 Commons.\r\n\r\nThe next day there was another visit to Doctors\xe2\x80\x99 Commons, and a great\r\nto-do with an attesting hostler, who, being inebriated, declined\r\nswearing anything but profane oaths, to the great scandal of a proctor\r\nand surrogate. Next week, there were more visits to Doctors\xe2\x80\x99 Commons,\r\nand there was a visit to the Legacy Duty Office besides, and there were\r\ntreaties entered into, for the disposal of the lease and business, and\r\nratifications of the same, and inventories to be made out, and lunches\r\nto be taken, and dinners to be eaten, and so many profitable things to\r\nbe done, and such a mass of papers accumulated that Mr. Solomon Pell,\r\nand the boy, and the blue bag to boot, all got so stout that scarcely\r\nanybody would have known them for the same man, boy, and bag, that had\r\nloitered about Portugal Street, a few days before.\r\n\r\nAt length all these weighty matters being arranged, a day was fixed for\r\nselling out and transferring the stock, and of waiting with that view\r\nupon Wilkins Flasher, Esquire, stock-broker, of somewhere near the bank,\r\nwho had been recommended by Mr. Solomon Pell for the purpose.\r\n\r\nIt was a kind of festive occasion, and the parties were attired\r\naccordingly. Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s tops were newly cleaned, and his dress was\r\narranged with peculiar care; the mottled-faced gentleman wore at his\r\nbutton-hole a full-sized dahlia with several leaves; and the coats of\r\nhis two friends were adorned with nosegays of laurel and other\r\nevergreens. All three were habited in strict holiday costume; that is to\r\nsay, they were wrapped up to the chins, and wore as many clothes as\r\npossible, which is, and has been, a stage-coachman\xe2\x80\x99s idea of full dress\r\never since stage-coaches were invented.\r\n\r\nMr. Pell was waiting at the usual place of meeting at the appointed\r\ntime; even he wore a pair of gloves and a clean shirt, much frayed at\r\nthe collar and wristbands by frequent washings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A quarter to two,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pell, looking at the parlour clock. \xe2\x80\x98If we are\r\nwith Mr. Flasher at a quarter past, we shall just hit the best time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What should you say to a drop o\xe2\x80\x99 beer, gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n?\xe2\x80\x99 suggested the\r\nmottled-faced man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And a little bit o\xe2\x80\x99 cold beef,\xe2\x80\x99 said the second coachman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Or a oyster,\xe2\x80\x99 added the third, who was a hoarse gentleman, supported by\r\nvery round legs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hear, hear!\xe2\x80\x99 said Pell; \xe2\x80\x98to congratulate Mr. Weller, on his coming into\r\npossession of his property, eh? Ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m quite agreeable, gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Sammy, pull the\r\nbell.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSammy complied; and the porter, cold beef, and oysters being promptly\r\nproduced, the lunch was done ample justice to. Where everybody took so\r\nactive a part, it is almost invidious to make a distinction; but if one\r\nindividual evinced greater powers than another, it was the coachman with\r\nthe hoarse voice, who took an imperial pint of vinegar with his oysters,\r\nwithout betraying the least emotion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pell, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the elder Mr. Weller, stirring a glass of brandy-\r\nand-water, of which one was placed before every gentleman when the\r\noyster shells were removed--\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pell, Sir, it wos my intention to have\r\nproposed the funs on this occasion, but Samivel has vispered to me--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere Mr. Samuel Weller, who had silently eaten his oysters with tranquil\r\nsmiles, cried, \xe2\x80\x98Hear!\xe2\x80\x99 in a very loud voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--Has vispered to me,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed his father, \xe2\x80\x98that it vould be better to\r\ndewote the liquor to vishin\xe2\x80\x99 you success and prosperity, and thankin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nyou for the manner in which you\xe2\x80\x99ve brought this here business through.\r\nHere\xe2\x80\x99s your health, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hold hard there,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed the mottled-faced gentleman, with sudden\r\nenergy; \xe2\x80\x98your eyes on me, gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x99n!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\nSaying this, the mottled-faced gentleman rose, as did the other\r\ngentlemen. The mottled-faced gentleman reviewed the company, and slowly\r\nlifted his hand, upon which every man (including him of the mottled\r\ncountenance) drew a long breath, and lifted his tumbler to his lips. In\r\none instant, the mottled-faced gentleman depressed his hand again, and\r\nevery glass was set down empty. It is impossible to describe the\r\nthrilling effect produced by this striking ceremony. At once dignified,\r\nsolemn, and impressive, it combined every element of grandeur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pell, \xe2\x80\x98all I can say is, that such marks of\r\nconfidence must be very gratifying to a professional man. I don\xe2\x80\x99t wish\r\nto say anything that might appear egotistical, gentlemen, but I\xe2\x80\x99m very\r\nglad, for your own sakes, that you came to me; that\xe2\x80\x99s all. If you had\r\ngone to any low member of the profession, it\xe2\x80\x99s my firm conviction, and I\r\nassure you of it as a fact, that you would have found yourselves in\r\nQueer Street before this. I could have wished my noble friend had been\r\nalive to have seen my management of this case. I don\xe2\x80\x99t say it out of\r\npride, but I think--However, gentlemen, I won\xe2\x80\x99t trouble you with that.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m generally to be found here, gentlemen, but if I\xe2\x80\x99m not here, or over\r\nthe way, that\xe2\x80\x99s my address. You\xe2\x80\x99ll find my terms very cheap and\r\nreasonable, and no man attends more to his clients than I do, and I hope\r\nI know a little of my profession besides. If you have any opportunity of\r\nrecommending me to any of your friends, gentlemen, I shall be very much\r\nobliged to you, and so will they too, when they come to know me. Your\r\nhealths, gentlemen.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith this expression of his feelings, Mr. Solomon Pell laid three small\r\nwritten cards before Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s friends, and, looking at the clock\r\nagain, feared it was time to be walking. Upon this hint Mr. Weller\r\nsettled the bill, and, issuing forth, the executor, legatee, attorney,\r\nand umpires, directed their steps towards the city.\r\n\r\nThe office of Wilkins Flasher, Esquire, of the Stock Exchange, was in a\r\nfirst floor up a court behind the Bank of England; the house of Wilkins\r\nFlasher, Esquire, was at Brixton, Surrey; the horse and stanhope of\r\nWilkins Flasher, Esquire, were at an adjacent livery stable; the groom\r\nof Wilkins Flasher, Esquire, was on his way to the West End to deliver\r\nsome game; the clerk of Wilkins Flasher, Esquire, had gone to his\r\ndinner; and so Wilkins Flasher, Esquire, himself, cried, \xe2\x80\x98Come in,\xe2\x80\x99 when\r\nMr. Pell and his companions knocked at the counting-house door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-morning, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pell, bowing obsequiously. \xe2\x80\x98We want to make a\r\nlittle transfer, if you please.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, just come in, will you?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Flasher. \xe2\x80\x98Sit down a minute; I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nattend to you directly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pell, \xe2\x80\x98there\xe2\x80\x99s no hurry. Take a chair, Mr.\r\nWeller.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller took a chair, and Sam took a box, and the umpires took what\r\nthey could get, and looked at the almanac and one or two papers which\r\nwere wafered against the wall, with as much open-eyed reverence as if\r\nthey had been the finest efforts of the old masters.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, I\xe2\x80\x99ll bet you half a dozen of claret on it; come!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wilkins\r\nFlasher, Esquire, resuming the conversation to which Mr. Pell\xe2\x80\x99s entrance\r\nhad caused a momentary interruption.\r\n\r\nThis was addressed to a very smart young gentleman who wore his hat on\r\nhis right whisker, and was lounging over the desk, killing flies with a\r\nruler. Wilkins Flasher, Esquire, was balancing himself on two legs of an\r\noffice stool, spearing a wafer-box with a penknife, which he dropped\r\nevery now and then with great dexterity into the very centre of a small\r\nred wafer that was stuck outside. Both gentlemen had very open\r\nwaistcoats and very rolling collars, and very small boots, and very big\r\nrings, and very little watches, and very large guard-chains, and\r\nsymmetrical inexpressibles, and scented pocket-handkerchiefs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never bet half a dozen!\xe2\x80\x99 said the other gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll take a\r\ndozen.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Done, Simmery, done!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wilkins Flasher, Esquire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98P. P., mind,\xe2\x80\x99 observed the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wilkins Flasher, Esquire. Wilkins Flasher, Esquire,\r\nentered it in a little book, with a gold pencil-case, and the other\r\ngentleman entered it also, in another little book with another gold\r\npencil-case.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see there\xe2\x80\x99s a notice up this morning about Boffer,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Mr.\r\nSimmery. \xe2\x80\x98Poor devil, he\xe2\x80\x99s expelled the house!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll bet you ten guineas to five, he cuts his throat,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wilkins\r\nFlasher, Esquire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Done,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Simmery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop! I bar,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wilkins Flasher, Esquire, thoughtfully. \xe2\x80\x98Perhaps he\r\nmay hang himself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Simmery, pulling out the gold pencil-case\r\nagain. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve no objection to take you that way. Say, makes away with\r\nhimself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Kills himself, in fact,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wilkins Flasher, Esquire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just so,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Simmery, putting it down. \xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cFlasher--ten guineas\r\nto five, Boffer kills himself.\xe2\x80\x9d Within what time shall we say?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A fortnight?\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Wilkins Flasher, Esquire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Con-found it, no,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Simmery, stopping for an instant to\r\nsmash a fly with the ruler. \xe2\x80\x98Say a week.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Split the difference,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wilkins Flasher, Esquire. \xe2\x80\x98Make it ten\r\ndays.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well; ten days,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Simmery.\r\n\r\nSo it was entered down on the little books that Boffer was to kill\r\nhimself within ten days, or Wilkins Flasher, Esquire, was to hand over\r\nto Frank Simmery, Esquire, the sum of ten guineas; and that if Boffer\r\ndid kill himself within that time, Frank Simmery, Esquire, would pay to\r\nWilkins Flasher, Esquire, five guineas, instead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m very sorry he has failed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wilkins Flasher, Esquire. \xe2\x80\x98Capital\r\ndinners he gave.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fine port he had are!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wilkins Flasher, Esquire. \xe2\x80\x98My man\xe2\x80\x99s going too.\r\nFive guineas my man outbids your man.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Done.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAnother entry was made in the little books, with the gold pencil-cases;\r\nand Mr. Simmery, having by this time killed all the flies and taken all\r\nthe bets, strolled away to the Stock Exchange to see what was going\r\nforward.\r\n\r\nWilkins Flasher, Esquire, now condescended to receive Mr. Solomon Pell\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninstructions, and having filled up some printed forms, requested the\r\nparty to disturb.\r\n\r\nCrossing a courtyard which was all noise and bustle, and passing a\r\ncouple of porters who seemed dressed to match the red fire engine which\r\nwas wheeled away into a corner, they passed into an office where their\r\nbusiness was to be transacted, and where Pell and Mr. Flasher left them\r\nstanding for a few moments, while they went upstairs into the Will\r\nOffice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot place is this here?\xe2\x80\x99 whispered the mottled-faced gentleman to the\r\nelder Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Counsel\xe2\x80\x99s Office,\xe2\x80\x99
