Samivel?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wy, you don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose the reduced counsels is alive, do you?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired\r\nSam, with some disdain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How should I know?\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98I thought they looked wery\r\nlike it. Wot are they, then?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Clerks,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot are they all a-eatin\xe2\x80\x99 ham sangwidges for?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired his father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Cos it\xe2\x80\x99s in their dooty, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s a part o\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\nsystem; they\xe2\x80\x99re alvays a-doin\xe2\x80\x99 it here, all day long!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller and his friends had scarcely had a moment to reflect upon\r\nthis singular regulation as connected with the monetary system of the\r\ncountry, when they were rejoined by Pell and Wilkins Flasher, Esquire,\r\nwho led them to a part of the counter above which was a round blackboard\r\nwith a large \xe2\x80\x98W.\xe2\x80\x99 on it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot\xe2\x80\x99s that for, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Weller, directing Pell\xe2\x80\x99s attention\r\nto the target in question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The first letter of the name of the deceased,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Pell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, turning round to the umpires, there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsomethin\xe2\x80\x99 wrong here. We\xe2\x80\x99s our letter--this won\xe2\x80\x99t do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe referees at once gave it as their decided opinion that the business\r\ncould not be legally proceeded with, under the letter W., and in all\r\nprobability it would have stood over for one day at least, had it not\r\nbeen for the prompt, though, at first sight, undutiful behaviour of Sam,\r\nwho, seizing his father by the skirt of the coat, dragged him to the\r\ncounter, and pinned him there, until he had affixed his signature to a\r\ncouple of instruments; which, from Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s habit of printing, was a\r\nwork of so much labour and time, that the officiating clerk peeled and\r\nate three Ribstone pippins while it was performing.\r\n\r\nAs the elder Mr. Weller insisted on selling out his portion forthwith,\r\nthey proceeded from the bank to the gate of the Stock Exchange, to which\r\nWilkins Flasher, Esquire, after a short absence, returned with a cheque\r\non Smith, Payne, & Smith, for five hundred and thirty pounds; that being\r\nthe money to which Mr. Weller, at the market price of the day, was\r\nentitled, in consideration of the balance of the second Mrs. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfunded savings. Sam\xe2\x80\x99s two hundred pounds stood transferred to his name,\r\nand Wilkins Flasher, Esquire, having been paid his commission, dropped\r\nthe money carelessly into his coat pocket, and lounged back to his\r\noffice.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller was at first obstinately determined on cashing the cheque in\r\nnothing but sovereigns; but it being represented by the umpires that by\r\nso doing he must incur the expense of a small sack to carry them home\r\nin, he consented to receive the amount in five-pound notes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My son,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, as they came out of the banking-house--\xe2\x80\x98my\r\nson and me has a wery partickler engagement this arternoon, and I should\r\nlike to have this here bis\xe2\x80\x99ness settled out of hand, so let\xe2\x80\x99s jest go\r\nstraight avay someveres, vere ve can hordit the accounts.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA quiet room was soon found, and the accounts were produced and audited.\r\nMr. Pell\xe2\x80\x99s bill was taxed by Sam, and some charges were disallowed by\r\nthe umpires; but, notwithstanding Mr. Pell\xe2\x80\x99s declaration, accompanied\r\nwith many solemn asseverations that they were really too hard upon him,\r\nit was by very many degrees the best professional job he had ever had,\r\nand one on which he boarded, lodged, and washed, for six months\r\nafterwards.\r\n\r\nThe umpires having partaken of a dram, shook hands and departed, as they\r\nhad to drive out of town that night. Mr. Solomon Pell, finding that\r\nnothing more was going forward, either in the eating or drinking way,\r\ntook a friendly leave, and Sam and his father were left alone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, thrusting his pocket-book in his side pocket.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vith the bills for the lease, and that, there\xe2\x80\x99s eleven hundred and\r\neighty pound here. Now, Samivel, my boy, turn the horses\xe2\x80\x99 heads to the\r\nGeorge and Wulter!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LVI. AN IMPORTANT CONFERENCE TAKES PLACE BETWEEN MR. PICKWICK\r\nAND SAMUEL WELLER, AT WHICH HIS PARENT ASSISTS--AN OLD GENTLEMAN IN A\r\nSNUFF-COLOURED SUIT ARRIVES UNEXPECTEDLY\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick was sitting alone, musing over many things, and thinking\r\namong other considerations how he could best provide for the young\r\ncouple whose present unsettled condition was matter of constant regret\r\nand anxiety to him, when Mary stepped lightly into the room, and,\r\nadvancing to the table, said, rather hastily--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, if you please, Sir, Samuel is downstairs, and he says may his\r\nfather see you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Surely,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary, tripping towards the door again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam has not been here long, has he?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, no, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mary eagerly. \xe2\x80\x98He has only just come home. He is\r\nnot going to ask you for any more leave, Sir, he says.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMary might have been conscious that she had communicated this last\r\nintelligence with more warmth than seemed actually necessary, or she\r\nmight have observed the good-humoured smile with which Mr. Pickwick\r\nregarded her, when she had finished speaking. She certainly held down\r\nher head, and examined the corner of a very smart little apron, with\r\nmore closeness than there appeared any absolute occasion for.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tell them they can come up at once, by all means,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\nMary, apparently much relieved, hurried away with her message.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick took two or three turns up and down the room; and, rubbing\r\nhis chin with his left hand as he did so, appeared lost in thought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, at length in a kind but somewhat\r\nmelancholy tone, \xe2\x80\x98it is the best way in which I could reward him for his\r\nattachment and fidelity; let it be so, in Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s name. It is the fate\r\nof a lonely old man, that those about him should form new and different\r\nattachments and leave him. I have no right to expect that it should be\r\notherwise with me. No, no,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr. Pickwick more cheerfully, \xe2\x80\x98it\r\nwould be selfish and ungrateful. I ought to be happy to have an\r\nopportunity of providing for him so well. I am. Of course I am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick had been so absorbed in these reflections, that a knock at\r\nthe door was three or four times repeated before he heard it. Hastily\r\nseating himself, and calling up his accustomed pleasant looks, he gave\r\nthe required permission, and Sam Weller entered, followed by his father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Glad to see you back again, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98How do you do,\r\nMr. Weller?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery hearty, thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the widower; \xe2\x80\x98hope I see you well,\r\nsir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite, I thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wanted to have a little bit o\xe2\x80\x99 conwersation with you, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nWeller, \xe2\x80\x98if you could spare me five minits or so, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Sam, give your father a chair.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, Samivel, I\xe2\x80\x99ve got a cheer here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, bringing\r\none forward as he spoke; \xe2\x80\x98uncommon fine day it\xe2\x80\x99s been, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 added the\r\nold gentleman, laying his hat on the floor as he sat himself down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Remarkably so, indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98Very seasonable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Seasonablest veather I ever see, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Weller. Here, the\r\nold gentleman was seized with a violent fit of coughing, which, being\r\nterminated, he nodded his head and winked and made several supplicatory\r\nand threatening gestures to his son, all of which Sam Weller steadily\r\nabstained from seeing.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick, perceiving that there was some embarrassment on the old\r\ngentleman\xe2\x80\x99s part, affected to be engaged in cutting the leaves of a book\r\nthat lay beside him, and waited patiently until Mr. Weller should arrive\r\nat the object of his visit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never see sich a aggrawatin\xe2\x80\x99 boy as you are, Samivel,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nWeller, looking indignantly at his son; \xe2\x80\x98never in all my born days.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is he doing, Mr. Weller?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He von\xe2\x80\x99t begin, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Weller; \xe2\x80\x98he knows I ain\xe2\x80\x99t ekal to\r\nex-pressin\xe2\x80\x99 myself ven there\xe2\x80\x99s anythin\xe2\x80\x99 partickler to be done, and yet\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99ll stand and see me a-settin\xe2\x80\x99 here taking up your walable time, and\r\nmakin\xe2\x80\x99 a reg\xe2\x80\x99lar spectacle o\xe2\x80\x99 myself, rayther than help me out vith a\r\nsyllable. It ain\xe2\x80\x99t filial conduct, Samivel,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, wiping his\r\nforehead; \xe2\x80\x98wery far from it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You said you\xe2\x80\x99d speak,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam; \xe2\x80\x98how should I know you wos done up\r\nat the wery beginnin\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You might ha\xe2\x80\x99 seen I warn\xe2\x80\x99t able to start,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined his father; \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\non the wrong side of the road, and backin\xe2\x80\x99 into the palin\xe2\x80\x99s, and all\r\nmanner of unpleasantness, and yet you von\xe2\x80\x99t put out a hand to help me.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m ashamed on you, Samivel.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The fact is, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, with a slight bow, \xe2\x80\x98the gov\xe2\x80\x99nor\xe2\x80\x99s been a-\r\ndrawin\xe2\x80\x99 his money.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery good, Samivel, wery good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, nodding his head with\r\na satisfied air, \xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean to speak harsh to you, Sammy. Wery good.\r\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s the vay to begin. Come to the pint at once. Wery good indeed,\r\nSamivel.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller nodded his head an extraordinary number of times, in the\r\nexcess of his gratification, and waited in a listening attitude for Sam\r\nto resume his statement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You may sit down, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, apprehending that the\r\ninterview was likely to prove rather longer than he had expected.\r\n\r\nSam bowed again and sat down; his father looking round, he continued--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The gov\xe2\x80\x99nor, sir, has drawn out five hundred and thirty pound.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Reduced counsels,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Weller, senior, in an undertone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It don\xe2\x80\x99t much matter vether it\xe2\x80\x99s reduced counsels, or wot not,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nSam; \xe2\x80\x98five hundred and thirty pounds is the sum, ain\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All right, Samivel,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To vich sum, he has added for the house and bisness--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lease, good-vill, stock, and fixters,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Weller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As much as makes it,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Sam, \xe2\x80\x98altogether, eleven hundred and\r\neighty pound.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98I am delighted to hear it. I congratulate\r\nyou, Mr. Weller, on having done so well.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vait a minit, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, raising his hand in a deprecatory\r\nmanner. \xe2\x80\x98Get on, Samivel.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This here money,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, with a little hesitation, \xe2\x80\x98he\xe2\x80\x99s anxious to\r\nput someveres, vere he knows it\xe2\x80\x99ll be safe, and I\xe2\x80\x99m wery anxious too,\r\nfor if he keeps it, he\xe2\x80\x99ll go a-lendin\xe2\x80\x99 it to somebody, or inwestin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nproperty in horses, or droppin\xe2\x80\x99 his pocket-book down an airy, or makin\xe2\x80\x99\r\na Egyptian mummy of his-self in some vay or another.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery good, Samivel,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Mr. Weller, in as complacent a manner as\r\nif Sam had been passing the highest eulogiums on his prudence and\r\nforesight. \xe2\x80\x98Wery good.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For vich reasons,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Sam, plucking nervously at the brim of his\r\nhat--\xe2\x80\x98for vich reasons, he\xe2\x80\x99s drawn it out to-day, and come here vith me\r\nto say, leastvays to offer, or in other vords--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To say this here,\xe2\x80\x99 said the elder Mr. Weller impatiently, \xe2\x80\x98that it\r\nain\xe2\x80\x99t o\xe2\x80\x99 no use to me. I\xe2\x80\x99m a-goin\xe2\x80\x99 to vork a coach reg\xe2\x80\x99lar, and ha\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ngot noveres to keep it in, unless I vos to pay the guard for takin\xe2\x80\x99 care\r\non it, or to put it in vun o\xe2\x80\x99 the coach pockets, vich \xe2\x80\x98ud be a\r\ntemptation to the insides. If you\xe2\x80\x99ll take care on it for me, sir, I\r\nshall be wery much obliged to you. P\xe2\x80\x99raps,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, walking up\r\nto Mr. Pickwick and whispering in his ear--\xe2\x80\x98p\xe2\x80\x99raps it\xe2\x80\x99ll go a little vay\r\ntowards the expenses o\xe2\x80\x99 that \xe2\x80\x98ere conwiction. All I say is, just you\r\nkeep it till I ask you for it again.\xe2\x80\x99 With these words, Mr. Weller\r\nplaced the pocket-book in Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s hands, caught up his hat, and\r\nran out of the room with a celerity scarcely to be expected from so\r\ncorpulent a subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop him, Sam!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr. Pickwick earnestly. \xe2\x80\x98Overtake him; bring\r\nhim back instantly! Mr. Weller--here--come back!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSam saw that his master\xe2\x80\x99s injunctions were not to be disobeyed; and,\r\ncatching his father by the arm as he was descending the stairs, dragged\r\nhim back by main force.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My good friend,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, taking the old man by the hand,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98your honest confidence overpowers me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t see no occasion for nothin\xe2\x80\x99 o\xe2\x80\x99 the kind, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr.\r\nWeller obstinately.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I assure you, my good friend, I have more money than I can ever need;\r\nfar more than a man at my age can ever live to spend,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nPickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No man knows how much he can spend, till he tries,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Mr.\r\nWeller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps not,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98but as I have no intention of\r\ntrying any such experiments, I am not likely to come to want. I must beg\r\nyou to take this back, Mr. Weller.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWery well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, with a discontented look. \xe2\x80\x98Mark my vords,\r\nSammy, I\xe2\x80\x99ll do somethin\xe2\x80\x99 desperate vith this here property; somethin\xe2\x80\x99\r\ndesperate!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99d better not,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Sam.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller reflected for a short time, and then, buttoning up his coat\r\nwith great determination, said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll keep a pike.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wot!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A pike!\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Weller, through his set teeth; \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll keep a pike.\r\nSay good-bye to your father, Samivel. I dewote the remainder of my days\r\nto a pike.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis threat was such an awful one, and Mr. Weller, besides appearing\r\nfully resolved to carry it into execution, seemed so deeply mortified by\r\nMr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s refusal, that that gentleman, after a short reflection,\r\nsaid--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, well, Mr. Weller, I will keep your money. I can do more good with\r\nit, perhaps, than you can.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just the wery thing, to be sure,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, brightening up; \xe2\x80\x98o\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncourse you can, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Say no more about it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, locking the pocket-book in\r\nhis desk; \xe2\x80\x98I am heartily obliged to you, my good friend. Now sit down\r\nagain. I want to ask your advice.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe internal laughter occasioned by the triumphant success of his visit,\r\nwhich had convulsed not only Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s face, but his arms, legs, and\r\nbody also, during the locking up of the pocket-book, suddenly gave place\r\nto the most dignified gravity as he heard these words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wait outside a few minutes, Sam, will you?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\nSam immediately withdrew.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller looked uncommonly wise and very much amazed, when Mr.\r\nPickwick opened the discourse by saying--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are not an advocate for matrimony, I think, Mr. Weller?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller shook his head. He was wholly unable to speak; vague thoughts\r\nof some wicked widow having been successful in her designs on Mr.\r\nPickwick, choked his utterance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you happen to see a young girl downstairs when you came in just now\r\nwith your son?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. I see a young gal,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller shortly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What did you think of her, now? Candidly, Mr. Weller, what did you\r\nthink of her?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought she wos wery plump, and vell made,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, with a\r\ncritical air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So she is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98so she is. What did you think of her\r\nmanners, from what you saw of her?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery pleasant,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mr. Weller. \xe2\x80\x98Wery pleasant and comformable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe precise meaning which Mr. Weller attached to this last-mentioned\r\nadjective, did not appear; but, as it was evident from the tone in which\r\nhe used it that it was a favourable expression, Mr. Pickwick was as well\r\nsatisfied as if he had been thoroughly enlightened on the subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I take a great interest in her, Mr. Weller,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\nMr. Weller coughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I mean an interest in her doing well,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Mr. Pickwick; \xe2\x80\x98a desire\r\nthat she may be comfortable and prosperous. You understand?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery clearly,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Weller, who understood nothing yet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That young person,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98is attached to your son.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To Samivel Veller!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed the parent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s nat\xe2\x80\x99ral,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, after some consideration, \xe2\x80\x98nat\xe2\x80\x99ral, but\r\nrayther alarmin\xe2\x80\x99. Sammy must be careful.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery careful that he don\xe2\x80\x99t say nothin\xe2\x80\x99 to her,\xe2\x80\x99 responded Mr. Weller.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery careful that he ain\xe2\x80\x99t led avay, in a innocent moment, to say\r\nanythin\xe2\x80\x99 as may lead to a conwiction for breach. You\xe2\x80\x99re never safe vith\r\n\xe2\x80\x98em, Mr. Pickwick, ven they vunce has designs on you; there\xe2\x80\x99s no knowin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nvere to have \xe2\x80\x98em; and vile you\xe2\x80\x99re a-considering of it, they have you. I\r\nwos married fust, that vay myself, Sir, and Sammy wos the consekens o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthe manoover.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You give me no great encouragement to conclude what I have to say,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nobserved Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98but I had better do so at once. This young\r\nperson is not only attached to your son, Mr. Weller, but your son is\r\nattached to her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Vell,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, \xe2\x80\x98this here\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty sort o\xe2\x80\x99 thing to come to\r\na father\xe2\x80\x99s ears, this is!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have observed them on several occasions,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, making\r\nno comment on Mr. Weller\xe2\x80\x99s last remark; \xe2\x80\x98and entertain no doubt at all\r\nabout it. Supposing I were desirous of establishing them comfortably as\r\nman and wife in some little business or situation, where they might hope\r\nto obtain a decent living, what should you think of it, Mr. Weller?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt first, Mr. Weller received with wry faces a proposition involving the\r\nmarriage of anybody in whom he took an interest; but, as Mr. Pickwick\r\nargued the point with him, and laid great stress on the fact that Mary\r\nwas not a widow, he gradually became more tractable. Mr. Pickwick had\r\ngreat influence over him, and he had been much struck with Mary\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nappearance; having, in fact, bestowed several very unfatherly winks upon\r\nher, already. At length he said that it was not for him to oppose Mr.\r\nPickwick\xe2\x80\x99s inclination, and that he would be very happy to yield to his\r\nadvice; upon which, Mr. Pickwick joyfully took him at his word, and\r\ncalled Sam back into the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, clearing his throat, \xe2\x80\x98your father and I have\r\nbeen having some conversation about you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98About you, Samivel,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, in a patronising and impressive\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not so blind, Sam, as not to have seen, a long time since, that\r\nyou entertain something more than a friendly feeling towards Mrs.\r\nWinkle\xe2\x80\x99s maid,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You hear this, Samivel?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, in the same judicial form of\r\nspeech as before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam, addressing his master, \xe2\x80\x98I hope there\xe2\x80\x99s no harm\r\nin a young man takin\xe2\x80\x99 notice of a young \xe2\x80\x98ooman as is undeniably good-\r\nlooking and well-conducted.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly not,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not by no means,\xe2\x80\x99 acquiesced Mr. Weller, affably but magisterially.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So far from thinking there is anything wrong in conduct so natural,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nresumed Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98it is my wish to assist and promote your wishes\r\nin this respect. With this view, I have had a little conversation with\r\nyour father; and finding that he is of my opinion--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The lady not bein\xe2\x80\x99 a widder,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr. Weller in explanation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The lady not being a widow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, smiling. \xe2\x80\x98I wish to\r\nfree you from the restraint which your present position imposes upon\r\nyou, and to mark my sense of your fidelity and many excellent qualities,\r\nby enabling you to marry this girl at once, and to earn an independent\r\nlivelihood for yourself and family. I shall be proud, Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nPickwick, whose voice had faltered a little hitherto, but now resumed\r\nits customary tone, \xe2\x80\x98proud and happy to make your future prospects in\r\nlife my grateful and peculiar care.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was a profound silence for a short time, and then Sam said, in a\r\nlow, husky sort of voice, but firmly withal--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m very much obliged to you for your goodness, Sir, as is only like\r\nyourself; but it can\xe2\x80\x99t be done.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can\xe2\x80\x99t be done!\xe2\x80\x99 ejaculated Mr. Pickwick in astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Samivel!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller, with dignity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say it can\xe2\x80\x99t be done,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Sam in a louder key. \xe2\x80\x98Wot\xe2\x80\x99s to become\r\nof you, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My good fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98the recent changes among my\r\nfriends will alter my mode of life in future, entirely; besides, I am\r\ngrowing older, and want repose and quiet. My rambles, Sam, are over.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How do I know that \xe2\x80\x98ere, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 argued Sam. \xe2\x80\x98You think so now! S\xe2\x80\x99pose\r\nyou wos to change your mind, vich is not unlikely, for you\xe2\x80\x99ve the spirit\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 five-and-twenty in you still, what \xe2\x80\x98ud become on you vithout me? It\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t be done, Sir, it can\xe2\x80\x99t be done.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery good, Samivel, there\xe2\x80\x99s a good deal in that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Weller\r\nencouragingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I speak after long deliberation, Sam, and with the certainty that I\r\nshall keep my word,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, shaking his head. \xe2\x80\x98New scenes\r\nhave closed upon me; my rambles are at an end.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wery good,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Sam. \xe2\x80\x98Then, that\xe2\x80\x99s the wery best reason wy you\r\nshould alvays have somebody by you as understands you, to keep you up\r\nand make you comfortable. If you vant a more polished sort o\xe2\x80\x99 feller,\r\nvell and good, have him; but vages or no vages, notice or no notice,\r\nboard or no board, lodgin\xe2\x80\x99 or no lodgin\xe2\x80\x99, Sam Veller, as you took from\r\nthe old inn in the Borough, sticks by you, come what may; and let\r\nev\xe2\x80\x99rythin\xe2\x80\x99 and ev\xe2\x80\x99rybody do their wery fiercest, nothin\xe2\x80\x99 shall ever\r\nperwent it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt the close of this declaration, which Sam made with great emotion, the\r\nelder Mr. Weller rose from his chair, and, forgetting all considerations\r\nof time, place, or propriety, waved his hat above his head, and gave\r\nthree vehement cheers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My good fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, when Mr. Weller had sat down again,\r\nrather abashed at his own enthusiasm, \xe2\x80\x98you are bound to consider the\r\nyoung woman also.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I do consider the young \xe2\x80\x98ooman, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sam. \xe2\x80\x98I have considered the\r\nyoung \xe2\x80\x98ooman. I\xe2\x80\x99ve spoke to her. I\xe2\x80\x99ve told her how I\xe2\x80\x99m sitivated; she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nready to vait till I\xe2\x80\x99m ready, and I believe she vill. If she don\xe2\x80\x99t,\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99s not the young \xe2\x80\x98ooman I take her for, and I give her up vith\r\nreadiness. You\xe2\x80\x99ve know\xe2\x80\x99d me afore, Sir. My mind\xe2\x80\x99s made up, and nothin\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncan ever alter it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWho could combat this resolution? Not Mr. Pickwick. He derived, at that\r\nmoment, more pride and luxury of feeling from the disinterested\r\nattachment of his humble friends, than ten thousand protestations from\r\nthe greatest men living could have awakened in his heart.\r\n\r\nWhile this conversation was passing in Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s room, a little old\r\ngentleman in a suit of snuff-coloured clothes, followed by a porter\r\ncarrying a small portmanteau, presented himself below; and, after\r\nsecuring a bed for the night, inquired of the waiter whether one Mrs.\r\nWinkle was staying there, to which question the waiter of course\r\nresponded in the affirmative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is she alone?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the old gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I believe she is, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the waiter; \xe2\x80\x98I can call her own maid,\r\nSir, if you--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I don\xe2\x80\x99t want her,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman quickly. \xe2\x80\x98Show me to her\r\nroom without announcing me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 said the waiter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you deaf?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the little old gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then listen, if you please. Can you hear me now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s well. Show me to Mrs. Winkle\xe2\x80\x99s room, without announcing me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs the little old gentleman uttered this command, he slipped five\r\nshillings into the waiter\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and looked steadily at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Really, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the waiter, \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know, sir, whether--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! you\xe2\x80\x99ll do it, I see,\xe2\x80\x99 said the little old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98You had\r\nbetter do it at once. It will save time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was something so very cool and collected in the gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmanner, that the waiter put the five shillings in his pocket, and led\r\nhim upstairs without another word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is the room, is it?\xe2\x80\x99 said the gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98You may go.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe waiter complied, wondering much who the gentleman could be, and what\r\nhe wanted; the little old gentleman, waiting till he was out of sight,\r\ntapped at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come in,\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Um, a pretty voice, at any rate,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured the little old gentleman;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98but that\xe2\x80\x99s nothing.\xe2\x80\x99 As he said this, he opened the door and walked in.\r\nArabella, who was sitting at work, rose on beholding a stranger--a\r\nlittle confused--but by no means ungracefully so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pray don\xe2\x80\x99t rise, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said the unknown, walking in, and closing the\r\ndoor after him. \xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Winkle, I believe?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nArabella inclined her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Nathaniel Winkle, who married the son of the old man at\r\nBirmingham?\xe2\x80\x99 said the stranger, eyeing Arabella with visible curiosity.\r\n\r\nAgain Arabella inclined her head, and looked uneasily round, as if\r\nuncertain whether to call for assistance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I surprise you, I see, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Rather, I confess,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Arabella, wondering more and more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll take a chair, if you\xe2\x80\x99ll allow me, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 said the stranger.\r\n\r\nHe took one; and drawing a spectacle-case from his pocket, leisurely\r\npulled out a pair of spectacles, which he adjusted on his nose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t know me, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x99 he said, looking so intently at Arabella\r\nthat she began to feel alarmed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 she replied timidly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said the gentleman, nursing his left leg; \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how you\r\nshould. You know my name, though, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do I?\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella, trembling, though she scarcely knew why. \xe2\x80\x98May I\r\nask what it is?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Presently, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, presently,\xe2\x80\x99 said the stranger, not having yet removed\r\nhis eyes from her countenance. \xe2\x80\x98You have been recently married, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Arabella, in a scarcely audible tone, laying aside her\r\nwork, and becoming greatly agitated as a thought, that had occurred to\r\nher before, struck more forcibly upon her mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Without having represented to your husband the propriety of first\r\nconsulting his father, on whom he is dependent, I think?\xe2\x80\x99 said the\r\nstranger.\r\n\r\nArabella applied her handkerchief to her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Without an endeavour, even, to ascertain, by some indirect appeal, what\r\nwere the old man\xe2\x80\x99s sentiments on a point in which he would naturally\r\nfeel much interested?\xe2\x80\x99 said the stranger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I cannot deny it, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And without having sufficient property of your own to afford your\r\nhusband any permanent assistance in exchange for the worldly advantages\r\nwhich you knew he would have gained if he had married agreeably to his\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s wishes?\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98This is what boys and girls\r\ncall disinterested affection, till they have boys and girls of their\r\nown, and then they see it in a rougher and very different light!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nArabella\xe2\x80\x99s tears flowed fast, as she pleaded in extenuation that she was\r\nyoung and inexperienced; that her attachment had alone induced her to\r\ntake the step to which she had resorted; and that she had been deprived\r\nof the counsel and guidance of her parents almost from infancy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was wrong,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman in a milder tone, \xe2\x80\x98very wrong. It\r\nwas romantic, unbusinesslike, foolish.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was my fault; all my fault, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied poor Arabella, weeping.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman; \xe2\x80\x98it was not your fault that he fell\r\nin love with you, I suppose? Yes it was, though,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old\r\ngentleman, looking rather slily at Arabella. \xe2\x80\x98It was your fault. He\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis little compliment, or the little gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s odd way of paying it,\r\nor his altered manner--so much kinder than it was, at first--or all\r\nthree together, forced a smile from Arabella in the midst of her tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where\xe2\x80\x99s your husband?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the old gentleman, abruptly; stopping a\r\nsmile which was just coming over his own face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I expect him every instant, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella. \xe2\x80\x98I persuaded him to\r\ntake a walk this morning. He is very low and wretched at not having\r\nheard from his father.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Low, is he?\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentlemen. \xe2\x80\x98Serve him right!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He feels it on my account, I am afraid,\xe2\x80\x99 said Arabella; \xe2\x80\x98and indeed,\r\nSir, I feel it deeply on his. I have been the sole means of bringing him\r\nto his present condition.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t mind it on his account, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98It\r\nserves him right. I am glad of it--actually glad of it, as far as he is\r\nconcerned.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe words were scarcely out of the old gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s lips, when footsteps\r\nwere heard ascending the stairs, which he and Arabella seemed both to\r\nrecognise at the same moment. The little gentleman turned pale; and,\r\nmaking a strong effort to appear composed, stood up, as Mr. Winkle\r\nentered the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Father!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr. Winkle, recoiling in amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the little old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98Well, Sir, what have you\r\ngot to say to me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Winkle remained silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are ashamed of yourself, I hope, Sir?\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman.\r\n\r\nStill Mr. Winkle said nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you ashamed of yourself, Sir, or are you not?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired the old\r\ngentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr. Winkle, drawing Arabella\xe2\x80\x99s arm through his. \xe2\x80\x98I am\r\nnot ashamed of myself, or of my wife either.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Upon my word!\xe2\x80\x99 cried the old gentleman ironically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am very sorry to have done anything which has lessened your affection\r\nfor me, Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Winkle; \xe2\x80\x98but I will say, at the same time, that I\r\nhave no reason to be ashamed of having this lady for my wife, nor you of\r\nhaving her for a daughter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Give me your hand, Nat,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman, in an altered voice.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Kiss me, my love. You are a very charming little daughter-in-law after\r\nall!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn a few minutes\xe2\x80\x99 time Mr. Winkle went in search of Mr. Pickwick, and\r\nreturning with that gentleman, presented him to his father, whereupon\r\nthey shook hands for five minutes incessantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Pickwick, I thank you most heartily for all your kindness to my\r\nson,\xe2\x80\x99 said old Mr. Winkle, in a bluff, straightforward way. \xe2\x80\x98I am a\r\nhasty fellow, and when I saw you last, I was vexed and taken by\r\nsurprise. I have judged for myself now, and am more than satisfied.\r\nShall I make any more apologies, Mr. Pickwick?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not one,\xe2\x80\x99 replied that gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98You have done the only thing wanting\r\nto complete my happiness.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHereupon there was another shaking of hands for five minutes longer,\r\naccompanied by a great number of complimentary speeches, which, besides\r\nbeing complimentary, had the additional and very novel recommendation of\r\nbeing sincere.\r\n\r\nSam had dutifully seen his father to the Belle Sauvage, when, on\r\nreturning, he encountered the fat boy in the court, who had been charged\r\nwith the delivery of a note from Emily Wardle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say,\xe2\x80\x99 said Joe, who was unusually loquacious, \xe2\x80\x98what a pretty girl\r\nMary is, isn\xe2\x80\x99t she? I am _so_ fond of her, I am!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Weller made no verbal remark in reply; but eyeing the fat boy for a\r\nmoment, quite transfixed at his presumption, led him by the collar to\r\nthe corner, and dismissed him with a harmless but ceremonious kick.\r\nAfter which, he walked home, whistling.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LVII. IN WHICH THE PICKWICK CLUB IS FINALLY DISSOLVED, AND\r\nEVERYTHING CONCLUDED TO THE SATISFACTION OF EVERYBODY\r\n\r\nFor a whole week after the happy arrival of Mr. Winkle from Birmingham,\r\nMr. Pickwick and Sam Weller were from home all day long, only returning\r\njust in time for dinner, and then wearing an air of mystery and\r\nimportance quite foreign to their natures. It was evident that very\r\ngrave and eventful proceedings were on foot; but various surmises were\r\nafloat, respecting their precise character. Some (among whom was Mr.\r\nTupman) were disposed to think that Mr. Pickwick contemplated a\r\nmatrimonial alliance; but this idea the ladies most strenuously\r\nrepudiated. Others rather inclined to the belief that he had projected\r\nsome distant tour, and was at present occupied in effecting the\r\npreliminary arrangements; but this again was stoutly denied by Sam\r\nhimself, who had unequivocally stated, when cross-examined by Mary, that\r\nno new journeys were to be undertaken. At length, when the brains of the\r\nwhole party had been racked for six long days, by unavailing\r\nspeculation, it was unanimously resolved that Mr. Pickwick should be\r\ncalled upon to explain his conduct, and to state distinctly why he had\r\nthus absented himself from the society of his admiring friends.\r\n\r\nWith this view, Mr. Wardle invited the full circle to dinner at the\r\nAdelphi; and the decanters having been thrice sent round, opened the\r\nbusiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We are all anxious to know,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old gentleman, \xe2\x80\x98what we have done\r\nto offend you, and to induce you to desert us and devote yourself to\r\nthese solitary walks.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick. \xe2\x80\x98It is singular enough that I had intended\r\nto volunteer a full explanation this very day; so, if you will give me\r\nanother glass of wine, I will satisfy your curiosity.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe decanters passed from hand to hand with unwonted briskness, and Mr.\r\nPickwick, looking round on the faces of his friends with a cheerful\r\nsmile, proceeded--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All the changes that have taken place among us,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nmean the marriage that _has _taken place, and the marriage that WILL\r\ntake place, with the changes they involve, rendered it necessary for me\r\nto think, soberly and at once, upon my future plans. I determined on\r\nretiring to some quiet, pretty neighbourhood in the vicinity of London;\r\nI saw a house which exactly suited my fancy; I have taken it and\r\nfurnished it. It is fully prepared for my reception, and I intend\r\nentering upon it at once, trusting that I may yet live to spend many\r\nquiet years in peaceful retirement, cheered through life by the society\r\nof my friends, and followed in death by their affectionate remembrance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere Mr. Pickwick paused, and a low murmur ran round the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The house I have taken,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98is at Dulwich. It has a\r\nlarge garden, and is situated in one of the most pleasant spots near\r\nLondon. It has been fitted up with every attention to substantial\r\ncomfort; perhaps to a little elegance besides; but of that you shall\r\njudge for yourselves. Sam accompanies me there. I have engaged, on\r\nPerker\xe2\x80\x99s representation, a housekeeper--a very old one--and such other\r\nservants as she thinks I shall require. I propose to consecrate this\r\nlittle retreat, by having a ceremony in which I take a great interest,\r\nperformed there. I wish, if my friend Wardle entertains no objection,\r\nthat his daughter should be married from my new house, on the day I take\r\npossession of it. The happiness of young people,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick, a\r\nlittle moved, \xe2\x80\x98has ever been the chief pleasure of my life. It will warm\r\nmy heart to witness the happiness of those friends who are dearest to\r\nme, beneath my own roof.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick paused again: Emily and Arabella sobbed audibly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have communicated, both personally and by letter, with the club,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nresumed Mr. Pickwick, \xe2\x80\x98acquainting them with my intention. During our\r\nlong absence, it has suffered much from internal dissentions; and the\r\nwithdrawal of my name, coupled with this and other circumstances, has\r\noccasioned its dissolution. The Pickwick Club exists no longer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall never regret,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Pickwick in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x98I shall never\r\nregret having devoted the greater part of two years to mixing with\r\ndifferent varieties and shades of human character, frivolous as my\r\npursuit of novelty may have appeared to many. Nearly the whole of my\r\nprevious life having been devoted to business and the pursuit of wealth,\r\nnumerous scenes of which I had no previous conception have dawned upon\r\nme--I hope to the enlargement of my mind, and the improvement of my\r\nunderstanding. If I have done but little good, I trust I have done less\r\nharm, and that none of my adventures will be other than a source of\r\namusing and pleasant recollection to me in the decline of life. God\r\nbless you all!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith these words, Mr. Pickwick filled and drained a bumper with a\r\ntrembling hand; and his eyes moistened as his friends rose with one\r\naccord, and pledged him from their hearts.\r\n\r\nThere were few preparatory arrangements to be made for the marriage of\r\nMr. Snodgrass. As he had neither father nor mother, and had been in his\r\nminority a ward of Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s, that gentleman was perfectly well\r\nacquainted with his possessions and prospects. His account of both was\r\nquite satisfactory to Wardle--as almost any other account would have\r\nbeen, for the good old gentleman was overflowing with hilarity and\r\nkindness--and a handsome portion having been bestowed upon Emily, the\r\nmarriage was fixed to take place on the fourth day from that time--the\r\nsuddenness of which preparations reduced three dressmakers and a tailor\r\nto the extreme verge of insanity.\r\n\r\nGetting post-horses to the carriage, old Wardle started off, next day,\r\nto bring his mother back to town. Communicating his intelligence to the\r\nold lady with characteristic impetuosity, she instantly fainted away;\r\nbut being promptly revived, ordered the brocaded silk gown to be packed\r\nup forthwith, and proceeded to relate some circumstances of a similar\r\nnature attending the marriage of the eldest daughter of Lady\r\nTollimglower, deceased, which occupied three hours in the recital, and\r\nwere not half finished at last.\r\n\r\nMrs. Trundle had to be informed of all the mighty preparations that were\r\nmaking in London; and, being in a delicate state of health, was informed\r\nthereof through Mr. Trundle, lest the news should be too much for her;\r\nbut it was not too much for her, inasmuch as she at once wrote off to\r\nMuggleton, to order a new cap and a black satin gown, and moreover\r\navowed her determination of being present at the ceremony. Hereupon, Mr.\r\nTrundle called in the doctor, and the doctor said Mrs. Trundle ought to\r\nknow best how she felt herself, to which Mrs. Trundle replied that she\r\nfelt herself quite equal to it, and that she had made up her mind to go;\r\nupon which the doctor, who was a wise and discreet doctor, and knew what\r\nwas good for himself, as well as for other people, said that perhaps if\r\nMrs. Trundle stopped at home, she might hurt herself more by fretting,\r\nthan by going, so perhaps she had better go. And she did go; the doctor\r\nwith great attention sending in half a dozen of medicine, to be drunk\r\nupon the road.\r\n\r\nIn addition to these points of distraction, Wardle was intrusted with\r\ntwo small letters to two small young ladies who were to act as\r\nbridesmaids; upon the receipt of which, the two young ladies were driven\r\nto despair by having no \xe2\x80\x98things\xe2\x80\x99 ready for so important an occasion, and\r\nno time to make them in--a circumstance which appeared to afford the two\r\nworthy papas of the two small young ladies rather a feeling of\r\nsatisfaction than otherwise. However, old frocks were trimmed, and new\r\nbonnets made, and the young ladies looked as well as could possibly have\r\nbeen expected of them. And as they cried at the subsequent ceremony in\r\nthe proper places, and trembled at the right times, they acquitted\r\nthemselves to the admiration of all beholders.\r\n\r\nHow the two poor relations ever reached London--whether they walked, or\r\ngot behind coaches, or procured lifts in wagons, or carried each other\r\nby turns--is uncertain; but there they were, before Wardle; and the very\r\nfirst people that knocked at the door of Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s house, on the\r\nbridal morning, were the two poor relations, all smiles and shirt\r\ncollar.\r\n\r\nThey were welcomed heartily though, for riches or poverty had no\r\ninfluence on Mr. Pickwick; the new servants were all alacrity and\r\nreadiness; Sam was in a most unrivalled state of high spirits and\r\nexcitement; Mary was glowing with beauty and smart ribands.\r\n\r\nThe bridegroom, who had been staying at the house for two or three days\r\nprevious, sallied forth gallantly to Dulwich Church to meet the bride,\r\nattended by Mr. Pickwick, Ben Allen, Bob Sawyer, and Mr. Tupman; with\r\nSam Weller outside, having at his button-hole a white favour, the gift\r\nof his lady-love, and clad in a new and gorgeous suit of livery invented\r\nfor the occasion. They were met by the Wardles, and the Winkles, and the\r\nbride and bridesmaids, and the Trundles; and the ceremony having been\r\nperformed, the coaches rattled back to Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s to breakfast,\r\nwhere little Mr. Perker already awaited them.\r\n\r\nHere, all the light clouds of the more solemn part of the proceedings\r\npassed away; every face shone forth joyously; and nothing was to be\r\nheard but congratulations and commendations. Everything was so\r\nbeautiful! The lawn in front, the garden behind, the miniature\r\nconservatory, the dining-room, the drawing-room, the bedrooms, the\r\nsmoking-room, and, above all, the study, with its pictures and easy-\r\nchairs, and odd cabinets, and queer tables, and books out of number,\r\nwith a large cheerful window opening upon a pleasant lawn and commanding\r\na pretty landscape, dotted here and there with little houses almost\r\nhidden by the trees; and then the curtains, and the carpets, and the\r\nchairs, and the sofas! Everything was so beautiful, so compact, so neat,\r\nand in such exquisite taste, said everybody, that there really was no\r\ndeciding what to admire most.\r\n\r\nAnd in the midst of all this, stood Mr. Pickwick, his countenance\r\nlighted up with smiles, which the heart of no man, woman, or child,\r\ncould resist: himself the happiest of the group: shaking hands, over and\r\nover again, with the same people, and when his own hands were not so\r\nemployed, rubbing them with pleasure: turning round in a different\r\ndirection at every fresh expression of gratification or curiosity, and\r\ninspiring everybody with his looks of gladness and delight.\r\n\r\nBreakfast is announced. Mr. Pickwick leads the old lady (who has been\r\nvery eloquent on the subject of Lady Tollimglower) to the top of a long\r\ntable; Wardle takes the bottom; the friends arrange themselves on either\r\nside; Sam takes his station behind his master\xe2\x80\x99s chair; the laughter and\r\ntalking cease; Mr. Pickwick, having said grace, pauses for an instant\r\nand looks round him. As he does so, the tears roll down his cheeks, in\r\nthe fullness of his joy.\r\n\r\nLet us leave our old friend in one of those moments of unmixed\r\nhappiness, of which, if we seek them, there are ever some, to cheer our\r\ntransitory existence here. There are dark shadows on the earth, but its\r\nlights are stronger in the contrast. Some men, like bats or owls, have\r\nbetter eyes for the darkness than for the light. We, who have no such\r\noptical powers, are better pleased to take our last parting look at the\r\nvisionary companions of many solitary hours, when the brief sunshine of\r\nthe world is blazing full upon them.\r\n\r\nIt is the fate of most men who mingle with the world, and attain even\r\nthe prime of life, to make many real friends, and lose them in the\r\ncourse of nature. It is the fate of all authors or chroniclers to create\r\nimaginary friends, and lose them in the course of art. Nor is this the\r\nfull extent of their misfortunes; for they are required to furnish an\r\naccount of them besides.\r\n\r\nIn compliance with this custom--unquestionably a bad one--we subjoin a\r\nfew biographical words, in relation to the party at Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nassembled.\r\n\r\nMr. and Mrs. Winkle, being fully received into favour by the old\r\ngentleman, were shortly afterwards installed in a newly-built house, not\r\nhalf a mile from Mr. Pickwick\xe2\x80\x99s. Mr. Winkle, being engaged in the city\r\nas agent or town correspondent of his father, exchanged his old costume\r\nfor the ordinary dress of Englishmen, and presented all the external\r\nappearance of a civilised Christian ever afterwards.\r\n\r\nMr. and Mrs. Snodgrass settled at Dingley Dell, where they purchased and\r\ncultivated a small farm, more for occupation than profit. Mr. Snodgrass,\r\nbeing occasionally abstracted and melancholy, is to this day reputed a\r\ngreat poet among his friends and acquaintance, although we do not find\r\nthat he has ever written anything to encourage the belief. There are\r\nmany celebrated characters, literary, philosophical, and otherwise, who\r\nhold a high reputation on a similar tenure.\r\n\r\nMr. Tupman, when his friends married, and Mr. Pickwick settled, took\r\nlodgings at Richmond, where he has ever since resided. He walks\r\nconstantly on the terrace during the summer months, with a youthful and\r\njaunty air, which has rendered him the admiration of the numerous\r\nelderly ladies of single condition, who reside in the vicinity. He has\r\nnever proposed again.\r\n\r\nMr. Bob Sawyer, having previously passed through the _Gazette_, passed\r\nover to Bengal, accompanied by Mr. Benjamin Allen; both gentlemen having\r\nreceived surgical appointments from the East India Company. They each\r\nhad the yellow fever fourteen times, and then resolved to try a little\r\nabstinence; since which period, they have been doing well. Mrs. Bardell\r\nlet lodgings to many conversable single gentlemen, with great profit,\r\nbut never brought any more actions for breach of promise of marriage.\r\nHer attorneys, Messrs. Dodson & Fogg, continue in business, from which\r\nthey realise a large income, and in which they are universally\r\nconsidered among the sharpest of the sharp.\r\n\r\nSam Weller kept his word, and remained unmarried, for two years. The old\r\nhousekeeper dying at the end of that time, Mr. Pickwick promoted Mary to\r\nthe situation, on condition of her marrying Mr. Weller at once, which\r\nshe did without a murmur. From the circumstance of two sturdy little\r\nboys having been repeatedly seen at the gate of the back garden, there\r\nis reason to suppose that Sam has some family.\r\n\r\nThe elder Mr. Weller drove a coach for twelve months, but being\r\nafflicted with the gout, was compelled to retire. The contents of the\r\npocket-book had been so well invested for him, however, by Mr. Pickwick,\r\nthat he had a handsome independence to retire on, upon which he still\r\nlives at an excellent public-house near Shooter\xe2\x80\x99s Hill, where he is\r\nquite reverenced as an oracle, boasting very much of his intimacy with\r\nMr. Pickwick, and retaining a most unconquerable aversion to widows.\r\n\r\nMr. Pickwick himself continued to reside in his new house, employing his\r\nleisure hours in arranging the memoranda which he afterwards presented\r\nto the secretary of the once famous club, or in hearing Sam Weller read\r\naloud, with such remarks as suggested themselves to his mind, which\r\nnever failed to afford Mr. Pickwick great amusement. He was much\r\ntroubled at first, by the numerous applications made to him by Mr.\r\nSnodgrass, Mr. Winkle, and Mr. Trundle, to act as godfather to their\r\noffspring; but he has become used to it now, and officiates as a matter\r\nof course. He never had occasion to regret his bounty to Mr. Jingle; for\r\nboth that person and Job Trotter became, in time, worthy members of\r\nsociety, although they have always steadily objected to return to the\r\nscenes of their old haunts and temptations. Mr. Pickwick is somewhat\r\ninfirm now; but he retains all his former juvenility of spirit, and may\r\nstill be frequently seen, contemplating the pictures in the Dulwich\r\nGallery, or enjoying a walk about the pleasant neighbourhood on a fine\r\nday. He is known by all the poor people about, who never fail to take\r\ntheir hats off, as he passes, with great respect. The children idolise\r\nhim, and so indeed does the whole neighbourhood. Every year he repairs\r\nto a large family merry-making at Mr. Wardle\xe2\x80\x99s; on this, as on all other\r\noccasions, he is invariably attended by the faithful Sam, between whom\r\nand his master there exists a steady and reciprocal attachment which\r\nnothing but death will terminate.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of the Project Gutenberg EBook of The Pickwick Papers, by Charles\r\nDickens\r\n\r\n*** END OF THIS PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK THE PICKWICK PAPERS ***\r\n\r\n***** This file should be named 580-0.txt or 580-0.zip ***** This and all\r\nassociated files of various formats will be found in:\r\nhttp://www.gutenberg.org/5/8/580/\r\n\r\nProduced by Jo Churcher, and David Widger\r\n\r\n\r\nUpdated editions will replace the previous one--the old editions will be\r\nrenamed.\r\n\r\nCreating the works from public domain print editions means that no one\r\nowns a United States copyright in these works, so the Foundation (and\r\nyou!) can copy and distribute it in the United States without permission\r\nand without paying copyright royalties.
